hebrew_text: ב) עוד במדרש ויגש אליו יהודה ויאמר וגו' ר' יהודה אומר הגשה למלחמה שנאמר וכו', ר' נחמי' אומר הגשה לפיוס וכו', רבנן אמרי הגשה לתפלה וכו', ר' אלעזר אמר פשט להון (שהי' יהודה מפרש דבריו ליוסף וא"ל) אם למלחמה אני בא, אם לפיוס אני בא. אם לתפלה אני בא ע"כ, ראוי להבין דבשלמא מ"ש אם למלחמה אם לפיוס. תלה הדבר בדרך תנאי וע"צ הספק, דאם ירצה במלחמה אלחום עמו, ואם בפיוס אכנס עמו לפיוס, אבל מ"ש אם לתפלה איך תלה את התפלה בתנאי ובספק, והרי התפלה מחוייבת בכל אופן. ואף לפי"ד הרמב"ן ז"ל דס"ל תפלה דרבנן. אבל בעת צרה חיובא דאורייתא הוא, א"כ אף אם יבוא למלחמה, יתחייב להקדים אלי' התפלה, דאין לך צרה גדולה מהמלחמה, ולמה תלה את התפלה בתנאי ובספק.

2) Further in the Midrash on "Vayigash eilav Yehudah vayomer [And Judah approached him and said]" etc.: Rabbi Yehudah says it was an approach for war, as it is said etc.; Rabbi Nechemiah says it was an approach for appeasement etc.; The Rabbanan (Sages) say it was an approach for prayer etc.; Rabbi Elazar says he explained to them (that Yehudah was explaining his words to Yosef and said to him): "If I come for war, if I come for appeasement, if I come for prayer." Until here.

It is worthy to understand that while what he said about "if for war" and "if for appeasement" makes sense, as he made it conditional and uncertain - that if war is desired, he would fight with him, and if appeasement is desired, he would enter into appeasement with him - but regarding what he said "if for prayer," how could he make prayer conditional and uncertain? Prayer is obligatory in all circumstances. And even according to the Ramban z"l who holds that prayer is rabbinical, nevertheless in times of distress it is a Torah obligation. If so, even if he comes for war, he would be obligated to precede it with prayer, for there is no greater distress than war. So why did he make prayer conditional and uncertain?
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the Midrashic interpretation of "Vayigash eilav Yehuda" (And Judah approached him), exploring three possible meanings of Yehudah's approach to Joseph: for war, for appeasement, or for prayer. The key theological question raised is why prayer is presented as a conditional option ("if I come for prayer") when prayer is actually obligatory, especially in times of distress, according to both rabbinic and biblical law. The passage points to a deeper understanding of the relationship between human initiative and divine service, questioning why Yehudah would present prayer as one possible approach when it should have been a fundamental prerequisite regardless of whether he was coming for war or peace.

hebrew_text: ג) והנה עיניכם ראות וגו' כי פי המדבר אליכם פרש"י והנה עיניכם רואות בכבודי ושאני אחיכם שאני מהול ככם, ועוד כי פי המדבר אליכם בלשון הקודש עכ"ל, ראוי להבין דאינו מפורש בקרא כי אם ראיית הדיבור כמ"ש כי פי המדבר אליכם, ודרשו חז"ל בלשון הקודש, אבל א"כ מהו עיניכם הרואות הול"ל אזניכם שומעות, כי לא יתכן הראי' על הדיבור, ואם נאמר דעיניכם הרואות קאי על מה שהראה להם שהוא מהול, א"כ איך יתקשר תחלת המקרא אל סופו, והנה עיניכם הרואות כי פי המדבר אליכם, כי מלת כי משמשת בד' לשונות, ובכל א' מהלשונות כוונתו מורה אל הקישור למאמר הקודם, וכאן הוא ענין נפרד לגמרי, וצ"ב.

And behold, "your eyes see, etc., that it is my mouth speaking to you." Rashi explains: "Behold, your eyes see my glory and that I am your brother, for I am circumcised like you. Furthermore, 'for my mouth speaks to you' in Lashon HaKodesh (the Holy Tongue)."

It is worthy to understand that the verse only explicitly mentions seeing the speech, as it says "for my mouth speaks to you," and Chazal (our Sages) interpreted this as referring to Lashon HaKodesh. However, if so, what is meant by "your eyes see"? It should have said "your ears hear," as seeing cannot apply to speech. And if we say that "your eyes see" refers to his showing them that he was circumcised, how then does the beginning of the verse connect to its end: "your eyes see that my mouth speaks to you"? For the word "ki" (that/because) serves four different linguistic functions, and in each of these functions, its intention indicates a connection to the preceding statement. Yet here it appears to be a completely separate matter, and this requires explanation.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the verse "Your eyes see... that it is my mouth speaking to you" and Rashi's interpretation of it. The key theological question centers on the seeming contradiction between visual perception ("your eyes see") and auditory experience (speech/hearing), particularly in relation to holy speech in Lashon Hakodesh (the Hebrew language). The text grapples with why the Torah uses visual terminology ("eyes see") rather than auditory terminology ("ears hear") when describing speech, and explores how this connects to the deeper concept of spiritual perception versus physical perception. The passage also examines the grammatical connection between the parts of the verse through the word "ki" (because/that), suggesting there may be a deeper theological meaning to how we perceive and experience divine communication.

In Tractate Megillah (16b), our Sages interpreted "For my mouth is speaking to you" [to mean] "as my mouth, so is my heart." This requires explanation, as how does this connect with the beginning of his statement "Behold, your eyes see," as seeing with the eyes does not relate to this. Additionally, the Rabbeinu Bachya z"l questioned that "my heart" is not mentioned in the verse at all, only "my mouth," so from where did our Sages learn to interpret it this way?

Notes:
- "Chazal" is translated as "our Sages"
- "z"l" is kept as is, meaning "of blessed memory"
- The text discusses the Talmudic interpretation of Yosef's words to his brothers
- The question raised examines the connection between visual confirmation ("your eyes see") and the Sages' interpretation about the alignment of speech and heart/intent
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a Talmudic interpretation (from Megillah 16b) of Yosef's words to his brothers "for it is my mouth speaking to you" (כי פי המדבר אליכם). The text raises two key questions: First, how this interpretation connects to the previous phrase "behold your eyes see" (והנה עיניכם רואות), as visual evidence seems unrelated to the matter. Second, following Rabbeinu Bachya's question, it asks how the Sages derived an interpretation about the heart (לבי) when the verse only explicitly mentions the mouth (פי). This represents a classic example of how Hasidic thought explores the deeper connections between external speech (פה), inner intent (לב), and divine truth.

6) It also needs clarification, how did he bring this as proof to them, for it is impossible to verify the truth of the matter, since no person knows what is in another's heart. And if it were possible to recognize the inner workings of the heart, then no proof would have been necessary at all, as the truth would have been verified through recognizing the hidden depths of his heart. From the verse it implies that they had doubt about the truth of his words, and he wanted to verify this through proofs, as our Sages of blessed memory said that he showed them that he was circumcised and that he spoke in Lashon HaKodesh (the Holy Tongue). If so, this proof that "his mouth and his heart are aligned" would not help at all to resolve their doubts, since the proof itself cannot be verified or tested for its truth.

Note: The text appears to be discussing a theological question about proving or verifying someone's sincerity, using traditional rabbinic concepts about the relationship between external actions and internal intentions.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a fundamental question about the nature of spiritual authenticity and verification. The text questions how one can prove what's in another person's heart, since inner thoughts and intentions are inherently private and unknowable to others. It specifically analyzes an apparent paradox: if it were possible to truly know someone's inner state (that their "inside matches their outside"), there would be no need for external proofs of authenticity; yet if such knowledge is impossible, then using it as proof is ineffective. This leads to a deeper theological discussion about the relationship between external religious demonstrations and internal spiritual truth, and how we can verify spiritual authenticity in religious leadership.

hebrew_text: ז) כי פי המדבר אליכם. פירש"י בלשון הקודש, והרמב"ן ז"ל הקשה עליו כי איננה ראיה מזה שהוא אחיהם, כי רבים במצרים יודעים הלשון ההוא. כי קרוב הוא אל ארץ כנען, ואף כי המושל, שדרך המלכים והמושלים לדעת הלשונות, וכמו שבא יוסף מכנען למצרים, יתכן שבאו רבים אחרים וידעו ג"כ בשפה ההוא, והמזרחי והגור אריה הוסיפו להקשות על ראיית המילה שאיננה ראיה גמורה, דהא כל הישמעאלים הם נימולים. וכל זרע אברהם שהם מבני קטורה, וגם המצריים נימולו בשני הרעב כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל והוא בב"ר עה"פ לכו אל יוסף את אשר יאמר אליכם תעשו, ותירץ המזרחי ז"ל דאע"ג דאין שום א' מהראיות מספיק לבדו, מ"מ בהתחברו שניהם הוא ראיה גדולה בלי ספק שהרי המילה לא תמצא בבני כנען שמדברים בלה"ק, ובני ישמעאל ובני קטורה שיש להם המילה אין להם לה"ק, ובחד סימנא איכא למימר דלמא איתרמי, ושמא הוא מבני קטורה וע"כ הוא מהול, או שמא הוא מבני כנען וע"כ הוא יודע בלה"ק, ואיננו יוסף, אבל בב' סימנים דבר רחוק הוא שיתרמי בצירוף ב' הסימנים יחד וכו', וע"כ חיבור סימן המילה והלשון יחד הוא ראיה גדולה בלי ספק, עכת"ד המזרחי ז"ל, והגו"א כתב כעין זה בדרך אחר, עיי"ש.

"For I am the one speaking to you" - Rashi explains [this means] in the Holy Tongue (Hebrew). The Ramban, of blessed memory, challenged this interpretation, saying this is not proof that he was their brother, as many in Egypt knew that language. For Egypt was close to the land of Canaan, and especially for a ruler, as it is the way of kings and rulers to know languages. Just as Joseph came from Canaan to Egypt, it's possible that many others came and also knew that language.

The Mizrachi and the Gur Aryeh further challenged the proof from circumcision, saying it's not complete proof, since all Ishmaelites are circumcised, as well as all of Abraham's descendants through Keturah. Even the Egyptians were circumcised during the years of famine, as Rashi explains (based on Bereishit Rabbah) on the verse "Go to Joseph; what he tells you, do."

The Mizrachi resolves this by explaining that although neither proof is sufficient on its own, when combined they provide definitive proof. For circumcision was not found among the Canaanites who spoke the Holy Tongue, and the descendants of Ishmael and Keturah who were circumcised did not speak the Holy Tongue. With just one sign, one could say it's coincidental - perhaps he's from the children of Keturah (explaining the circumcision), or perhaps he's from Canaan (explaining the language), and not Joseph. But the combination of both signs occurring together would be highly unlikely, and therefore the combination of circumcision and language together serves as definitive proof. This is the essence of the Mizrachi's words, and the Gur Aryeh wrote similarly but in a different way, see there.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the biblical episode where Joseph reveals himself to his brothers in Egypt, focusing on Rashi's interpretation and subsequent commentators' analysis. The key debate centers on how Joseph proved his identity through two signs: speaking Hebrew (lashon hakodesh) and being circumcised. The theological insight emerges from the Mizrachi's resolution that while neither sign alone was sufficient proof (as other peoples either spoke Hebrew or practiced circumcision), the combination of both signs created definitive proof of Joseph's identity as their brother. This discussion reflects a deeper principle in Jewish thought about how multiple partial proofs can combine to create certainty in matters of faith and identity, particularly when dealing with questions of Jewish authenticity and divine providence.

At first glance, this would seem to provide support for the words of the Masas Binyamin who holds that two intermediate simanim (signs/identifying marks) have the status of a siman muvhak (definitive sign). For although one siman alone is insufficient since we can say it happened by chance (itrami), with two simanim we cannot say it happened by chance. However, many disagree with him and hold that simanim that are not muvhak (definitive), even two of them, are not effective and we can still say it happened by chance (itrami). Thus the question returns to its place: seeing the milah (circumcision) and seeing the [knowledge of the holy] language are not complete proof that it was Yosef, as it's possible that it happened by chance with one of the sons of Keturah or the sons of Yishmael who also knew Lashon Hakodesh (the holy tongue/Hebrew).

Note: I preserved Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "siman muvhak," "itrami," and "Lashon Hakodesh" as they are technical terms with specific halachic and conceptual meanings in rabbinic literature.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of positive identification (simanim) through the lens of the biblical story of Joseph. The text debates the position of the Masas Binyamin, who holds that two intermediate signs can be considered as definitive proof, against those who disagree and maintain that even two non-distinctive signs are insufficient as they could be coincidental. The specific context relates to Joseph's brothers' identification of him through his circumcision and knowledge of the holy tongue (Hebrew), with the counterargument that these signs alone weren't absolutely conclusive since descendants of Keturah or Ishmael could also have had these characteristics. This discussion reflects a deeper theological exploration of certainty, divine providence, and the nature of proof in Jewish law and thought.

hebrew_text: ח) גם קשה למה הוצרך יוסף ליתן להם סימנים, והלא היו יכולין להכירו ע"י טביעות עינא דקלא דעדיפא מסימנים, כמבואר בגמרא דמתירין על ידו איסורא דאורייתא, דאי לאו הכי האיך סומא מותר באשתו והאיך בני אדם מותרין בנשותיהן בלילה, אלא ע"י טביעות עינא דקלא, ואפשר דחששו והיו מסופקים שמא משנה קולו, ואע"פ שראו קולו שוה לשל יוסף, עדיין לא היה בירור גמור, כמ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל בפ' תולדות דיש בני אדם יודעים לעשות כן, וע"כ לא הכיר יצחק את יעקב בטביעות עינא דקלא עיי"ש, ולהלן נבאר עוד בעזר השי"ת.

8) It is also difficult [to understand] why Joseph needed to give them signs [to prove his identity], for they could have recognized him through voice recognition (tevias eina d'kala), which is superior to signs, as explained in the Gemara that permits [identification] through it even in matters of Biblical prohibition. For if not so, how would a blind man be permitted to his wife, and how would people be permitted to their wives at night? Rather, it must be through voice recognition. 

It is possible that they were concerned and doubtful that perhaps he changed his voice, and even though they heard his voice was similar to Joseph's, it still wasn't complete verification, as the Ramban z"l writes in Parshas Toldos that there are people who know how to do this [imitate voices], and therefore Yitzchak did not recognize Yaakov through voice recognition, see there. And further on we will explain more with Hashem's help.

Note: I preserved Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "tevias eina d'kala" (voice recognition) and maintained the traditional references to the Ramban z"l (of blessed memory) and other rabbinic concepts.
summary:
This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses why Joseph needed to provide signs (simanim) to his brothers to prove his identity, rather than relying on voice recognition (tvias eina d'kala). The text raises a fundamental question based on the Talmudic principle that voice recognition is legally considered stronger evidence than physical signs, as demonstrated by the fact that a blind man can recognize his wife by voice. The resolution suggests that the brothers may have been concerned that Joseph's voice could have been intentionally altered or imitated, similar to the case of Jacob and Isaac where voice imitation was possible, thus requiring additional proof of identity beyond voice recognition alone.

This discussion reflects deeper theological themes about certainty, truth, and the nature of divine providence in human recognition and relationships.

hebrew_text: ט) בפרשת ויחי הקשה המזרחי ז"ל איך הורשה ליוסף לדבר עם אחיו בלשון הקודש והרי נשבע לפרעה שלא יגלה סודו שהוא מכיר בלה"ק, ואיך עבר על שבועתו, ועיי"ש שתירץ שפרעה השביעו שלא ידבר כן בפני המצריים, אבל על אחיו לא הקפיד, והשפתי חכמים בשם ספר נחלת יעקב הקשה עוד. דהרי כל דברי המליץ היה בלשון הקודש, ודיבר עמהם בפקודת יוסף והיו שם הרבה מהמצריים.

In Parshat Vayechi, the Mizrachi (Rabbi Elijah Mizrachi) raises a difficulty: How was Joseph permitted to speak with his brothers in Lashon Hakodesh (the Holy Tongue/Hebrew), when he had sworn to Pharaoh not to reveal his secret that he knew Lashon Hakodesh? How could he violate his oath? See there where he resolves that Pharaoh only made him swear not to speak thus in front of the Egyptians, but he wasn't particular about Joseph speaking it with his brothers. The Siftei Chachamim, quoting the Sefer Nachalat Yaakov, raises a further difficulty: for all the words of the interpreter were in Lashon Hakodesh, and he spoke with them under Joseph's orders while many Egyptians were present.

Note: I've preserved Hebrew terms like "Lashon Hakodesh" which refers to the Hebrew language, as these terms have specific religious and cultural significance in Jewish texts.
summary: This passage discusses a fascinating theological question raised by the Mizrachi regarding Yosef's use of Lashon Hakodesh (the Hebrew language) with his brothers. The core issue is how Yosef could speak Hebrew to his brothers when he had sworn to Pharaoh not to reveal his knowledge of the holy tongue. While the Mizrachi resolves this by suggesting that Pharaoh's restriction only applied to speaking Hebrew in front of Egyptians, the Siftei Chachamim (citing the Nachalat Yaakov) raises a further difficulty: the interpreter spoke in Hebrew in the presence of many Egyptians at Yosef's command. This discussion reflects deeper themes about the sanctity of language, the nature of oaths, and the delicate balance between divine service and secular obligations in Jewish thought.

hebrew_text: י) להלן בפ' ואתה צויתה זאת עשו קחו לכם מארץ מצרים עגלות לטפכם וגו' ונשאתם את אביכם ובאתם וגו' ויעשו כן בנ"י ויתן להם יוסף עגלות על פי פרעה וגו', ויש להבין מהו ויעשו כן: הרי העשיה לא היה אלא אח"כ, דעדיין לא ניתנו להם העגלות, ואם כוונת הכתוב לומר שעשו כן לאח"ז, למה הקדים את המאוחר, ובחד ענינא לכ"ע יש מוקדם ומאוחר בתורה, וגם מפורש להלן בפסוק שעשו כן ולמה לו למכפלינהו, וצ"ב כוונת הכתוב בעשי' זו מה טיבה.

Later in the parsha [Torah portion], "And you are commanded, do this: take for yourselves wagons from the land of Egypt for your children, etc., and carry your father and come, etc." And the Children of Israel did so, and Yosef gave them wagons according to Pharaoh's word, etc. We need to understand what [the phrase] "and they did so" means: The actual doing [taking the wagons] only happened afterwards, as they hadn't yet received the wagons. And if the Torah's intention is to say that they did so later, why did it put the later event first? For in a single matter, everyone agrees there is chronological order in the Torah. Also, it's explicitly stated later in the verse that they did so, so why the need to repeat it? We need to understand the Torah's intention regarding this "doing" - what is its nature?

Note: I've preserved Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "parsha" where they're commonly used in religious discourse. The translation maintains the analytical style characteristic of Torah commentary.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a textual difficulty in the story of Joseph providing wagons to his brothers to bring Jacob to Egypt. The key question raised is about the seemingly out-of-order sequence in the verses - it states "and they did so" (ויעשו כן) before actually describing that Joseph gave them the wagons, which appears to contradict the natural chronological order. The passage questions why the Torah would present these events in this sequence and what deeper meaning lies in mentioning their "doing" before the actual receipt of the wagons, especially since the text later repeats that they carried out the instructions. This textual analysis reflects the Hasidic approach of finding deeper spiritual significance in apparent textual irregularities.

hebrew_text: יא) במד"ר וירא את העגלות אשר שלח יוסף, ואותן עגלות ששלח פרעה היכן היו, א"ל אותן עגלות היתה חקוקה ע"ז עליהן. עמד יהודה ושרפן וכו', ראוי להבין דאינו מוזכר בפסוק עגלות פרעה כלל, לא שליחתן ולא שריפתן, וכן הקשה היפ"ת דמשמעות הכתוב משמע דיוסף היה השולח במצות פרעה, כמשה"כ ויתן להם יוסף עגלות עפ"י פרעה, וא"כ מאי קשיא ליה למדרש דאותן עגלות ששלח פרעה היכן היו, דלמא הן הן העגלות האמורות בפסוק וירא את העגלות אשר שלח יוסף. ומנ"ל ששרפן יהודה, ותירץ היפ"ת דלהלן כתיב וישאו בנ"י וגו' בעגלות אשר שלח פרעה, וקשיא ליה למדרש למה פעם יחסן אל יוסף ופעם אל פרעה, אלא ודאי דב' מיני עגלות היו, ואותן ששלח פרעה שרפן יהודה, עכת"ד. אמנם עדיין צ"ב דברי המדרש, כי בפסוק מבואר וישאו בנ"י את נשיהם ואת טפם בעגלות אשר שלח פרעה, ולפי"ד המדרש שרפן יהודה לפני יציאתן ממצרים, ומיד שלח יוסף אחרים תחתיהן, וא"כ איך נשאו בנ"י את נשיהם ואת טפם בעגלות ששלח פרעה, והלא נשרפו במקומן, ולא הגיעו לארץ כנען, גם הול"ל להזכיר עגלות פרעה במאמר ואתה צויתה, שנאמר ויתן להם יוסף עגלות וגו' והול"ל ג"כ ויתן להם פרעה עגלות.

Here's the English translation, preserving the religious terminology:

11) In Midrash Rabbah: "And he saw the wagons that Yosef sent." But where were the wagons that Pharaoh sent? They explained that those wagons had idolatrous images engraved on them. Yehudah stood up and burned them, etc. This requires understanding, as Pharaoh's wagons are not mentioned in the verse at all - neither their sending nor their burning. The Yefeh Toar also questioned this, as the verse implies that Yosef was the sender by Pharaoh's command, as it is written "And Yosef gave them wagons according to Pharaoh's word." If so, what is the Midrash's question about "where were the wagons that Pharaoh sent?" Perhaps these are the same wagons mentioned in the verse "and he saw the wagons that Yosef sent."

And how do we know that Yehudah burned them? The Yefeh Toar answers that later it is written "And the Children of Israel carried... in the wagons that Pharaoh sent." The Midrash found it difficult to understand why sometimes they are attributed to Yosef and sometimes to Pharaoh. Therefore, there must have been two types of wagons, and those sent by Pharaoh were burned by Yehudah.

However, the Midrash's words still need clarification, because the verse clearly states "And the Children of Israel carried their wives and children in the wagons that Pharaoh sent." According to the Midrash, Yehudah burned them before they left Egypt, and Yosef immediately sent others in their place. If so, how did the Children of Israel carry their wives and children in Pharaoh's wagons if they were burned in their place and never reached the land of Canaan? Also, Pharaoh's wagons should have been mentioned in the statement "And you have commanded," where it says "And Yosef gave them wagons," it should have also said "And Pharaoh gave them wagons."
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a Midrashic interpretation regarding the wagons (agalot) sent to transport Jacob's family to Egypt. The key theological tension centers on why the Torah attributes the wagons sometimes to Joseph and sometimes to Pharaoh, with the Midrash suggesting that Pharaoh sent wagons with idolatrous imagery that Judah burned, requiring Joseph to send replacement wagons. The deeper spiritual message appears to be about maintaining religious purity even in moments of salvation - while Pharaoh's assistance was necessary for the physical journey, the spiritual journey required rejecting any trace of idolatry, symbolized by Judah's burning of the contaminated wagons. This creates a dialectic between accepting necessary material aid while maintaining strict spiritual boundaries.

hebrew_text: יב) וירא את העגלות אשר שלח יוסף, פירש"י סימן מסר להם, במה היה עוסק כשפירש ממנו בפ' עגלה ערופה, וזהו וירא את העגלות אשר שלח יוסף, עכ"ד רש"י ז"ל. וכתבו בעלי התוספות ז"ל וצריך פי' לפירושו, והכי רוצה לומר כי כשפירש מאביו הי' מלוה אותו וכו' ואמר לו יעקב, בני גדולה לוי' שעלי' נתוספה פרשה אחת בתורה דכתיב ידינו לא שפכה את הדם שלא פטרנוהו בלא לוי' וכו', והיינו פרשת עגלה ערופה שהי' עסוק בה, ועוד הוקשה להם על פירוש רש"י דלא יתכן לפרש עגלות שבמקרא בלשון עגלה, ע"כ פירשו שעסק יעקב עמו בפ' עגלות המשכן דכתיב שש עגלות צב עכ"ד. וגם פירושם צ"ב, דמה ענין עגלות צב לכאן, ולמה עסק עמו בפ' זו דווקא.

"And he saw the wagons (agalot) that Yosef sent" - Rashi explains that he [Yosef] gave them a sign, [showing] what they were studying when he separated from him [Yaakov], which was the passage of the eglah arufah (broken-necked heifer). This is the meaning of "and he saw the wagons that Yosef sent," these are Rashi's holy words.

The Baalei HaTosfot wrote that Rashi's explanation needs clarification, and this is what it means: when he [Yosef] separated from his father, he accompanied him, etc., and Yaakov said to him, "My son, great is the mitzvah of accompaniment (levayah), for which an additional passage was added to the Torah, as it is written 'our hands did not spill this blood,' meaning we did not send him away without accompaniment, etc." This refers to the passage of eglah arufah that they were studying.

Furthermore, they [the Tosfot] questioned Rashi's interpretation, noting that it's not appropriate to interpret the word 'agalot' (wagons) in the verse as relating to 'eglah' (heifer). Therefore, they explained that Yaakov was studying with him the passage about the wagons of the Mishkan (Tabernacle), where it is written "six covered wagons." These are their words.

Their interpretation also needs explanation, as what is the relevance of the covered wagons here, and why did he specifically study this passage with him?
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the reunion of Yaakov and Yosef, specifically focusing on the wagons (agalot) that Yosef sent to his father. It explores an interpretive debate between Rashi and Tosafot regarding what these wagons symbolically represented - Rashi connects it to their last Torah study together about the eglah arufah (broken-necked heifer), while Tosafot links it to the wagons used for the Mishkan (Tabernacle). The deeper theological message appears to be about the continuity of Torah study between father and son, and how even during their separation, their spiritual connection remained through their shared learning. This interpretation emphasizes how Torah study serves as a bridge between generations and maintains spiritual bonds even during physical separation.

hebrew_text: יג) ופלא שבזוה"ק מבאר ענין העגלות אשר שלח יוסף, שרמז בהם על פרשת עגלה ערופה, וז"ל ר"א אמר רמז רמז לי' יוסף ליעקב על עגלה ערופה וכו', וסיים ת"ח כמה עגלות הוו שית, כד"א שש עגלות צב עכ"ל, ראוי להבין מה שכלל ב' הרמזים יחד, ופתח בעגלה ערופה וסיים דבריו בעגלות צב, ובעלי התוספות לא היה ניחא להם ברמז עגלה ערופה כנ"ל, ופי' דרמז על עגלת צב, ובזוה"ק ערבינהו ותנינהו לתרווייהו, וראוי להבין הכוונה מה שרמז לו יוסף על ב' דברים אלו ביחד.

Here's the English translation:

13) It is remarkable that in the holy Zohar, it explains the matter of the wagons that Joseph sent, that he hinted in them about the passage of the eglah arufah (broken-necked heifer), and these are the words: "Rabbi Elazar said that Joseph gave Jacob a hint about the eglah arufah, etc." And it concludes, "Come and see how many wagons there were - six, as it is written 'six covered wagons.'" End quote. It is worthy to understand why it combined these two hints together, beginning with eglah arufah and concluding with covered wagons. The Baalei HaTosafot were not satisfied with the hint of eglah arufah as mentioned above, and explained that he hinted at the covered wagon, while in the holy Zohar both interpretations are mixed and taught together. It is worthy to understand the intention of why Joseph hinted to these two matters together.

Notes:
- "Zohar HaKadosh" (Zohar"k) is preserved as "holy Zohar"
- "Eglah arufah" is kept in Hebrew as it's a specific Torah concept
- "Baalei HaTosafot" is kept as is, referring to the medieval Tosafist scholars
- "Agalot tzav" is translated as "covered wagons" which is its meaning in context
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the symbolic meaning of the wagons (agalot) that Yosef sent to Yaakov. The Zohar presents two simultaneous interpretations - that these wagons alluded to both the eglah arufah (the broken-necked heifer ritual) and to the agalot tzav (covered wagons used in the Mishkan). The text raises the question of why these two distinct allusions were combined, especially given that the Tosafists preferred only the Mishkan wagons interpretation. The deeper theological implication seems to be about the relationship between ritual atonement (represented by eglah arufah) and sacred service (represented by the Mishkan wagons), suggesting these two spiritual concepts are fundamentally interconnected in Yosef's message to Yaakov.

hebrew_text: יד) עוד שם בזוה"ק קחו לכם מארץ מצרים עגלות וגו'. ר"ח פתח שמחו את ירושלים וגילו בה כל אוהביה שישו אתה משוש כל המתאבלים עלי', ומבאר והולך ענין החורבן ואבילות ירושלים, שבשעת החורבן כביכול הקב"ה התאבל על ירושלים, שמיא וארעא איתאבלו וכו', שמשא וסיהרא וכלא עילאי ותתאי בכו ואיתאבלו וכו' ובתוך דבריו מבאר ענין העגלות ששלח יוסף, רמז רמז ליה על עגלה ערופה, ת"ח כל בני נשא כולהו עברין ע"י דמלאך המות בר מהאי דאקדימו לי' בני נשא. שזהו הנהרג בלא עתו עדיין לא היה רשות למלאך המות לשלוט עליו, וע"כ יש לו למלאך המות רשות לקטרג ולעורר דין. ולכן ולקחו זקני העיר עגלת בקר וגו' וכו' כדי לפייסו ולאעברא דיני' דההוא אתר דלא ישלוט עליה ההוא מקטרגא ולאשתזבא מני', וממשמעות דברי הזוה"ק נראה שהוא בבחי' דורן כענין שעיר המשתלח עיי"ש, ובהמשך דבריו הקשה דבקדמיתא כתיב בעגלות אשר שלח יוסף, ולבסוף כתיב בעגלות אשר שלח פרעה, ותירץ דב' מיני עגלות היו, ואלו אשר שלח יוסף היו כחשבון עגלת צב שבמשכן ומרמזין עליו. ואלו אשר שלח פרעה לא היו בחשבון זה ולא רמזו על סודו, אבל שניהם באו אל יעקב, בג"כ כד יפקון ישראל מן גלותא מה כתיב והביאו את כל אחיכם מכל הגוים מנחה לה' בסוסים וברכב ובצבים וגו' ישעי' ס"ו) ע"כ שטחיות לשון הזוה"ק. ולכאורה קישור דברי הזוה"ק אינם מובנים בפשטות, שמבאר והולך ענין אבילות ציון וירושלים, ואינו מתקשר ענין זה לא לתחלת המאמר ולא לסופו, שמדבר מענין העגלות אשר שלח פרעה ואשר שלח יוסף, ומה שייכות אבילות ציון וירושלים לענין העגלות.

Further in the Zohar HaKadosh, regarding "Take for yourselves wagons from the land of Egypt, etc." Rabbi Chiya began, "Rejoice with Jerusalem and be glad with her, all you who love her; rejoice for joy with her, all you who mourn for her." He proceeds to explain the matter of the destruction and mourning of Jerusalem, that at the time of the destruction, as it were, the Holy One Blessed be He mourned for Jerusalem. The heavens and earth mourned, etc., the sun and moon and all above and below wept and mourned, etc.

Within his words, he explains the matter of the wagons that Yosef sent, hinting at the eglah arufah (broken-necked heifer). Come and see: all people pass through the hands of the Angel of Death except for those who precede him [die prematurely]. For one who is killed before his time, the Angel of Death did not yet have permission to rule over him, and therefore the Angel of Death has permission to prosecute and arouse judgment.

Therefore, "The elders of the city shall take a heifer, etc." in order to appease and remove his judgment from that place so that the prosecutor should not rule over it and to be saved from it. From the implication of the Zohar's words, it appears this is in the aspect of a gift, similar to the concept of the scapegoat.

In the continuation, he asks why initially it is written "in the wagons that Yosef sent," and later it is written "in the wagons that Pharaoh sent." He answers that there were two types of wagons: those sent by Yosef corresponded to the number of covered wagons in the Mishkan (Tabernacle) and alluded to it. Those sent by Pharaoh were not in this calculation and did not allude to its secret, but both came to Yaakov. Therefore, when Israel will be redeemed from exile, what is written? "And they shall bring all your brethren from all the nations as an offering to Hashem, on horses, and in chariots, and in covered wagons, etc." (Isaiah 66).

This is the surface meaning of the Zohar's words. Apparently, the connection of the Zohar's words is not readily understood, as it explains the matter of mourning for Zion and Jerusalem, and this matter doesn't connect either to the beginning of the discourse or to its end, which speaks about the wagons sent by Pharaoh and those sent by Yosef, and what is the connection between the mourning of Zion and Jerusalem to the matter of the wagons.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a Zoharic interpretation connecting several seemingly disparate concepts: the wagons (agalot) sent by Joseph and Pharaoh to Jacob, the ritual of the eglah arufah (broken-necked heifer), and the mourning for Jerusalem. The key theological insight is that these wagons served as a spiritual rectification and contained mystical allusions - Joseph's wagons specifically corresponded to the sacred numbers of the Mishkan's wagons, while Pharaoh's did not hold this spiritual significance. The text weaves together themes of exile and redemption, suggesting that just as the wagons brought Jacob's family to Egypt, the future redemption will involve gathering the Jewish people from exile through similar divine transportation, while also addressing the deeper spiritual mechanisms of death, judgment, and atonement represented by the eglah arufah ritual.

hebrew_text: טו) גם מה שמבאר ענין עגלה ערופה בסודן של דברים שהוא בחינת דורן ופיוס להמקטרג. צ"ב קישור ביאור זה לענין העגלות אשר שלח יוסף, ואם הכוונה שרמז יוסף ליעקב אבינו על בחי' זו, צ"ב הכוונה למה רמז על זה. גם מה שמסיק בזוה"ק דב' מיני עגלות היו, עגלות פרעה ועגלות יוסף אינו מבואר הכוונה בדבריו, מדוע הוצרכו שניהם ומב' סיגים נפרדים ורחוקים, והיה אפשר ליוסף לשלוח עגלות די סיפוקם, ולא יצטרכו עוד לעגלות פרעה. גם מה שסיים דבריו כד יפקין ישראל מן גלותא מה כתיב והביאו את כל אחיכם מנחה לה' וכו', אין לו הבנת קישור לענין עגלות דעסיק ביה.

Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Also, regarding what is explained about the concept of the Eglah Arufah (broken-necked heifer) in the secret meaning of things - that it represents a gift and appeasement to the prosecutor (mekatreg) - clarification is needed regarding how this explanation connects to the wagons (agalot) that Yosef sent. And if the intention is that Yosef was hinting to Yaakov Avinu about this aspect, clarification is needed as to why he hinted about this.

Additionally, regarding what the Zohar HaKadosh concludes - that there were two types of wagons, Pharaoh's wagons and Yosef's wagons - the intention of these words is not clear. Why were both types needed, and from two separate and distant categories? It would have been possible for Yosef to send enough wagons by himself, without needing Pharaoh's wagons as well.

Also, regarding how he concludes his words "when Israel will leave exile, what is written? 'And they will bring all your brothers as an offering to Hashem, etc.'" - there is no clear understanding of how this connects to the matter of the wagons being discussed.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the mystical significance of the wagons (agalot) sent by Joseph to his father Jacob, connecting it to the concept of the eglah arufah (the broken-necked heifer ritual). The text raises questions about why there were two types of wagons - those from Pharaoh and those from Joseph - and explores their deeper spiritual significance as a form of appeasement or gift (doron) to spiritual prosecutors. The passage concludes by connecting this to the future redemption when the Jewish people will be gathered from exile, though the text questions this connection's relevance to the main discussion about the wagons. The overall thrust appears to be exploring the deeper mystical meanings behind seemingly mundane biblical details, particularly how physical objects like wagons can serve as vehicles for spiritual rectification and reconciliation.

hebrew_text: והאור החמה בפי' על הזוה"ק כתב קצת ביאור בענין זה, ותו"ד שב' מיני עגלות אלו הרמז בהם על ב' בחינות, ורמז בהם יוסף על הגלות ועל הגאולה עד סוף כל הדורות, דהיינו עגלות יוסף רמז על זמן הגלות, ועגלות הם כלי גולה, כמו שהיו בחי' עגלות אלו, שהלכו בהם לגלות מצרים, ועגלות פרעה רמז ופועל דמיוני אל העתיד ימי הגאולה, שהאומות העולם יביאו את בני ישראל מארצות גלותם, האובדים בארץ אשור והנדחים בארץ מצרים מנחה לה' ברכב ובצבים, וזהו שסיים הזוה"ק כד יפקין מן גלותא והביאו את כל אחיכם מנחה לה', כי הוא הרמז בעגלות פרעה, שיביאו אומות העולם את ישראל בעגלותיהם מנחה לה' כמבואר בפסוק עכת"ד ז"ל. והשביבי נגה כתב שהזוה"ק פליג על מ"ד במדרש דאותן עגלות של פרעה הי' ע"ז חקוקה עליהם ועמד יהודה ושרפן, ולפי"ד הזוה"ק ליתא להא, אלא אלין ואלין קאתי לות יעקב עכת"ד, אמנם אין נראה לעשות מחלוקת בין החכמים, במקום שאין מפורש פלוגתתם להדיא, וצ"ע להשוות דבריהם.
translation:
Here's the translation:

The Or HaChama in his commentary on the Zohar wrote some explanation on this matter. The essence of his words is that these two types of wagons allude to two aspects, through which Joseph hinted about the exile and redemption until the end of all generations. That is, Joseph's wagons allude to the time of exile, and wagons are vessels of exile, just as these wagons were used when they went into Egyptian exile. Pharaoh's wagons allude to and serve as a symbolic act regarding the future days of redemption, when the nations of the world will bring the Children of Israel from their lands of exile - "those lost in the land of Assyria and those dispersed in the land of Egypt" - as an offering to Hashem with chariots and mules. This is why the Zohar concludes "when they leave from exile, 'and they shall bring all your brethren as an offering to Hashem,'" for this is alluded to in Pharaoh's wagons - that the nations of the world will bring Israel in their wagons as an offering to Hashem, as explained in the verse.

The Shevivei Nogah wrote that the Zohar disagrees with the opinion in the Midrash which states that those wagons of Pharaoh had idolatrous images engraved on them and Judah stood up and burned them. According to the Zohar's view, this is not so; rather, both these and those [wagons] came to Jacob. However, it doesn't seem appropriate to create a dispute between the Sages where their disagreement is not explicitly stated, and this requires further investigation to reconcile their words.
summary:
This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the symbolic meaning of two types of wagons (agalot) mentioned in relation to Joseph and Pharaoh, based on interpretations from the Zohar and its commentaries. The key theological insight is that Joseph's wagons symbolize the exile (galut), while Pharaoh's wagons represent the future redemption (geulah), when the nations of the world will bring the Jewish people back to their land as an offering to God. The text addresses an apparent contradiction between the Zohar's positive interpretation of Pharaoh's wagons and a Midrashic view that suggests these wagons had idolatrous imagery and were burned by Judah, concluding that we should be cautious about establishing disputes between sages when their disagreement isn't explicitly stated.

This interpretation reflects the classic Hasidic approach of finding deep redemptive meaning even within seemingly mundane historical details, while also demonstrating how exile and redemption are interconnected in Jewish theological thought.

אותה כנ"ל, ומקודם נבאר דכל א' מהראיות בירור גמור הוא וראוי לסמוך עליו, ואח"כ נפרש למה הוצרכו לשניהם ביחד, ולא הספיק בא' מהם, והנה ראיית המילה יובן עפ"י מ"ש בזוה"ק דהנוטר בריתו שריא עליה שם ש-ד-י מלבר, ב"ה, ומזה הבין כי ה' אתו עיי"ש, ובאמת ל"ק קושיתו דמבואר במד"ר במדבר (פ' י"ד ס"ג) וירא אדוניו כי ה' אתו, א"ל אדוניו ליוסף אני מבקש לראות להקב"ה, א"ל יוסף הרי חמה א' מכמה שמשין שלו, ואין אתה יכול להסתכל בו, והאיך תוכל להסתכל בכבודו א"ל הקב"ה חייך בשביל כבודך אני נגלה עליו שנאמר וירא אדוניו כי ה' אתו, ובזוה"ק וידע אדוניו כי ה' אתו אין כתיב כאן, אלא וירא אדוניו כי ה' אתו, דהא בעיני' הוה חמי וכו' עיי"ש, ולדרכינו יובן כי היה שורה על יוסף הצדיק בחי' השם יתברך, ע"י שהי' נוטר בריתו וכמ"ש בזוה"ק עה"פ אחרי ראותי את פניך כי עודך חי, דאתקיימת ברזא דברית קדישא דאקרי חי העולמים, ויעקב ראה זאת על פניו של יוסף, יתברך שראו עליו, אין מציאות שיהיה אלא בצדיקים וקדושים נוטרי הברית, ומעתה היתה ראיית המילה נכונה וברורה.
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving Hasidic terminology:

Let us proceed with the explanation, beginning with what the Ramban z"l, Mizrachi, and Gur Aryeh questioned - that the proof from circumcision is not complete proof, as perhaps he was a circumcised Arab or from the children of Keturah, etc. Also, the proof from the holy tongue (Hebrew) is not conclusive since many in Egypt knew it, as mentioned above.

First, let us explain that each proof is complete verification and worthy to rely upon. Then we will explain why both proofs together were necessary, and why one alone was not sufficient.

The proof from circumcision can be understood based on what is written in the holy Zohar - that one who guards his covenant (bris) has the name Sha-dai manifest upon him externally, and heaven forbid, one who does not guard his covenant has the Samech Mem (Satan) dwelling upon him.

It states in the holy Zohar (Parshas Lech Lecha) that our father Abraham, before he was circumcised, the Holy One Blessed be He did not reveal Himself to him with the name E-l Sha-dai until afterwards. And so it was taught: The Holy One Blessed be He made lower crowns that are not holy, and all those who are not circumcised become defiled through them and are marked by them. What is this mark? The letters Shin and Dalet appear on them, but nothing more, and therefore they become defiled and attach themselves to these forces. After they are circumcised, they depart from these forces and enter under the wings of the Shechinah, and the holy letter Yud is revealed to them - the complete sign of the covenant, and Sha-dai is inscribed upon them completely.

summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the spiritual significance of circumcision (brit milah) through a Kabbalistic lens, particularly focusing on how the Divine name Sha-dai becomes manifest upon one who guards the holy covenant. The text explains that when Joseph revealed his circumcision to his brothers, it wasn't merely physical proof of his identity, but rather demonstrated the Divine presence (Shechinah) that rested upon him due to his moral purity and protection of the covenant. The passage uses this to resolve earlier commentators' questions about how circumcision could be definitive proof of Joseph's identity, explaining that the brothers could actually perceive the Divine presence associated with a true guardian of the covenant, something that wouldn't be present in an ordinary circumcised person like an Arab or descendant of Keturah.

hebrew_text: ועתה נבוא לבאר ראיית הלשון הקודש, שטען הרמב"ן ז"ל כי רבים היו במצרים שידעו הלשון ההוא, וכמו שבא יוסף מארץ כנען יתכן שבאו רבים אחרים מארץ כנען ומעבר הנהר, וידעו ג"כ בשפה ההיא, וא"כ אין ראית לה"ק ראיה כלל, עכת"ד. ולכאורה ראוי להעיר על דבריו, דא"כ מה הועיל פרעה במה שהשביעו ליוסף שלא יגלה שאינו מכיר בלה"ק, ובלאו הכי יתגלה סודו ע"י אחרים וכל אנשי ארץ כנען ועבר הנהר יודעים לדבר בלשון הזה, ופן יבוא א' מגדוליהם לדבר עם פרעה בלשונם ולא יהיה לו מענה להשיב, ויתגלה חרפתו לרבים, גם קשה מה שאמרו ז"ל במסכת סוטה (דף ל"ו) דאגמרי' יוסף לפרעה לה"ק ולא גמר, ואיך יתכן שלא עלתה בידו ללמוד ולבא לידי ידיעת לשון הקודש, אם אנשי כל ארץ כנען ועבר הנהר ידעו בו מגדוליהם ועד קטניהם, ואיך לא יכול גם פרעה ללמוד אותו, וכמו שלמד וידע בכל שבעים הלשונות מדוע לא השיג גם לשון הקודש. וראיתי בנזר הקודש שהקשה כן, והאריך לבאר דודאי לשון הקודש אינו שפת עברי ולשון כנען הארור, אלא הוא לשון נבדל בפ"ע, אשר לא נמסר לשום אומה ולשון מדור הפלגה ואילך, כי אם לאבות העולם ומשך זרעם הקודש, ולא נתפשטה לה"ק בין העמים אלא ממתן תורה ואילך שידעו בו ע"י העתקת התורה, ואפילו השתא הא אמרינן עכו"ם אפילו מדבר בלשון הקודש לשונו סרוח. שאינו מתנת חלקם וגורלם, וע"כ אף כי אגמרי' יוסף לפרעה בלשון הקודש לא הוה גמר, כי מצד שורשו לא היה לו חלק ונחלה כלל בבחינת מדריגת לה"ק המיוחד להקב"ה לבדו, כמ"ש בפדר"א (פכ"ד) שבדור הפלגה ירד הקב"ה וע' מלאכים הסובבים כסא כבודו, ובלבל את לשונם לע' לשון, ומנה מלאך על כל לשון ולשון, ונפל גורלו של הקב"ה על אברהם ועל ביתו, וזכו הם בלה"ק עיי"ש, עכת"ד הנזה"ק ז"ל.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hebrew/Aramaic terminology where appropriate:

Now let us explain the proof regarding Lashon Hakodesh (the Holy Tongue), about which the Ramban z"l argued that many people in Egypt knew that language. Just as Yosef came from Eretz Canaan, it's possible that many others came from Eretz Canaan and from across the river who also knew this language. Therefore, the proof from Lashon Hakodesh is no proof at all.

At first glance, one should note regarding his words: If so, what did Pharaoh accomplish by making Yosef swear not to reveal that Pharaoh didn't know Lashon Hakodesh? His secret would be revealed through others anyway, since all the people of Canaan and across the river knew how to speak this language. Perhaps one of their leaders would come to speak with Pharaoh in their language, and he would have no response, thus revealing his shame to many.

Also difficult is what our Sages z"l said in Masechet Sotah (36) that Yosef taught Pharaoh Lashon Hakodesh but he couldn't learn it. How is it possible that he failed to learn and acquire knowledge of Lashon Hakodesh if all the people of Canaan and across the river, from their greatest to their smallest, knew it? How could Pharaoh not learn it? Just as he learned and knew all seventy languages, why couldn't he master Lashon Hakodesh?

I saw in the Nezer Hakodesh that he raised this difficulty and explained at length that surely Lashon Hakodesh is not the Hebrew language and cursed tongue of Canaan, but rather a distinct language of its own, which was not given to any nation or tongue from the Generation of the Dispersion onward, except to the Patriarchs of the world and their holy descendants. Lashon Hakodesh did not spread among the nations until after the giving of the Torah, when they learned it through the Torah's translation. Even now we say that even if an idolater speaks Lashon Hakodesh, his speech is corrupt, as it is not their portion and lot.

Therefore, even though Yosef taught Pharaoh Lashon Hakodesh, he could not learn it because, due to his root, he had no portion or inheritance in the level of Lashon Hakodesh, which is unique to HaKadosh Baruch Hu alone. As it is written in Pirkei D'Rabbi Eliezer (Chapter 24) that in the Generation of the Dispersion, HaKadosh Baruch Hu descended with 70 angels surrounding His Throne of Glory, and confused their language into 70 languages, appointing an angel over each language, and HaKadosh Baruch Hu's lot fell upon Avraham and his household, and they merited Lashon Hakodesh.
summary: This passage discusses a fundamental debate about the nature of Lashon HaKodesh (the Holy Tongue/Hebrew). The key theological insight centers on the unique spiritual status of Hebrew as distinct from other languages - it's not merely another ancient Canaanite dialect, but rather a separate, divine language exclusively given to the Patriarchs and their holy descendants. The text challenges Ramban's position that many in Egypt knew Hebrew, using Pharaoh's inability to learn it (despite knowing 70 languages) as proof of its supernatural character. The passage concludes by citing Pirkei D'Rabbi Eliezer that at the Tower of Babel, while angels were appointed over 70 languages, God specifically reserved Hebrew for Abraham and his household, establishing it as a unique spiritual inheritance rather than just a conventional language.

hebrew_text: אולם אין זה דבר ברור, ויש פלוגתא בזה בין הראשונים כמו שביארתי בספרי (ויואל משה מאמר ג' אות ט"ז), ודעת הכוזרי דלשון עברי שהיו משתמשים בה בני עבר הנהר הוא לשון הקודש, וכ"כ הרע"ב והתוספות יו"ט במסכת ידים עיי"ש, ולדבריהם יקשו כל אלו הקושיות הנ"ל, גם קושית הרמב"ן ז"ל דאין לה"ק ראיה כלל, אמנם נראה דאפי' למאן דס"ל דלשון בני עבר וארץ כנען הי' בלה"ק, ברור שלא ידעו אמיתת הלשון בשרשו, והי' בחי' לה"ק אצלם משובש ומקולקל, כמ"ש הרבינו בחיי (בפ' וירא), כי המחליף אפילו נקודה א' בלשון הקודש יהרוס הכוונה או יבא לידי כפירה ח"ו עיי"ש, ויותר מזה מבואר בשל"ה הקדוש (ח"א דף י"ט) בשער בית אחרון, וז"ל דע כי אותיות הקדושות והתיבות כולם רוחניים בשורשם, ואמרו חכמי האמת האותיות מבינה, והנקודות מחכמה, והטעמים מכתר וכו', וביאור הענין כי יש לאותיות רוחניות הן מצד תמונתן הן מצד מספרן וכו', ומכ"ש בהתחברות אותיות הקדושות ונעשה ממנו תיבה, שרוחניות התיבה ההוא ענין גדול למעלה וכו', וכל מה שיש למטה בגשמיות הוא התפשטות והשתלשלות השפע מלמעלה, וע"כ נקרא לשוננו לשון הקודש, כי כל השמות והתיבות הם למעלה בשרשם במקום קדוש עליון, ואח"כ כשיורד ומשתלשל בעולם הזה נקרא בשמו העליון ע"ד השאלה, וכל מה שאנו קורין דבר בשמו, אין זה שמו העצם אלא מושאל, ועצם השם הוא למעלה בקדושה, כענין ד' יסודות אש מים רוח עפר שהאריך הזוה"ק וכתב שהם משתלשלים מהמרכבה העליונה. חסד מים, גבורה אש, תפארת רוח, מלכות עפר, ואלו התיבות שורשם למעלה הם עצמיים וכו' ובהשתלשלותם למטה בעוה"ז נקראו אלו הד' יסודות בשמות אלו בלשון מושאל, וכן מה שנקרא יד ורגל ואוזן וכן כולם, אין זה שמו העצם, אבל שמם העצם למעלה בקודש כולה רוחניות, אלא שבהשתלשלות העולמות רבבות מדריגות, יקרא זה יד ורגל בלשון מושאל, ושורש שם העצם למעלה עכת"ד ז"ל.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hebrew/Hasidic terminology:

However, this matter is not clear, and there is a dispute (plugta) among the Rishonim about this, as I explained in my book (Va'Yoel Moshe, Article 3, Section 16). The Kuzari's opinion is that the Hebrew language used by the people of Ever HaNahar (beyond the river) is Lashon HaKodesh (the holy tongue), and so wrote the Ra'av and Tosafot Yom Tov in Masechet Yadayim, see there. According to their words, all the aforementioned questions are difficult, including the Ramban's question that there is no proof regarding Lashon HaKodesh.

However, it appears that even according to those who hold that the language of the people of Ever and the land of Canaan was Lashon HaKodesh, it is clear they did not know the true essence of the language in its root, and the aspect of Lashon HaKodesh among them was corrupted and damaged. As Rabbeinu Bachya wrote (in Parshat Vayeira), that one who changes even one nekudah (vowel point) in Lashon HaKodesh destroys the intention or may come to heresy, God forbid.

Even more explicit is what's written in the holy Shelah (Part 1, page 19) in Sha'ar Beit Acharon, which states: "Know that the holy letters and all words are spiritual in their root, and the masters of truth said that the letters come from Binah, the nekudot from Chochmah, and the ta'amim from Keter, etc. The explanation is that the letters have spirituality both in their form and in their numerical value, etc. All the more so when holy letters combine to form a word, the spirituality of that word is a great matter above, etc.

Everything that exists below in physicality is an extension and chain of influence from above. Therefore, our language is called Lashon HaKodesh, because all names and words exist above in their root in a supreme holy place. When it descends and chains down to this world, it is called by its supreme name by way of borrowing. Everything we call by its name is not its essential name but borrowed, and the essence of the name is above in holiness.

This is like the four elements - fire, water, wind, and earth - which the holy Zohar elaborates on, writing that they chain down from the supreme Merkavah (Divine Chariot): Chesed is water, Gevurah is fire, Tiferet is wind, and Malchut is earth. These words in their root above are essential, etc. In their descent below to this world, these four elements are called by these names in borrowed language. Similarly, what we call hand, foot, and ear, etc., these are not their essential names, but their essential names are above in holiness, entirely spiritual. Through the descent of the worlds through countless levels, these are called hand and foot in borrowed language, while the root of the essential name is above."
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the profound nature of Lashon Hakodesh (the Hebrew holy tongue) and its relationship to spiritual realms. The text explains that even a single change in Hebrew pronunciation or vowelization can destroy the intended meaning or lead to heretical understanding, as each letter and word has deep spiritual roots. The core argument is that Hebrew words and letters are spiritual in their essence, with the letters emanating from Binah, the vowels from Chochmah, and the cantillation from Keter in the sefirotic system. The passage concludes by explaining that physical objects' Hebrew names are merely "borrowed" terms that reflect their true spiritual roots in the upper worlds, similar to how the four elements (fire, water, air, earth) correspond to higher spiritual attributes (Gevurah, Chesed, Tiferet, Malchut).
keywords: לשון הקודש (Lashon HaKodesh) ,שורש (Shoresh) ,אותיות הקדושות (Otiot HaKedoshot) ,חכמי האמת (Chachmei HaEmet) ,מרכבה העליונה (Merkavah HaElyonah) ,ד' יסודות (Dalet Yesodot) ,עולמות (Olamot) ,השתלשלות (Hishtalshelut) ,כתר (Keter) ,רוחניות (Ruchaniyut)

hebrew_text: ומעתה יוצדק ראיית הלשון אפילו לשיטת הרמב"ן והראשונים ז"ל שכל בני עבר וארץ כנען היו מדברים בלשון הקודש, אבל השבטים הקדושים ראו ביוסף שמדבר בלשון הקודש כפי שורשה למעלה, והשיג שורש הלשון והתיבות והשמות בשמם העצם ברוחניות, ומעתה היתה ראיית הלשון סימן מובהק וראיה חזקה, דלא נתגלה שורש לשון הקודש בבחי' זו לבני כנען ולבני עבר, כי כולם היו משתמשים בלשון ההוא בדרך מושאל, ובהשתלשלות הלשון רבבות מדריגות עד שנתלבשה אצלם בלבוש גשמי, ובודאי הי' לשונם משובש ומקולקל כמ"ש הרבינו בחיי, כי אפילו בשנוי מעט יתקלקל הכוונה, אבל יוסף הצדיק דיבר אליהם בלשון הקודש כפי שרשו למעלה, ובחי' זו לא יוודע רק לאבות הקדושים ומשך זרעם, ונתברר להם מזה בראי' ברורה כי הוא יוסף.
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

And now, the "seeing of the language" is justified, even according to the approach of the Ramban and the early authorities (Rishonim) of blessed memory, that all the descendants of Ever and the land of Canaan spoke in Lashon HaKodesh (the Holy Tongue). However, the holy tribes saw that Yosef spoke Lashon HaKodesh according to its supernal root, and he grasped the root of the language, words, and names in their essential spiritual nature. Therefore, the "seeing of the language" was a clear sign and strong proof, for this level of the root of Lashon HaKodesh was not revealed to the Canaanites and the descendants of Ever, as they all used the language in a borrowed manner, with the language descending through myriad levels until it became clothed in physical garments for them. Their language was certainly distorted and corrupted, as Rabbeinu Bachya writes, for even with a small change the intention becomes corrupted. But Yosef HaTzaddik spoke to them in Lashon HaKodesh according to its supernal root, and this level was known only to the holy Patriarchs and their descendants. Through this, it became clear to them with definitive proof that he was indeed Yosef.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a profound concept regarding the spiritual nature of Lashon Hakodesh (the Holy Tongue/Hebrew). The key insight is that while many people in Canaan and Ever spoke Hebrew, Yosef HaTzaddik had a unique ability to speak it at its highest spiritual root (shoresh), accessing its pure spiritual essence rather than just its physical manifestation. The text explains that most people used the language in a "borrowed" or derivative way, many spiritual levels removed from its true source, but Yosef's brothers recognized him specifically because he could speak Hebrew at its elevated spiritual root-level, a capability that was unique to the holy Patriarchs and their worthy descendants. This interpretation adds a mystical dimension to the biblical story of Yosef's revelation to his brothers, suggesting that true recognition came through spiritual authenticity rather than mere linguistic ability.
keywords: לשון הקודש (Lashon HaKodesh) ,שורש (Shoresh) ,רוחניות (Ruchniut) ,השתלשלות (Hishtalshelut) ,מדריגות (Madregot) ,לבוש גשמי (Levush Gashmi) ,אבות הקדושים (Avot HaKedoshim) ,השבטים הקדושים (HaShvatim HaKedoshim) ,בחינה (Bechina) ,סימן מובהק (Siman Muvhak)

hebrew_text: ועפ"י הנ"ל נבין מאמר הכתוב והנה עיניכם רואות כי פי המדבר אליכם, ולכאורה איך יוצדק הראיה על הדיבור והול"ל ואזניכם שומעות, ויובן עפי"מ שפירשתי דברי המכילתא, וכל העם רואים את הקולות, רואין את הנשמע שאי אפשר לראות במקום אחר עכ"ל. ולכאורה מדוע לא חשבוהו רז"ל בין הניסים שנעשו במתן תורה, כמו שמנו שאר הניסים שנתרפאו בעלי מומים, ועוד הרבה ניסים הוזכרו בגמרא ובמדרשים, ואפשר מפני שדבר זה יתקרב אל לב בני אדם להשכילו גם עפ"י חקי הטבע ואין הנס מוחלט בו, ע"כ לא חשבוהו חז"ל לנס, דהנה כל קול יש בו ממשות, והראיה שנקלט הקול בזמנינו בכלים שונים. ונשמר לזמן מרובה, ואלמלא לא היה בקול ממשות לא היה אפשר לקלטו ולשמרו, אלא שלרוב דקותו א"א לחוש הראות להשיגו, ואפשר דזכי הראות מרגישים בחי' הקול גם ע"י ראיה, ומעתה אותן הקולות דמתן תורה שיצאו מפי הגבורה, וקול ה' בכח, קול ה' שובר ארזים, השכל מחייב שאחרי שזכו לקול אלקים מדבר, שירגישו גם בחוש הראיה בחי' הקול ההוא לרוב תקפו, וע"כ לא חשבוהו חז"ל לנס, כי הראי' בעצמיותה אינה נס, ועיקר הנס שזכו לקול אלקים חיים מדבר אליהם וחיו כמשה"כ, וגדר השמיעה והראיה שווים בקול זה.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts and terminology:

Based on the above, we can understand the verse "And behold, your eyes see that it is my mouth speaking to you." At first glance, how can sight be justified in relation to speech - it should have said "your ears hear"? This can be understood based on how I explained the words of the Mechilta: "And all the people saw the voices" - they saw what is normally heard, which is impossible to see elsewhere.

Initially, one might ask why our Sages didn't count this among the miracles that occurred at Matan Torah (the Giving of the Torah), as they counted other miracles such as the healing of those with physical defects, and many other miracles mentioned in the Gemara and Midrashim. Perhaps it's because this phenomenon can be somewhat understood by human intellect even according to natural law, and thus the miracle is not absolute. Therefore, Chazal didn't count it as a miracle.

For indeed, every sound has substance, as evidenced by the fact that in our times, sound can be captured by various devices and preserved for long periods. If sound had no substance, it would be impossible to capture and preserve it. However, due to its extreme subtlety, it cannot normally be perceived by the sense of sight. It's possible that those with exceptionally keen vision can perceive aspects of sound through sight.

Therefore, those voices at Matan Torah that emerged from the Divine Presence - "the voice of Hashem in strength," "the voice of Hashem breaks cedars" - logic dictates that after meriting to hear the voice of Elokim speaking, they would also perceive that powerful voice through their sense of sight due to its intense power. Thus, Chazal didn't count it as a miracle, because the seeing itself wasn't miraculous - the main miracle was that they merited to hear the voice of the living G-d speaking to them and lived, as it is written. In this divine voice, the boundaries between hearing and seeing were equal.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the unique phenomenon at Mount Sinai where the Jewish people "saw the sounds" (רואים את הקולות). The author explains that this wasn't listed among the miracles of Sinai because there's a natural basis for sound having physical substance, as evidenced by modern sound recording technology. The key theological insight is that the Divine voice at Sinai was so powerful and tangible that it crossed the normal boundaries between senses, allowing people to literally see God's words - not as a supernatural miracle, but as an intensified natural phenomenon reflecting the unique spiritual level achieved at the revelation. This interpretation connects the physical and metaphysical aspects of Divine revelation, suggesting that the boundaries between natural and supernatural experiences can blur during moments of intense Divine manifestation.
keywords: מתן תורה (Matan Torah) ,קול ה' (Kol Hashem) ,פי הגבורה (Pi HaGevurah) ,קול אלקים חיים (Kol Elokim Chaim) ,חוש הראיה (Chush HaReiyah) ,ניסים (Nissim) ,חקי הטבע (Chukei HaTeva) ,נשמע (Nishma) ,דקות (Dakut) ,עצמיות (Atzmiyut)

hebrew_text: ועפ"י בחי' זו פירשתי מאה"כ יען לא האמנתם בי להקדישני לעיני בנ"י וגו', עפי"מ שכתב הכלי יקר ז"ל בטעם החטא דמי מריבה, דע"י שעשו את הנס במטה גרמו חולשא באמונתם, שהיו קצתם מישראל מרננים אחר המטה. ואמרו שכל הניסים שעשה משה במטהו היה ע"צ הכישוף ח"ו, וע"כ צוה הקב"ה בקריעת ים סוף ואתה הרם את מטך ונטה ידך וגו', פי' שיסלק את המטה, מלשון הרמה וסילוק, ויעשה נס הבקיעה ע"י נטיית ידו, ועי"ז ויאמינו בה' ובמשה עבדו עיי"ש לדרכו, ולדרכינו אלמלא היו מדברים אל הסלע ושכינה מדברת מגרונו של משה, היה בחי' הקול נרגש להם בחוש הראות, והיו רואים את הקולות כמו שהיה במתן תורה, וזה היה להם למופת חותך כי בחינת הנס הוא מהקב"ה, ועי"ז היה נתחזק אצלם האמונה בהשי"ת ובמשה עבדו, וזשאה"כ יען לא האמנתם בי להקדישני לעיני בני ישראל, שאילו היה הדיבור נראה לעיני בנ"י, לא היה מקום להסתפק ולהתלונן, והיה נתחזק אמונתם עי"ז.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Based on this aspect, I have interpreted the verse "Because you did not believe in Me to sanctify Me in the eyes of the Children of Israel, etc." According to what the Kli Yakar wrote regarding the sin of Mei Merivah (Waters of Strife), that by performing the miracle with the staff, they caused a weakness in their faith, as some of Israel complained about the staff. They said that all the miracles Moses performed with his staff were done through sorcery, Heaven forbid. Therefore, at the splitting of the Red Sea, Hashem commanded "And you, lift up your staff and stretch out your hand," meaning he should remove the staff (the word "harem" meaning to lift up and remove), and perform the miracle of splitting through stretching his hand, and through this "they believed in Hashem and Moses His servant."

Following our approach: had they spoken to the rock with the Shechinah (Divine Presence) speaking through Moses's throat, the aspect of the voice would have been tangibly perceived through their sense of sight, and they would have seen the voices as they did at Matan Torah (the Giving of the Torah). This would have been decisive proof that the miracle was from Hakadosh Baruch Hu (the Holy One, Blessed be He), and through this their faith in Hashem and Moses His servant would have been strengthened. This is what the verse means: "Because you did not believe in Me to sanctify Me in the eyes of the Children of Israel" - for if the speech had been visible to the eyes of the Children of Israel, there would have been no room for doubt and complaint, and their faith would have been strengthened through this.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the sin of Mei Merivah (Waters of Strife), building on the Kli Yakar's interpretation. The core insight is that using the staff for miracles potentially weakened the people's faith, as some might attribute the miracles to sorcery rather than divine power. Had Moses spoken to the rock as commanded, the Divine Presence would have been visibly manifest through Moses' throat when he spoke, similar to how the voices were "seen" at Mount Sinai, providing irrefutable proof of God's direct involvement. The passage suggests that this visible manifestation of Divine speech would have strengthened the people's faith in both God and Moses, eliminating any doubts or complaints - which explains the verse "because you did not believe in Me to sanctify Me in the eyes of the Children of Israel."
keywords: אמונה (Emunah) ,שכינה (Shechina) ,קדושה (Kedusha) ,להקדישני],ניסים (Nissim) ,השי"ת (Hashem Yitbarach) ,בחינה (Bechina) ,קול (Kol) ,מופת (Mofet) ,גרון (Garon) ,חוש הראות (Chush HaRe'ut)

hebrew_text: ועד"ז יתבאר ביוסף הצדיק שבהתוודע אל אחיו דיבר אליהם בלשון הקודש כפי שרשו למעלה, באותו הלשון שנתן הקב"ה התורה לעמו ישראל, ולגודל קדושתם של השבטים, ולגודל קדושת הדיבורים ההם, נמשך עליו השראת השכינה, והיתה השכינה מדברת מתוך גרונו, והיו רואים את הקולות בחוש הראות, ומזה ראיה ברורה כי הוא יוסף הצדיק, כי א"א לאדם אחר במצרים שיזכה למדריגה זו שיהיה השכינה מדברת מתוך גרונו, ויהיה דיבורו נרגש בחוש הראות, וז"ש כי עיניכם הרואות כי פי המדבר אליכם, ובחי' דיבור כזה, ובחי' לה"ק כזה, א"א שיהיה במציאות אצל בני עבר הנהר ובני כנען והרי זה ראי' ומופת חותך שאני יוסף, ובחי' דיבור כזה שיהיה רואין את הנשמע א"א אלא בלה"ק, הגם שאמרו ז"ל שכל דיבור שיצא מפי הקב"ה במ"ת נתחלק לע' לשונות, אפשר דאלו החלקים שנתלבשו בשאר הלשונות. לא היה להם מדרגת דיבורו של הקב"ה להיותן מורגשים בחוש הראות, ואותיות ותיבות מע' לשונות שמצטרפים לשקר וטומאה, א"א שיחול עליהם בחי' השראת השכינה ובחי' התורה, שבאותיות התורה ברא הקב"ה את עולמו ושמים וארץ וכל העולמות אין מספר, וכ"ז היה ע"י בחי' לה"ק שבה, וכמו"כ ענין דרואין את הקולות לא היה אלא בבחינת לה"ק שבה, ולא במה שנתלבש בע' לשון, וע"כ פירש"י כי פי המדבר אליכם בלה"ק, ועל כי עיניכם הרואות בחי' הדיבור, מעתה הוא ראיה ובירור גמור שאני יוסף אחיכם.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts and terminology:

In this way, it can be explained regarding Yosef HaTzaddik that when he revealed himself to his brothers, he spoke to them in Lashon HaKodesh (the Holy Tongue) according to his spiritual root above, in the same language that the Holy One Blessed be He gave the Torah to His people Israel. Due to the great holiness of the tribes and the great holiness of those words, the Divine Presence (Shechinah) came to rest upon him, and the Shechinah spoke through his throat. They could see the voices with their physical sense of sight, and this was clear proof that he was indeed Yosef HaTzaddik, for it would be impossible for any other person in Egypt to merit such a level where the Shechinah would speak through his throat and his speech would be perceived through the sense of sight.

This is what is meant by "for your eyes see that it is my mouth speaking to you." Such a level of speech and such a quality of Lashon HaKodesh could not possibly exist among the people from across the river or the Canaanites. This serves as definitive proof that "I am Yosef." Such speech, where the heard becomes visible, is only possible in Lashon HaKodesh.

Although our Sages said that every utterance that came from the Holy One Blessed be He at Mount Sinai was divided into seventy languages, it's possible that those portions that were clothed in other languages did not maintain the level of Hashem's speech to be perceived through sight. Letters and words from the seventy languages that can combine to form falsehood and impurity cannot possibly have the Divine Presence rest upon them or contain the aspect of Torah, for with the letters of the Torah, the Holy One Blessed be He created His world, heaven and earth, and countless worlds. All this was through the aspect of Lashon HaKodesh within it.

Similarly, the phenomenon of "seeing the voices" only occurred through the aspect of Lashon HaKodesh within it, and not through what was clothed in the seventy languages. Therefore, Rashi explains "for my mouth speaks to you" refers to Lashon HaKodesh, and "your eyes see" refers to the visible aspect of the speech, which serves as complete proof and verification that "I am Yosef your brother."
summary: This passage discusses a profound moment when Joseph revealed himself to his brothers in Egypt, focusing on the spiritual significance of his use of Lashon Hakodesh (the Holy Tongue/Hebrew). The text explains that due to the brothers' great holiness and the sanctity of that moment, the Divine Presence (Shechinah) spoke through Joseph's throat, causing his words to become visibly manifest - a phenomenon similar to what occurred at Mount Sinai where the Israelites "saw the sounds." The passage emphasizes that this level of Divine manifestation could only occur through Lashon Hakodesh, not through other languages, as only the Holy Tongue has the spiritual capacity to bridge the physical and spiritual realms in this way. This served as definitive proof to the brothers of Joseph's true identity, as no other person in Egypt could have achieved such a spiritual level where the Shechinah would speak through them and their words would become visible to the physical eye.

hebrew_text: ומעתה יובנו מאמר חז"ל מה שדרשו במסכת מגילה (דף ט"ז ע"ב) כי פי המדבר אליכם כפי כן לבי, ולכאורה איך נתברר להם מצפוני לבבו, גם הקשה הרבינו בחיי זלל"ה, כי אין נזכר בכתוב לבו כלל רק פי ומאין למדו חז"ל לומר כן, ולדרכינו א"ש על כי היו רואין את הנשמע, המה ראו והשיגו השראת השכינה בהדיבורים ההם ושהי' שכינה מדברת מתוך גרונו, כי אי אפשר במדרגת קול זולתו להרגיש בחוש הראות, ומזה השיגו כי כפיו כן לבו, כי על דיבורים של שקר אי אפשר שיחול השראת השכינה ולהיות נרגשים בחוש הראות, ונמצא מבואר בפסוק ראיה זו דכפיו כן לבו, ממ"ש והנה עיניכם הרואות ול"ק קושית הרבינו בחיי זלל"ה.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Now we can understand the statement of our Sages, who expounded in Tractate Megillah (16b) on the verse "for my mouth speaks to you" - that "as is my mouth, so is my heart." At first glance, how did they determine the hidden contents of his heart? Additionally, the Rabbeinu Bachya, of blessed memory, raised a difficulty: the text doesn't mention his heart at all, only his mouth, so from where did our Sages derive this interpretation?

Following our approach, this can be well understood because they "saw what was heard" - they saw and perceived the Divine Presence (Shechina) in those words, and that the Shechina was speaking through his throat. For it is impossible to perceive such a level of voice through the sense of sight except in this case. From this, they understood that "as was his mouth, so was his heart," because the Divine Presence cannot rest upon false words and be perceived through the sense of sight. Thus, this proof that "as was his mouth, so was his heart" is explained in the verse through the words "behold, your eyes see," and the question of Rabbeinu Bachya, of blessed memory, is no longer difficult.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a Talmudic interpretation (from Megillah 16b) about Joseph's revelation to his brothers, specifically focusing on the concept that "his mouth and heart were aligned." The text addresses how the brothers could verify Joseph's sincerity, explaining that they were able to "see what was heard" - meaning they perceived the Divine Presence (Shechinah) speaking through Joseph's words. The key theological insight is that the Divine Presence can only rest upon words of truth, not falsehood, so the visible manifestation of the Shechinah in Joseph's speech served as proof that his external words matched his internal intentions. This explains the seemingly puzzling biblical phrase "your eyes see" in a spiritual sense, teaching that authentic Divine communication carries a tangible spiritual presence that can be perceived by those on an appropriate spiritual level.

hebrew_text: ועל בחי' לה"ק כזה שהי' ליוסף הצדיק אמרו חז"ל דאגמרי' לפרעה ולא גמר. שאי אפשר לפה טמא להשיג בחי' לה"ק כזה, משא"כ השפה שהיו מדברים אנשי עבר הנהר ואנשי ארץ כנען גם פרעה היה יודע בו, כמו שהיה יכול ללמוד כל הע' לשונות. ועל כן השביע ליוסף שלא יגלה יתרון ידיעתו בלה"ק, ואפשר שלא הקפיד אם ידבר לה"ק אל אחיו כמ"ש המזרחי, וע"כ לא עבר יוסף על שבועתו במה שדיבר אל אחיו בלה"ק, כי היה משביעו ע"ד כן שלא יגלה בפני המצרים. ומה שדיבר המליץ בלה"ק בפני המצריים זה היה לשון עבר הנהר וארץ כנען. וזה לא היה סוד כי רבים במצרים ידעו הלשון ההוא, ומתורץ קושית הנזה"ק כי לא הי' מתיירא פרעה פן יבא א' מגדולי ארץ כנען ועבר הנהר וירצה לדבר אתו בלה"ק ויתגלה חרפתו, כי הלשון המורגל אצלם גם פרעה הי' יודע בו אלא שלא היה שומע ויודע לשון יוסף, וסרו כל הספיקות בענין הנ"ל.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Regarding this level of Lashon HaKodesh (the Holy Tongue) that Yosef HaTzaddik possessed, our Sages said that he tried to teach it to Pharaoh but Pharaoh couldn't learn it. For it is impossible for an impure mouth to grasp such a level of Lashon HaKodesh. However, the language spoken by the people from across the river (Ever HaNahar) and the people of Canaan, even Pharaoh knew this, just as he was able to learn all 70 languages.

Therefore, he made Yosef swear not to reveal his superior knowledge of Lashon HaKodesh. It's possible that he wasn't particular about Yosef speaking Lashon HaKodesh with his brothers, as the Mizrachi states. Therefore, Yosef didn't violate his oath when he spoke to his brothers in Lashon HaKodesh, because the oath was specifically about not revealing it before the Egyptians.

And when the interpreter spoke in Lashon HaKodesh before the Egyptians, this was actually the language of Ever HaNahar and Canaan. This wasn't a secret, as many in Egypt knew this language. This resolves the question of the Zohar HaKadosh, as Pharaoh wasn't afraid that one of the great ones from Canaan or Ever HaNahar would come and want to speak with him in Lashon HaKodesh, thereby revealing his shame, because Pharaoh knew the common language they used. He just couldn't understand and know Yosef's [higher level of] language. Thus, all doubts regarding this matter are resolved.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the unique nature of Joseph's mastery of Lashon Hakodesh (the Holy Tongue/Hebrew) and its relationship to Pharaoh. The key theological insight is that there were two levels of Hebrew: a higher, sacred form that Joseph possessed which Pharaoh couldn't grasp due to his spiritual impurity ("peh tamei"), and a more common form spoken by people from across the river and Canaan which Pharaoh did know. The text explains that Pharaoh made Joseph swear not to reveal his superior knowledge of the holy Hebrew, though Joseph was permitted to speak it with his brothers since this wouldn't expose Pharaoh's inability to grasp it. This distinction between sacred and common Hebrew reflects a deeper Hasidic concept about levels of spiritual attainment and how one's spiritual state affects their ability to access higher realms of holiness.

hebrew_text: ועתה נבאר דלמה הוצרך יוסף לשני הראיות גם יחד, אחרי שכל א' מהראיות הוא בירור גמור כנ"ל, א"כ יספיק בא' מהם, ואפ"ל כי אמנם שנתברר להם ע"י ראיית המילה שהוא צדיק גמור ע"י שראו עליו השראת שמו יתברך כנ"ל, ואי אפשר להסתפק בו בערבי מהול ומבני קטורה, אולם עדיין היה להם מקום לספק, דאפשר שיש עוד צדיק בארץ נוטר הברית ושריא עלי' שמא קדישא, ואינו יוסף. ורק להפיס דעתם ולשם שמים משנה בדיבורו לאמר שהוא יוסף, על כי ראה בצרת נפשם, גם כי השבטים היו מוכנים למלחמה להרוג אותו ואת כל העיר כמ"ש במדרש, ע"כ חששו שמא שינה את דיבורו ע"ד שאמרו ז"ל מותר לשנות מפני דרכי שלו', ואפשר שיגלה להם לאח"ז שאינו יוסף אחיהם, אמנם נתברר ספיקותם זה מראיית הלשון, כי מבחי' הלשון שהיה במדרגת רואין את הנשמע, שאי אפשר להיות כן כי אם ע"י השראת השכינה בהדיבורים עצמן ולהיות שכינה מדברת מתוך גרונו מזה ידעו שכפיו כן לבו ואינו משנה בדיבורו, כי לא יחול השראת השכינה על דיבור שקר ח"ו, ואילו לא היו דיבורים של אמת אפילו על צד ההיתר כגון לשנות מפני השלום או מפני הסכנה, א"א שיהיה שכינה מדברת מתוך גרונו, וע"כ מזה ידעו בראיה ברורה כי דבר אמת בפיו כי הוא יוסף אחיהם.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Now we will explain why Yosef needed both proofs together, since each proof was a complete verification as mentioned above. If so, one should have been sufficient. One can explain that although it was verified to them through seeing the milah (circumcision) that he was a complete tzaddik (righteous person), as they saw upon him the Divine Presence (hashra'at Shemo Yitbarach) as mentioned above, and it was impossible to mistake him for an Arab who was circumcised or from the children of Keturah.

However, they still had room for doubt, as it was possible that there was another tzaddik in the land who guarded the bris (covenant) and had the holy name (shema kadisha) rest upon him, and he wasn't Yosef. Perhaps he was only changing his speech to ease their minds and for the sake of Heaven (l'shem shamayim) by saying he was Yosef, because he saw their spiritual distress. Also, since the tribes were prepared for war to kill him and the entire city as stated in the Midrash, they were concerned that perhaps he changed his speech in the way our Sages said it is permitted to change [the truth] for the sake of peace (mipnei darchei shalom), and perhaps he would later reveal to them that he wasn't their brother Yosef.

However, their doubts were resolved through seeing his language capability, for regarding the aspect of language that was at the level of "seeing what is heard," which is impossible except through the Divine Presence (hashra'at HaShechinah) speaking through his throat. From this they knew that his mouth and heart were aligned and he wasn't changing his speech, for the Divine Presence cannot rest upon false speech, Heaven forbid. If the words weren't truthful, even in a permitted way such as changing for the sake of peace or because of danger, it would have been impossible for the Shechinah to speak through his throat. Therefore, from this they knew with clear proof that truth was in his mouth and that he was indeed their brother Yosef.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses why Joseph needed two proofs to convince his brothers of his identity. The first proof (his circumcision) demonstrated his righteousness through the Divine presence upon him, but the brothers could have doubted whether he might be another righteous person falsely claiming to be Joseph for peaceful purposes. The second proof, his ability to speak in the holy tongue (Hebrew) at such a high spiritual level where "the heard could be seen," demonstrated that the Divine Presence was speaking through his throat - something that would be impossible if he were speaking falsely, even for permitted reasons like maintaining peace. The passage reveals a deep theological principle that the Divine Presence (Shechinah) cannot rest upon false speech, even when the falsehood would be technically permitted by Jewish law.
