Another way to interpret the meaning of the verse "Behold, your eyes see that it is my mouth speaking to you," and also what is written in the Midrash "as my mouth is, so is my heart," is by first explaining what Rashi z"l wrote in the name of the Midrash (Parshat Vayechi) on the verse "Gather and I will tell you what will happen to you in the end of days." Yaakov sought to reveal the End (ketz), but the Shechinah departed from him, and he began saying other things.

At first glance, we must understand: since this speech was ultimately not fulfilled, why was it written in the holy Torah if it didn't happen? Also, how did Yaakov speak words that weren't fulfilled, and how could it be that he didn't fulfill his statement? After all, Yaakov Avinu a"h's attribute was truth, as it is written "Give truth to Yaakov."

However, Chazal said regarding the End of the Redemption (in Midrash Shocher Tov 9) "to the mouth it was not revealed," and they said in Masechet Sanhedrin (99a) on "For the day of vengeance is in my heart, and the year of my redemption has come" - what is meant by "day of vengeance is in my heart"? Rabbi Yochanan said: "To my heart I revealed it, to my limbs I did not reveal it." Reish Lakish said: "To my heart I revealed it, to the ministering angels I did not reveal it."

The Sages of Truth (Chachmei HaEmet) explain that there are souls of tzaddikim who are in the aspect of "mouth" and to them it was not revealed, and there are souls of tzaddikim who are in the aspect of "heart" and to them the secret of redemption was revealed. The simple meaning of the statement is that permission was not given to reveal the secret of redemption through speech, only through thought in the heart.

Yaakov Avinu initially thought to reveal to the holy tribes the secret of redemption explicitly and openly. The commentators explained his reasoning, each according to their approach (see Yefat Toar and Nitzotzei HaKodesh). When he saw that Heaven did not agree to reveal it through speech, he began speaking other things. In those words - the blessings he blessed them with - he clothed the secret of redemption in hints, and the secret of redemption was hidden within them in the aspect of thought. As Chazal explained in the Midrash that to each of the tribes, Yaakov informed them in their blessings what would happen to them until the coming of Mashiach.

This is what Rashi z"l meant when he said Yaakov sought to reveal the End and the Shechinah departed from him, and he began saying other things - meaning that within those words he clothed the secret of redemption. Otherwise, why would Rashi z"l need to say that he began saying other things, when this is explicitly stated in the verse?
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a profound theological concept regarding Jacob's attempt to reveal the end of days (קץ הגאולה) to his sons. The key insight is that while Jacob initially wanted to explicitly reveal the time of redemption, divine intervention prevented him from doing so directly, leading him instead to embed these secrets within the blessings he gave to his sons. The text explains that there are two levels of divine knowledge: that which can be revealed through speech (פומא) and that which can only be known in the heart (ליבא), with the timing of redemption belonging to the latter category. This interpretation reconciles Jacob's attribute of truth (מדת אמת) with the apparent unfulfillment of his initial intention, explaining that he ultimately did convey the information, but in a concealed, encoded form within the blessings rather than explicitly.
keywords: שכינה (Shechina) ,תוה"ק (Torah HaKedosha) ,קץ הגאולה (Ketz HaGeulah) ,נשמות צדיקים (Nishmot Tzadikim) ,באתגליא (B'Itgalia) ,סוד הגאולה (Sod HaGeulah) ,ביאת המשיח (Bi'at HaMashiach) ,מידת אמת (Midat Emet) ,מלאכי השרת (Malachei HaSharet) ,חכמי האמת (Chachmei HaEmet)

hebrew_text: ומעתה א"ש דמ"ש ואגידה לכם את אשר יקרא אתכם באחרית הימים נתקיים דיבורו וקיים יעקב אבינו מאמרו, אלא שלא גילהו אלא ברמז ובבחינת ליבא, וכמו"כ יוסף הצדיק בעת שדיבר אל אחיו, רמז בדיבוריו עתידות ועניני הגאולה כמו שביארנו לעיל, וכמו שביארו בזוה"ק בפרשת העגלות כד יפקון מן גלותא וכו', ודיבורים אלו אי אפשר לגלות בפה רק בבחינת ליבא, ע"כ אמר והנה עיניכם הרואות כי פי המדבר אליכם, וראי' האמור כאן פירושו ראיה שכלית, כמ"ש רואה אנו את דברי אדמון, והכוונה שתתבוננו בדברי ותראו שמרומז בהם בחינת העתיד, ודרשו חז"ל כפי כן לבי, והכוונה שהדיבורים שבפי הם הוכחה להבין מתוכם עניני הגאולה שהם בבחינת ליבא לפומא לא גליא.

And now it is well understood that what is written "I will tell you what will happen to you in the end of days" - Yaakov Avinu fulfilled his words and kept his statement, except that he only revealed it through remez (hints) and in the aspect of "liba" (heart/inner dimension). Similarly, Yosef HaTzaddik, when speaking to his brothers, hinted in his words to future events and matters of the geulah (redemption) as we explained above, and as explained in the holy Zohar regarding the wagons [referring to] when they will leave from galus (exile), etc. These matters cannot be revealed explicitly through speech, only in the aspect of "liba" (heart).

Therefore he said "Behold your eyes see that it is my mouth speaking to you," and the "seeing" mentioned here means intellectual sight, as it is written "we see the words of Admon." The intention is that you should contemplate my words and see that hinted within them is the aspect of the future. Our Sages interpreted "as my mouth so is my heart," meaning that the words in my mouth are proof to understand from within them the matters of redemption, which are in the aspect of "liba l'puma lo galya" (what is in the heart is not revealed to the mouth).
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of prophetic communication, particularly focusing on how both Yaakov Avinu and Yosef HaTzaddik communicated future events and matters of redemption (geulah) through hints and allusions rather than explicit statements. The text explains that certain spiritual matters, especially those concerning the final redemption, can only be conveyed through "bechinat liba" (matters of the heart) and cannot be explicitly verbalized. The passage emphasizes that when Yosef told his brothers "my mouth is speaking to you," he was indicating that his words contained deeper meanings about future redemption that could only be understood through spiritual and intellectual insight (re'iyah sichlit), not through literal interpretation.

hebrew_text: ועפי"ז נבין דברי המדרש שבפתח דברנו ויגש אליו יהודה. מים עמוקים עצה בלב איש וגו' משל לבאר עמוקה וכו' כך לא זז יהודה וכו' עד שעמד על לבו, כוונת המשל שהמשיל דברי יוסף למים עמוקים, כי עניני הגאולה הרמוזים בדבוריו הוא עמוק מאד ואי אפשר לעמוד על סודם, וליבא לפומא לא גליא, ובא א' וקשר חבל בחבל נימא בנימא וכו' כך לא זז יהודה משיב דבר על דבר עד שעמד על לבו, שמתוך דבריו עמד על סוד הגאולה שנסתר בהם בבחינת מחשבה שבלב, וז"ש עמד על לבו והבן. ויובן גם המשך המשל מ"ש שבא אדם א' ודלה הימנה ושתה התחילו הכל דולין הימנה ושותין, הרמז על השבטים שגם הם הבינו רמז המחשבה וסוד הגאולה, שכיון שירדה ההשגה מעולם המחשבה ע"י יהודה, מעתה השיגו גם הם, וז"ש התחילו הכל דולין הימנה.

Based on this, we can understand the words of the Midrash that we began with "And Judah approached him." "Deep waters are counsel in the heart of man, etc." - This is comparable to a deep well, etc. Thus Judah did not move, etc. until he understood his heart. The meaning of the mashal (parable) that compares Joseph's words to deep waters is because the matters of redemption (geulah) that were hinted at in his words were very deep and impossible to fully comprehend their secret (sod), and the heart does not reveal to the mouth. Then one came and tied rope to rope, thread to thread, etc. Similarly, Judah did not cease responding word for word until he understood his heart, meaning that through his words he understood the secret of redemption that was hidden within them at the level of thought in the heart. This is the meaning of "understood his heart" - contemplate this.

The continuation of the mashal can also be understood, which states that one person came and drew from it and drank, and then everyone began drawing from it and drinking. This alludes to the tribes, who also understood the hint of the thought and the secret of redemption. Once the understanding descended from the world of thought through Judah, they too were able to grasp it, and this is the meaning of "everyone began drawing from it."
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the deeper meaning of Yehuda's approach to Yosef through the metaphor of "deep waters" from the Midrash. The key insight is that Yosef's words contained profound hidden meanings about redemption (geulah) that were too deep to be readily understood, like deep waters that are hard to access. Through Yehuda's persistent dialogue with Yosef, described as connecting rope to rope and thread to thread, he was able to penetrate to the heart of the matter and understand these hidden redemptive meanings, which then enabled the other tribes to access this deep understanding as well. The passage emphasizes how spiritual insights about redemption exist first in the realm of thought/heart (machshavah/lev) before they can be accessed and brought into revelation through proper spiritual effort and dialogue.
keywords: גאולה (Geulah) ,סוד (Sod) ,מחשבה (Machshavah) ,לב (Lev) ,השגה (Hasagah) ,ליבא לפומא (Liba L'Puma) ,רמז (Remez) ,עולם המחשבה (Olam HaMachshavah) ,נסתר (Nistar) ,דבור (Dibur)

hebrew_text: ועפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל נבין במאמה"כ ואתה צויתה זאת עשו קחו לכם עגלות לטפכם וגו' ונשאתם את אביכם ובאתם וגו' ויעשו כן בנ"י ויתן להם יוסף עגלות וגו'. ולכאורה עשיה זו מה טיבה, ועדיין לא נתן להם העגלות אלא לאח"כ, ואחר שקבלו העגלות שייך לומר העשיה ולא קודם לכן (עיין לעיל קושיא י'). אמנם כפי מה שביארנו עיקר הכוונה בעגלות האלה היה להמשיך כח העבודה וכח התיקון למסעות הגלות, וע"כ רמז להם יוסף לעגלות צב שבמשכן כנ"ל, להמשיך כח השמירה לישראל בכל מסעיהם בגלותם. וזה רמז להם יוסף במצו' עגלה ערופה ובמצות לויה כנ"ל והשבטים הקדושים הבינו כל הרמז בהם, וקבלו עליהם לעשות תיקונים אלו, ולהמשיך בכח קדושתם הצלה לדורות ישראל בעגלות אלו, ואמרו חז"ל במכילתא (פ' בא) וילכו ויעשו בנ"י כאשר צוה ה' את משה כן עשו, וכי כבר עשו, והלא מר"ח נאמר להם פ' קרבן פסח ועדיין לא עשו עד ארבעה עשר בניסן, אלא מכיון שקבלו עליהם מעלה עליהם הכתוב כאילו עשו, כמו"כ השבטים הקדושים אף דלא ניתנו להם העגלות עדיין, ופעולת הנסיעה לא נתקיים אלא לאח"כ, אבל מיד הבינו הכוונה בשעת הצווי, וקבלו עליהם לעשות תיקונים האלה, ומעלה עליהם הכתוב כאלו עשו, ובפרט כי עיקר בזה היתה הכנה הרוחני בכח קדושתם להמשיך לבניהם אחריהם כנ"ל, והוכנו אליה מיד, וע"כ אמר הכתוב ויעשו כן בנ"י מיד אחר שנצטוו מפי יוסף.

According to our approach mentioned above, we can understand the verse "And you have commanded this: do this, take wagons for your children, etc... and carry your father and come, etc... And the Children of Israel did so, and Joseph gave them wagons, etc." At first glance, what is the nature of this "doing," when they hadn't yet received the wagons until later? The term "doing" would only be appropriate after receiving the wagons, not before (see earlier question 10).

However, as we explained, the main intention with these wagons was to draw down the power of divine service (koach ha'avodah) and the power of tikkun for the journeys of exile. Therefore, Joseph alluded to them about the covered wagons (agalot tzav) of the Mishkan, as mentioned above, to draw down the power of protection for Israel in all their journeys in exile. Joseph hinted at this through the mitzvah of the eglah arufah (broken-necked heifer) and the mitzvah of levayah (accompaniment) as mentioned above.

The holy tribes understood all these allusions and accepted upon themselves to make these tikkunim and to draw down, through their holy power, salvation for future generations of Israel through these wagons. Our Sages said in the Mechilta (Parshat Bo) regarding "And the Children of Israel went and did as Hashem commanded Moses, so they did" - Did they already do it? Wasn't the section about the Pesach sacrifice told to them on Rosh Chodesh, and they didn't actually do it until the fourteenth of Nissan? Rather, since they accepted it upon themselves, Scripture considers it as if they had already done it.

Similarly, even though the holy tribes hadn't yet received the wagons, and the actual journey didn't take place until later, they immediately understood the intention at the time of the command and accepted upon themselves to make these tikkunim. Scripture considers it as if they had done it, especially since the main aspect was the spiritual preparation through their holy power to draw down [blessing] for their children after them, as mentioned above. They were prepared for this immediately, and therefore Scripture says "And the Children of Israel did so" immediately after they were commanded by Joseph.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the deeper significance of the wagons (agalot) that Joseph sent to transport Jacob and his family to Egypt. The key theological insight is that these wagons weren't merely physical vehicles, but represented a spiritual protective force that would accompany the Jewish people throughout their future exiles. The text draws a parallel between these wagons and the wagons used in the Mishkan (Tabernacle), suggesting that Joseph was prophetically embedding spiritual safeguards for future generations. The passage emphasizes that the mere acceptance and understanding of this spiritual mission by the tribes was considered as if they had already performed it, similar to how the Jews' acceptance of the Pesach offering was considered as if they had already brought it, highlighting the power of spiritual intention in Jewish thought.

hebrew_text: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל שאמר יהודה אם למלחמה אני בא, אם לפיוס אני בא, אם לתפלה אני בא, עפימ"ש ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה (בפ' וישב) בשם ספה"ק קדושת לוי זלל"ה דבימי החשמונאים לא הי' הנס בשלימות מפני שהיה דרך מלחמה, ודרך התורה שלא יעשו התחתונים שום פעולה גשמית רק בתפלה ובתחנונים לפני הקב"ה עשיי"ד. אמנם ישנם זמנים שהסכימו מן השמים למלחמה, כמו בימי החשמונאים הכהנים הגדולים שהיו לוחמים עפ"י רוה"ק, ודוד המלך ע"ה לחם מלחמותיו בעצת אורים ותומים ועפ"י רוה"ק, ועוד מלכים אחרים שהראו להם הסכמה מן השמים על המלחמה, והיו זמנים שלא הוסכם מן השמים להלחם עם האומות, והוצרכו לפייסם בדורונות ולשחדם בממון בצירוף כח התפלה, ובאופן זה ניצולו מהם, ועתידים אומות העולם להחזיר כל אותן הדורונות כנ"ל, ובזמנינו אלה עיקבתא דמשיחא אין לנו רשות לערוך נגדם מלחמה ואין לנו עצה ותרופה כי אם להתפלל להבוי"ת וזה כל תוחלתינו, וע"כ אמר יהודה כל אלו הג' בחינות, שהי' מלך על השבטים, ומלך המשיח עתיד לצאת מיהודה, ע"כ מונה והולך כל אלו הזמנים וכל הבחינות שיעברו על ישראל עד ביאת המשיח. וז"ש אם למלחמה. ר"ל אם יסכימו מן השמים למלחמה, ויהיה רצון העליון כן, אז אני בא להלחם, ורמז על דוד דאתי מיהודה, וגם רמז על שאר המלכים שנלחמו במצות השי"ת, שיהודה הוא ראש המלוכה, ורמז גם עליהם באמרו אני בא, וכן אם לפיוס אני בא. ואם לתפלה כשיהיה רצון העליון שיבא הישועה ע"י תפלה לבדה, אז אני בא בכח התפלה, והכוונה על מלך המשיח דאתי מיהודה, שיבא משיח צדקינו בלי פעולה גשמיות ובלי מלחמה, ובאמת כח וזכות התפלה צריך שיהיה מצורף גם למלחמה ולפיוס, ומ"ש אם לתפלה הכוונה על תפלה לבדה לאפוקי מלחמה, ובכח התפלה לבד יבא משיח צדקינו. ולא יצטרכו לפעולה טבעיות ולמלחמה, ובעוה"ר בימינו אלה נסתמו הלבבות, ואין היכולת בידינו לשפוך שיח ותחנונים בלב שלם, אבל כבר הוכן כח התפלה ע"י האבות הקדושים והשבטים, כמ"ש בזוה"ק ע' תולדות שע"י צלותהון דצדיקיא יתרבי ויתוסף רבות קודשא לכל מאן דאצטריך, ובפרט על גלות האחרון ועל גאולה העתידה שראו כל זה ברוח קדשם והתפללו עליה, ושמורה כח וזכות תפילתם לעת חננה כי בא מועד, ובודאי שיהיה לסיוע ועזר שיתקבל גם תפילתינו אכיה"ר.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

This explains the words of the aforementioned Midrash where Yehudah said, "If I come for war, if I come for appeasement, if I come for prayer." This is based on what the holy Yismach Moshe wrote (in Parshat Vayeshev) in the name of the holy Kedushat Levi, that in the days of the Chashmonaim, the miracle was not complete because it came through war. The way of the Torah is that those below should not take any physical action, but rather [rely] only on prayer and supplication before the Holy One, Blessed be He.

However, there are times when Heaven agreed to war, such as in the days of the Chashmonaim, the Kohanim Gedolim who fought according to Ruach HaKodesh (Divine inspiration), and King David who fought his wars through the counsel of the Urim v'Tumim and Ruach HaKodesh. There were other kings who received Heaven's consent for war. There were also times when Heaven did not agree to fight against the nations, and they needed to appease them with gifts and bribe them with money, combined with the power of prayer, and in this way they were saved from them. In the future, the nations of the world will return all these gifts, as mentioned above.

In our times, these being Ikveta d'Meshicha (the footsteps of Mashiach), we have no permission to wage war against them, and we have no counsel or remedy except to pray to Hashem, and this is our only hope. Therefore, Yehudah mentioned all these three aspects, as he was king over the tribes, and Melech HaMashiach (King Messiah) will come from Yehudah. Thus, he enumerated all these times and aspects that Israel will experience until the coming of Mashiach.

This is what is meant by "if for war" - meaning if Heaven agrees to war and it is the Supreme Will, then I come to fight, alluding to David who comes from Yehudah, and also alluding to other kings who fought by Hashem's command, as Yehudah is the head of kingship. He also alluded to them by saying "I come." Similarly, "if for appeasement I come," and "if for prayer" - when it is the Supreme Will that salvation should come through prayer alone, then I come with the power of prayer.

This refers to Melech HaMashiach who comes from Yehudah, that Mashiach Tzidkeinu will come without physical action and without war. In truth, the power and merit of prayer must be combined with both war and appeasement. When it says "if for prayer," it means prayer alone, excluding war, and through the power of prayer alone Mashiach Tzidkeinu will come.

Unfortunately, in our days, hearts have become blocked, and we lack the ability to pour out speech and supplications with a complete heart. However, the power of prayer has already been prepared by the holy Avot and the Shevatim (tribes), as written in the holy Zohar (Parshat Toldot), that through the prayers of the tzaddikim, holiness increases and is added to all who need it, especially regarding the final exile and the future redemption, which they saw through their holy spirit and prayed for. The power and merit of their prayers are preserved for the time of grace when the appointed time comes, and surely it will help and assist that our prayers too will be accepted, Amen, so may it be His will.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses three approaches to dealing with adversity, as exemplified by Yehudah: through warfare, appeasement, or prayer. The text emphasizes that while there were times in Jewish history when Heaven sanctioned physical warfare (like during the Hasmonean period) or diplomatic appeasement, in the current pre-Messianic era (ikvesa d'meshicha), prayer is the only legitimate approach. The passage particularly stresses that the ultimate redemption through Mashiach will come through the power of prayer alone, without physical warfare, and that while our current generation may lack the ability to pray with complete devotion, we can rely on the accumulated merit of the prayers of our righteous ancestors (particularly the Avot and Shevatim) who foresaw and prayed for the final redemption.
keywords: רוה"ק (Ruach HaKodesh) ,אורים ותומים (Urim V'Tumim) ,עיקבתא דמשיחא (Ikveta d'Meshicha) ,משיח צדקינו (Moshiach Tzidkeinu) ,זוה"ק (Zohar HaKadosh) ,צלותהון דצדיקיא (Tzlothon d'Tzadikaya) ,רבות קודשא (Revut Kudsha) ,האבות הקדושים (Ha'Avot HaKedoshim) ,ספה"ק (Seforim HaKedoshim) ,קדושת לוי (Kedushat Levi)

hebrew_text: באופן אחר יתבארו דברי המדרשים הנ"ל, בהקדם לבאר דברי רש"י שאמר יהודה וכי זו היא שימת עין שאמרת לשום עינך עליו, והקשה הרמב"ן ז"ל דאינה טענה כלל כי המושל שיצוה להביא אדם לפניו, לא יעשה על מנת לפטור אותו מן הרעות שיעשה, וכ"ש על הגניבה שיגנוב מבית המלך וכו' עיי"ש ובמד"ר איתא שאמר יהודה וכי זו היא השמת עין נהפך הדבר שאמרת לסמיות עינים, וצ"ב הכוונה.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Another way to explain the words of the aforementioned Midrashim is by first explaining Rashi's commentary where he says that Yehudah asked "Is this the 'setting of eyes' that you spoke of when you said you would set your eyes upon him?" The Ramban z"l questioned this, arguing that this is not a valid claim at all, because when a ruler commands someone to be brought before him, it is not done with the intention of protecting him from harm that he might do, and certainly not regarding theft that he might steal from the king's house, etc. See there. And in the Midrash Rabbah it states that Yehudah said "Is this the 'setting of eyes' - the matter has been reversed to become a 'blinding of eyes'?" This requires explanation of its meaning.

Note: I've preserved Hebrew terms like "Midrashim," "z"l" (of blessed memory), and maintained the reference to traditional Jewish sources like Rashi, Ramban, and Midrash Rabbah. The text discusses the biblical narrative of Yehudah confronting Yosef regarding Binyamin, specifically addressing the concept of "setting eyes upon" someone.
summary: This passage discusses an interaction between Yehuda and the Egyptian ruler (Joseph, though his identity was still concealed), focusing on the concept of "שימת עין" (watching over/supervision). The text analyzes a dispute between Rashi and Ramban regarding Yehuda's complaint about how Benjamin was treated, with Rashi suggesting Yehuda questioned whether this was the proper "watching over" that was promised, while Ramban challenges this interpretation. The Midrash adds another layer by suggesting that Yehuda claimed the "watching over" had transformed into "blindness" (סמיות עינים), implying that what was meant to be protective supervision had instead become harmful oversight. This passage explores the deeper theological tension between divine providence (השגחה) and apparent misfortune, questioning how protective oversight can sometimes appear to transform into its opposite.
keywords: מדרש (Midrash) ,רש"י (Rashi) ,עין (Ayin) ,מושל (Moshel) ,רמב"ן (Ramban) ,סמיות עינים (Smiyut Einayim) ,השמת עין (Hasamat Ayin) ,מלך (Melech) ,מד"ר (Midrash Rabbah) ,דברי (Divrei)

hebrew_text: ב) הקשו המפרשים מדוע מתחלה נתרצו שיהיו כולם עבדים אליו והצדיקו עליהם את הדין ועכשיו שנתחסד עמהם ואמר חלילה לי מעשות זאת וגו', ואתם עלו לשלו' וגו', אז ניגש יהודה לדבר אתו קשות.
translation:
Here's the translation:

"The commentators asked: Why did they initially agree to all become his slaves and accepted the judgment upon themselves, but now that he [Joseph] showed kindness to them and said 'Far be it from me to do this, etc.' and 'You go up in peace, etc.,' then Judah approached to speak harshly with him?"

Notes on terminology:
- "המפרשים" (HaMefarshim) refers to the traditional biblical commentators
- The text is discussing the interaction between Joseph and his brothers in Egypt, specifically the moment after Benjamin was found with the silver goblet
- "הצדיקו עליהם את הדין" (Hitzdiku aleihem et hadin) is a concept meaning "they accepted the justice/judgment upon themselves"
- The phrase "חלילה לי" (Chalilah li) is a biblical expression meaning "far be it from me" or "God forbid"
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses an apparent contradiction in the biblical story of Joseph and his brothers. The key question raised is why the brothers initially accepted the judgment of being servants to Joseph when Benjamin was found with the goblet, but later, when Joseph showed mercy and said "Far be it from me to do this" and told them to go in peace, Judah approached him to speak harshly. The theological insight here centers on the relationship between divine judgment (din) and mercy (chesed), suggesting that sometimes when one accepts harsh judgment with humility, it can paradoxically lead to a situation where they must then stand firm and advocate for justice, even in the face of offered mercy.
keywords: חסד (Chesed) ,דין (Din) ,צדק (Tzedek) ,שלום (Shalom) ,תשובה (Teshuvah) ,גילוי (Gilui) ,מידות (Middot) ,התקרבות (Hitkarvut) ,תיקון (Tikkun) ,אחדות (Achdut)

hebrew_text: ג) במד"ר ואתם עלו לשלו' אל אביכם אמרין לי' השלו' דכולי' נשפה (פי' היפ"ת ענין חשך כמו נשף שבמקרא, כלומר זה הוא שלו' של חשך ואפלה) ורוה"ק צווחת שלו' רב לאוהבי תורתך, פי' היפ"ת כדי שלא לסיים הפרשה בדבר רע נקט המדרש האי קרא. אבל פירושו קשה, דאילו כן הול"ל כתיב שלו' רב לאוהבי תורתך, ומדאמר ורוה"ק צווחת וכו' מבואר דאירע מילתא כך, וצ"ב מה היתה הרוה"ק מבשרת להם, דבאמת לא היתה עלי' זו של שלו' אלא צער להם ולאביהם, וצ"ב.
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving the Hebrew/Aramaic terminology:

In Midrash Rabbah [it states]: "And you go up in peace to your father." They said to him, "The peace of all is darkened" (the Yefat To'ar explains this as referring to darkness, like "neshef" in Scripture, meaning this is a peace of darkness and gloom), and the Ruach HaKodesh [Divine Spirit] cries out "Great peace have they who love Your Torah."

The Yefat To'ar explains that the Midrash cited this verse so as not to end the parsha with something negative. However, this explanation is difficult, because if that were the case, it should have simply stated "it is written 'Great peace have they who love Your Torah.'" From the fact that it says "and the Ruach HaKodesh cries out," it's clear that something actually occurred this way.

This requires explanation: What was the Ruach HaKodesh announcing to them? For in truth, this ascent of "peace" was actually nothing but pain for them and their father. This requires further examination.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the complex nature of peace (shalom) in the context of the brothers' return to their father Jacob after selling Joseph. The text explores a seeming contradiction: while the brothers speak of "peace" in returning to their father, the Midrash characterizes this as a dark or shadowy peace (נשפה). The key theological tension centers on how the Holy Spirit (רוח הקודש) proclaims "abundant peace to those who love Your Torah," even in this moment of apparent darkness and family strife. The passage questions the nature of this divine proclamation, noting that this ascent to their father wasn't truly peaceful but rather brought pain to both the brothers and their father, highlighting the complex interplay between divine messaging and human experience.
keywords: רוה"ק (Ruach HaKodesh) ,שלום (Shalom) ,תורתך (Toratecha) ,אפלה (Afeilah) ,נשף (Neshef) ,מדרש (Midrash) ,פרשה (Parasha) ,צווחת (Tzovachat) ,מילתא (Milta) ,מבשרת (Mevasseret)

hebrew_text: ונבוא אל הביאור בהקדם מ"ש בספה"ק מאור ושמש עה"פ והנה עיניכם רואות כי פי המדבר, פרש"י בלשון הקודש. וכבר טענו ע"ז גאוני קדמאי ובררו בראיות שגם במצרים יכלו לדבר בלה"ק, וא"כ איך יהיה מזה ראיה על האחו', גם איך יצדק לשון ראי' בדבר הנשמע, והול"ל והנה אזניכם שומעות, ועוד כמה דקדוקים בענין. ותו"ד לתרץ, דידוע וראיתי כן מצדיקים גדולים, שבהיותם מדבקים עצמם בעולמות עליונים, והמה מופשטים ממלבושי גופניות, והשכינה שורה עליהם ומדברת מתוך גרונם, פיהם מדבר נביאות ועתידות, ואותם הצדיקים עצמם אינם יודעים אח"כ מה שהיו אומרים וכו', וכמו כן יוסף היה מדבר עתידות והשכינה היתה מדברת מתוך גרונו וכו', וזהו ראיה שאני אחיכם וכו' ושייך שפיר לשון ראי' שראו בחי' זו אצלו עיי"ש לדרכו. ומדוייק הלשון כי פי המדבר, ר"ל שלא הוא היה המדבר אלא פיו ע"י שהשכינה היתה מדברת מגרונו, ועד"ז כתב הבאר מים חיים בפ' האזינו בשם המפרשים משאמז"ל (יומא ס"ו) כשהיו שומעין את השם הנכבד והנורא מפורש שהוא יוצא מפי כהן גדול וכו', שהיה יוצא מעצמו מפי כהן גדול על ידי השכינה המדברת מגרונו עיי"ש.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Let us begin the explanation by first citing what is written in the holy sefer Maor VaShemesh on the verse "Behold, your eyes see that it is my mouth that speaks" [to you], which Rashi explains as "[speaking] in the holy tongue (lashon hakodesh)." The early great scholars have already questioned this and clarified with proofs that they were also able to speak in lashon hakodesh in Egypt, so how could this serve as proof of brotherhood? Also, how is the term "seeing" appropriate for something that is heard - it should have said "behold, your ears hear." There are several other precise points to consider in this matter.

The essence of the answer is based on what is known, and I have seen this from great tzaddikim, that when they connect themselves to the upper worlds and become detached from physical garments, the Shechinah (Divine Presence) rests upon them and speaks through their throat. Their mouth speaks prophecies and future events, and these tzaddikim themselves don't even know afterwards what they had said, etc. Similarly, Yosef spoke of future events and the Shechinah was speaking through his throat, etc. This was the proof that "I am your brother," etc. The term "seeing" is indeed appropriate as they saw this spiritual level in him.

The language "for my mouth that speaks" is precise, meaning that it wasn't he who was speaking but rather his mouth through the Shechinah speaking from his throat. Similarly, the Be'er Mayim Chaim writes in Parshat Ha'azinu, citing the commentators on the Talmudic statement (Yoma 66) that when they would hear the honored and awesome Name explicitly coming from the mouth of the Kohen Gadol, etc., it would emerge on its own from the mouth of the Kohen Gadol through the Shechinah speaking from his throat.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a profound concept regarding divine speech and prophecy, centered on the verse about Joseph speaking to his brothers in Egypt. The key insight is that when great tzaddikim (righteous individuals) achieve an elevated spiritual state where they connect to higher worlds, the Divine Presence (Shechinah) speaks through their throat, causing them to pronounce prophecies and future events without their own conscious awareness. This phenomenon is compared to the High Priest in the Temple when pronouncing the Divine Name, where the Shechinah would speak through him, and similarly with Joseph, whose ability to speak in the Holy Tongue (Lashon Hakodesh) and prophesy was evidence of divine presence speaking through him rather than his own speech. This teaching illuminates a deep Hasidic understanding of how divine communication can manifest through completely devoted vessels who have transcended their physical limitations.
keywords: שכינה (Shechina) ,לשון הקודש (Lashon HaKodesh) ,נביאות (Nevuot) ,עולמות עליונים (Olamot Elyonim) ,צדיקים (Tzaddikim) ,השם הנכבד והנורא (HaShem HaNichbad V'HaNora) ,מלבושי גופניות (Malbushei Gufniut) ,ספה"ק (Seforim HaKedoshim) ,גאוני קדמאי (Geonei Kadmai) ,כהן גדול (Kohen Gadol)

hebrew_text: ואפשר להוסיף על דברי קדשו בהקדם מ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל וז"ל: יש לתמוה אחר שעמד יוסף במצרים ימים רבים, והיה פקיד ונגיד בבית שר גדול במצרים. איך לא שלח מכתב לאביו להודיעו ולנחמו, כי מצרים קרוב לחברון כששה ימים, ואלו היה מהלך שנה היה ראוי להודיעו לכבוד אביו, ותירץ הרמב"ן ז"ל שעשה כל זה כדי שיסתבב הדבר שיבואו כולם למצרים ויתקיימו חלומותיו. והכלי יקר לא ניחא ליה בתירוצו של הרמב"ן ז"ל. והקשה דאם ירצה ד' בקיום חלומותיו המה יתקיימו מעצמם ויוסף מה פעל. ופי' הוא ז"ל דמה שלא גילה לאביו כי הוא חי, לפי שחשב אם הקב"ה לא גילה לו. א"כ רצה הקב"ה בצערו כ"ב שנה מדה כנגד מדה, ואיך יגלה הוא מה שכיסה הקב"ה, והשיג בשכלו שנגזרה על אביו צער כ"ב שנה בשביל שלא קיים כבוד אביו, ואחר שנשלמו אז נתוודע יוסף אל אחיו, וכן מה שציער את אחיו עשה כ"ז למרק עונם במה שמכרו אחיהם עכת"ד ז"ל. ובאמת צדקו שניהם יחדיו והיתה סיבה מן השמים שלא הודיע יוסף לאביו כדי שיסתבב הדבר ויחדו למצרים ויתקיימו חלומותיו כטעם שכתב הרמב"ן ז"ל, ולא יקשה קושית הכלי יקר דלא הוה צריך יוסף לעשות פעולה לזה לצער את אביו, כי אם ירצה ד' בקיומם בלאו הכי יתקיימו כנ"ל, אולם א"צ לומר שהתכוון יוסף לזה, אלא לפי שהי' סיבה מן השמים ורצון הבוי"ת כן, ויוסף הצדיק בגודל צדקתו הרגישו איבריו מה שהוא רצון הבוי"ת, ולא היה מדבר דיבורים כ"א מה שנשלחו לו מן השמים ושכינה מדברת מתוך גרונו כבחי' שכתב המאור ושמש ז"ל, וע"כ לא הודיע לאביו כי לא היה רצון הבוי"ת בזה. הן לטעם שכתב הרמב"ן ז"ל כדי שיתקיים החלום, והן לטעם הכלי יקר ז"ל כנ"ל. וע"ד שכתבו בספרים הק' אצל אברהם אבינו ע"ה שהיו איבריו מושכים אותו למה שהוא רצון הבוי"ת, ומונעים אותו ממה שהוא נגד רצונו יתברך, ופי' בזה אל תשלח ידך אל הנער, עיין בדברינו במקו"א.

One can add to his holy words by first considering what the Ramban z"l wrote: "One must wonder, after Yosef remained in Egypt for many days and was an officer and ruler in the house of a great Egyptian minister, how did he not send a letter to his father to inform him and comfort him? Egypt was only about six days' journey from Chevron, and even if it were a year's journey, he should have informed him out of respect for his father."

The Ramban z"l answered that he did all this so that events would unfold in such a way that they would all come to Egypt and his dreams would be fulfilled. However, the Kli Yakar was not satisfied with the Ramban's answer. He questioned that if Hashem wanted the dreams to be fulfilled, they would be fulfilled on their own - what did Yosef need to do?

The Kli Yakar explained that Yosef didn't reveal to his father that he was alive because he reasoned: if HaKadosh Baruch Hu didn't reveal it, then clearly Hashem wanted his father to suffer for 22 years as a measure-for-measure punishment. How could he reveal what Hashem had concealed? He understood that his father was decreed to suffer for 22 years because he hadn't fulfilled the mitzvah of honoring his own father. Only after this period was complete did Yosef reveal himself to his brothers. Similarly, the suffering he caused his brothers was to cleanse them of their sin of selling their brother.

In truth, both explanations are correct. It was ordained from Heaven that Yosef shouldn't inform his father so that events would unfold leading them to Egypt and fulfilling his dreams, as the Ramban wrote. The Kli Yakar's question isn't difficult - that Yosef didn't need to take action and cause his father pain, since if Hashem wanted the dreams fulfilled, they would be fulfilled anyway. Rather, we don't need to say Yosef intended this; it was Heaven's cause and the will of the Blessed Creator. Yosef HaTzaddik, in his great righteousness, felt in his limbs what was Hashem's will, and he only spoke words that were sent to him from Heaven, with the Shechinah speaking through his throat, as explained by the Maor VaShemesh z"l. Therefore, he didn't inform his father as it wasn't Hashem's will - both for the Ramban's reason (to fulfill the dreams) and the Kli Yakar's reason.

This is similar to what is written in holy books about Avraham Avinu a"h, that his limbs drew him toward Hashem's will and prevented him from what was against His will, explaining the verse "Do not send forth your hand to the lad," as we've discussed elsewhere.
summary: This passage discusses a fundamental debate between the Ramban and the Kli Yakar regarding why Joseph didn't contact his father Jacob during his years in Egypt. The text synthesizes their views through a Hasidic lens, suggesting that both interpretations are valid because Joseph, in his great righteousness (tzidkut), was so attuned to divine will that his very limbs naturally responded to God's intentions - similar to Abraham, whose body instinctively moved toward or away from actions based on God's will. The passage introduces the profound Hasidic concept that true tzadikim (righteous individuals) operate on such a heightened spiritual level that their physical actions become naturally aligned with divine will, with the Shechinah (divine presence) speaking through them. This represents a deep theological understanding of how human free will can align perfectly with divine providence through spiritual elevation.
keywords: שכינה (Shechina) ,רצון הבוי"ת (Ratzon HaBorei Yitbarach) ,מן השמים (Min HaShamayim) ,צדקתו (Tzidkuto) ,מדה כנגד מדה (Midah Keneged Midah) ,מאור ושמש (Maor VaShemesh) ,ספרים הק' (Sefarim HaKedoshim) ,כלי יקר (Kli Yakar) ,דברי קדשו (Divrei Kodsho) ,נשלחו לו מן השמים (Nishlechu Lo Min HaShamayim)

hebrew_text: וכמו"כ מה שציער את אחיו בעלילת מרגלים ובעלילת הגביע היתה סיבה מן השמים למרק עונם כטעם שכתב הכלי יקר אבל א"צ לומר שהתכוין יוסף לזה, דלאו אדידי' רמיא לצערם, אלא לפי שהיתה רצון הבוי"ת בזה הושמו בפיו הקדוש דיבורים אלו, והיה כ"ז דברי נביאות ורוה"ק, וכבר פירשנו בדברינו במקו"א דכל אלו הטענות והעלילות המה ענינים גבוהים ורומזים על דורות ישראל העתידים, כי לא בחינם האריך התוה"ק בסיפור עלילת המרגלים וגניבת הגביע וכדומה אשר קשה להבינם עפ"י פשוטן, אלא שכ"ז נרמז בהם ענינים גבוהים ונבואה על העתיד, ורוה"ק היתה מדברת מגרונו בדברו דיבורים האלו, אלא שלפי שעה הבינו השבעים הדיבורים ההם כפשוטן, ולא הבינו העמקות והסוד דגניז בגוי', והי' סיבה מן השמים כן, כדי למרק עונם כמ"ש הכלי יקר ז"ל.

Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Similarly, how he caused pain to his brothers through the spying accusation and the goblet incident was ordained from Heaven to cleanse their sin, as explained by the Kli Yakar. However, we need not say that Yosef intended this, as it was not his responsibility to cause them pain. Rather, because this was the will of the Blessed Creator, these words were placed in his holy mouth, and all of this was prophetic speech and Ruach HaKodesh (Divine inspiration).

We have already explained elsewhere in our writings that all these claims and accusations are lofty matters that allude to future generations of Israel. For the Torah did not needlessly elaborate on the story of the spying accusation and the stealing of the goblet and similar incidents, which are difficult to understand according to their simple meaning. Rather, all of these hint at lofty matters and prophecy about the future, and Ruach HaKodesh was speaking through his throat when he spoke these words.

However, at that time, the tribes understood these words only in their simple meaning and did not understand the depths and the secret hidden within them. This was ordained from Heaven in order to cleanse their sin, as written by the Kli Yakar, of blessed memory.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the deeper spiritual significance of Joseph's actions toward his brothers (the spy accusation and the goblet incident). The key insight is that while Joseph himself may not have consciously intended to cause his brothers suffering, his words and actions were divinely inspired and contained prophetic significance beyond their simple meaning. The text emphasizes that these episodes in the Torah aren't merely historical narratives but contain profound allusions to future generations of Israel, with Joseph speaking with divine inspiration (ruach hakodesh). The suffering experienced by the brothers served as a heavenly-ordained atonement for their sins, though this deeper purpose was hidden from them at the time, as they only understood the events at their simple level.
keywords: רוה"ק (Ruach HaKodesh) ,מן השמים (Min HaShamayim) ,תוה"ק (Torah HaKedosha) ,דברי נביאות (Divrei Nevuot) ,ענינים גבוהים (Inyanim Gevohim) ,הבוי"ת (HaBorei Yitbarach) ,סוד (Sod) ,דגניז בגוי' (D'Ganiz B'Gavei) ,העמקות (Ha'Amkut) ,כלי יקר (Kli Yakar)

hebrew_text: ומעתה בהתודע אל אחיו ואמר להם אני יוסף העוד אבי חי וגו'. הנה היה מקום לאחיו שיתמהו עליו ויפקפקו בהאמנת דבריו, דאלו הי' האמת כדבריו איך יתכן שסבל כ"כ שנים צער אביו ולא הודיעו, אחרי שהיה סיפק בידו להודיעו שהיה מלך ומושל ומי יאמר לו מה תעשה, גם איך לא הרגיש באהבת האחו' עד הנה וציער אותם בכל מיני עלילות של חינם, ע"כ הצטדק עצמו לפניהם וא"ל עיניכם הרואות כי פי המדבר אליכם, וכבחי' שכתב המאור ושמש ז"ל, שאתם רואים שאיני מדבר אלא דיבורים שנשלחו לי מן השמים. ולא אני המדבר אלא פי מדבר ברצון הבוי"ת ע"י ששכינה מדברת מגרוני, ומעתה אל תתמהו על כ"ז, כי היה רצון הבוי"ת וסיבה מן השמים, והושמו בפי ברוה"ק כל אלה הדיבורים, ומה שלא היה רצון הבוי"ת לא דברתי. וע"כ לא הודעתי לאבי, וקבלו השבטים דבריו שראו אמיתתם כי בהתודע אל אחיו נתגלה להם פנימיותו ומדריגתו מה שהיה נסתר ומכוסה מהם במשך כל הזמן עד עכשיו.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Now when he made himself known to his brothers and said to them "I am Yosef, is my father still alive, etc." His brothers could have been puzzled and doubted the truthfulness of his words, for if his words were true, how could he have endured his father's pain for so many years without informing him, especially since he had the ability to do so as he was king and ruler, and who could question his actions? Also, how did he not feel brotherly love until now and caused them distress with all kinds of baseless accusations?

Therefore, he justified himself before them saying "Your eyes see that it is my mouth speaking to you," as explained by the Maor VaShemesh, that "you see that I speak only words that were sent to me from Heaven. It is not I who speaks, but rather my mouth speaks with the will of the Blessed Creator (Borei Yisbarach) through the Shechinah (Divine Presence) speaking from my throat. Therefore, do not be puzzled by all this, as it was the will of the Blessed Creator and a cause from Heaven, and all these words were placed in my mouth through Ruach HaKodesh (Divine Spirit), and what was not the will of the Blessed Creator, I did not speak. This is why I did not inform my father."

The tribes (brothers) accepted his words as they saw their truth, for when he revealed himself to his brothers, his inner essence and spiritual level were revealed to them, which had been hidden and concealed from them throughout all this time until now.
summary: This passage discusses the moment when Joseph reveals himself to his brothers and addresses potential questions about his behavior. The key theological insight is that Joseph explains his actions were not his own, but rather divinely orchestrated - "the words were sent to me from Heaven" and "the Divine Presence speaks through my throat." The text emphasizes that Joseph's seemingly harsh treatment of his brothers and his silence towards his father were not personal choices, but rather part of God's plan, with Joseph serving as a vessel for divine will. This reveals a deep Hasidic concept that what appears as human action may actually be direct divine orchestration, and when Joseph finally revealed himself, his brothers were able to see his true spiritual level that had been hidden from them until that moment.

hebrew_text: ובזה יתבאר מאמר הכתוב ויכר יוסף את אחיו והם לא הכירוהו, ורז"ל אמרו בב"ר (פ' צ"א) לפי שיצא מאצלם בלא חתימת זקן ועכשיו מצאוהו בחתימת זקן, והאוהחה"ק נתקשה בטעם זה. כי מטבע אנושי כשתולד הידיעה בלב אחד מהשנים, גם בלב השני יתעורר בחינת הזכרון, כי הלבבות יגידו סודות נעלמים. כאומרם כמים הפנים לפנים כן לב אדם לאדם, וידקדקו בעינים כמנה ובשרטוטי הפנים ובדיבור ובטביעת עינא דקלא, והידיעה הולכת וגדלה עד שישלים הבחון, אעפ"כ מודיע הכתוב שהם לא הכירוהו והטעם לצד ראותו ברום המעלות החליטו הבחינה והרחיקו מלבם מחשוב בדבר הזה עכת"ד ז"ל. והרמב"ן ז"ל חתר למצוא טעם על מה שלא הכירוהו, ופי' לפי שהתנכר אליהם ששם המצנפת על מצחו וקצת הפנים ושינה עצמו וכו', או לפי שהתנכר להם בדבריו שדיבר להם קשות ואמר להם בכעס וכו' ורש"י פי' ויתנכר אליהם נעשה להם כנכרי לדבר קשות, ופי' הרא"ם שהראה עצמו נכרי. אמנם כל זה איננו שוה ולא יספיק לגבי קדושי עליונים שבטי ד', שבלא ספק היה להם להרגיש בחי' נפשו הפנימיות של יוסף ובחינת הקדושה שבו, כי מטבע הקדושה להימשך אחר מינו. ומכל שכן שהיה השראת השכינה אצלו כמשה"כ וירא אדוניו כי ד' אתו, והשכינה מדברת מתוך גרונו כמ"ש המאור ושמש זלל"ה. ואיך לא הרגישו הם בכל זה ומאי טעמא לא הכירוהו.

This explains the verse "Joseph recognized his brothers, but they did not recognize him." Our Sages said in Bereishit Rabbah (Chapter 91) that this was because he left them without a beard, and now they found him with a beard. The Holy Ohr HaChaim questioned this explanation, saying that it is human nature that when recognition awakens in the heart of one of two people, it also awakens a sense of memory in the heart of the other, for hearts reveal hidden secrets. As they say, "As water reflects face to face, so does the heart of man to man," and they examine the eyes carefully, facial features, speech, and voice recognition. The recognition grows until identification is complete. Nevertheless, the verse tells us they did not recognize him, and the reason was that seeing him in such an elevated position, they dismissed the possibility and removed such thoughts from their hearts.

The Ramban sought to find a reason why they didn't recognize him, explaining that he disguised himself by placing a turban on his forehead and part of his face and changed himself, etc. Or because he made himself strange to them through his words, speaking harshly to them and addressing them with anger. Rashi explains "vayitnaker" (he made himself strange) to mean he acted like a stranger by speaking harshly, and the Re'em explains that he made himself appear as a stranger.

However, all these explanations are insufficient regarding the holy supreme tribes of God, who undoubtedly should have sensed Joseph's inner soul nature and his level of kedushah (holiness), for it is the nature of holiness to be drawn to its own kind. All the more so since the Divine Presence resided with him, as it is written "his master saw that Hashem was with him," and the Shechinah (Divine Presence) spoke through his throat, as the Maor VaShemesh writes. How then did they not sense all this, and what is the reason they did not recognize him?
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the puzzling biblical account of Joseph recognizing his brothers while they failed to recognize him. The text explores various traditional explanations (from the Midrash, Ohr HaChaim, and Ramban) but suggests these are insufficient given the brothers' spiritual stature as the "holy tribes." The core theological insight is that the brothers, being on such a high spiritual level, should have been able to sense Joseph's inner holiness and Divine presence (Shechinah) that dwelt with him, as "holiness naturally draws to its own kind." The passage ultimately points to a deeper mystery of why these spiritually elevated brothers were unable to recognize Joseph despite his evident spiritual qualities, suggesting there may have been a Divine purpose in this temporary spiritual blindness.
keywords: השראת השכינה (Hashra'at HaShechina) ,קדושי עליונים (Kedoshei Elyonim) ,בחינת הקדושה (Bechinat HaKedusha) ,נפשו הפנימיות (Nafsho HaPnimiyut) ,שבטי ד' (Shivtei Hashem) ,טביעת עינא (Teviat Eina) ,סודות נעלמים (Sodot Ne'elamim) ,רום המעלות (Rom HaMa'alot) ,הלבבות (HaLevavot) ,בחינת הזכרון (Bechinat HaZikaron)

hebrew_text: אמנם יובן עפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל, דלפי שהיה רצון הבוי"ת כן שלא יכירוהו, הן לטעם הרמב"ן ז"ל כדי שיתקיימו החלומות ויסתבב עי"ז ירידתן למצרים, והן לטעם שכתב הכלי יקר ז"ל, ועוד טעמים הכמוסים ונעלמים מאתנו, ע"כ היתה סיבה מאת ד' שירחקו מלבם מחשוב בדבר זה, ונסתר מהם פנימיות בחי' נפשו ובחי' הקדושה והשראת שכינה השורה אתו, גם נעלמה מהם מלהשיג פנימיות הדיבורים שדיבר יוסף אליהם, האמנם שכל דיבוריו אליהם הי' ברוה"ק ונבואה על לעתיד, והם דיבורים קדושים וגבוהים עד אין חקר, אבל לפי שהי' רצון הבוי"ת להעלים מהם בחי' ההכרה והבחנה, ע"כ נשלחו בפיו מן השמים דיבורים מלובש בכמה לבושין. וטמיר ומכוסה וסתום ונעלם כל בחי' הפנימיות שבהם, ונוסף ע"ז היתה סיבה מהשי"ת שלא ישימו על לבם לחקור בפנימיות הדיבורים, אלא קבלו הדברים כפשוטן, והחליטו הבחינה והרחיקו מלבם מחשוב ומלהסתפק בדבר.
translation:
Here is the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

However, it can be understood according to our aforementioned approach: It was the will of the Blessed Creator that they should not recognize him [Joseph], whether for the reason given by the Ramban z"l - so that the dreams would be fulfilled and thereby cause their descent to Egypt, or for the reason written by the Kli Yakar z"l, and for other reasons hidden and concealed from us. Therefore, it was caused by Hashem that they should distance from their hearts any thought about this matter, and the inner aspects of his soul's qualities and the qualities of holiness and the Divine Presence (Shechina) that rested with him were concealed from them. Also hidden from them was the ability to grasp the inner meaning of the words that Joseph spoke to them, even though all his words to them were with Ruach HaKodesh (Divine inspiration) and prophecy about the future, and they were holy and elevated words beyond investigation. But since it was the will of the Blessed Creator to conceal from them the quality of recognition and discernment, therefore words were sent from Heaven through his mouth clothed in many garments [layers of meaning], and the inner aspects within them were hidden, covered, sealed and concealed. Additionally, it was caused by Hashem that they should not take to heart to investigate the inner meanings of the words, but rather they accepted the words at their simple meaning, and they concluded their assessment and distanced from their hearts any thought or doubt about the matter.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the divine purpose behind the brothers' inability to recognize Joseph in Egypt. The text explains that it was God's will (ratzon Hashem) that they should not recognize him, both for the reason given by the Ramban (to fulfill the dreams and facilitate the descent to Egypt) and for the reason given by the Kli Yakar, along with other hidden reasons. The passage emphasizes that God deliberately concealed Joseph's spiritual essence, the Divine Presence (Shechina) that dwelt with him, and the deeper prophetic meaning of his words, causing his brothers to understand his speech only at its simple level rather than its profound spiritual dimension. This divine concealment was orchestrated through "many garments" (levushin) that cloaked the true spiritual nature of Joseph's communications, preventing the brothers from investigating or questioning matters too deeply.

hebrew_text: ובזה יבואר דברי המדרש הנ"ל שאמר יהודה וכי זו היא השמת עין נהפך הדבר שאמרת לסמיות עינים, דאיתא בב"ר (פר' צ"ג) שאמר יהודה תדע שבעלילה אתה בא עלינו מתחילה, כמה מדינות ירדו לכאן ליקח אוכל. כלום שאלת להם כמו ששאלת לנו שמא בתך היינו מבקש או אחותינו אתה מבקש, ואעפ"כ ונאמר אל אדוני וגו' ולא כחדנו דבר, ולכאורה צ"ב בפשטות איך לא עמדו על דעתו מתחילה כי בעלילה הוא בא עליהם. ואיך לא ראו ההשתנות וההבדל שעשה עמהם מכל עמי הארצות שבאו לפניו, ומדוע הגידו לו כל עניניהם ולא כחדו ממנו דבר, אמנם כ"ז היתה גזירה מן השמים שלא יעמדו באמיתת העלילה, ויביאו את בנימין ויסתבב ענין ירידתן למצרים. וע"כ היתה סיבה מאת ד' שנאמרו אליהם דיבוריו של יוסף בדרך סמיות עינים, עד שלא שמו לבם על המחקר לעמוד על אמיתותן, ולא היה בדרך הטבע אלא סיבה מאת ד' ומלובש בטבע ועכשיו שניגש יהודה לדבר קשות אל יוסף, הגם שלא השיגו עדיין אמיתת הדברים ולא נתגלה להם פנימיותן עד שנתודע יוסף אליהם, אבל זאת השיגו שכל דיבוריו היו בבחי' סמיות עינים: שאילולי כן לא יצוייר בטבע שילכדו ויאמינו לכל דבריו ולא יסתפקו בהם. עד שהגידו לו כל מה ששאל אותם ולא כיחדו דבר, וז"ש במדרש הנ"ל שאמר יהודה וכי זו היא שימת העין שאמרת, ומתחלה לא הי' דעתך לכך. נהפך הדבר ונתברר שכל זה היה סמיות עינים ומעתה ל"ק קושית הרמב"ן ז"ל (קושיא ג') דאין זו טענה לפטור אחרי שנחשד על הגניבה, ולדרכנו לא היתה טענתו של יהודה ע"ז, אלא כל תרעומתו היתה שמתחילה בעלילה באת, ושאמרת ואשימה עיני עליו לא היתה דעתך לכך אלא סמיות עינים הי' להכין עלילה עלינו. וכמו כן עכשיו בעלילת הגביע כן הדבר, וזה עיקר טענתו עליו שכל דיבוריו נאמרו אליהם בדרך סמיות עינים, ובאמת כן היה אלא שהיתה סיבה מהשי"ת ונעלמה מהם השגה זו, כנ"ל.

This explains the words of the aforementioned Midrash where Yehudah said, "Is this what you meant by 'setting your eyes'? The matter has been reversed - what you said was actually [meant for] blinding our eyes." For it states in Bereishit Rabbah (Chapter 93) that Yehudah said, "Know that you came upon us with a false pretense from the beginning. How many provinces came down here to buy food? Did you ask any of them what you asked us? Were you perhaps seeking your daughter or your sister from us? Nevertheless, 'we said to my master,' etc., and we concealed nothing."

At first glance, we need to understand why they didn't realize from the beginning that he was coming upon them with a false pretense. How did they not see the difference and distinction he made with them compared to all other peoples who came before him? And why did they tell him all their affairs and conceal nothing from him?

However, all this was a decree from Heaven that they should not understand the true nature of the pretense, so that they would bring Binyamin and the matter of their descent to Egypt would unfold. Therefore, it was caused by Hashem that Yosef's words were spoken to them in a way that blinded their eyes, so that they wouldn't investigate to understand their true meaning. This was not natural but rather a divine cause clothed in nature.

Now when Yehudah approached to speak harshly to Yosef, even though they still hadn't grasped the truth of the matters and their inner meaning wasn't revealed until Yosef made himself known to them, they did realize that all his words were in the nature of "blinding of the eyes." For otherwise, it would be unnatural that they would be caught and believe all his words without doubting them, to the point that they told him everything he asked and concealed nothing.

This is what the Midrash means when it says that Yehudah said, "Is this what you meant by 'setting your eyes'? Initially, this wasn't your intention. The matter has been reversed and it's become clear that all this was a blinding of the eyes."

This now resolves the Ramban's question (the third question) that this isn't a valid argument for exemption after being suspected of theft. According to our approach, Yehudah's argument wasn't about this at all, but rather his entire complaint was that "from the beginning you came with a false pretense, and when you said 'I will set my eyes upon him,' that wasn't your real intention - it was [meant for] blinding our eyes to prepare a false pretense against us." Similarly now with the goblet incident, the same applies. This was his main argument - that all his words were spoken to them in a way that blinded their eyes. And indeed this was true, but it was caused by Hashem, and this understanding was hidden from them, as mentioned above.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the interaction between Yehudah and Yosef, focusing on the concept of "smiyas einayim" (spiritual blindness). The key theological insight is that the brothers' inability to recognize Yosef and their willingness to reveal all their family details to him was not merely a natural occurrence, but rather a divinely orchestrated plan. The text explains that Hashem deliberately created this state of "spiritual blindness" to ensure the fulfillment of His greater plan of bringing the family down to Egypt. The passage particularly emphasizes how Yehudah eventually realized that all of Yosef's interactions with them were characterized by this divinely-imposed "smiyas einayim," though he still didn't understand the full picture until Yosef revealed himself.

hebrew_text: ויבואר דברי המדרש הנ"ל (בדרוש הקודם) ויגש אליו יהודה רי"א הגשה למלחמה ר' נחמי' אומר הגשה לפיוס וכו' רבנן אמרי הגשה לתפלה ואלו ואלו דא"ח, שהיו כלולים בדבריו כל אלו הבחינות, וע"ד שפירשנו בדיבוריו של יוסף שמלבד הבנה הפשוטה שבהם, פנימיות הדיבורים היה בהם רמז ורמיזא לדברים גבוהים ונעלמים. וכמו"כ היו דיבוריו של יהודה, וע"ד שכתב בספה"ק נוע"א זלל"ה בפרשת וישלח) עה"פ כה תאמרון לאדוני לעשו עם לבן גרתי וגו'. ודקדק ז"ל דלמה לו ליעקב לאמר בביתו בדברו עם המלאכים להזכיר ולקראו לעשו אדוני, גם הלמד של לעשו אין לו שחר, וכך הי"ל לומר לאדוני עשו, וגם מה שפירש רש"י ז"ל עם לבן גרתי ותרי"ג מצות שמרתי, וכי בשביל זה ישא חן בעיניו וכו'. אך הענין הוא דדרך הצדיק בדברו עם אנשים. אזי הוא מדקדק בדבריו להשכיל, שיהיו דבריו נשמעים במשמעותיהן כפשוטן לאיש המדבר עמו, ועיקר תוכן דבר שמכוין באותן הדיבורים שיהיו תפלה ותחנונים לפני המקום ב"ה וב"ש, והכוונה בזה שמסתיר דבריו של תפלה בהדיבורים שמדבר עם האדם, ואינו מתפלל תפלתו הצורך לו בפירוש, הוא למען המקטרג שלא יבין כוונתו ולא יקטרג עליו וכו', וז"ש יעקב אל המלאכים כה תאמרון באופן זה ובכוונה זאת תאמרון כל דבריכם, לאדוני ר"ל שיהי' כוונתכם לאדון הכל הוא הבוי"ת ויתעלה, וגם דברים כפשוטן לעשו שיהיה דברי רצוי אליו, וז"ש כה אמר עבדך יעקב עם לבן גרתי וגו' ומשתמע לתרי אנפין שהוא דברי מליצה לפניו ית"ש ששמר תרי"ג מצות, וזכות זה יעמוד לו שינצל מעשו, וגם דברים כפשוטן דברי רצוי והכנעה לעשו שהייתי גר ולא נעשתי שר וחשוב כפרש"י, עיי"ש שפי' בדרך זה כל הפסוקים ויהי לי שור וגו' שמשמעותן וכוונתו לתרי אנפין. ומעתה יתפרש כמו"כ בדברי יהודה אל יוסף שאמר בי אדוני ידבר נא עבדך דבר באזני אדוני וגו', ובמה שהזכיר אדוני היתה תוכן כוונת דבריו תפלה ותחנונים לפני הבוי"ת ומלין לצד עילאה ימלל אלא שהסתיר והלביש בדיבוריו גם משמעות פשוטו שיהיה דברי רצוי ופיוס ודברים קשות ליוסף הנאמר אליו, וא"ש מ"ש ז"ל במדרש שהיה הגשה זו לפיוס ולמלחמה ליוסף כפי משמעותן הפשוט. והגשה לתפלה להבוי"ת כנ"ל.

The words of the Midrash mentioned above (in the previous drush) can be explained: "And Judah approached him" - Rabbi Yehuda says it was an approach for war, Rabbi Nechemia says it was an approach for appeasement, etc., and the Rabbis say it was an approach for prayer - and all these are the words of the living G-d. All these aspects were included in his words.

As we explained regarding Joseph's words, besides their simple meaning, the inner meaning of the words contained hints to lofty and hidden matters. Similarly were Judah's words, as written in the holy sefer Noam Elimelech (in Parshat Vayishlach) on the verse "Thus shall you say to my master, to Esau: 'I have sojourned with Laban, etc.'"

He [the Noam Elimelech] questioned why Jacob needed to mention and call Esau "my master" when speaking to the angels in his house. Also, the letter "lamed" in "l'Esau" (to Esau) seems unnecessary - he should have said "adoni Esau" (my master Esau). Furthermore, regarding Rashi's explanation that "I have sojourned with Laban" means "I kept the 613 mitzvot," would this really find favor in Esau's eyes?

Rather, the matter is that when a tzaddik speaks with people, he is precise in his words, ensuring that his words are heard in their simple meaning by the person he's speaking with, while the main content he intends with those words is prayer and supplication before HaKadosh Baruch Hu. The intention is to hide his words of prayer within the conversation he has with the person, and he doesn't explicitly state his needed prayer in order that the prosecutor (satan) won't understand his intention and won't prosecute him.

This is what Jacob said to the angels: "Thus shall you say" - in this manner and with this intention you should say all your words - "to my master," meaning your intention should be to the Master of All, the Blessed Creator, while also having a simple meaning for Esau that would be pleasing to him. This is why it says "Thus says your servant Jacob: 'I have sojourned with Laban,'" which can be understood in two ways: as words of advocacy before Hashem that he kept the 613 mitzvot, and this merit should protect him from Esau, and also in its simple meaning as words of appeasement and submission to Esau, that he was merely a stranger and didn't become important or powerful, as Rashi explains.

Similarly can be explained Judah's words to Joseph when he said "Please, my master, let your servant speak a word in my master's ears." When he mentioned "my master," the inner content of his words was prayer and supplication before the Creator, speaking words toward Above, but he concealed and clothed in his words also the simple meaning that would be words of appeasement and harsh words to Joseph. This explains well what our Sages said in the Midrash that this approach was for appeasement and for war with Joseph according to the simple meaning, and an approach of prayer to the Creator as mentioned above.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the multilayered meaning of Yehuda's approach to Yosef, based on the Midrash's three interpretations: for war, appeasement, and prayer. The key insight is that righteous individuals (tzaddikim) intentionally construct their speech with dual meanings - one level that is understood plainly by their human audience, and a deeper level that constitutes prayer to Hashem, deliberately concealed within the plain speech to avoid spiritual prosecution (kitrug). This concept is demonstrated through both Yaakov's message to Esav and Yehuda's words to Yosef, where phrases like "my master" (adoni) simultaneously addressed the human recipient while serving as concealed prayers to the true Master, Hashem. This teaching reveals a sophisticated Hasidic understanding of how the tzaddikim navigate both earthly and spiritual realms through carefully crafted speech that operates on multiple levels simultaneously.

hebrew_text: ומ"ש ר' נחמי' אין ויגש אלא קרבן יובן עפי"ד הפסיקתא רבתי (פ"ז) וכן הוא ברבה במדבר (פי"ג ס"ג) שפל רוח יתמך כבוד (משלי כ"ט) זה יהודה שהשפיל עצמו לפני יוסף בשביל בנימין. אמר הקב"ה אתה השפלת עצמך מפני אחיך הקטן הימך, חייך כשיוקם המשכן ויבואו השבטים להקריב, אין א' מהם מקריב ראשון לפניך, אלא חולקים לך כבוד ואתה הוא שתקריב ראשון שנאמר ויהי המקריב ביום הראשון למטה יהודה וגו', מבואר דע"י הגשה זו זכה לקרבן. ובזה יבואר הכוונה אין ויגש אלא קרבן, והבן.

Regarding what Rabbi Nechemiah said "there is no 'Vayigash' (and he approached) except [in relation to] sacrifice," this can be understood according to the words of the Pesikta Rabbati (Chapter 7), and similarly in Rabbah Bamidbar (Chapter 13:3): "He who is of humble spirit will obtain honor" (Proverbs 29) - this refers to Judah who humbled himself before Joseph for the sake of Benjamin. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: "You humbled yourself before your younger brother; by your life, when the Mishkan (Tabernacle) will be established and the tribes will come to offer sacrifices, none of them will offer before you, rather they will give honor to you, and you will be the one to offer first, as it is said 'And he that offered his offering on the first day was from the tribe of Judah, etc.'" It is explained that through this approach (hagasha), he merited the sacrifice. And with this, the intention of "there is no 'Vayigash' except [in relation to] sacrifice" is explained, understand this.

Note: I've preserved Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "Mishkan" and "hagasha" where they carry specific religious significance. The text connects Judah's humility in approaching Joseph to his tribe's later privilege of offering the first sacrifice at the dedication of the Tabernacle.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the connection between Yehuda's humility and his tribe's future privilege in the Mishkan (Tabernacle). It explains that when Yehuda approached (vayigash) Yosef and humbled himself for the sake of his younger brother Binyamin, Hashem rewarded this act of self-effacement by granting Yehuda's tribe the honor of being the first to bring sacrifices when the Mishkan was established. The text draws on the verse from Proverbs "The humble in spirit will retain honor" and connects the word "vayigash" (approaching) with the concept of korban (sacrifice), teaching that true spiritual elevation and the privilege of bringing offerings comes through genuine humility and self-nullification before others.

hebrew_text: ויובן דברי המדרש הנ"ל (קושיא ב') ויגש אליו יהודה וגו' תפוחי זהב במשכיות כסף דבר דבור על אופניו, מה אופן זה מראה פנים מכל צד, כך היו דבריו של יהודה נראים לכל צד בשעה שדיבר עם יוסף. ר"ל שנתלבש ונסתר הפנימיות שבדבריו. והמשילן לתפוחי זהב במשכיות כסף, שהזהב טמיר ומכוסה מעין רואה לרוב חשיבותו, כמו כן פנימיות דבריו של יהודה היו בהסתר ומכוסה מפני המקטרג, והיו בהם תפלה ותחנונים לפני הבוי"ת כבחי' שכתב הנועם אלימלך זלל"ה, וז"ש שהיו דבריו נראים לכל צד בשעה שדיבר עם יוסף, שהיו המשמעות נראה כפשוטו ליוסף המדבר אליו, ותוכן הדיבורים נראים ומכוונים דברי תפלה להבוי"ת כנ"ל.

The words of the aforementioned Midrash can be understood (addressing the second question): "And Judah approached him, etc." - "Like golden apples in silver settings, a word spoken in its proper way." Just as a wheel shows faces (aspects) from every side, so too were Judah's words visible from every angle when he spoke with Joseph. This means that the inner meaning of his words was clothed and concealed. They are compared to golden apples in silver settings, as gold is hidden and covered from the eye of the beholder due to its great importance. Similarly, the inner meaning of Judah's words was hidden and concealed from the prosecutor, and they contained prayer and supplications before the Blessed Creator (Borei Yitbarach), as explained by the Noam Elimelech of blessed memory. This is what is meant by "his words were visible from every side when he spoke with Joseph" - the apparent meaning was visible in its simple form to Joseph who was speaking with him, while the content of the words were also visible and directed as words of prayer to the Blessed Creator, as mentioned above.

Note: I've preserved Hebrew/Hasidic terms like "Borei Yitbarach" and "Noam Elimelech" as they appear in the original text, as these are specific religious and cultural references.
summary: This passage from Divrei Yoel discusses the Midrashic interpretation of Yehudah's approach to Yosef, comparing his words to "golden apples in silver settings." The key insight is that Yehudah's words operated on two simultaneous levels: the external level that appeared as a straightforward plea to Yosef, and a deeper, hidden spiritual level that contained prayers and supplications to Hashem. Drawing on the Noam Elimelech's teaching, the text explains that just as gold is concealed within silver due to its preciousness, so too Yehudah's true spiritual intentions were concealed from potential accusers while maintaining their dual effectiveness - both as communication with Yosef and as prayer to the Divine.

hebrew_text: ועתה נבוא לבאר המדרש הנ"ל עה"פ ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם (עיין לעיל קושיא ה') בהקדם מ"ש ברבינו בחיי עה"ת סו"פ מקץ וז"ל וע"ד הקבלה מה שנחתמה הפרשה ואתם עלו לשלו' אל אביכם, והיה יכול לומר לכו לשלו' לדרככם, אבל הפרשה מבוארת באחי יוסף לשעה, ורומזת לעשרה הרוגי מלכות לדורות אשר עלו לשלו' אל אביהם שבשמים, אחר שנתלבנו ונצרפו מחטא מכירת יוסף, עוד כתב שם בשם פרקי היכלות (מר"י כוה"ג) כי ר' חנינא בן תרדיון הוחלף בלופינס קיסר ולופינס הוא שנשרף וכו' וכמידה הזאת לכל חכמי ישראל עכ"ד פרקי היכלות. ושמעתי כשם שהוחלף יצחק באיל, והוקבע לו שכר כאלו הוקרב וכאלו עפרו צבור ע"ג המזבח. כן הוחלפו חכמי ישראל באחרים. וכיון שטעמו טעם מיתה במה שנתפשו ונגמר דינם לכך, הם קבלו ענשם וה"ז כאלו נהרגו עכ"ד הרבינו בחיי ז"ל.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hebrew/Hasidic terminology:

And now we will come to explain the aforementioned Midrash on the verse "And you go up in peace to your father" (see above question 5), by first introducing what Rabbeinu Bachya wrote on the Torah at the end of Parshat Miketz, and these are his words: According to the way of Kabbalah, regarding how the Parsha ends with "And you go up in peace to your father" - it could have said "Go in peace on your way," but while the Parsha explicitly discusses Yosef's brothers at that time, it alludes to the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut) for future generations who ascended in peace to their Father in Heaven, after they were purified and refined from the sin of selling Yosef. He further wrote there in the name of Pirkei Heichalot (from Rabbi Yishmael Kohen Gadol) that Rabbi Chanina ben Teradion was exchanged with Lupinus Caesar, and it was Lupinus who was burned, etc. And this measure applied to all the Sages of Israel, these are the words of Pirkei Heichalot. And I heard that just as Yitzchak was exchanged with the ram, and it was established for him reward as if he was sacrificed and as if his ashes were gathered on the altar, so too the Sages of Israel were exchanged with others. And since they tasted the taste of death when they were seized and their judgment was sealed for this, they received their punishment and it is as if they were killed, these are the words of Rabbeinu Bachya z"l.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a deep kabbalistic interpretation of the verse "And you shall go up in peace to your father" from the Joseph narrative. The text, citing Rabbeinu Bachya, explains that this verse cryptically alludes to the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut), suggesting that after being purified from the sin of selling Joseph, they "ascended in peace to their Father in Heaven." The passage then presents a fascinating theological concept comparing these martyrs to the binding of Isaac (Akeidat Yitzchak), suggesting that just as Isaac was substituted with a ram but received reward as if he was actually sacrificed, similarly some of the Ten Martyrs were mysteriously substituted with others but received full spiritual credit as if they had actually been martyred, having experienced the taste of death through their sentencing.

hebrew_text: ובזה יתורץ קושית המפרשים לעיל (קושיא ד') דמדוע מתחלה נתרצו שיהיו כולם עבדים והצדיקו הדין עליהם, ואח"כ כשנתחסד עמהם ואמר חלילה לי מעשות זאת וגו' ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם, אז עמד יהודה לדבר קשות נגדו, אמנם יבואר לדרכינו עפי"ד רבינו בחיי ז"ל, דמעיקרא סברו שכ"ז נגזר עליהם בעון מכירת יוסף, כמ"ש האלקים מצא את עון עבדיך הננו עבדים לאדני גם אנחנו וגו' וחשבו שעי"ז יתמרק עונם בעולם הזה, אבל אחר שאמר להם יוסף ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם, ורמז על גזירת עשרה הרוגי מלכות שבזה יקבלו ענשם למרק עונם, ע"כ התנגדו לדין הקשה הזה שבאמת לא הגיע אליהם עונש כזה, לפי שמחל להם יוסף כדאיתא ברבינו בחיי ובמדרשי חז"ל שהתרו בו בס"מ התראות חמורות בעונשין קשין. והוא קיבל עליו הכל, וגזירת עשרה הרוגי מלכות היה הכרח וסוד גדול איכא בגווי', כמ"ש ז"ל שתוק כך עלה במחשבה לפני, ומבואר בכתבי האר"י ז"ל שהיה כדי להוציא בלעם מפיהם עייש"ד בטעמם, ועכשיו עדיין לא נתגלה להם להשבטים הקדושים טעם ההכרח. עד שהיה צורך השעה לכך, שעלה ר' ישמעאל כהן גדול ושאל מאת לבוש הבדים וכו', וע"כ התנגדו לדין הקשה הזה.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

This resolves the question raised by the commentators above (Question 4): Why did they initially agree to all become slaves and accept the divine judgment upon themselves, but later, when he [Yosef] showed them kindness and said "Far be it from me to do this" etc., and "You go up in peace to your father," then Yehuda stood up to speak harshly against him?

However, according to our approach, it can be explained based on the words of Rabbeinu Bachya z"l, that initially they thought all this was decreed upon them as punishment for the sin of selling Yosef, as they said "G-d has uncovered the sin of your servants; we are servants to my master, both we..." They thought that through this their sin would be atoned for in this world.

But after Yosef told them "You go up in peace to your father," alluding to the decree of the Ten Martyrs [Asara Harugei Malchus] through which they would receive their punishment to atone for their sin, they therefore opposed this harsh judgment because such a punishment truly did not befit them, since Yosef had forgiven them, as brought in Rabbeinu Bachya and in the Midrashim of Chazal that they warned him with severe warnings of harsh punishments, and he accepted it all upon himself.

The decree of the Ten Martyrs was a necessity and contained within it a great secret, as Chazal said "Be silent, for this is what arose in My thought." It is explained in the writings of the Arizal that it was necessary to extract what they had swallowed, see there for their reasons. At this point, the holy tribes had not yet been revealed the reason for this necessity, until the time came when Rabbi Yishmael Kohen Gadol ascended and asked the One clothed in linen, etc., and therefore they opposed this harsh judgment.
summary: This passage discusses a profound theological question regarding divine justice and atonement in the story of Joseph and his brothers. The key insight revolves around why the brothers initially accepted being servants as punishment for selling Joseph, but later objected when Joseph freed them. According to the text, they first believed their servitude would atone for their sin of selling Joseph, but when Joseph sent them home in peace, it hinted at a future, more severe atonement - the martyrdom of the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut). The brothers objected to this harsher decree because Joseph had already forgiven them, though the text explains this martyrdom was ultimately a divine necessity containing deep mystical significance that was not yet revealed to them, as explained in the writings of the Arizal.

hebrew_text: או אפ"ל ע"ד שכתב ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה בשם המפרשים דמתחילה חשבו שהוא בעון מכירת יוסף, לזאת שמו יד לפה וקבלו עליהם את הדין, אבל אחר שראו שרק בנימין לבדו נלכד, והוא לא היה בחטא ההוא ע"כ חשבו שהוא רק ענין בחיריי מהמושל ע"כ ניגש יהודה לדבר קשות עכת"ד. ולדרכנו כיון שאמר עלו לשלו' אל אביכם, א"כ לא יקבלו עונשם עכשיו לכפרת החטא אלא לעתיד, וע"כ שהוא רק ענין בחיריי מדעת המושל, ולכך ניגש יהודה לדבר אליו קשות.
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

One could also explain according to what my holy grandfather, the Yismach Moshe of blessed memory, wrote in the name of the commentators: Initially, they thought this was punishment for the sin of selling Yosef, and therefore they remained silent and accepted the divine judgment. However, after they saw that only Binyamin was caught, and he had not been involved in that sin, they concluded that this must merely be an arbitrary decision of the ruler. Therefore, Yehuda approached to speak harshly [with Yosef].

And according to our approach, since he [Yosef] said "Go up in peace to your father," this meant they would not receive their punishment now as atonement for the sin, but rather in the future. Therefore, this must have been merely an arbitrary matter from the ruler's own decision, and that is why Yehuda approached to speak harshly with him.

Note: I've preserved terms like "Yismach Moshe" and kept the biblical names in their Hebrew form (Yosef, Yehuda, Binyamin) to maintain the authentic feel of the text.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the brothers' reaction to Benjamin's capture, citing an interpretation from the Yismach Moshe. Initially, the brothers assumed their troubles were divine punishment for selling Joseph, so they accepted the judgment silently. However, when they realized only Benjamin (who wasn't involved in selling Joseph) was caught, they concluded this must be merely the ruler's arbitrary decision rather than divine retribution. The key theological insight is that when Joseph told them to "go up in peace to your father," it indicated their punishment for selling him would come later, not now - thus confirming this was a human-initiated situation rather than immediate divine justice, which is why Judah felt empowered to speak up forcefully.

hebrew_text: ובזה יבואר המדרש הנ"ל אמרין לי' השלו' דכולי' נשפה, ר"ל השלו' שאתה רומז עלי' בעשרה הרוגי מלכות, היא שלו' של חשך ואפילה וגזירה נוראה, ורוה"ק צווחת שלו' רב לאוהבי תורתך ואין למו מכשול, דבסוף יהי' להם שלו' ולא יגיע אליהם העונש בפועל, אלא יתמרק ענשם במה שנתפשו ונגמר דינם כדברי הפרקי היכלות הנ"ל. אלא שלא נתגלה להם הרוה"ק, דאם לא כן לא היה להם צער בגמר דינם ול"ה נתמרק עונם, ואפשר דבמה שאמר יהודה סמיות עינים יש כאן ניבא ולא ידע, שגם דברי יוסף ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם הרומז לגזירת עשרה הרוגי מלכות, אינו אלא סמיות עינים, למרק עונשם בצער הגזירה ולא יתקיים הגזירה בפועל כנ"ל, אבל לא השיג נבואתו, כדי שלא ידעו בהצלה ויתכפר ענשם בצער הגזירה ובמה שטעמו טעם מיתה כנ"ל.

Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

This explains the aforementioned Midrash "They said to him 'the peace' of all has been poured out." Meaning, the peace that you are alluding to regarding the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut) is a peace of darkness and gloom and terrible decree. Yet the Ruach HaKodesh (Divine Spirit) calls out "Great peace have they who love Your Torah, and there is no stumbling block for them," because in the end they will have peace and the punishment will not actually befall them. Rather, their punishment will be cleansed through their being seized and their judgment being sealed, as stated in the aforementioned Pirkei Heichalot.

However, the Ruach HaKodesh was not revealed to them, because if it had been, they would not have experienced anguish at their judgment and their sin would not have been cleansed. Perhaps when Yehudah said "there is blindness here," he prophesied without knowing it - that even Yosef's words "and you shall go up in peace to your father," which alludes to the decree of the Ten Martyrs, is merely a blindness, to cleanse their punishment through the anguish of the decree without it actually being fulfilled, as mentioned above. But he did not fully grasp his own prophecy, so that they would not know of their salvation and their sin would be atoned through the anguish of the decree and through their having tasted the taste of death, as mentioned above.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of suffering and divine justice through the lens of the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut). The key insight is that what appeared as harsh judgment and darkness was actually a form of divine mercy - the martyrs experienced the fear and anguish of their death sentence, which served as atonement, but according to the text, they may not have actually experienced the physical execution. The passage suggests that their not knowing they would be saved was intentional, as the spiritual cleansing required them to experience genuine fear and anguish, tasting "the taste of death" without necessarily experiencing it physically. This interpretation connects to the story of Joseph and his brothers, suggesting that Joseph's words about "going up in peace" contained a hidden prophecy about this future dynamic of apparent harsh judgment being transformed into mercy.

hebrew_text: ויבואר דברי המדרש הנ"ל מים עמוקים עצה בלב איש, והמשיל דיבוריו של יוסף למים עמוקים, שהיה דיבורו ברוה"ק וטמיר ומכוסה הפנימיות שבהם עד שלא יכלו לעמוד על סודה כנ"ל, וע"כ המשילוה לבאר עמוק מלאה צוננין ולא היתה ברי' יכולה לשתותה מפני עמקותה, עד שבא א' וקשר חבל בחבל וכו' כך לא זז יהודה משיב ליוסף דבר על דבר עד שעמד על לבו, והוכרח להתודע אליהם ואז נתגלה להם פנימיות לבו ופנימיות דבריו. והבן.
