"And he sent Judah ahead of him, etc." In the Midrash Tanchuma: "Let our Rabbi teach us: When do we recite the blessing over the fire at the conclusion of Shabbos? Thus our Rabbis taught: We do not recite the blessing over the fire until we can derive benefit from its light. And from where did they learn this? From the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is written, 'And G-d saw the light that it was good' and afterward 'And G-d separated between the light and the darkness.'" And this requires explanation - the connection between this halacha and this verse "And he sent Judah ahead of him."

Notes:
- I preserved Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "Shabbos" (rather than Sabbath) and "halacha" (rather than law) to maintain the Hasidic style
- I kept the reference to "the Holy One, Blessed be He" (הקב"ה) in its traditional form
- The abbreviation "וצ"ב" (v'tzarich biur) is translated as "requires explanation"
- The text discusses the connection between the laws of Havdalah (the ceremony marking the end of Shabbos) and the verse about Jacob sending Judah ahead
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a Midrash Tanchuma that connects the verse "And he sent Judah ahead" (regarding Jacob sending Judah ahead to Egypt) with the laws of Havdalah (the separation ceremony at the conclusion of Shabbat). The Midrash teaches that just as God first saw that the light was good before making a separation between light and darkness during Creation, we must first benefit from/see the light of the Havdalah candle before reciting the blessing over it. The text raises the question of understanding the deeper connection between this law of Havdalah and the story of Judah being sent ahead, suggesting there may be a profound parallel between the concepts of separation/distinction (havdalah) and preparation/sending ahead (shlichtut).

hebrew_text: ד) במדרש תנחומא ואת יהודה שלח זש"ה ו)מלאכי ג') הנני שולח מלאכי וגו'. בא וראה כל צרות שאירע ליוסף אירע לציון וכו'. ומה שאירע ליוסף טובות אירע לציון טובות וכו'. ביוסף כתיב ואת יהודה שלח לפניו, ובציון הנני שולח מלאכי ופנה דרך לפני ופתאם יבוא אל היכלו האדון אשר אתם מבקשים וגו' עכ"ד המדרש. ראוי להבין ענין הדמיון מזה לזה, דהלא הפסוק הנני שולח מלאכי וגו' מדבר מענין הגאולה, כמו שפירשו המפרשים רש"י והרד"ק ז"ל הנני שולח מלאכי ופנה דרך לבער את הרשעים, וזה יהיה בזמן קבוץ גליות שלא ימצא בדרכם שטן ופגע רע וכו' עיי"ש, ופסוק זה מדבר מענין הגלות ואינו מענינו כלל.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

4) In Midrash Tanchuma, regarding "And he sent Judah," this is what is written (Malachi 3): "Behold, I send My messenger, etc." Come and see that all the troubles that happened to Joseph happened to Zion, etc. And all the good things that happened to Joseph happened to Zion, etc. Regarding Joseph, it is written "And he sent Judah before him," and regarding Zion, "Behold, I send My messenger, and he shall clear the way before Me, and suddenly the Master whom you seek will come to His Temple, etc." - these are the words of the Midrash. 

It is worthy to understand the comparison between these two matters, for indeed the verse "Behold, I send My messenger, etc." speaks about the matter of redemption (Geulah), as explained by the commentators Rashi and Radak z"l: "Behold, I send My messenger and he shall clear the way" - to eliminate the wicked, and this will be at the time of the ingathering of the exiles (Kibbutz Galuyot) when there will be no satan or evil occurrence in their path, etc. - see there. Yet this verse [about Judah] speaks about the matter of exile (Galut) and is not related to that subject at all.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a Midrash Tanchuma that draws a parallel between Joseph's story and the future redemption of Zion. The key theological insight centers on how Judah being "sent ahead" (to Joseph) mirrors the concept of God sending His messenger to prepare the way before the final redemption, as mentioned in Malachi 3. The text raises an apparent difficulty in this comparison, noting that while the verse in Malachi clearly speaks about the future messianic redemption (as explained by Rashi and Radak), the story of Judah being sent to Joseph deals with the exile in Egypt. This juxtaposition suggests a deeper connection between personal/historical events and the ultimate redemption, a common theme in Hasidic thought that sees cosmic significance in seemingly mundane historical occurrences.

hebrew_text: ולבאר הענין נקדים דברי השלה"ק ופ' וישב) בדרוש צאן יוסף בענין מחלקותם של יוסף עם השבעים, ותו"ד דלכאורה קשה איך השבטים הקדושים בני עלי' כאלה יעשו ביחד עבירה הגדולה. שדימו להרוג את יוסף איש צדיק עמוד יסוד עולם, אך הענין הוא כו הנה כתר מלוכה זכה בו יהודה והוא מלכות בית דוד, וכן לעתיד המשיח יהיה משבט יהודה מזרע דוד, אך סברת יוסף היה להכין המלוכה לדוד, כו אילו לא הקדים מלוכת יוסף. במצרים, לא היה מעולם מלוכת יהודה, כי לא היו ישראל לעם ח"ו. וכן לעתיד יוקדם משיח בן יוסף למשיח בן דוד, ובשני המלוכות אלו כוונתו בשביל מלכות יהודה ושניהן שווין לטובה, והשבטים לא הבינו דבר זה רק היו סבורים אך לו המלוכה, שהוא מבקש המלוכה בעצם לו ולזרעו, ע"כ הלכו דותינה לבקש נכלו דתות, כלומר לדון אותו בדת תורה. והסכימו כולם שהוא בן מות מאחר שחולקת על מלכות בית דוד, וכל החולק על מלכות בית דוד כחולק על השכינה, זה תוכן קצת דבריו שם עיי"ש. ולכאורה עדיין קשה דהרי לפי האמת כל כוונתו של יוסף היה רק להכין מלכות בית דוד ולא רצה ליעול המלוכה משבע יהודה, א"כ יוסף הצדיק לשיטתו לא היה חייב בדבר כלום, ואיך לא דני אותו לכף זכות.

To explain this matter, we'll preface with the words of the Shelah (Parshat Vayeshev) in his discourse on "Tzon Yosef" regarding the dispute between Yosef and the tribes. The essence of his words: At first glance, it's difficult to understand how the holy tribes, such elevated beings, could collectively commit such a grave transgression by plotting to kill Yosef, a righteous man who was a foundational pillar of the world.

However, the matter is as follows: The crown of kingship was awarded to Yehudah, which became the Kingdom of the House of David, and similarly in the future, Mashiach will come from the tribe of Yehudah, from David's seed. But Yosef's reasoning was to prepare the kingship for David, for if Yosef's reign in Egypt hadn't preceded it, Yehudah's kingdom would never have existed, as the Jewish people would not have become a nation, Heaven forbid. Similarly, in the future, Mashiach ben Yosef will precede Mashiach ben David, and both these kingdoms are intended for the sake of Yehudah's kingdom, and both are equally beneficial.

The tribes didn't understand this matter and thought that he was seeking the kingdom for himself and his descendants. Therefore, they went to Dotan to seek legal judgment ("nichlu datot"), meaning to judge him according to Torah law. They all agreed that he deserved death since he was opposing the Kingdom of the House of David, and whoever opposes the Kingdom of the House of David is like one who opposes the Divine Presence. This is the basic content of his words there.

However, it's still seemingly difficult: according to the truth, all of Yosef's intention was only to prepare for the Kingdom of the House of David, and he didn't want to take the kingship from the tribe of Yehudah. If so, Yosef HaTzaddik, according to his perspective, wasn't guilty of anything, so why didn't they judge him favorably?
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the complex relationship between Yosef and his brothers, specifically regarding the concept of monarchy (malchut). The key insight revolves around the Shlah's explanation that while the crown of kingship was destined for Yehudah (and ultimately David's dynasty), Yosef's role was actually to prepare the way for this eventual Davidic kingdom through his own temporary leadership in Egypt. The brothers misunderstood Yosef's intentions, thinking he was trying to usurp the monarchy for himself, when in reality he was creating the necessary conditions for the Jewish people's formation as a nation that would eventually be led by the Davidic dynasty. This dynamic is presented as a prototype for the messianic era, where Mashiach ben Yosef must precede Mashiach ben David, demonstrating how apparent conflicts in Jewish history often reveal deeper divine purposes.

hebrew_text: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הגמרא (סוכה נ"ב ע"א) וספדה הארץ משפחות משפחות לבד וכו' (זכרי' י"ב), והלא דברים ק"ו, ומה לעתיד לבוא שעוסקין בהספד ואין יצה"ר שולט בהם. אמרה תורה אנשים לבד ונשים לבד עכשיו וכו' עאכו"כ, האי הספידא מאי עבידתי', פליגי בה ר' דוסא ורבנן חד אמר על משיח בן יוסף שנהרג, וחד אמר על יצה"ר שנהרג עכ"ד הגמרא. וראוי להבין סברת פלוגתתם ובמה פליגי.

It will be explained by first considering the words of the Gemara (Sukkah 52a) regarding the verse "and the land shall mourn, every family apart" (Zechariah 12). The Gemara makes a kal vachomer (logical inference): If in the future time, when people will be engaged in mourning and the yetzer hara (evil inclination) will not have control over them, the Torah still says men and women should be separate, then all the more so now [when the yetzer hara does have control].

[The Gemara then asks:] What is the nature of this mourning? Rabbi Dosa and the Rabbis disagree about this. One says it is mourning for Mashiach ben Yosef who will be killed, and one says it is mourning for the yetzer hara that will be killed. These are the words of the Gemara. It is worthy to understand the reasoning behind their disagreement and what exactly they are disagreeing about.

Note: I've kept terms like "yetzer hara," "Mashiach ben Yosef," and "kal vachomer" in their original forms as these are commonly used terms in Jewish theological discourse.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a Talmudic debate (Sukkah 52a) about the future mourning described in Zechariah 12, where men and women will mourn separately. The text presents a kal vachomer (a fortiori) argument: if in the messianic future, when the evil inclination won't have control, separation between men and women will still be required during mourning, how much more so is it required in the present time. The key debate is between Rabbi Dosa and the Sages regarding what exactly will be mourned - one opinion says it will be for Mashiach ben Yosef who will be killed, while the other says it will be mourning over the death of the yetzer hara (evil inclination) itself. The passage raises deep questions about the nature of spiritual progress and purification in the messianic era, and how even in a time of elevated spiritual consciousness, certain boundaries between men and women will remain necessary.

hebrew_text: אמנם ממה דאיתא בגמרא עירובין מ"ג ע"א) הריני נזיר ביום שבן דוד בא. מותר לשתות יין בשבתות ובימים טובים ואסור לשתות יין כל ימי החול, נראה דאינו מוכרח שיקדים משיח בן יוסף לפני משיח בן דוד. דאל"ה תקשי א"כ בחול נמי לישתרי, דהא לא אתא משיח בן יוסף מאתמול, וכמו שהקשו בגמרא דהא לא אתא אליהו מאתמול, אע"כ דאינו מוכרח שיקדים משיח בן יוסף לפני ביאת משיח בן דוד, אולם לפי' ר"ת שם בתוספות (ד"ה ואסור) נראה דס"ל שיקדים משיח בן יוסף עיי"ש, וכבר ראיתי בדברי המפרשים שיש פלוגתא ישינה בזה. ומדברי הרמב"ם ז"ל נראה שסובר דאינו מוכרח שיקדים משיח בן יוסף, שכתב (בספר הוד פי"א הל' ד' מהלכות מלכים) ואם יעמוד מלך מבית דוד הוגה בתורה ועוסק במצות כדוד אביו וכו', הרי זה בחזקת שהוא משיח, אם עשה והצליח ובנה מקדש במקומו וקבץ נדחי ישראל הרי זה משיח בוודאי וכו', ולכאורה אם מוכרח שיקדים ביאת בן יוסף טרם ביאת בן דוד. הי"ל למנות גם זה לסימן מובהק, אלא ע"כ שסובר כשיטה זו שאינו מוכרח שיוקדם משיח בן יוסף, ונראה שבזה יהיה פלוגתת רש"י ורד"ק עם האבן עזרא בפסוק הנ"ל (מלאכי ג') הנני שולח מלאכי ופנה דרך וגו' פירש"י לבער את הרשעים, ולא פי' מי יהיה המלאך, והרד"ק כתב והוא מלאך ה' מן השמים והוא יפנה דרך בעת קיבוץ גליות עיי"ש. והאבן עזרא פי' יתכן להיותו משיח בן יוסף ע"כ.

However, from what appears in the Gemara (Eruvin 43a) regarding one who says "I am a Nazir on the day that Ben David (Mashiach ben David) comes" - it is permitted to drink wine on Shabbatot and Yamim Tovim but forbidden to drink wine on weekdays - it appears that it's not necessary for Mashiach ben Yosef to precede Mashiach ben David. For if it were otherwise, it would be difficult to understand why drinking isn't permitted even on weekdays, since Mashiach ben Yosef didn't come yesterday, similar to the Gemara's question about Eliyahu not having come yesterday. Therefore, it must be that Mashiach ben Yosef's arrival before Mashiach ben David is not mandatory.

However, according to Rabbeinu Tam's interpretation in Tosafot (beginning with "v'asur"), it appears he holds that Mashiach ben Yosef will come first, see there. I have already seen in the commentaries that this is an old dispute.

From the Rambam's words, it appears he holds that Mashiach ben Yosef's precedence is not necessary, as he writes (in Hilchot Melachim 11:4): "If a king will arise from the House of David who delves in Torah and occupies himself with mitzvot like David his father, etc., he is presumed to be Mashiach. If he succeeds and builds the Beit HaMikdash in its place and gathers the dispersed of Israel, then he is certainly Mashiach, etc." If Mashiach ben Yosef's arrival was necessary before Mashiach ben David, the Rambam should have included this as a definitive sign.

It appears this is also the dispute between Rashi and Radak versus Ibn Ezra on the aforementioned verse (Malachi 3) "Behold, I send My messenger, and he shall clear the way, etc." Rashi explains it as "to eliminate the wicked" without specifying who the messenger will be. The Radak writes that it refers to an angel of Hashem from heaven who will clear the way during the ingathering of exiles. Ibn Ezra explains that it could be Mashiach ben Yosef.
summary: This passage discusses a fundamental debate regarding the messianic process, specifically focusing on whether Mashiach ben Yosef (Messiah son of Joseph) must necessarily precede Mashiach ben David (Messiah son of David). The text analyzes various rabbinic sources, including a Talmudic discussion from Eruvin about taking a Nazirite vow contingent on Mashiach's arrival, and presents differing views from Rambam, Rashi, Radak, and Ibn Ezra. The core theological insight centers on the flexibility of the redemptive process, with some authorities (like Rambam) suggesting that Mashiach ben Yosef's arrival is not a mandatory prerequisite, while others (like Ibn Ezra) view it as an essential part of the messianic sequence. This debate has profound implications for understanding how the final redemption may unfold and how to interpret various prophetic texts about the messianic era.

hebrew_text: ואני חשבתי שזה תליא באיזה מדה יהיה הגאולה, וע"ד שכתבו בכל פלוגתת חז"ל, דשורש ההלכה הוא לפי המדה, וכמ"ש הרמ"ק ז"ל דמה"ט לא פסקו חז"ל הילכתא למשיחא, שאין לידע איזה מדה יהיה שולט אז, ובאיזה זמן יהיה ביאת בן דוד, וכמו"כ לענינינו אפשר שזה תליא איך יעברו החבלי משיח, ואולי לא יהיה נהרג משיח בן יוסף. וכמ"ש שראוי להתפלל בברכת ולירושלים עירך וכו' שלא יהרג משיח בן יוסף, מבואר דאינו מוכרח שיהיה כן ותליא כפי המדה.

"And I thought that this depends on which middah (divine attribute) will be dominant during the Geulah (redemption). This follows what was written regarding all disputes of Chazal (our Sages), that the root of the halachah is according to the middah, as the Ramak z"l wrote. For this reason, Chazal did not establish halachot for the Messianic era, because we cannot know which middah will rule then, and at what time the coming of Ben David (Mashiach ben David) will occur. Similarly, regarding our matter, it's possible that this depends on how the Chevlei Mashiach (birth pangs of Mashiach) will unfold, and perhaps Mashiach ben Yosef will not be killed. As it is written, it is proper to pray in the blessing of 'V'liYerushalayim Ircha' that Mashiach ben Yosef should not be killed, which shows that it is not inevitable that it will be so, but rather depends on the middah."
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the nature of the future redemption (geulah) and its relationship to divine attributes (middot). The author suggests that just as many halakhic disputes among the Sages depend on which divine attribute is dominant, similarly the exact nature of the messianic redemption - including whether Mashiach ben Yosef will be killed - depends on which divine attribute will be prevalent at that time. He cites the Ramak's explanation for why the Sages didn't establish definitive halakhot for the messianic era, since we cannot know which divine attribute will dominate then, and notes that one should pray in the Amidah that Mashiach ben Yosef not be killed, indicating this outcome is not predetermined but depends on the prevailing spiritual conditions.

hebrew_text: ומעתה שורש פלוגתתם תליא במידות, וכ"א מהחולקים אומר דעתו כפו מדתו ושורש נשמתו, ואלו ואלו דברי אלקים חיים, ממילא זה המ"ד שסובר לפי מידתו ושורש נשמתו שיהיה משיח בן יוסף, אינו רואה כלל שיטת בר פלוגתיה, שגם הוא קאמר לפי שורש נשמתו ומדתו. ואינם רואין זה את זה, וכמבואר בספה"ק בענין המידות שאינן רואין זא"ז, ולפי זה אפ"ל שהשבטים הק' לא ראו כלל שיהיה משיח בן יוסף, וע"כ חשדו בו שרוצה ליעול המלוכה מבית דוד. גם הי' סיבה מן השמים להעלים מהם ענין זה, כדי שיסתבב מכירתו לקיים גזירת ידוע תדע, ויוסף לשיטתו סובר שיהיה משיח בן יוסף. אלא שהשבטים הק' לא ראו שיטתו כלל וכן להיפוך יוסף הצדיק לא ראה בשיטתם דהכל לפי המידה.

And from here, the root of their disagreement depends on middot (spiritual attributes), and each of those who disagree states his opinion according to his middah and the root of his neshamah (soul), and both these and those are the words of the living G-d. Consequently, this opinion holder who believes according to his middah and soul-root that there will be Mashiach ben Yosef, does not see at all the approach of his disputant, who also speaks according to his soul-root and middah. And they do not see each other['s perspective], as explained in the holy sefarim regarding the middot that they don't see one another. According to this, one could say that the holy Shevatim (tribes) did not see at all that there would be Mashiach ben Yosef, and therefore they suspected him of wanting to take the monarchy from the House of David. There was also a reason from Heaven to conceal this matter from them, in order to bring about his sale to fulfill the decree of "Know with certainty" [referring to the Egyptian exile]. And Yosef, according to his approach, believed there would be Mashiach ben Yosef. However, the holy Shevatim did not see his approach at all, and likewise, conversely, Yosef HaTzaddik did not see their approach, as everything depends on the middah.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of different spiritual perspectives based on soul-roots (shoresh neshamah) and divine attributes (middot). The key insight is that disagreements between different views, particularly regarding Mashiach ben Yosef, stem from each person or group perceiving truth through their unique spiritual lens and soul-root, with both perspectives being valid ("eilu v'eilu divrei Elokim chaim"). The text applies this principle to explain the conflict between Yosef and his brothers - the tribes couldn't see the possibility of Mashiach ben Yosef due to their spiritual root and attributes, while Yosef, from his perspective, understood this role, leading to their misunderstanding of his intentions regarding leadership. This theological framework suggests that apparent contradictions in Jewish thought can be understood as different manifestations of divine truth viewed through distinct spiritual prisms.

hebrew_text: והנה בכל פלוגתת חז"ל אמרינן אלו ואלו דברי אלקים חיים, וההכרעה ביד חכמי הדור, כמ"ש הריטב"א (עירובין י"ג) שאלו רבני צרפת ז"ל האיך אפשר שיהיו שניהם דברי אלקים חיים וזה אוסר וזה מתיר, ותירצו כי כשעלה משה למרום לקבל תורה הראו לו על כל דבר ודבר מ"ט פנים לאיסור ומ"ט פנים להיתר. ושאל להקב"ה על זה ואמר שיהא זו מסור לחכמי ישראל שבכל דור ודור ויהיה הכרעה כמותם, עכ"ל. אמנם ענין הגאולה וביאת בן דוד לא נמסרה לחכמי הדור, וכמ"ש הרמב"ם (בפי"ב מהלכות מלכים) וכל אלו הדברים וכיוצא בהן לא ידע אדם איך יהיה עד שיהיו. שדברים סתומין הן אצל הנשיאים גם החכמים אין להם קבלה בדברים אלו וכו' עיי"ש, והוא רק ביד השי"ת להכריע שהוא יודע ורואה באיזה מדה יהיה הגאולה.

And behold, regarding all disputes of our Sages of blessed memory, we say "These and these are the words of the living G-d," and the final ruling is in the hands of the Sages of each generation, as the Ritva wrote (Eruvin 13): The Rabbis of France of blessed memory asked how it's possible that both could be the words of the living G-d when one forbids and one permits. They answered that when Moshe ascended to heaven to receive the Torah, he was shown for each and every matter 49 faces (aspects) of prohibition and 49 faces of permission. He asked the Holy One, Blessed be He, about this, and He said that this would be given over to the Sages of Israel in each and every generation, and the ruling would be according to them.

However, the matter of redemption and the coming of Ben David (Mashiach) was not given over to the Sages of each generation, as the Rambam wrote (in Chapter 12 of the Laws of Kings): "All these matters and similar ones - no person will know how they will occur until they actually happen. These matters were unclear even to the prophets, and even the Sages have no tradition regarding these matters, etc." See there. This is only in the hands of Hashem to decide, as He knows and sees in which measure the redemption will come.
summary:
This passage discusses a fundamental concept in Jewish thought regarding disputes among the Sages. It begins by citing the Ritva's explanation of the principle "these and these are the words of the living God" (Eilu v'Eilu divrei Elokim chaim), explaining that when Moses received the Torah, he was shown 49 ways to prohibit and 49 ways to permit each matter, with the ultimate decision being given to the Sages of each generation.

However, the passage then makes a crucial distinction: while regular halakhic matters are entrusted to the Sages of each generation, matters concerning the redemption (geulah) and the coming of Mashiach are different. Citing the Rambam, it emphasizes that these matters remain sealed and unknown even to the greatest scholars and leaders, with their ultimate resolution resting solely with God, who alone knows how and when the redemption will unfold.

This creates a profound theological framework distinguishing between the human authority granted in halakhic matters and the divine mystery of redemption, highlighting the limits of human wisdom and the ultimate sovereignty of God in matters of redemption.

hebrew_text: ובזה נבוא לבאר דברי המדרש שבפתח דברינו, כו הנה המלכים נועדו עברו יחדיו וכו', עפומ"ד במד"ר ויגש אליו יהודה וגו' כתיב מים עמוקים עצה בלב איש וגו', לבאר עמוקה מלאה צונן והיו מימיה צוננין ויפין, ולא היתה בריה יכולה לשתות הימנה, בא אחד וקשר חבל בחבל ונימה בנימה משיחה במשיחה ודלה הימנה ושתה, התחילו הכל דולין וכו'. כך לא זז יהודה משיב ליוסף דבר על דבר עד שעמד על לבו עכ"ד המדרש. ולדרכינו אפ"ל הכוונה שעמד על שיטתו של יוסף הצדיק במה שהיה חולק עליו, שעד עכשיו לא ראה שיטתו של יוסף הצדיק כנ"ל, ועכשיו עמד על לבו ונתוודע לו שיטתו, שכן היה סיבה מן השמים שאז במכירתו לא ראו שיטת יוסף הצדיק, שכן היה מוכרח להתגלגל על ידם שיהיה נמכר לעבד למצרים, וחק עכשיו עמד על לבו ונתוודע לו שיטתו, וז"ש המה ראו כן תמהו וכו' אמרו מלכים מדיינים אלו עם אלו אנו מה איכפת לנו. ר"ל שנתוודע להם שורש פלוגתתם בענין המלוכה אם יהיה משיח בן יוסף או לא, ע"כ אמרו אנו מה איכפת לנו שאין בידינו להכריע בפלוגתא זו, שהכרעה זו רק ביד הקב"ה לבדו כנ"ל.

With this, we can explain the words of the Midrash that we opened with, "Behold, the kings assembled, they passed together, etc." Based on what is explained in Midrash Rabbah on "Vayigash eilav Yehudah," it is written "Deep waters are counsel in a man's heart, etc." [This can be compared to] a deep well full of cold water, and its waters were cold and beautiful, but no creature could drink from it. Someone came and tied rope to rope, string to string, cord to cord, and drew water from it and drank. Then everyone began drawing water, etc. Similarly, Yehudah continued responding to Yosef point by point until he understood his heart.

Following our approach, we can explain that the meaning is that he understood the perspective of Yosef HaTzaddik regarding their disagreement, for until now he had not seen Yosef HaTzaddik's approach as mentioned above. Now he understood his heart and became aware of his perspective, for it was ordained from Heaven that at the time of his sale they did not see Yosef HaTzaddik's approach, as it was necessary for events to unfold through them that he would be sold as a slave to Egypt. And now he understood his heart and became aware of his approach.

This is what is meant by "They saw and were amazed... The kings said, 'They are arguing with each other, what does it matter to us?'" Meaning, they became aware of the root of their disagreement regarding kingship - whether there would be a Mashiach ben Yosef or not. Therefore they said, "What does it matter to us?" as it is not in their power to resolve this dispute, for this resolution is only in the hands of the Holy One, Blessed be He, as mentioned above.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the encounter between Judah and Joseph, using a midrashic metaphor of drawing water from a deep well to illustrate how Judah gradually came to understand Joseph's true perspective. The key theological insight centers on the concept that their initial conflict was divinely orchestrated - their disagreement about Joseph's approach was necessary for the fulfillment of God's plan to send Joseph to Egypt. The text ultimately points to a deeper discussion about the messianic lineage (the debate between Mashiach ben Yosef and Mashiach ben David), suggesting that such fundamental theological matters can only be resolved by God Himself, not through human deliberation.

hebrew_text: והנה בענין קץ הגאולה אמרו רז"ל בזוה"ק שאמר הקב"ה ללבי גליתי לאברי לא גליתי, ופירשו המפרשים דהצדיקים שהם בבחי' ליבא להם נתגלה קץ הגאולה ולא לזולתם, ולא נתגלה ענין זה אף להמלאכים ומפני זה כששמעו מלאכי השרת, שיהודה ויוסף מתווכחין בענין הגאולה אם יקדים משית בן יוסף כנ"ל, ע"כ אמרו כאן זל"ז בואו נרד למטה נראה שור וארי מתנגחין זה עם זה, שהיו משתוקקים לשמוע דברי התווכחותם אולי אליהם דבר יגונב מענין הגאולה. ולדרכנו יתבאר דברי המדרש תנחומא ואת יהודה שלח לפניו ובציון הנני שולח מלאכי ופנה דרך לפני וגו', דשורש פלוגתתם של יוסף עם יהודה היה אם יקדים משיח בן יוסף או לא. והוא מבואר ג"כ בכוונת הכתוב הנני שולח מלאכי וגו', כנ"ל בפי' האבן עזרא, וע"כ את יהודה שלח לפניו לתווך שלום ביניהם. כמ"ש במדרש תנחומא ואת יהודה שלח וגו' זש"ה וסרה קנאת אפרים וכו', ולזה הסמיכו במדרש להכא מאמר הכתוב הנני שולח מלאכי שהוא מענינו והבן. ס

Regarding the time of redemption (Keitz HaGeulah), our Sages taught in the holy Zohar that the Holy One, Blessed be He, said "To My heart I revealed it, to My limbs I did not reveal it." The commentators explained that the tzaddikim, who are on the level of "heart," to them the time of redemption was revealed, but not to others. This matter was not even revealed to the angels. Because of this, when the ministering angels heard that Yehudah and Yosef were debating about the redemption - whether Mashiach ben Yosef would come first, as mentioned above - they said to each other, "Come, let us descend below and see the ox and lion fighting with each other," as they were yearning to hear their debate, hoping perhaps they might catch some hint about the redemption.

Following our approach, we can explain the words of the Midrash Tanchuma: "And he sent Yehudah before him" and "Behold, I send My messenger, and he shall clear the way before Me." The root of the dispute between Yosef and Yehudah was whether Mashiach ben Yosef would come first or not. This is also explained in the meaning of the verse "Behold, I send My messenger," as explained above in Ibn Ezra's commentary. Therefore, "he sent Yehudah before him" to make peace between them, as it is written in Midrash Tanchuma: "And he sent Yehudah..." This is what is meant by "The envy of Ephraim shall depart." This is why they connected in the Midrash the verse "Behold, I send My messenger," as it relates to this matter - understand this.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the mystical concept of the redemption's timing (קץ הגאולה) and explains that God revealed this secret only to the righteous ones (צדיקים) who are on the level of "heart," but not to the angels or others. The text explores the debate between Judah and Joseph as a metaphor for the discussion about whether Mashiach ben Yosef will precede the final redemption, a conversation that even the angels desired to understand. The passage connects this to the Midrash Tanchuma's interpretation of "Judah was sent ahead" and "Behold, I send My messenger," suggesting that the historical meeting between Judah and Joseph prefigured the future process of redemption and the resolution of tensions between different messianic traditions.

hebrew_text: באופן אחר יתבאר קישור דברי המדרש, בהקדם לפחש דברי המדרש תנחומא הנ"ל, אימתי מברכין על הנר במוצאי שבת, דהנה בפרק ערבי פסחים (ק"ג ע"ב) איכא מ"ד דס"ל המבדיל צריך שיאמר מעין הבדלות האמורות בתורה וז' הבדלות הם עיי"ש, ויש מי שסובר שאין להזכיר רק המבדיל בין קודש לחול ואנו נוהגין כמסקנת הרי"ף והרא"ש לומר המבדיל בין קודש לחול בין אור לחושך בין ישראל לעמים, בין יום השביעי לששת ימי המעשה, ובארתי בדברינו (בפרשת שמיני) מדוע לא תקנו להזכיר גם המבדיל בין טמא לטהור, שנאמר בו ג"כ הבדלה בתורה, ויובן עפי"מ שפירש"י עה"פ בין הטמא ובין הטהור, אין צ"ל בין חמור לפרה והלא כבר מפורשים הם, אלא בין טמאה לך לטהורה לך בין נשחט חציו של קנה לנשחט רובו. ע"כ והוא מאחז"ל, הרי מבואר דמה שהוא ניכר ומופרש אינו שייך לגביה לשון הבדלה, כ"א בדבר שאין הבדל ביניהם רק משהו כגון בין נשחט חציו של קנה לנשחט רובו שאין ביניהם אלא מלא נימא ולזה צריך דעת להבחין ולהבדיל ביניהם, ועד"ז בין קודש לחול צריך הבחנה להבדיל בין חולין שנעשו על טהרת הקודש לקודש שנעשו על טהרת הקודש, טבל טומאה שנעשה על טהרת הקודש ניכר ההבדל מאליו ואין צריך להבחנה בזה, עיי"ש בדברינו בביאור יותר

Another way to explain the connection of the Midrash's words, by first examining the words of the Midrash Tanchuma mentioned above, regarding when we make the blessing over fire at Motzaei Shabbat [Saturday night]. In Perek Arvei Pesachim (103b), there is an opinion that holds that during Havdalah, one needs to mention the types of separations mentioned in the Torah, and there are seven separations, see there. And there are those who hold that one only needs to mention "Who separates between holy and mundane." We follow the conclusion of the Rif and the Rosh to say "Who separates between holy and mundane, between light and darkness, between Israel and the nations, between the seventh day and the six days of creation."

I explained in our words (in Parshat Shemini) why they didn't establish to also mention "Who separates between pure and impure," which is also mentioned as a separation in the Torah. This can be understood based on Rashi's explanation on the verse "between the impure and the pure" - it's not necessary to specify between a donkey and a cow as these are already clearly distinguished, rather [it refers to] between what is impure for you and pure for you, between when most of the windpipe is cut and when only half is cut.

This is based on Chazal's teaching, which explains that when something is clearly distinguishable and separate, the language of "separation" (havdalah) doesn't apply. Rather, it applies to things where the difference is minimal, such as between cutting half the windpipe versus most of it, where the difference is merely a hair's breadth - this requires knowledge to discern and separate between them. Similarly, regarding holy and mundane, discernment is needed to separate between chullin (non-sacred items) that were prepared under conditions of ritual purity and sacred items prepared under conditions of ritual purity. [However,] ritual impurity that was prepared under conditions of sanctity - the difference is self-evident and requires no discernment, see there in our words for further explanation.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of Havdalah (separation/distinction) in Jewish law, particularly focusing on the blessings recited at the conclusion of Shabbat. The key theological insight centers on the nature of true distinction (havdalah) - explaining that the concept of havdalah is most relevant when distinguishing between things that are subtly different rather than obviously distinct. The text explains that this is why we specifically mention distinctions like "between holy and mundane" and "between light and darkness" in the Havdalah service, but not distinctions like "between pure and impure" - because the latter are already clearly distinct and don't require special discernment. This teaching reflects a deeper Hasidic concept that spiritual wisdom often lies in perceiving subtle distinctions rather than obvious differences, particularly in matters of holiness.

hebrew_text: ובש"ע (או"ח סימן רצ"ח סעיף ד') נפסק להלכה דאין מברכין על הנר עד שיאותו לאורו דהיינו סמוך לו בכדי שיוכל להכיר בין מטבע מדינה זו למטבע מדינה אחרת. הרי דגדר הבדלה הוא רק אם מבחין ההבדל, כמ"ש רז"ל אם אין דעת הבדלה מנין וע"כ התקינו הבדלה בחונן הדעת, ומטעם זה אין מברכין על הנר בהבדלה עד שיאותו לאורו, לרמוז שצריך להבחנה ברורה לעשות הבדלה. ובחינת הבדלה זו נרמז ג"כ במאמר הכתוב וירא אלקים את האור כי עוב וכפירש"י לפי פשוטו שאין נאה לו ולחושך שיהיו משתמשים בערבוביא וכו', ועפימ"ש כ"ק אבא מארי זלה"ה דאיתא במדרש אור זה מעשיהם של צדיקים חושך אלו מעשיהם של רשעים, והיה זה רמז שיהיה ערבוביא בין מעשיהם של צדיקים ומעשיהם של רשעים, ואין נאה שיהיו משתמשים בערבוביא, ע"כ ויבדל בין האור ובין החושך, עכדה"ק וצריך בזה להבחנה ברורה שהוא גדר הבדלה כנתל,

In the Shulchan Aruch (Orach Chaim 298:4), it is ruled that one does not recite the blessing over the havdalah candle until they can benefit from its light, meaning they must be close enough to distinguish between coins of this country and coins of another country. This shows that the essential nature of havdalah (separation) is only when one can discern the difference, as our Sages taught, "Without knowledge, how can there be havdalah?" Therefore, they established havdalah in the blessing of "Chonen HaDaat" (the blessing for wisdom). For this reason, we don't recite the blessing over the candle during havdalah until we can benefit from its light, hinting that clear discernment is needed to make havdalah.

This concept of havdalah is also alluded to in the verse "And G-d saw the light that it was good," which Rashi explains according to its simple meaning that it was not fitting for light and darkness to serve in mixture. Based on what my father and teacher of blessed memory wrote, the Midrash states that "light" refers to the deeds of the righteous, while "darkness" refers to the deeds of the wicked. This was a hint that there would be a mixture between the deeds of the righteous and the deeds of the wicked, and it was not fitting for them to serve in mixture. Therefore, "He separated between the light and the darkness." These are his holy words, and this requires clear discernment, which is the essential nature of havdalah, as mentioned above.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the deeper meaning of Havdalah (the separation ceremony at the end of Shabbat) and connects it to the cosmic separation of light and darkness in Creation. The key insight is that true Havdalah requires clear discernment (havchana) - just as one must be close enough to the Havdalah candle to distinguish between different coins, so too must one have clear spiritual discernment to separate between holy and mundane. The text draws a parallel to Rashi's commentary on Genesis, where God separated light from darkness because they shouldn't serve in mixture, interpreting this allegorically as the necessary separation between the deeds of the righteous (light) and the deeds of the wicked (darkness). This teaching emphasizes that proper spiritual life requires clear boundaries and the wisdom to distinguish between sacred and profane realms.

hebrew_text: והנה יעקב אבינו ע"ה שלח את יהודה לפניו להורות לפניו גושנה, ולהכין לו בית תלמוד כאמרם ז"ל, ולכאורה היה יכול יוסף בעצמו להכין את זאת, גם היה אפשר לעשות שליחות זו ע"י אחד מהשבטים ומדוע שלח את יהודה שהיה מלך, אך נראה עפומ"ד במדרש וירא את העגלות אשר שלח יוסף ואותן העגלות ששלח פרעה היכן היו, א"ל אותן עגלות ששלח פרעה לשאת אותו היתה ע"ז חקוקה עליהם עמד יהודה ושרפן, למוד הוא השבט הזה להיות שורף ע"ז, ודייקו ביפ"ת ובנזה"ק מדוע לא שרפם יוסף בעצמו, ותירצו דמפני שיהודה מסוגל לזה ע"כ הניחו אליו, ובנזה"ק האריך לבאר עפי"ד המדרש אין אנו בקיאים בדקדוקי ע"ז כיעקב אבינו, וכמו כן יהודה היה בקו בדקדוקי ע"ז עכ"ד, וע"כ שלח יעקב אבינו את יהודה שהוא יכיר ויבחין גם בחי' ע"ז הטמון בסתר, גם מחשבת ע"ז, דהרי למוד אותו שבט להיות שורף ע"ז, ולפי שרצה יע"א להכין לו בית שמשם תצא הוראה, ע"כ היה צורך לזה הבחנה והבדלה שלא יהיה מעורב בו אף שמץ ע"ז ולזה מסוגל רק יהודה כנ"ל, וע"כ שלח את יהודה דייקא שהוא יכין לו בית תלמוד, שלא יהיה בה שום שמץ ע"ז ומשם תצא הוראה, ומזה אפשר לראות עד היכן צריכין להיות נשמר מדרך ע"ז שלזה צריך חכמה יתירה להבין ולהבדיל ולהפריש מהם, ולזה הסמיכו לכאן ההלכה ילמדנו רבינו אימתי מברכין על הנר במוצ"ש כך שנו רבותינו אין מברכין על הנר עד שיאותו לאורו, והיינו מטעמא שצריך הכרה יתירה להבדיל ומנין למדו מן הקב"ה שנאמר וירא אלקים את האור כי טוב ואח"כ ויבדל אלקים בין האור ובין החושך ומה"ט את יהודה שלח לפניו מפני שהוצרך להכרה יתירה להכין ביהמ"ד שיהיה מסוגל וראוי לכך שמשם תצא הוראה.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts and terminology:

Our father Yaakov, peace be upon him, sent Yehudah ahead of him to prepare the way to Goshen, and to establish a Beis Medrash (house of study) as our Sages said. Seemingly, Yosef himself could have prepared this, or it could have been done through any of the other tribes, so why did he send Yehudah who was king?

It appears to be explained based on the Midrash regarding "and he saw the wagons that Yosef sent" - where were the wagons that Pharaoh sent? It teaches that those wagons that Pharaoh sent to carry him had idolatrous images engraved on them, so Yehudah stood up and burned them. This tribe was accustomed to burning avodah zarah (idolatry). The Yefeh Toar and Nitzotzei Kedushah questioned why Yosef didn't burn them himself, and they answered that since Yehudah was especially suited for this task, it was left to him. The Nitzotzei Kedushah elaborates based on the Midrash that "we are not as expert in the details of avodah zarah as our father Yaakov," and similarly, Yehudah was expert in the details of avodah zarah.

Therefore, Yaakov sent Yehudah because he could recognize and discern even hidden aspects of avodah zarah, including thoughts of idolatry, as that tribe was accustomed to burning avodah zarah. Since Yaakov wanted to establish a house from which Torah instruction would emanate, it required careful discrimination to ensure there would be no trace of avodah zarah, and only Yehudah was suited for this as mentioned above. Therefore, he specifically sent Yehudah to prepare the Beis Medrash, ensuring it would be completely free of any trace of avodah zarah, and from there Torah instruction would emerge.

From this, we can see how carefully one must guard against the ways of avodah zarah, requiring extra wisdom to understand, distinguish, and separate from them. This connects to the halachah they taught: "When do we make the blessing over fire at the conclusion of Shabbos? Our rabbis taught that we don't make the blessing until we can benefit from its light." This is because extra recognition is needed to make distinctions, and where did they learn this from? From the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it says, "And God saw the light that it was good" and afterward "God separated between the light and the darkness." For this reason, he sent Yehudah ahead, because extra discernment was needed to prepare a Beis Medrash that would be suitable and worthy for Torah instruction to emanate from it.
summary: This passage discusses why Jacob specifically sent Judah ahead to establish a house of study (Beit Midrash) in Goshen. The key theological insight centers on Judah's unique spiritual capacity to identify and eliminate any trace of idolatry (avodah zarah), even in its most subtle forms. The text draws a parallel between this ability and the Havdalah blessing over fire at the conclusion of Shabbat - just as one must clearly discern the light before making the blessing, Judah possessed the special wisdom to discern and separate the holy from the profane. This spiritual sensitivity was essential for establishing a pure place of Torah study, free from any subtle influences of idolatry, from which authentic Jewish teaching could emerge.

hebrew_text: ובזה יתיישב קישור דברי המדרש תנחומא הנ"ל ואת יהודה שלח לפניו וכן בציון הנני שולח מלאכי פי' רש"י לבער את הרשעים ופנה דרך מן הרשעים וכן פי' המפרשים שקודם ביאת המשיח ובא מלאך הברית ויעשה הבדל בין הרשעים ובין אלו שראויים לקרב שיעשו תשובה, והוא הכנה אל הגאולה, ומטעם זה בעצמו שלח יעקב אבינו את יהודה לפניו להכין לו בית תלמוד שמשם תצא הוראה, לעשות הבדלה שלא יהיה מעורב בה שמץ ע"ז, ואף זה היה הכנה לגאולה העתידה. דאם לא זה לא הוה ח"ו קיום לישראל שם במצרים, ולא היו יכולין לצאת משם ולא הי' ח"ו גאולה העתידה, וע"כ הכין בית תלמוד שלא יהיה בו שמץ ע"ז שמשם תצא הוראה ועי"ז יהיה קיום לישראל גם בגלות ויזכו לגאולה העתידה, ונזכה לראות במהרה בביאת אלי' ומשיח בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו ב"ב אמן.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

And with this we can understand the connection of the words of the Midrash Tanchuma mentioned above: "And he sent Judah before him," and similarly [regarding] Zion, "Behold, I send My messenger." Rashi explains [this means] to eliminate the wicked ones and clear the path from the wicked. The commentators similarly explain that before the coming of Mashiach, the angel of the covenant will come and make a separation between the wicked and those who are worthy of drawing near and will do teshuvah (repentance). This is a preparation for the geulah (redemption).

For this very reason, our father Yaakov sent Yehudah ahead of him to prepare a Beis Talmud (house of study) from which hora'ah (Torah instruction) would emanate, to make a separation so that no trace of avodah zarah (idolatry) would be mixed in. This too was a preparation for the future redemption. For without this, there would not have been, Heaven forbid, any survival for Israel there in Mitzrayim (Egypt), and they would not have been able to leave from there, and there would not have been, Heaven forbid, a future redemption.

Therefore, he prepared a Beis Talmud that would have no trace of avodah zarah, from which hora'ah would emanate, and through this, Israel would have survival even in galus (exile) and merit the future redemption. May we merit to see speedily the coming of Eliyahu and Mashiach, with the elevation of the glory of Torah and Israel, and the revelation of Heaven's glory upon us, speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the parallel between Yehuda being sent ahead of Yaakov to Egypt and the concept of Elijah being sent as a messenger before the Messianic era. The key theological insight is that both serve as preparatory stages for redemption - Yehuda established a house of Torah study (beis midrash) free from idolatry, while Elijah will separate the righteous from the wicked before the final redemption. The text emphasizes that establishing pure Torah learning was essential for the Jews' spiritual survival in Egypt and remains crucial for sustaining them through exile until the future redemption. The passage connects historical events with messianic prophecy, highlighting how maintaining authentic Torah learning, untainted by foreign influences, is a prerequisite for both immediate and ultimate redemption.

hebrew_text: ויגש אליו יהודה וגו'. במדרש ילקוט: ר"י אומר הגשה למלחמה וכו' רנ"א הגשה לפיוס וכו' רמ"א אין ויגש אלא לשון שלו' וכו' ר' נחמי' אומר אין ויגש אלא לשון קרבן שנאמר ויגש את פר החטאת וכו' עכ"ד המדרש. וצ"ב מה ענין הקרבת קרבן לכאן.

"And Judah approached him, etc." In the Midrash Yalkut: Rabbi Yehuda says it was an approach for war, etc.; Rabbi Binyamin says it was an approach for appeasement, etc.; Rabbi Meir says the word "Vayigash" (and he approached) only means peace, etc.; Rabbi Nechemiah says "Vayigash" only refers to the language of sacrifice/offering, as it is said "And he brought forth the sin offering," etc. These are the words of the Midrash. And it needs clarification what the bringing of a korban (sacrifice) has to do with this situation.

Note: I preserved Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "Vayigash" and "korban" which have specific religious significance in their original form. The text is discussing various interpretations of the word "Vayigash" from the biblical story of Judah approaching Joseph in Egypt, comparing it to different contexts where similar language is used in the Torah.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the multiple interpretations of the word "Vayigash" (ויגש) from when Judah approached Joseph. The Midrash presents several understandings: one sees it as an approach to battle, another as reconciliation, another as peace, and Rabbi Nechemiah interprets it as relating to sacrificial offerings (korbanot), comparing it to the bringing of a sin offering. The key theological insight appears to be that true approaching or drawing near (in this case, Judah to Joseph) contains multiple spiritual dimensions - it can simultaneously be an act of confrontation, peacemaking, and sacrificial self-nullification before a higher authority, similar to the essence of a korban which draws one closer to the Divine.

hebrew_text: ב) להלן בפרשה ויסע ישראל וכל אשר לו ויבא בארה שבע ויזבח זבחים לאלקי אביו יצחק פירש"י חייב אדם בכבוד אביו יותר מכבוד זקנו, לפיכך תלה ביצחק ולא באברהם, והקשה הרמב"ן, וז"ל: ואיננו מספיק שהראוי לומר לאלקי אבותיו בלי שייחד אדם וכו'. או יאמר ויזבח זבחים לה' כמ"ש באברהם ויבן מזבח לה' ומה צורך לפרש בו יותר.
translation:
Here's the English translation:

2) Later in the parsha [it states]: "And Israel journeyed with all that he had and came to Beer-sheba, and offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac." Rashi explains that a person is obligated to honor his father more than his grandfather, therefore he attributed [the sacrifice] to Isaac and not to Abraham. The Ramban questions this, saying: "This explanation is insufficient, as it would have been more appropriate to say 'to the God of his fathers' without specifying any individual... Or it could have simply stated 'and he offered sacrifices to Hashem' as it says regarding Abraham 'and he built an altar to Hashem' - what need was there to elaborate further?"

Note: I've preserved the Hebrew terms "parsha" (Torah portion) and "Hashem" (God's name) as they are commonly used in religious Jewish discourse. The names Rashi and Ramban refer to prominent Torah commentators.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses Yaakov's journey to Beer Sheva where he offered sacrifices to "the God of his father Yitzchak." It explores Rashi's interpretation that one is more obligated to honor their father than their grandfather, which is why Yaakov specifically mentioned Yitzchak rather than Avraham. The passage then presents the Ramban's challenge to this interpretation, questioning why the text needed to specify any particular patriarch rather than simply saying "the God of his fathers" or just "to Hashem" as was written regarding Avraham. This textual analysis reflects a deeper theological discussion about the nature of generational religious inheritance and the specific spiritual connections between fathers and sons in Jewish thought.

hebrew_text: ג) ויאמר אנכי הארל אלקי אביך אל תירא מרדה מצרימה גוו'. במדרש ילקוט: שמע יעקב על יוסף שהוא חי, היה מהרהר בלבו ואמר אעזוב את ארץ אבותי ואת ארץ מולדתי ואת ארץ מגורי אבותי ואת ארץ ששכינתו של הקב"ה שרוי בתוכה. ואלך לו אל ארץ טמאה אל תוך ערלים שאין יחאת שמים ביניהם, א"ל הקב"ה יעקב אל תירא אנכי ארד עמך וגו' ע"כ. ראוי להבין מדוע לא צוה לו הקב"ה בפירוש שירד למצרים, דלא מצינו אלא שאמר לו אל תירא מרדה מצרימה, גם למה הוצרך הקב"ה לגלגל כל הסיבות ע"י יוסף הצדיק שירד תחלה כדי למשוך לשם את יעקב אבינו עם השבטים הק', כמבואר בדברי חכז"ל שזה הי' טעם המכירה, הלא אם הקב"ה היה מצוהו להדיא שירד עם בניו למצרים, ודאי שלא היה נמנע מלקיים מצות ד' ית"ש.

"And He said, 'I am the G-d (Ha-Kel), the G-d of your father. Do not fear going down to Egypt, etc.' In the Midrash Yalkut: When Yaakov heard that Yosef was alive, he was contemplating in his heart and said, 'Shall I leave the land of my fathers, my birthplace, the land where my fathers dwelled, and the land where the Shechinah (Divine Presence) of the Holy One, Blessed be He, resides? And shall I go to an impure land, among the uncircumcised where there is no fear of Heaven?' The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him, 'Yaakov, do not fear, I will go down with you, etc.'

It is worthy to understand why Hashem didn't explicitly command him to go down to Egypt, as we only find that He said to him 'do not fear going down to Egypt.' Also, why did Hashem need to orchestrate all these circumstances through Yosef HaTzaddik, who went down first in order to draw Yaakov Avinu and the holy Shevatim (tribes) there, as explained in the words of our Sages of blessed memory that this was the reason for the sale [of Yosef]. After all, if Hashem had directly commanded him to go down to Egypt with his sons, surely he would not have refrained from fulfilling the command of Hashem Yisbarach (the Blessed One)."
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses Ya'akov's hesitation to descend to Egypt despite hearing that Yosef was alive. The key theological question centers on why Hashem didn't directly command Ya'akov to go to Egypt, instead only reassuring him "don't be afraid," and why Hashem orchestrated the complex series of events with Yosef being sold to bring about this descent. The text highlights the tension between Ya'akov's desire to remain in the Holy Land where the Divine Presence dwells versus descending to an "impure land" among uncircumcised people who lack fear of Heaven, raising deeper questions about divine providence and how Hashem sometimes guides people through indirect means rather than explicit commands.

hebrew_text: ד) במדרש ילקוט פ' עקב עה"פ כי הארץ אשר אתה בא שמה לרשתה לא כארץ מצרים הוא אשר יצאתם משם וגו'. הפריש בין ביאתה של זו לביאתה של זו, ביאת ארץ מצרים רשות וביאת א"י חובה ארץ מצרים בין עושין רצונו של מקום בין שאין עושין רצונו של מקום הרי לכם ארץ מצרים, ארץ ישראל אינו כן, אם אתם עושין רצונו של מקום הרי לכם ארץ כנען ואם לאו אתם גולין מעלי', וכה"א ולא תקיא הארץ אתכם ע"כ. ראוי להבין הכוונה במ"ש ארץ מצרים לכם הוא בין עושין רצונו של מקום ובין שאין עושין.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the religious terminology:

4) In the Midrash Yalkut Parshat Eikev, regarding the verse "For the land which you are entering to possess is not like the land of Egypt from where you came out, etc." It distinguishes between entering this land and entering that land: entering Egypt was optional (reshut) while entering Eretz Yisrael was obligatory (chova). Regarding Egypt - whether they do the will of HaMakom (the Omnipresent/God) or whether they don't do the will of HaMakom - Egypt remains theirs. But Eretz Yisrael is not so - if you do the will of HaMakom, the land of Canaan is yours, and if not, you will be exiled from it, as it is written "and the land will not vomit you out." It is worthy to understand the intention of what was said that Egypt is yours whether you do the will of HaMakom or whether you don't do it.

Note: I've preserved terms like "HaMakom" (a name for God), "Eretz Yisrael" (the Land of Israel), and "reshut" (optional) versus "chova" (obligation) as these are important conceptual terms in Jewish thought.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a Midrash from Yalkut on Parshat Eikev that contrasts the nature of living in Egypt versus living in Eretz Yisrael. The key theological insight is that Egypt remained available to the Jewish people regardless of their spiritual conduct, while dwelling in Eretz Yisrael was contingent upon following God's will. This reflects a fundamental difference in the spiritual nature of these lands - Eretz Yisrael's holiness demands a higher level of religious observance and moral conduct, while Egypt represents a more mundane existence without such spiritual prerequisites. The passage emphasizes the unique covenantal relationship between the Jewish people and Eretz Yisrael, where maintaining the right to dwell in the Holy Land is directly tied to fulfilling God's commandments.

hebrew_text: והנל"פ בהקדם דברי הרבינו בחיי (סו"פ מקץ) עה"פ ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם וז"ל: וע"ד הקבלה מה שנחתמה פרשה זאת בפסוק עלו לשלום אל אביכם זה רמז לעשרה הרוגי מלכות אשר עלו לשלום אל אביהם שבשמים, אחר שנתלבנו ונצרפו מחטאו של יוסף וכו', ומפני זה נחתמה הפרשה ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם, והי' יכול לומר לכו לשלום לדרככם, אבל הפרשה מבוארת באחי יוסף לשעה, ורומזת לעשרה הרוגי מלכות לדורות אשר עלו לשלום אל אביהם שבשמים ע"כ, וצ"ב לפי' הרמז איך קרא יוסף לענין זה של עשרה הרוגי מלכות שלום.

Here's the English translation:

And it can be explained by prefacing the words of Rabbeinu Bachya (end of Parshat Miketz) on the verse "And you, go up in peace to your father." He writes: According to the way of Kabbalah, the reason this portion ends with the verse "go up in peace to your father" is that it alludes to the Ten Martyrs who ascended in peace to their Father in Heaven, after they were purified and refined from the sin related to Joseph, etc. This is why the portion concludes with "and you, go up in peace to your father," when it could have simply said "go in peace on your way." While the portion explicitly deals with Joseph's brothers at that time, it alludes to the Ten Martyrs throughout the generations who ascended in peace to their Father in Heaven. End quote. This requires explanation: according to this allusion, how could Joseph refer to the matter of the Ten Martyrs as "peace"?

Note: I preserved key terms like "Parshat Miketz," "Kabbalah," and "Ten Martyrs" (Aseret Harugei Malchut) as these are specific religious concepts in Jewish tradition.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses Rabbeinu Bachya's kabbalistic interpretation of the verse "go up in peace to your father" from the end of Parshat Miketz. The key insight is that this verse cryptically alludes to the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut), suggesting that their deaths served as an atonement for the sin of selling Joseph. The passage questions why Joseph used the term "peace" (shalom) when referring to something that would ultimately lead to martyrdom, highlighting the deeper theological concept that even apparent tragedy can be part of a divine plan leading to spiritual elevation and reconciliation with "their Father in Heaven."
keywords: קבלה (Kabbalah) ,פרשה (Parasha) ,עשרה הרוגי מלכות (Aseret Harugei Malchut) ,אביהם שבשמים (Avihem SheBaShamayim) ,רמז (Remez) ,נתלבנו (Nitlabnu) ,נצרפו (Nitzrafu) ,חטא (Chet) ,דורות (Dorot) ,שלום (Shalom)

hebrew_text: אמנם יתבאר עפי"מ שהביא הרבינו בחיי בשם פירקי היכלות: כי ר' חנינא בן תרדיון הוחלף בלופינוס קיסר ולופינוס קיסר הוא שנשרף וכן כל השאר, כו כן כתוב שם וכמדה זאת לכל חכמי ישראל, ע"כ בפירקי היכלות. ושמעתי בזה כי כשם שהוחלף יצחק באיל והוקבע לו שכר כאילו הוקרב, וכאילו עפרו צבור ע"ג המזבח, כן הוחלפו חכמי ישראל באחרים, וכיון שטעמו טעם מיתה במה שנתפשו ונגמר דינם לכך, הם קבלו עונשם וה"ז כאילו נהרגו עכלה"ק. והנה דרשו ז"ל בגמרא (קידושין מ"א ע"ב) אתם גם אתם למה לו, סד"א הואיל ואמר מר אתם ולא אריסין אתם ולא שותפין וכו', אימא אתם לא שלוחכם נמי קמ"ל הרי מבואר שתיבת אתם בא למעט אתם ולא שלוחכם, וזה שרמז להם יוס באומרו ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם אתם ולא שלוחכם. שהם יסבלו עונש מר בעשרה הרוגי מלכות, אבל אתם עלו לשלום שלא תסבלו מגזירת המלכות כלום כ"א תשלחו אחרים במקומכם לסבול העונש תחתיכם.
translation:
Here is the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

However, it will be explained according to what Rabbeinu Bachya brought in the name of Pirkei Heichalot: That Rabbi Chanina ben Teradion was exchanged with Lupinus Caesar, and it was Lupinus Caesar who was burned, and so too with all the others. And so it is written there that this measure applied to all the Sages of Israel, thus concludes Pirkei Heichalot. And I heard regarding this that just as Yitzchak was exchanged with the ram and was credited as if he had been sacrificed, and as if his ashes were gathered on the altar, so too the Sages of Israel were exchanged with others. And since they tasted the taste of death when they were seized and their judgment was sealed for this, they received their punishment and it is as if they were killed, end of the holy words.

And behold, our Sages of blessed memory expounded in the Gemara (Kiddushin 41b) why does it say "you, also you"? You might have thought that since the Master said "you" and not sharecroppers, "you" and not partners, etc., I might say "you" and not your agents - therefore it teaches us [otherwise]. It is thus explained that the word "you" comes to exclude "you and not your agents," and this is what Yosef hinted to them when he said "and you go up in peace to your father" - you and not your agents. That they would suffer bitter punishment among the Ten Martyrs, but "you go up in peace" - that you will not suffer anything from the government's decree, rather you will send others in your place to suffer the punishment instead of you.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a profound theological concept regarding martyrdom and divine substitution, drawing from Pirkei Heichalot about Rabbi Chanina ben Teradyon and others. It explains that just as Isaac was substituted with a ram at the Akeidah (and received reward as if he had been sacrificed), similarly certain Jewish sages were substituted with others during times of persecution, though they received the spiritual merit as if they had been martyred. The text then connects this to a Talmudic discussion about agency (shlichut) and the word "atem" (you), suggesting that Joseph's words to his brothers "you go up in peace" hinted that they would be spared from actual martyrdom while others would serve as their substitutes in the future martyrdom of the Ten Martyrs.

hebrew_text: ונקדים דברי ק"ז זלה"ה בישמח משה (פ' וירא) עה"פ ויאמר אברהם אלקים יראה לו השה לעולה בנו, וז"ל: ויל"ד שהוא שני הפכים אם השה לאו בני ואם בני לאו השה, ועו"ק מה יחאה לשון עתיד אלקים ראה לעולה בני ראוי לומר, ולפירוש רש"י נחסרו שנו תיבות ואם לאו" והבן, ועו"ק הא באמת ודע שכבר נבחר יצחק וכי ח"ו שקר ידבר והנ"ל עפי"ד התנחומא (ריש פ' צו) זאת תורת העולה מה עולה שהוא עולה לפני הקב"ה ומכפרת עונותיהם של ישראל, כי בעת שעשה אברהם עולת האיל שנאמר וירא והנה איל אחר, ומהו אחר, שראה הקב"ה שבכל לבבו ובכל נפשו בא להעלות את יצחק בנו לעולה וכו', שם הבטיחו הקב"ה שבעת שיעלו בניו עולות שיקבלם מיד עכ"ל עיי"ש, וביאור הדברים דמאז נצמח דקרבן בהמה מכפרת על אדם, דאבות הקדושים היו פועל דמיוני כמ"ש הרמב"ן בפ' לך. והנה אז היה ממש יצחק לעולה, ואף באיל נכנס נשמתו כנודע, לכן מן אז נחשב הקרבת בהמה כאילו הקריב את עצמו והבן. והיינו מאמר אברהם אלקים יראה לו השה בעתיד כשיהיה קודש לעולה בנו, והבן זה עכלה"ק.

Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Let us preface with the words of his holy grandfather in Yismach Moshe (Parshat Vayeira) on the verse "And Abraham said, 'God will see for Himself the lamb for the offering, my son.'" And these are his words:

We must understand that these are two opposites - if it's the lamb then not my son, and if it's my son then not the lamb. Furthermore, why does it say "will see" in future tense, when it should say "God saw the offering, my son." And according to Rashi's interpretation, two words are missing: "and if not." Also difficult is that in truth he knew that Isaac was already chosen, and would he, God forbid, speak falsely?

The explanation follows the Midrash Tanchuma (beginning of Parshat Tzav): "This is the law of the Olah (burnt offering)" - just as the Olah rises before the Holy One Blessed be He and atones for the sins of Israel. For when Abraham offered the ram as an Olah, as it says "and behold a ram after," what does "after" mean? That the Holy One Blessed be He saw that with all his heart and soul he came to offer Isaac his son as an offering, etc. There, the Holy One Blessed be He promised him that when his children would offer Olot (burnt offerings), He would accept them immediately.

The explanation is that from then on, it was established that an animal sacrifice could atone for a person, as the holy forefathers were creating symbolic actions, as the Ramban writes in Parshat Lech Lecha. And at that time, Isaac was truly meant for the offering, and even in the ram his soul entered, as is known. Therefore, from then on, offering an animal is considered as if one offered oneself, understand this.

This is what Abraham meant when he said "God will see for Himself the lamb" - in the future, when it will be holy - "for the offering, my son." Understand this.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the Akeidas Yitzchak (Binding of Isaac) and explores a profound theological concept about the nature of sacrificial offerings. The key insight is that through Avraham's willingness to sacrifice Yitzchak, and the subsequent substitution of the ram, a spiritual mechanism was established whereby animal sacrifices could serve as atonement for humans. The text explains that the holy Patriarchs created spiritual paradigms, and in this case, Yitzchak's soul became mystically connected with the ram's sacrifice, establishing for all future generations that when one brings an animal sacrifice, it's considered as if they offered themselves. This interpretation resolves the apparent contradiction in Avraham's statement "God will see for Himself the lamb for the offering, my son" by explaining it as a prophetic reference to the future efficacy of sacrificial offerings.
keywords: עולה (Olah) ,נשמה (Neshama) ,קדושים (Kedoshim) ,קרבן (Korban) ,פועל דמיוני (Po'el Dimyoni) ,מכפרת (Mechaperet) ,הקב"ה (HaKadosh Baruch Hu) ,אבות הקדושים (Avot HaKedoshim) ,קודש (Kodesh) ,עונותיהם (Avonoteihem)

hebrew_text: ובחינה זו הי' גם בעשרה הרוגי מלכות עפ"י המבואר בדברי האר"י הק' שנתעבר נשמת הצדיקים בגופות הנענשום בבחינת חילוף ותמורה, ודבר זה מקורו מאילו של יצחק כדברי הוש"מ, דזהו ג"כ בחינת הקרבת הקרבן שנחשב לאדם כאילו הקריב את עצמו, ובזה יובן דברי הילקוט שהקריב יהודה קרבן, ר"ל לפי שאמר להם יוסף ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם, ורמז להם ענין התמורה שלא יסבלו בעצמם את העונש, והוא דוגמת הקרבת הקרבן שהוא תמורת האדם לזה הקריב יהודה קרבן שיוסף לימד אותו ענין זה בדבריו ואתם עלו לשלום וגו', היוצא לנו מזה שמקור הקרבת הקרבנות הוא מיצחק אבינו, שעשה עמו אברהם אביו פועל דמיוני לכל הדורות במה שהקריב תמורתו איל, ולזה הזכיר יעקב אבינו ע"ה בהקרבת הקרבנות את יצחק אביו לעורר בחי' זו, שמקור הקרבנות הוא מיצחק וע"כ ויזבח זבחים לאלקי אביו יצחק' דוקא.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts and terminology:

This aspect was also present in the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut), as explained in the writings of the holy Arizal, that the souls of the tzaddikim were transferred into the bodies of those who were punished, in the aspect of exchange and substitution. This concept originates from the ram of Yitzchak, as explained in the Midrash, which is also the aspect of offering a korban (sacrifice) that is considered as if the person offered himself.

Through this, we can understand the words of the Yalkut that Yehudah offered a korban. This means that when Yosef told them "and you go up in peace to your father," he hinted to them about the concept of substitution - that they would not have to suffer the punishment themselves. This is similar to offering a korban, which serves as a substitute for the person. Therefore, Yehudah offered a korban because Yosef taught him this concept through his words "and you go up in peace, etc."

What emerges from this is that the source of offering korbanot comes from our father Yitzchak, as Avraham his father performed a symbolic act for all generations by offering the ram as his substitute. This is why Yaakov our father, peace be upon him, mentioned his father Yitzchak when offering korbanot, to awaken this aspect - that the source of korbanot is from Yitzchak. Therefore, specifically "he offered sacrifices to the God of his father Yitzchak."
summary:
This passage discusses the deep mystical concept of substitutionary atonement in Jewish thought, connecting several key ideas:

The text explains that the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut) embodied the principle of spiritual substitution, as explained by the Arizal, where righteous souls were transferred into bodies that received punishment as a form of exchange and substitution. This concept is rooted in the binding of Isaac (Akeidat Yitzchak), where the ram was substituted for Isaac, establishing a paradigm for all future sacrificial offerings where the sacrifice is considered as if the person themselves were offered. The passage then connects this to the story of Judah and Joseph, suggesting that Joseph hinted at this concept of substitution when telling his brothers to "go up in peace," and concludes that Isaac is the spiritual source for all sacrificial offerings, which is why Jacob specifically offered sacrifices to "the God of his father Isaac."

hebrew_text: ונל"פ עוד בהקדם לתרץ קושית המפרשים. במ"ש יהודה ליוסף הננו עבדים לאדוני גם אנחנו גם אשר נמצא הגביע בידו, וקיבל עליו את הדין שיהיו כולם עבדים, ואחר שמיאן יוסף בזה ואמר חלילה לו מעשות זאת האיש אשר נמצא הגביע בידו הוא יהיה לו עבד ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם, אז חרה אפו ויגש אליו לדבר קשות עמו, והלא הוא בעצמו הסכים בדבר ותירצו המפרשים גם ק"ז זלה"ה היש"מ תירץ בדרך זה, שמתחלה חשב שהם נתפסים על עון מכירת יוסף. לזאת קיבלו דין שמים באהבה. אבל אחר שראה שאינו תופס חק את בנימין. שהוא לא הוה במכירת יוסף כלל, חשב שאינו עונש מן השמים רק יוסף לצד רוע בחירתו עושה כן. לזה ויגש אליו לדבר עמו קשות.

Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

It appears to us to further explain, by first resolving the question raised by the commentators: Regarding what Yehuda said to Yosef, "We will be slaves to my master - both we and the one in whose possession the goblet was found." He accepted the judgment that they should all be slaves. However, after Yosef refused this and said "Heaven forbid that I should do this; only the man in whose possession the goblet was found shall be my slave, but you may go up in peace to your father," then Yehuda became angry and approached him to speak harshly with him. But hadn't he himself already agreed to this matter?

The commentators explained - and the holy Kedushas Tzion, zichrono livracha, also explained similarly - that initially, Yehuda thought they were being held accountable for the sin of selling Yosef. Therefore, they accepted the Divine judgment (din shamayim) with love. However, when he saw that Yosef was only seizing Binyamin, who had no part whatsoever in the selling of Yosef, he concluded that this was not a punishment from Heaven but rather Yosef acting out of his own poor choice. Therefore, "he approached him to speak harshly."
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a profound theological point regarding the interaction between Yehuda and Yosef over Binyamin's fate. Initially, when Yehuda offered that all the brothers become slaves, he believed they were being divinely punished for selling Yosef, and thus accepted this punishment with love (b'ahava). However, when Yosef insisted that only Binyamin (who was innocent of the original sin of selling Yosef) should become a slave, Yehuda's perspective shifted dramatically - he concluded this couldn't be divine justice but rather Yosef's personal choice (b'chirah), which is why he then approached Yosef confrontationally. This passage illustrates the Hasidic concept of discerning between divine judgment (din shamayim) and human free will, and demonstrates how accepting suffering depends on understanding its source.

hebrew_text: ונ"ל לתרץ באופן אחר קצת, דהנה השבטים הק' ידעו שעליהם להשלים החוב גזירת ידוע תדע כי גר יהיה זרעך וגו', שנאמר לאברהם בברית בין הבתרים, ע"כ מתחלה חשבו שעכשיו הוא התחלת זמן הגלות וקבלו על עצמם הגזירה באהבה, אולם כשאמר להם ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם הבינו שעדיין אינו התחלת השעבוד, ורק הוא מעצמו תופס את בנימין, ע"כ ויגש אליו יהודה וגו'. ובזה מדוייק לשון הפסוק סו"פ מקץ ויאמר גם עתה כדבריכם כן הוא וגו', דלכאורה הלשון גם עתה אינו מובן בפשטות, ולדברינו רמז להם שהדין עמהם שמיד הוא התחלת זמן הגלות במצרים, וז"פ גם עתה ר"ל מיד כדבריכם כן הוא שאתם חושבין שעכשיו מתחלת זמן הגלות, אבל חלילה לי מעשות זאת שאשתעבד בכם רק עלו עכשיו לשלום אל אביכם, ומן השמים יזמינו סיבה שתבואו לכאן לסבול עול הגלות.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts and terminology:

It seems to me to explain in a slightly different way: The holy tribes knew that they had to fulfill the debt of the decree "You shall surely know that your seed will be strangers [in a land not theirs]" which was told to Abraham at the Covenant Between the Parts (Bris Bein HaBesarim). Therefore, initially they thought that now was the beginning of the time of exile, and they accepted the decree upon themselves with love.

However, when he [Joseph] told them "Go up in peace to your father," they understood that it was not yet the beginning of the servitude, and that he was only seizing Benjamin on his own accord. Therefore, "Judah approached him, etc."

This explains precisely the language of the verse at the end of Parshas Miketz, "And he said, 'Now also according to your words, so it is...'" For seemingly, the phrase "now also" is not readily understood in its simple meaning. According to our explanation, he was hinting to them that they were correct that this was immediately the beginning of the Egyptian exile. This is the meaning of "now also" - meaning immediately "according to your words, so it is" - that you think that now the time of exile is beginning. But "God forbid that I should do this" to enslave you; rather, "go up now in peace to your father," and Heaven will arrange circumstances that will bring you here to bear the yoke of exile.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the theological understanding of the Egyptian exile's beginning, focusing on the interaction between Joseph and his brothers. The key insight is that the tribes (brothers) initially believed their encounter with Joseph marked the beginning of the prophesied exile that was foretold to Abraham in the Covenant Between the Parts (ברית בין הבתרים). However, when Joseph told them to "go up in peace to your father," they realized this wasn't yet the divinely ordained beginning of the exile, but rather Joseph's personal action against Benjamin. The passage emphasizes that the actual exile would begin through divine orchestration rather than through Joseph's individual actions, highlighting the distinction between human agency and divine providence in the unfolding of Jewish history.
keywords: גזירה (Gezeirah) ,ברית בין הבתרים (Brit Bein HaBetarim) ,גלות (Galut) ,שעבוד (Shi'abud) ,מן השמים (Min HaShamayim) ,השבטים הק' (HaShevatim HaKedoshim) ,באהבה (B'Ahavah) ,חוב (Chov) ,זרעך (Zar'echa) ,סיבה (Sibah)

hebrew_text: והנה הרמב"ן הק' כתב עה"פ ויזבח זבחים לאלקי אביו יצחק, וז"ל: הפסוק הזה יש בו סוד, יגלו לנו אותו שם בב"ר, כי כאשר בא יעקב לרדת למצרים ראה כי הגלות יתחיל בו ובזרעו ופחד ממנו, וזבח זבחים רבים לפחד אביו יצחק. שלא תהא מדת הדין מתוחה כנגדו וכו', והנה בזכות הקרבנות נראה אליו אלקי יצחק אביו במראות הלילה במדת הדין רפה וכו', והבטיחו שלא יירא במצרים, כי יזכה בדינו ויגאל אחר העינוי וכו' עכלה"ק, ומזה הטעם עצמו אחר שאמר להם יוסף גם עתה כדבריכם כן הוא, שעתה הוא התחלת זמן הגלות, לזה ויגש אליו שהקריב קרבן להמתיק בחינת הגלות שלא יהיה מדת הדין מתוחה לגנדם ע"ד שעשה יעקב אבינו בבאר שבע שהקריב קרבנות לטעם זה.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

The holy Ramban wrote on the verse "And he offered sacrifices to the G-d of his father Isaac" [explaining]: This verse contains a secret, which is revealed to us in Bereishit Rabbah. When Yaakov was about to descend to Egypt, he saw that the exile would begin with him and his descendants, and he feared it. Therefore, he offered many sacrifices to the 'Pachad' (attribute of fear/judgment) of his father Yitzchak, so that the attribute of strict judgment (Midat HaDin) would not be stretched out against him.

And behold, in the merit of these sacrifices, the G-d of his father Yitzchak appeared to him in night visions with a softened attribute of judgment, and assured him not to fear in Egypt, for he would merit [favorable] judgment and would be redeemed after the affliction.

For this same reason, after Yosef told them "Now too, as you say, so it is" - which marked the beginning of the exile period - "Vayigash eilav" (he approached him) means that [Yehuda] offered a sacrifice to sweeten the aspect of exile, so that the attribute of strict judgment would not be stretched out against them, just as our father Yaakov had done in Be'er Sheva when he offered sacrifices for this reason.
summary: This passage discusses a profound theological insight from Ramban's commentary on Jacob's sacrifices before descending to Egypt. The key concept is that Jacob, recognizing that the Egyptian exile was about to begin with him and his descendants, offered sacrifices specifically to "Pachad Yitzchak" (the Fear of Isaac, representing God's attribute of judgment) to mitigate the harshness of divine judgment during the upcoming exile. The text draws a parallel between Jacob's actions and Judah's approach to Joseph, suggesting that Judah similarly offered a spiritual sacrifice to sweeten the decree of exile, following the pattern established by Jacob in Beersheba. This teaching emphasizes the Hasidic concept of "hamtakat hadinim" (sweetening of harsh judgments) through spiritual service and sacrifice.

hebrew_text: ואפשר לומר הטעם שלא צוהו הקב"ה בפירוש ליעקב אבינו ע"ה שירד למצרים. דהנה רצה הקב"ה שיסבול יעקב אבינו במצרים עול גלות, ואם הוה הקב"ה מצוהו על ככה, הרי היה מקיים בזה מצות הבוב"ה, ואז לא היה נחשב לגלות אצל יעקב אבינו כי כל העולם כולו לא היה נחשב לכלום אצל יעקב אבינו נגד קיום מצוה אחת ממצות השי"ת, והיה עושה הדבר בשמחה רבה לקיים רצון הבורא ב"ה, משא"כ עכשיו שלא צוהו הקב"ה על ככה, והיה צריך לירד למצרים מעצמו. היה נחשב בעיניו לגלות מה שהוצרך לצאת מארץ ישראל לארץ טמאה מקום שאין שם יראת שמים. עד שהוצרך הקב"ה להבטיחו אל תירא מרדה מצרימה אנכי ארד עמך מצרימה וגו'.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

It is possible to explain the reason why HaKadosh Baruch Hu (the Holy One, Blessed be He) did not explicitly command Yaakov Avinu (our father Jacob), peace be upon him, to go down to Egypt. For HaKadosh Baruch Hu wanted Yaakov Avinu to endure the burden of exile (galus) in Egypt. Had HaKadosh Baruch Hu commanded him to do so, it would have been a fulfillment of Hashem's commandment, and then it would not have been considered exile for Yaakov Avinu, because the entire world meant nothing to Yaakov Avinu compared to fulfilling even a single mitzvah of Hashem Yisbarach (the Blessed Creator). He would have done it with great joy to fulfill the will of the Creator, blessed be He.

However, now that HaKadosh Baruch Hu did not command him to do so, and he had to go down to Egypt on his own, it was considered in his eyes as exile - having to leave Eretz Yisrael for an impure land, a place where there was no fear of Heaven (yiras shamayim). This was to such an extent that HaKadosh Baruch Hu had to reassure him, "Fear not to go down to Egypt, for I will go down with you to Egypt, etc."
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses why God didn't explicitly command Jacob to go down to Egypt. The key theological insight is that had God directly commanded Jacob, the descent wouldn't have truly felt like exile (galut) to him, since Jacob would have joyfully fulfilled it as a divine commandment, and for Jacob, fulfilling God's mitzvot superseded all worldly difficulties. By not making it an explicit command, Jacob had to go down to Egypt on his own accord, making it a genuine experience of exile - leaving the Holy Land for an impure place lacking fear of Heaven - which is why God needed to reassure him with the promise "Fear not to go down to Egypt, for I will go down with you." This interpretation reveals a profound understanding of how divine service through commandments can transform the nature of hardship, and why sometimes God specifically withholds direct commands to achieve certain spiritual purposes.
