hebrew_text: ונקדים דברי האוה"ח הק' עה"פ אנכי ארד עמך מצרימה וז"ל: מהכתוב משמע כי ירדה עמו שכינה, וקשה לדבריהם ז"ל שאמרו כי מצרים להיותה מלאה גילולים לא היתה שכינה שם וכו', אכן אשכולך כי הדרגת אור השכינה רבים המה, הלא תמצא שעשרה שיושבים ועוסקים בתורה שכינה שרויה ביניהם, ואפילו ב' ואחד אמרו ז"ל כו מצויה שכינה, ומצינו שלא ירדה שכינה ביניהם של ישראל. אלא אחר שעשו משכן ואחר כמה הכנות האמורים וכו'. אלא וודאי יש הדרגות אין מספר להשראת שכינה, בסוד כי גבוה מעל גבוה שומר וכו' עכ"ל. ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש ילקוט הנ"ל כי ארץ מצרים בין עושין רצונו של מקום ובין אין עושין רצונו של מקום הרי לכם ארץ מצרים, פי' שהשראת השכינה שירדה עם ישראל למצרים, אינה מסתלקת משם בין עושין רצונו של מקום ובין אין עושין רצונו של מקום כי בחינה זו של השראת השכינה שיש עם ישראל בגלותם, יש עמהם גם בהסתר היותר גדול, משא"כ בחי' השראת השכינה בארץ ישראל שהוא גילוי שכינתו ית"ש. ע"ד שהיה בבית המקדש, זה הוא דוקא כשישראל עושין רצונו של מקום ואם לאו ח"ו אתם גולין מעלי' כמאמר הכתוב לא תקיא הארץ אתכם. והנה חכמינו ז"ל דרשו עה"פ ואנכי אעלך גם עלה אעלך בגלות זה, גם עלה בגליות אחרות, שמאז הבטיחנו הקב"ה לגאול אותנו מן הגליות וגם גלות זה בכלל, ויעזור הקב"ה שיקויים במהרה הבטחה זו של גם עלה, ובמהרה נזכה לראות בישועת כל ישראל ושמחתן בנחת ובשמחה ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Let us preface with the words of the Or HaChaim HaKadosh on the verse "I will go down with you to Egypt." He writes: From the verse it implies that the Shechinah (Divine Presence) descended with him, but this is difficult according to our Sages who said that Egypt, being full of idols, did not have the Shechinah there. However, I will tell you that there are many levels of the light of the Shechinah. We find that when ten people sit and engage in Torah, the Shechinah dwells among them, and even with two or one person, our Sages said the Shechinah is present. Yet we find that the Shechinah did not descend among Israel until after they built the Mishkan (Tabernacle) and after several preparations. Rather, certainly there are countless levels of the dwelling of the Shechinah, in the secret of "for one higher than the high watches."

This explains the words of the Midrash Yalkut mentioned above that regarding Egypt, "whether they do the will of Hashem or not, behold Egypt is yours." This means that the dwelling of the Shechinah that descended with Israel to Egypt does not depart from there whether they do Hashem's will or not, because this level of the Shechinah's presence that accompanies Israel in their exile remains with them even in the greatest concealment. This is unlike the dwelling of the Shechinah in Eretz Yisrael, which is a revelation of His blessed Presence, as it was in the Beis HaMikdash (Holy Temple). This only occurs when Israel does the will of Hashem; if not, Heaven forbid, "you will be exiled from it," as the verse states, "the land will not vomit you out."

Our Sages interpreted the verse "And I will surely bring you up" to refer to this exile, and "surely bring you up" to refer to other exiles, for from then Hashem promised to redeem us from the exiles, including this exile. May Hashem help fulfill this promise of "surely bring you up" speedily, and may we merit to see the salvation of all Israel and their joy with comfort and happiness, and the revelation of Heaven's glory upon us, speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the complex nature of Divine presence (Shechina) in exile, particularly in Egypt. Based on the Or HaChaim's commentary, it explains that there are multiple levels of Divine presence - while the highest level of Shechina was reserved for the Holy Temple in Israel when the Jews were following God's will, a different, more concealed level of Divine presence accompanies the Jewish people even in exile and impure places like Egypt. The text emphasizes that this "exilic" level of Divine presence remains with Israel regardless of their spiritual state ("whether they do God's will or not"), unlike the more revealed presence in the Land of Israel which was conditional on their behavior. The passage concludes with a message of hope, interpreting God's promise to Jacob "I will surely bring you up" as applying to all future exiles, including our current one, anticipating the final redemption.

hebrew_text: ש באופן אחר יתבאר דברי המדרש הנ"ל אין ויגש אלא קרבן בהקדם דברי הרמב"ם ז"ל בספר המורה (הביאו הרמב"ן ז"ל בפרשת ויקרא), כי טעם הקרבנות בעבור שהמצריים והכשדים אשר היו ישראל גרים ותושבים בארצם, מעולם היו עובדים לבקר ולצאן וכו' בעבור כן צוה לשחוט אלו הג' מינין לשם הנכבד, כדי שיוודע כי הדבר שהיו חושבים בו כי הם בתכלית העבודה, הוא ואשר יקריבו לבורא ובו יתכפרו העוונות, כי כן יתרפאו האמונות הרעות שהם מדוי הנפש, כו כל מדוי וכל חולי לא יתרפאו כו אם בהפכן, אלו דבריו ז"ל, והרמב"ן ז"ל הקשה על דבריו, דלפי שטותם של מצרים לא תתרפא מחלתם בזה אבל תוסיף מכאוב, כו מחשבת הרשעים הנזכרים לעבוד למזל טלה ומזל ושור שיש להם כח בהם כפי מחשבתם ולכן לא יאכלו אותם לכבוד כוחם ויסודם, אבל אם יזבחו אותם לשם הנכבד זה כבוד להם ומעלה, והם עצמם כך הם נוהגים וכו', ויותר תתרפא המחלה באכלינו מהם לשובע, שהוא אסור להם ומגונה בעיניהם ולא יעשו כן לעולם, עייש"ד שהאריך לסתור דעת הרמב"ם ז"ל.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the religious terminology:

Another explanation of the aforementioned Midrash "Ein Vayigash ela korban" (Vayigash only means sacrifice) can be understood by first considering the words of the Rambam z"l in Moreh Nevuchim (quoted by the Ramban z"l in Parshat Vayikra). The reason for the korbanos (sacrifices) was because the Egyptians and Chaldeans, in whose lands the Israelites dwelled as strangers and residents, had always worshipped cattle and sheep, etc. Therefore, Hashem commanded to slaughter these three species for His Holy Name, so that it would become known that the very thing they considered the ultimate form of worship would be that which we offer to the Creator and through which sins would be atoned. For thus are evil beliefs, which are ailments of the soul, healed, as all ailments and sicknesses are only healed through their opposite.

These are his words, z"l. The Ramban z"l challenged his position, arguing that according to the Egyptian's foolish beliefs, this wouldn't heal their illness but would rather increase their pain. For the thought of these mentioned wicked ones was to worship the zodiac sign of the lamb and ox, believing they had power in them, and therefore they wouldn't eat them out of respect for their power and essence. But if they would sacrifice them to Hashem's Holy Name, this would be an honor and elevation for these beings, and this is how they themselves practiced. The illness would be better healed by our eating them to satisfaction, which was forbidden and disgraceful in their eyes, and something they would never do. See there where he elaborates at length to refute the opinion of the Rambam z"l.
summary: This passage discusses a fundamental debate between the Rambam (Maimonides) and Ramban (Nachmanides) regarding the purpose of sacrificial offerings (korbanot). The Rambam suggests that God commanded sacrifices of cattle and sheep specifically because these animals were worshipped by the Egyptians and Chaldeans - the idea being to heal the Israelites from false beliefs by having them sacrifice what was previously considered divine to the one true God. The Ramban strongly criticizes this view, arguing that sacrificing these animals would actually reinforce Egyptian beliefs rather than counter them, since the Egyptians themselves offered such sacrifices to their deities; he suggests that eating these animals would be a more effective rejection of Egyptian worship since that was strictly forbidden in their culture. This debate reflects a deeper theological discussion about whether Divine commandments are primarily meant to counter idolatrous practices (Rambam's view) or have inherent spiritual significance independent of historical context (Ramban's view).

hebrew_text: ובאמת שכדעת הרמב"ם ז"ל מבואר בדברי חכז"ל (במד"ר פרשת בא) משכו וקחו לכם צאן הה"ד (תהלים צ"ב) יבושו כל עובדי פסל. בשעה שאמר הקב"ה למשה לשחוט הפסח, א"ל משה רבון העולם הדבר הזה האיך אני יכול לעשות, אי אתה יודע שהצאן אלהיהן של מצרים הן, שנאמר הן נזבח את תועבת מצרים לעיניהם ולא יסקלניג א"ל הקב"ה חייך אין ישראל יוצאין מכאן עד שישחטו אלהי מצרים לעיניהם, שאודיע להם שאין אלהי העכו"ם כלום וכו' ע"כ, מבואר כדעת הרמב"ם ז"ל שהטעם לשחיטת קרבן פסח הוא להודיע שאין ממש בע"ז כלום, ודחיית הרמב"ן ז"ל לא קשה, דהרי מצינו שאמר הכתוב כו לא יוכלון המצרים לאכול את העברים לחם כי תועבה הוא למצרים, ופי' בתרגום אונקלוס ארי בעירא דמצראי דחלין לי' עבראי אכלין, הרי שלא חרה אפם של המצריים על אכילת תועבותם עד כדי שיסקלו אותם בשבילה, רק שלא יכלו לאכול עם העברים כי תועבה הוא להם, משא"כ כשצוה הקב"ה לשחוט הטלה לשם קרבן פסח, כתיב הן נזבח וגו' ולא וסקלונו, מבואר שהוא ביטול יותר גדול אצליהם מאם שוחטין ואוכלין מהם לשובע, וסרה קושית הרמב"ן ז"ל שיותר תתרפא המחלה באכלינו מהם לשובע, עכ"פ מכל אלו הראיות מבואר כשיטת הרמב"ם ז"ל.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the religious terminology:

In truth, according to the opinion of the Rambam z"l, it is explained in the words of our Sages (Midrash Rabbah, Parshat Bo) regarding "Draw out and take for yourselves sheep," as it is written (Psalms 92), "All workers of idols shall be ashamed." When HaKadosh Baruch Hu told Moshe to slaughter the Pesach offering, Moshe said to Him, "Master of the Universe, how can I do this thing? Don't You know that sheep are the gods of Egypt, as it is said 'Will we not be stoned if we sacrifice the abomination of Egypt before their eyes?'" HaKadosh Baruch Hu replied, "By your life, Israel will not leave here until they slaughter the gods of Egypt before their eyes, so that I may make known to them that the gods of idolaters are nothing, etc."

This clearly supports the Rambam's z"l view that the reason for slaughtering the Pesach offering was to demonstrate that there is no substance to avodah zarah (idolatry). The Ramban's z"l objection is not difficult, for we find that Scripture states, "The Egyptians could not eat bread with the Hebrews, for it is an abomination to Egypt." Onkelos translates this as "because the animals that the Egyptians worship, the Hebrews eat." This shows that the Egyptians' anger over eating their sacred animals was not so severe that they would stone them for it; rather, they simply couldn't eat with the Hebrews because it was an abomination to them.

However, when HaKadosh Baruch Hu commanded to slaughter the lamb as a Pesach offering, it states "Will we not sacrifice... and they will stone us," showing that this was a greater nullification in their eyes than merely slaughtering and eating for sustenance. This resolves the Ramban's z"l question about how the illness would be better cured by eating them for satisfaction. In any case, from all these proofs, the Rambam's z"l position is clearly supported.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the deeper meaning behind the Korban Pesach (Paschal sacrifice) in Egypt, focusing on the debate between Rambam and Ramban. The text supports Rambam's view that the primary purpose of sacrificing the lamb was to demonstrate the powerlessness of Egyptian idolatry by having the Israelites publicly slaughter an animal the Egyptians considered divine. The passage makes a subtle distinction between merely eating an animal (which the Egyptians found distasteful but tolerable) versus sacrificing it as part of divine worship (which was a more profound rejection of Egyptian beliefs). This interpretation emphasizes how the Korban Pesach served as both a theological statement against idolatry and a demonstration of the Jewish people's complete faith in the one true God.

hebrew_text: והנה יהודה סבור היה שכבר הגיע קוצם של מצרים ליאבד מן העולם, וכדאיתא במדרש ילקוט שאמר יהודה לנפתלי קפוץ וראה כמה שווקים יש במצרים, קפץ וראה ואמר י"ב שווקים, אמר כל אחד ואחד יחריב שלו ואני אחריב שלשה. ומבואר בדברי המדרש הנ"ל שלא היו ישראל יכולין לצאת ממצרים עד שישחטו אלהי מצרים לעיניהם לשם קרבן, ולפי שחשב יהודה לחרוב את מצרים ע"כ רצה להקריב קרבן, כדרך שצוה השי"ת לישראל בעת צאתם ממצרים כדו לבטל כוחם של המצריים, וז"פ המדרש ויגש אליו יהודה שנגש למלחמה עם יוסף וחשב להחריב את כל מצרים, ע"כ ניגש להקריב קרבן כמו שהקריבו ישראל בעת צאתם ממצרים, ובזה יתבאר שיטת ר' נחמי' אין ויגש אלא לשון קרבן.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Yehudah thought that the time had come for Mitzrayim (Egypt) to be destroyed from the world, as it is brought in the Midrash Yalkut that Yehudah said to Naftali, "Jump and see how many marketplaces there are in Mitzrayim." He jumped and saw and said, "There are twelve marketplaces." [Yehudah] said, "Each one [of the brothers] will destroy his own [marketplace], and I will destroy three."

It is explained in the words of the aforementioned Midrash that the Yisrael could not leave Mitzrayim until they would slaughter the gods of Mitzrayim before their eyes as a korban (sacrifice). Since Yehudah thought to destroy Mitzrayim, he therefore wanted to bring a korban, just as Hashem commanded Yisrael at the time of their exodus from Mitzrayim in order to nullify the power of the Mitzrim (Egyptians).

This is the simple explanation of the Midrash "Vayigash eilav Yehudah" (And Yehudah approached him) - that he approached for war with Yosef and thought to destroy all of Mitzrayim. Therefore, he approached to bring a korban just as Yisrael brought [korbanos] at the time of their exodus from Mitzrayim. This explains Rabbi Nechemiah's position that the word "Vayigash" only refers to [bringing] a korban.
summary:
Here's a summary of the key theological concepts from this passage:

The text discusses Yehuda's approach to confronting Egypt, centered on the spiritual significance of sacrifice (korban) as a means of nullifying idolatrous powers. According to the Midrash cited, Yehuda believed Egypt's time of destruction had come and planned to destroy their marketplaces, but more importantly, understood that Israel's redemption required sacrificing Egypt's deities before their eyes - a profound act of spiritual warfare. The passage connects Yehuda's "approaching" (vayigash) to Joseph with the concept of offering a sacrifice, similar to how the Israelites would later need to sacrifice the Pascal lamb before leaving Egypt, demonstrating that physical liberation required first breaking the spiritual forces of Egypt through sacred ritual.

hebrew_text: סי ויגש אליו יהודה ויאמר בי אדוני וגו', ואל יחר אפך בעבדך כי כמוך כפרעה. פרש"י ז"ל חשוב אתה בעיני כמלך, זהו פשוטו. ומדרשו סופך ללקות עליו בצרעת כמו שלקה פרעה וכו' עכ"ל, ויל"ד דלכאורה לפי"ד המדרש הרי סתר דבריו הראשונים מני' וביה, שהתחיל לומר בי אדוני וגו' ואל יחר אפך בעבדך, ומיד בתוך כדי דיבור א"ל סופך ללקות וכו' ובודאי ראוי שיחר אפו עליו על אלו הדברים.
translation:
Here's the translation of the text from Sefer Divrey Yoel:

"[Regarding the verse] 'Then Judah approached him and said: Please, my lord,' etc., 'and let not your anger burn against your servant, for you are like Pharaoh.' Rashi of blessed memory explains: 'You are as important in my eyes as a king' - this is the simple meaning. And its midrashic interpretation is 'you will eventually be afflicted with tzara'at (spiritual leprosy) just as Pharaoh was afflicted,' etc.

One must examine this carefully, for according to the words of the Midrash, it appears that he [Judah] contradicted his own words immediately, as he began by saying 'Please, my lord,' etc., and 'let not your anger burn against your servant,' yet within the same breath he tells him 'you will eventually be afflicted,' etc. Surely such words would justify anger against him."

Note: I've preserved Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "tzara'at" and maintained the analytical style characteristic of Hasidic discourse. The text is discussing the apparent contradiction between Judah's respectful approach to Joseph and the seemingly threatening undertone in his words according to the midrashic interpretation.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the encounter between Judah and Joseph, focusing on Judah's statement "Please my lord... let not your anger burn against your servant, for you are like Pharaoh." The text explores an apparent contradiction between Rashi's two interpretations: the simple meaning (that Joseph is as important as a king) and the midrashic meaning (that Joseph will be afflicted with tzara'at/leprosy like Pharaoh was). The key theological tension highlighted is how Judah could simultaneously show deference to Joseph while also delivering what appears to be a veiled threat or negative prophecy, seemingly undermining his own expressed humility and respect.

hebrew_text: ב) במד"ר כתיב תפוחי זהב במשכיות כסף דבר דיבור על אופניו, מה אופן זה מראה פנים לכל צד, כך היו דבריו של יהודה נראים לכל צד בשעה שדבר עם יוסף, ופי' בנזה"ק שהיו דבריו נראים לפיוס ודרך רצוי ע"ד פשוטם. כמ"ש כי כמוך כפרעה חשוב אתה בעיני כמלך, גם הוכיחו בדברים קשים כדרשתם ז"ל סופך ללקות וכו' עכת"ד. אמנם צ"ב, דממנ"פ מה הי' דעתו של יהודה בזה, אם יבין יוסף הרמז שבדבריו, א"כ בודאי יחר אפו, ומה הועיל במ"ש ואל יחר אפך וגו', ואם לא יבין הרמז א"כ מה תועלתו
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

In the Midrash Rabbah it is written: "Like golden apples in silver settings is a word spoken in its proper place." Just as a wheel shows faces in every direction, so too were Yehudah's words apparent in every direction when he spoke with Yosef. The Nezha"k explains that his words appeared as appeasement and conciliation according to their simple meaning. As it is written "for you are like Pharaoh" - meaning you are as important as a king in my eyes. He also rebuked him with harsh words, as our Sages interpreted: "you will ultimately be punished," etc.

However, this requires explanation: What exactly was Yehudah's intention in this? If Yosef would understand the hint in his words, then surely he would become angry, so what benefit was there in saying "let not your anger flare up"? And if Yosef would not understand the hint, then what was its purpose?

Note: I've preserved terms like Midrash Rabbah (מד"ר) and maintained the questioning style characteristic of Hasidic texts, while keeping the essential meaning intact.
summary:
This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the Midrash's interpretation of "golden apples in silver settings" in relation to Yehuda's conversation with Yosef. The key insight revolves around the dual nature of Yehuda's words, which like a wheel, showed different faces in different directions - containing both respectful appeasement ("you are like Pharaoh") and subtle rebuke. The text raises an important theological tension: if Yosef understood the hidden rebuke in Yehuda's words, wouldn't it defeat the purpose of the appeasement, and if he didn't understand it, what was the purpose of including it? This paradox reflects a deeper Hasidic concept about the multi-layered nature of holy speech and the complexity of righteous communication.

Note: I aim to be respectful in discussing sacred texts and acknowledge that deeper interpretations may exist beyond this basic summary.

hebrew_text: ג) ויאמר יוסף אל אחיו אני יוסף העוד אבי חי ולא יכלו אחיו לענות אותו כי נבהלו מפניו. הקשו המפרשים דכבר הודיעוהו שאביהם חי. וזה הי' כל טענתם עבור בנימין להשיבו לידם עבור חמלתו על אביהם, כמ"ש נפשו קשורה בנפשו וגו' כי איך אעלה אל אבי וגו'. ומדוע בתוך כדי דיבור שאלוהו עוה"פ העוד אבי חי, וצ"ב. גם לא מצינו שהשיבו על שאלה זו, גם יוסף לא דרש מאתם תשובה, אבל אמר להם מהרו ועלו אל אבי וגו', וממה נפשך אם ידע בנפשי' שאביו חי. מדוע שאלם ללא צורך, גם צ"ב הקישור אני יוסף העוד אבי חי.
translation:
Here's the English translation:

"And Joseph said to his brothers, 'I am Joseph. Is my father still alive?' But his brothers could not answer him because they were frightened before him."

The commentators asked: They had already informed him that their father was alive. This was their entire argument regarding Benjamin, to return him to them because of [Joseph's presumed] compassion for their father, as it is written "his soul is bound up with his soul" etc., "for how can I go up to my father" etc. So why, in the midst of speaking, did he ask them again "Is my father still alive?" This requires explanation.

Also, we don't find that they answered this question, nor did Joseph demand an answer from them. Instead, he told them "Hurry and go up to my father" etc. And this presents a dilemma: if he knew in his heart that his father was alive, why did he ask them unnecessarily? Also requiring explanation is the connection between "I am Joseph" and "Is my father still alive?"

[Note: I've preserved Hebrew/Jewish terms like "Joseph" (Yosef) and maintained the analytical style typical of Hasidic commentary. The text discusses the biblical scene of Joseph revealing himself to his brothers in Egypt and analyzes the seeming redundancy and peculiarity of his questioning about his father Jacob's well-being.]
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the dramatic moment when Joseph reveals himself to his brothers and immediately asks if his father is still alive, despite already knowing this information from their previous conversations. The text raises a fundamental question about why Joseph would ask about his father's wellbeing when he was already aware of it, and why this question is connected to his self-revelation ("I am Joseph"). The deeper theological insight appears to be about the nature of authentic spiritual identity and relationship - suggesting that when Joseph finally revealed his true self ("I am Joseph"), he needed to reestablish his connection to his father Jacob in a new, more direct and personal way, transcending his previous knowledge that came through his brothers' indirect reports.

hebrew_text: ונר"פ בהקדם דברי ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה (בפרשת לך) לפרש אמרם ז"ל (ברכות ו' ע"ב) בשבתך בביתך פרט לעוסק במצוה (דפטור מקריאת שמע) מאי משמע בשבת דידך ובלכת דידך הוא דמחייבת, הא דמצוה פטירת עכ"ד הגמרא. לכאורה קשה דנראה נחה דצורכי הגוף הוי שלו, משא"כ דבר מצוה ואדרבה נהפוך הוא לפי האמת וכו', דזה שיש לו אינו שלו משא"כ צורכי הנפש הוא שלו לעדי עד, וקנו למעלה במקום שאין היד שולטת בו וא"כ אדרבה זאת נקרא הליכתו. גם צ"ב במ"ש בגמרא שם מעשה בר"ג שנשא אשה וקרא וכו', האיך החמיר ר"ג על עצמו, במה שפטרתו תורה להדיא, ואין בו שום חולק, והלא על כזה אמרינן דהפטור מן הדבר ועושהו נקרא הדיוט וכו', ותוכן דבריו לתרץ דודאי ר"ג כדין עבד, דהנה בכל אופן אינו יוצא מרכז התורה ממרכז האמת. כי הנה יש בנ"א שהם בעלי הנפש ונפשם עיקר והם בני עליה, משא"כ ההמון הם בעלי חומר ומלאכתם עיקר אצלם יקרא צורכי הגוף צורכם וכו'. משא"כ צורכי הנפש ולהיפך בבעלי הנפש וכו', וא"כ מדבר לכל א' לפי מדריגתו כפי האמת, והיינו בלשון בני אדם והבן.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Let us explain by first considering the words of my holy grandfather, the Yismach Moshe of blessed memory (in Parshat Lech Lecha), who explains the saying of our Sages (Berachot 6b) regarding "when you sit in your house" - excluding one who is engaged in a mitzvah (who is exempt from reciting the Shema). What is the textual basis? "Your sitting" and "your walking" - these are what obligate you, but when involved in a mitzvah matter, you are exempt - thus concludes the Gemara.

At first glance this is difficult, as it appears to suggest that bodily needs are considered "yours," whereas matters of mitzvot are not - but in truth it should be the opposite. For that which one has [materially] is not truly his, whereas spiritual needs are his eternally, acquired in a higher realm where physical hands have no control. If so, this should be called "his walking."

Also requiring explanation is the Gemara's account of Rabban Gamliel who married a woman and recited [Shema] - how could Rabban Gamliel be stringent upon himself in a matter from which the Torah explicitly exempted him, about which there is no dispute? Isn't it said about such cases that one who is exempt from something but does it anyway is called a hedyot (simpleton)?

The essence of his answer is that certainly Rabban Gamliel acted properly, for in any case one does not depart from the center point of Torah, from the center of truth. For there are people who are ba'alei hanefesh (spiritually oriented), for whom the soul is primary - these are the elevated ones. In contrast, the masses are ba'alei chomer (materially oriented), for whom their work is primary, and physical needs are considered their true needs. The opposite is true for the spiritually oriented regarding spiritual needs. Thus, the Torah speaks to each person according to their level, in accordance with truth - that is, in the language of people - understand this.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a complex interpretation of the Talmudic principle regarding exemption from Kriat Shema while engaged in another mitzvah. The key insight revolves around the Yismach Moshe's explanation of what constitutes "your" activities versus mitzvah activities, suggesting that for elevated souls (ba'alei hanefesh), spiritual pursuits are actually more essentially "theirs" than physical needs, while for ordinary people (hamon ha'am), physical pursuits feel more natural and personal. The text uses Rabban Gamliel's case of reading Shema while being a newlywed to illustrate how the Torah speaks differently to people at different spiritual levels, teaching that what counts as "your way" (belechtecha b'derech) depends on one's spiritual status. This represents a classic Hasidic interpretation that reads multiple spiritual levels into halachic texts while emphasizing the importance of serving God according to one's individual spiritual capacity.

hebrew_text: וכעין בחי' זו ביאר להלן (פ' תשא) על מה דפסק הרמ"א ז"ל (יו"ד סימן קי"ז) דאם הוא אדם גדול וחסיד ויר"ש, כ"ע מודי דרשאי למסור עצמו עקידה"ש אפילו על מצוה קלה, ולכאורה יש להפליא. הכו בשביל שהוא חסיד ויר"ש ישתנה דינו, הלא כתיב וחי בהם, ונל"פ דהאי וחי בהם יש לפרשו על שני פנים, א' כפירוש דרז"ל ולא שימות בהם, ב' שכל חיותו יהיה בתוה"ק ובמצות וכו', וזולתן לא יהיה לו שום חיות בעולם, וכ"כ יהי' דבוק ונתעצם עם התורה והעבודה והמצות, עד שאם ירצו להעבירהו על א' ממצות ד' יפסק חיותו. וא"כ לפי זה הוא להיפך דרשאי למסור נפשו על כל המצות, ואדרבה מצווה על כך וכו', וא"כ אצל ההמונים אשר כל עסקם בעניני העולם וכו', יהיה פי' הפסוק הנ"ל כפשוטו, ולא שימות בהם כפי' הגמרא, אמנם כן אצל הצדיקים הדבקים בו ית"ש תמיד וכו', עד שעיקר חיותם רק בתוה"ק, באלו יתכן כפירוש הב', וממילא מחוייבים למסור נפשם על כל המצות, כי הן המה חיותם ממש את"ד ז"ל,
translation:

Similar to this concept, he explained later (in Parshat Ki Tisa) regarding what the Rama z"l ruled (Yoreh Deah 117) that if someone is a great person, a chasid, and God-fearing, everyone agrees that he is permitted to sacrifice himself al kiddush Hashem (for the sanctification of God's name) even for a minor mitzvah. This seems puzzling - just because he is a chasid and God-fearing, should his law change? Doesn't it say "and live by them"?

It can be explained that "v'chai bahem" (and live by them) can be interpreted in two ways:
1) As our Sages explained - "and not die by them"
2) That all of one's vitality should be in Torah and mitzvot, etc., and without them, one should have no vitality in the world. One should be so attached and unified with Torah, avodah (divine service), and mitzvot that if someone tries to make them transgress even one of Hashem's commandments, their life-force would cease.

According to this second interpretation, it's the opposite - one is permitted to sacrifice their life for all mitzvot, and moreover, it's actually a mitzvah to do so. Therefore, for the masses whose primary occupation is with worldly matters, the verse should be interpreted simply as "not to die by them" as the Gemara explains. However, for tzaddikim who constantly cleave to Hashem, whose primary vitality comes from Torah, the second interpretation applies, and consequently, they are obligated to sacrifice their lives for all mitzvot, as these constitute their very life-force.
summary:
This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of martyrdom (mesiras nefesh) in Jewish law, specifically addressing the Rama's ruling that a great and pious person may sacrifice themselves even for a minor commandment. The text resolves an apparent contradiction with the principle of "v'chai bahem" (and you shall live by them) by offering two interpretations: the simple meaning that one should live rather than die by the commandments, and a deeper meaning that for the truly righteous, their entire life force is bound up in Torah and mitzvot. For such individuals who are completely devoted to God, their very existence is so intertwined with Torah observance that they are permitted (and even obligated) to sacrifice themselves for any commandment, since their true "life" is inseparable from fulfilling God's will.

This interpretation reflects a deep Hasidic understanding of the different spiritual levels between ordinary Jews and the completely righteous, suggesting that halachic obligations can vary based on one's level of spiritual attachment to the Divine.

hebrew_text: ועד"ז נבין לענינינו כי מתחלה התנכר אליהם יוסף ונדמה להם כאיש מצרי, וע"כ כששאל אותם השלום אביכם הזקן העודנו חי, השיבו לו כפשוטו עודנו חי, וכוונת תשובתם הי' כפי הבנתם בשאלתו על חיות הגוף כלשון בני אדם ההמוניים ובעלי החומר, אמנם עכשיו שהתוודע לפניהם ואמר אני יוסף העוד אבי חי, הבינו שאין כוונת שאלתו על חיות הגשמי, כי אם על בחינת השראת השכינה שזהו חיותו לגודל מדריגת קדושתו. וע"ד שדרשו ז"ל עה"פ ותחי רוח יעקב אביהם, פרש"י ז"ל (והוא במד"ר) ששרתה עליו שכינה שפירשה ממנו, ומהאי טעמא לא יכלו אחיו לענות אותו כי נבהלו מפניו. שנצטערו והתחרטו שהם גרמו סילוק השראת שכינתו יתברך מעליו בסיבת צערו, כי אין השכינה שוחה אלא מתוך שמחה כאמז"ל, ויוסף הבין המענה מתוך העדר תשובתם, ע"כ אמר מהרו ועלו אל אבי וגו', וזה יגרום שתחזור אליו השראת השכינה.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts and terminology:

Through this we can understand regarding our matter that initially, Yosef made himself a stranger to them and appeared to them as an Egyptian man. Therefore, when he asked them "Is your elderly father well, is he still alive?", they responded simply "he is still alive." Their intention in answering was based on their understanding of his question regarding physical life, as common people and materialistic beings would understand it.

However, now that he revealed himself to them and said "I am Yosef, is my father still alive?", they understood that his question wasn't about physical life, but rather about the level of the Shechinah's (Divine Presence's) dwelling with him, which was his true life-force due to his great level of holiness. This is similar to what our Sages interpreted on the verse "and the spirit of their father Yaakov was revived," which Rashi explains (from the Midrash Rabbah) that the Shechinah, which had departed from him, returned to rest upon him.

For this reason, his brothers could not answer him because they were dismayed before him. They were distressed and regretful that they had caused the removal of the Divine Presence from him through causing him anguish, for the Shechinah only dwells in joy, as our Sages taught. Yosef understood their response through their lack of answer, therefore he said "Hurry and go up to my father," etc., and this would cause the return of the Divine Presence to him.
summary:
Here's a summary of the key theological concepts from this passage:

The text explores a profound shift in understanding between two similar questions about Jacob's wellbeing - first when Joseph was disguised as an Egyptian, and later when he revealed himself. Initially, the brothers interpreted the question about their father being "alive" in a simple physical sense. However, when Joseph revealed himself and asked again, they understood he was asking about a deeper spiritual vitality - specifically about the presence of the Divine Presence (Shechinah) with Jacob. The passage explains that the brothers were distressed upon realizing they had caused the departure of the Shechinah from Jacob through the sorrow they brought him, as the Divine Presence only rests in a state of joy. This interpretation adds a mystical dimension to Joseph's urgent request for them to return to their father, suggesting it was motivated by his desire to restore the Divine Presence to Jacob through bringing him joy.

hebrew_text: והנה לכאורה ראוי להבין אמרם ז"ל שפירשה ממנו שכינה, והרי אמרז"ל אפילו אחד שיושב ועוסק בתורה השכינה עמו, שנאמר בכל מקום אשר אזכיר שמי אבוא אליך וגו' ומכ"ש לגבי יעקב אבינו ע"ה בחיר האבות, אמנם הרבה בחי' בהשראת השכינה, ויע"א זכה לבחי' התגלות באספקלריא המאירה, ובחי' זו פירשה ממנו מתוך הצער וחזרה אליו אח"כ, משא"כ סתם בני אדם זוכים רק לבחי' השחאת השכינה בהסתר ובלבושים, ובחי' זו לא נעדרה מיעקב אבינו אף בעת הצער.
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

"Now, at first glance, it is worthy to understand what our Sages of blessed memory said that 'the Shechinah (Divine Presence) departed from him.' After all, our Sages taught that even when one person sits and engages in Torah study, the Shechinah is with him, as it is said 'In every place where I cause My name to be mentioned, I will come to you, etc.' And all the more so regarding Yaakov Avinu (our father Jacob), peace be upon him, the chosen of the Patriarchs.

However, there are many levels (bechinot) in the resting of the Shechinah, and Yaakov Avinu merited the level of revelation through the 'illuminating lens' (aspaklaria ha'meirah), and this level departed from him due to his distress and later returned to him. This is unlike ordinary people who only merit the level of the Shechinah's resting in concealment and through 'garments' (levushim), and this level was never absent from Yaakov Avinu even during his time of distress."
summary: This passage discusses different levels of Divine presence (Shechina) and its relationship to Jacob. The text addresses an apparent contradiction: while the Sages say the Shechina departed from Jacob during his period of distress, they also teach that the Divine presence rests with anyone studying Torah. The resolution offered is that there are multiple levels of Divine presence - Jacob normally merited the highest level of clear prophetic vision (aspaklaria hame'ira), which temporarily departed during his suffering, while the basic level of Divine presence that ordinary people experience (through "veils and garments") remained with him even then. This teaching illustrates the Hasidic concept of varying degrees of Divine revelation and the special spiritual status of the Patriarchs while acknowledging that some level of Divine presence is always accessible.

hebrew_text: ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש, אבא כהן ברדלא אמר אוי לנו מיום הדין אוי לנו מיום התוכחה וכו', יוסף קטנן של שבטים היה, ולא היו יכולים לעמוד בתוכחתו, הה"ד ולא יכלו אחיו לענות אותו כו נבהלו מפניו, לכשיבא הקב"ה ויוכיח כל אחד ואחד לפי מה שהוא על אחת כמה וכמה, ולכאורה מה ענין תוכחה להכא, ויוסף לא הוכיח אותם, אדרבה נתרצה ונתפייס להם באותה שעה, ואיך נלמד מהכא לענין התוכחה, גם הכי צריך ראיה לזה, ומה ענין הדמיון להכא, ולדרכנו אפ"ל הכוונה כי אף שיהיה לימוד זכות גדול על ישראל ביום הדין והתוכחה, כי שעבוד הגלות והסתרת פנים הם היו סיבת התרשלותינו בעבודת השי"ת, ואלמלא זכינו להתגלות אור שכינתו יתברך, בודאי היינו דבוקים בו יתברך ובתוה"ק יותר, אמנם אעפ"כ יהיה הבושה גדולה מאוד, על כי במעשינו גרמנו ההסתרה הנורא וסילוק השראת שכינתו יתברך מישראל, ובזה יתבאר ענין הק"ו, כי יוסף לא הוכיח את אחיו, אדרבה נתרצה ונתפייס להם. גם בגוף המעשה לא היה להם חטא כמבואר בדברי המדרשים דזכות הוא להם וזכורה היא לעולם, גם כו היה הכרח בדבר לקיים גזירת ידוע תדע, מ"מ לא יכלו אחיו לענות אותו ונבהלו מפניו לטעם הנ"ל על שנגרם על ידיהם סילוק השראת שכינתו ית', עאכו"כ מה נענה אנן ביום הדין ץןץש יה
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

This explains the words of the Midrash: Abba Kohen Bardela said, "Woe to us from the Day of Judgment, woe to us from the Day of Rebuke, etc." Joseph was the youngest of the tribes, and they could not withstand his rebuke, as it is written "and his brothers could not answer him because they were frightened before him." When the Holy One, Blessed be He, comes to rebuke each and every person according to who they are, how much more so [will we be unable to withstand it].

At first glance, what does rebuke have to do with this? Joseph didn't actually rebuke them; on the contrary, he was appeased and reconciled with them at that time. So how do we learn about rebuke from here? Also, why is this comparison necessary, and what is the relevance of this analogy?

Following our approach, we can explain that even though there will be great merit for Israel on the Day of Judgment and Rebuke, as the subjugation of exile and the hiding of [God's] face (hester panim) were the causes of our negligence in serving Hashem, and had we merited the revelation of the light of His Divine Presence (Shechinah), we certainly would have been more attached to Him and to the holy Torah. Nevertheless, there will still be great shame because through our actions we caused this terrible concealment and the removal of His Divine Presence from Israel.

This explains the kal vachomer (a fortiori argument): Joseph didn't rebuke his brothers; on the contrary, he was appeased and reconciled with them. Even in the act itself, they had no sin, as explained in the Midrashim that it was to their merit and is remembered forever. Also, it was necessary to fulfill the decree of "Know with certainty." Still, his brothers could not answer him and were frightened before him for the above reason - because they caused the removal of the Divine Presence. How much more so, what will we answer on the Day of Judgment?
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the Midrashic interpretation of Joseph's reunion with his brothers, using it as a metaphor for divine judgment. The key insight is that even though Joseph was forgiving and his brothers' actions were arguably justified (fulfilling God's decree of exile), they still couldn't face him due to their shame - not because of the act itself, but because their actions caused a diminishment of divine presence (hashra'at hashechina). The text then makes a kal vachomer (a fortiori) argument: if Joseph's brothers were so ashamed despite having justification, how much more so should we be concerned about divine judgment, even when we have the excuse of exile and hester panim (divine concealment) for our spiritual shortcomings. This reflects a deep Hasidic concept that focuses not just on the technical aspects of sin, but on how our actions affect our relationship with and proximity to the Divine Presence.

hebrew_text: ובזאת יתבאר לנו ב' הפירושים שפרש"י ז"ל, במאמר כי כמוך כפרעה, גם קישור המאמר ואל יחר אפך בעבדך לפי"ד המדרש (עיין קושיא א' לעיל) כי הנה השבטים הכירו ביוסף שחכמתו גדולה אלא שלא ידעו בו שהוא יוסף כי התנכר להם להתדמות בפניהם כאיש מצרי, ולזאת דיבר אליו יהודה בלישנא דמשתמע לתרי אנפין דברי פיוס ורצוי כפשוטן, ונכלל בהם דברים קשים ותוכחה בדרך דרש כאמרם ז"ל, ויוסף יבין כוונת דבריו לפי בחינתו ומדריגתו, כי הלשון בני אדם לכל אחד כפו מדריגתו כמ"ש ק"ז הישמח משה זלל"ה דלבעלי הנפש לשון התורה ודרשת חז"ל היינו לשון בנ"א, ולבעלי החומר להיפך, והנה אמרז"ל ערכין (ט"ז ע"ב) איר יוחנן בן נורי מעיד אני עלו שמים וארץ, שהרבה פעמים לקה עקיבא על ידו, שהייתי קובל עליו לפני ר"ג בריבי, וכ"ש שהוסיף בי אהבה, לקיים מה שנאמר (משלי ט') אל תוכח לץ פן ישנאך הוכח לחכם ויאהבך עכ"ד הגמרא. הרי דדברי תוכחה הנאמרים לחכם אינם גורמים שנאה ופירוד הלבבות אדרבה מוסיפים אהבה, ומעתה א"ש קישור המאמר ואל יחר אפך בעבדך אף לפי"ד המדרש, כי איך שיהיה אינו ראוי שיקפיד יוסף על דיבוריו. וממנ"פ אם יהיה השגת יוסף בהבנת דבריו כלשון התורה ודרשות חז"ל שהוא לשון בנ"א אצל בעלי הנפש, א"כ בודאי לא יחר אפו על דברי תוכחתו אדרבה יוסיף אהבתו אליו ואם השגתו כבעלי החומר בודאי לא ישיג בדיבוריו כ"א הדברים כפשוטן, והם דברי רצוי ופיוס שחשוב בעיניו כמלך ומן הראוי שלא יחר אפו על זה, ובזה יבואר דברי המדרש הנ"ל, מה אופן זה מראה פנים לכל צד, כך היו דבריו של יהודה נראים לכל צד בשעה שדיבר עם יוסף, ר"ל שהיו נכללים במשמעות דבריו הרבה בחינות, דברים קשים ופיוס ורצוי, משמעות פשוטן ורמז דרשות חז"ל, ואוזן השומעם ישיג בהם כפו בחינת מדריגתו וז"ש מראים פנים לכל צד, והבן.

This explains to us the two interpretations that Rashi z"l gave on the statement "for you are like Pharaoh," and also connects the statement "let not your anger burn against your servant" according to the Midrash (see question 1 above). For behold, the tribes recognized that Yosef possessed great wisdom, but they did not know he was Yosef because he disguised himself to appear before them as an Egyptian man.

Therefore, Yehudah spoke to him in language that could be understood in two ways: words of appeasement and reconciliation in their simple meaning, while also including within them harsh words and rebuke in the way of drash, as our Sages z"l said. And Yosef would understand the intention of his words according to his level and spiritual standing, for human language is understood by each person according to their spiritual level, as the holy Yismach Moshe zll"h wrote that for ba'alei hanefesh (spiritually oriented people), the language of Torah and the interpretations of Chazal are their natural language, while for ba'alei hachomer (materially oriented people) it is the opposite.

Our Sages said in Arachin (16b): "Rabbi Yochanan ben Nuri testified: I call heaven and earth to witness that many times Akiva was struck because of me, as I would complain about him before Rabban Gamliel, and this only increased his love for me, fulfilling what is said (Proverbs 9), 'Do not rebuke a scoffer lest he hate you; rebuke a wise man and he will love you.'" This shows that words of rebuke spoken to a wise person do not cause hatred and division of hearts; on the contrary, they increase love.

From this, we can understand the connection of the statement "let not your anger burn against your servant" even according to the Midrash, for however it may be, it was not appropriate for Yosef to be particular about his words. For either way: if Yosef's comprehension of his words was like the language of Torah and the interpretations of Chazal, which is the natural language for ba'alei hanefesh, then certainly he would not be angry about words of rebuke but rather would increase his love. And if his comprehension was like that of ba'alei hachomer, he would certainly only grasp the simple meaning of the words, which were words of appeasement and reconciliation, considering him as important as a king, and it would be appropriate not to be angry about this.

This explains the words of the aforementioned Midrash: "Just as this wheel shows faces to all sides, so too were Yehudah's words seen from all sides when he spoke with Yosef." This means that his words included many aspects in their meaning: harsh words, appeasement and reconciliation, simple meaning and allusions to the interpretations of Chazal, and the ear of the listener would grasp them according to their spiritual level - this is what is meant by "showing faces to all sides." Understand this.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the multilayered conversation between Yehuda and Yosef, presenting a profound insight into how spiritual levels affect communication. The key concept is that Torah language can be understood differently based on one's spiritual madrega (level) - for those of higher spiritual refinement (ba'alei nefesh), the deeper interpretations of Chazal are their natural understanding, while those more connected to physicality (ba'alei chomer) grasp only the simple meaning. The text explains that Yehuda's words to Yosef were intentionally constructed to carry multiple meanings, like a "wheel that shows faces to all sides," allowing each listener to understand according to their spiritual level. This demonstrates a sophisticated Hasidic understanding of how Divine truth can be simultaneously accessed at different levels, with the same words carrying both simple and profound meanings based on the spiritual capacity of the receiver.

summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the encounter between Judah and Joseph, focusing on the verse "And Judah approached him... let not your anger burn against your servant." The text raises an important theological question about the behavior of the tribes: why did they initially agree to all become slaves (including Benjamin) without protest, but when Joseph later demanded only Benjamin as a slave, Judah suddenly approached to speak harshly? This apparent contradiction is used as a starting point for deeper analysis of the brothers' moral and spiritual motivations, particularly examining the concept of collective responsibility versus individual punishment in Jewish thought.

2) "For you are like Pharaoh." Rashi explains that just as Pharaoh makes decrees and doesn't fulfill them, etc., [Yehuda is asking Yosef] "Is this the 'watching over' that you said you would do - to keep your eye on him?" The Ramban z"l wrote that this isn't a valid argument, because when a ruler commands someone to be brought before him, it's not done with the intention of exempting him from the consequences of his wrongdoings, and certainly not regarding theft from the king's palace. Also needs clarification why [Yehuda] based the main argument on the concept of "watching over" (simat ayin).

summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the verse "for you are like Pharaoh" and explores the dialogue between Rashi's and Ramban's interpretations. The key point revolves around Rashi's criticism that Pharaoh makes decrees without fulfilling his promises, particularly regarding his pledge to "keep an eye" on Benjamin. The Ramban disagrees with this critique, arguing that a ruler who summons someone wouldn't necessarily do so just to absolve them of wrongdoing, especially in cases of theft from the royal palace. The passage raises a deeper theological question about the nature of authority, promises, and responsibility, particularly focusing on why the concept of "keeping an eye" (simat ayin) is central to this discussion.

The youth cannot leave his father, and if he leaves his father he will die. Ibn Ezra (of blessed memory) wrote: Why didn't the narrator bring [this verse as one of] the five verses that have no clear determination - meaning it's not clear whether the word "and he will die" refers to the youth or to his father? And the Ramban (of blessed memory) wrote that if the interpretation was that the father would die, it should have said "our father cannot leave his son, and he left his son and died." However, if [the word "died"] refers to Binyamin (Benjamin), why does it need to be stated with this repetition? It would have been sufficient to say "the youth cannot leave his father lest he die."

Note: I've preserved names like Ibn Ezra (Raab"a), Ramban, and Binyamin in their traditional forms, as these are commonly used in Jewish scholarly discourse.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the textual ambiguity in the verse about Benjamin potentially leaving his father Jacob. It presents a debate between the Ibn Ezra and Ramban regarding the phrase "and he will die" - whether it refers to the son (Benjamin) or the father (Jacob). The key theological insight centers on the deep interconnectedness between father and son in Jewish thought, suggesting that their spiritual and physical wellbeing are inextricably linked. The repetitive language in the verse ("cannot leave...and if he leaves") emphasizes the gravity of this father-son bond and the potentially fatal consequences of its disruption, reflecting a deeper teaching about the importance of familial bonds in Jewish spiritual life.

"At the end of Parshas Mikeitz, [regarding the verse] 'And he said: Now indeed as you say, so it should be: he with whom it is found shall be my servant; but you shall be blameless and go up to your father.' This requires explanation - what is meant by 'as you say, so it should be,' when it was actually the opposite of what they said, for they had said 'we will all be servants to my lord' (see Rashi's commentary). Also, the word 'indeed' (gam) needs explanation, as it should have simply stated 'as you say, so it should be.'"

The text raises a difficulty with Yosef saying he agrees with their words (כדבריכם) when in fact he does the opposite of what they proposed - they offered that all would be slaves, but he declared only the one found with the goblet would be enslaved. The passage particularly questions the seemingly superfluous word "גם" (also/indeed) in the verse, suggesting there's a deeper theological meaning beyond the simple narrative.

hebrew_text: ואפ"ל בדרך הפשוט. כו מתחילה קבלו על עצמם דין שמים באהבה, בהיותם חושבים כי כבר הגיע הזמן לפרוע שטר חוב של גזירת ידוע תדע, ולזה אמרו גם אנחנו נהי' עבדים וגו', ע"ז השיב להם שלוחו של יוסף גם עתה כדבריכם כן הוא, שהאמת כדבריכם, וכבר הגיע הזמן שתהיו עבדים למצרים, אבל חלילה לי מעשות זאת כו איננו רוצה להסב שתהי' ירידתכם בגלות באופן מבוזה וע"י עלילה, רק שיסבב הגוזר יתברך ותתקיים הגזירה באופן אחר. כאמרז"ל ראוי היה יעקב אבינו לירד למצרים בשלשלאות של ברזל אלא שזכותו גרמה לו, והנה בעוחום היו השבטים הק', דכ"ז שיהיו כולם בצוותא חדא אין שום אומה ולשון שולט בהם ויתקיימו בקדושתן ולא היו מתיראים מקליפות מצרים, אבל עכשיו שרצה יוסף שרק בנימין לבדו יהיה עבד במצרים וכולם ישובו אל אביהם, חשו מפני הסכנה פן יקראנו אסון בארץ הטמאה ערות הארץ ולטעם זה ניגש יהודה לדבר אתו קשות.

Here is the translation, preserving relevant terminology:

One can explain in a simple way: Initially, they accepted the heavenly decree with love, thinking that the time had come to pay the debt of the decree of "You shall surely know" [referring to the prophecy of exile given to Avraham]. Therefore, they said "We too shall be servants, etc." To this, Yosef's messenger responded "Now too, it is as you say" - meaning that they spoke truth, and indeed the time had arrived for them to be servants in Egypt.

However, "Heaven forbid that I should do this" - he did not want to cause their descent into exile to happen in a disgraceful way through a false accusation. Rather, the Divine decree should be fulfilled in another manner. As our Sages said: "Yaakov our father was meant to descend to Egypt in iron chains, but his merit caused [it to happen differently]."

Now the holy Shevatim (tribes) were concerned, for as long as they remained together as one, no nation or tongue could rule over them and they would maintain their kedushah (holiness) without fear of the klipot (impure forces) of Egypt. But now that Yosef wanted only Binyamin alone to be a servant in Egypt while they all returned to their father, they feared the danger that harm might befall him in the impure land, the ervat ha'aretz (nakedness of the land). For this reason, Yehudah approached to speak harshly with him.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the interaction between Joseph and his brothers, specifically focusing on the divine plan of the Egyptian exile. The key theological insight is that the brothers initially accepted their fate with love (קבלו על עצמם דין שמים באהבה), believing it was time to fulfill the divine decree of exile that had been prophesied. However, Joseph's representative explains that while their understanding about the time of servitude being due is correct, it shouldn't occur through humiliation or false pretenses. The passage concludes with an important Hasidic concept about unity - as long as the tribes remained together (בצוותא חדא), no nation could dominate them spiritually, but the prospect of Benjamin being separated from his brothers created concern about spiritual vulnerability in the impure land of Egypt.

hebrew_text: וזהו טעם טענתם לא יוכל הנער לעזוב את אביו ועזב את אביו ומת, וקאי על תרווייהו כ"א ישאר בנימין לבדו במצרים, פן ישלטו עליו קליפות מצרים ושוב אינו נחשב כחו רק כמת, וכמ"ש האוה"ח הק' עה"פ אחרי ראותי פניך כי עודך חי, היינו שהוא עדיין בבחינת צדיק הנקרא חי, וגם ליעקב אבינו יהיה נחשב לבחי' מיתה ח"ו, כמ"ש רז"ל שאמר יעקב אבינו ע"ה סימן זה מסור בידי, אם לא ימות ואחד מבני בחיי מובטח אני שאיני רואה פני גיהנם, ומכ"ש מיתת הנפש שקשה המחטיאו יותר מההרגו, וא"ש שלשון המקרא אין לו הכרע, דבאמת הכוונה במלת ומת על תרווייהו על יעקב אבינו ובנימין.

This is the reason for their argument "The youth cannot leave his father, for if he leaves his father, he will die." This refers to both situations: if Benjamin remains alone in Egypt, there is concern that the klipot (spiritual forces of impurity) of Egypt would overcome him, and he would be considered as if dead. As the holy Ohr HaChaim explains on the verse "after I have seen your face, that you are still alive" - meaning that he was still in the aspect of a tzaddik who is called "alive." And also for our father Yaakov, it would be considered like death, God forbid, as our Sages taught that our father Yaakov, peace be upon him, said: "This sign is passed down to me - if none of my sons die during my lifetime, I am assured that I will not see Gehinom." And all the more so regarding spiritual death, as one who causes another to sin is worse than one who kills him. And this explains why the verse's meaning is ambiguous, because truly the word "and he will die" refers to both - to our father Yaakov and to Benjamin.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the spiritual dangers that Benjamin faced in Egypt and its implications for both Benjamin and Jacob. The key concern was that if Benjamin remained alone in Egypt, he would be susceptible to the "kelipos" (negative spiritual forces) of Egypt, rendering him spiritually "dead" even while physically alive. The text draws on the concept that causing someone to sin is worse than killing them physically, and connects this to Jacob's statement that if none of his sons died in his lifetime, he was assured of not seeing Gehinnom. The passage ultimately suggests that the biblical phrase "and he will die" refers both to Benjamin's potential spiritual death through Egyptian influence and to Jacob's spiritual diminishment through losing his son.

hebrew_text: והנה איתא בספה"ק דכשצדיק פוגע ברשע צריך לשמור מאוד שלא יהיה נפגם מראיית פניו, ורק אם יש לו זכותים ניצול ממנו, וכאן הרי ידעו כולם כי בנימין מעודו צדיק גמור הוא, ואיך זה פתאום נכשל בדבר הגניבה, אע"כ בוודאי הוא ע"ו שנתעכב לילה אחד בשכונת רשע, או כל הדבר לא היה ולא נברא, והוא רק עלילה מצד המושל, וז"ש יהודה וכי זו הוא שימת עין שאמרת לשום עינך עליו, היינו כו בודאי מה שאירע לו דבר הגניבה, הוא רק מכוחך מה ששמת עינך עליו וזהו הכוונה בטענת שימת עון, ועכ"פ יוצא מזה כו אתה אינך ירא אלקים ואיך אמרת את האלקים ואני ירא, ועכשיו נוכחנו לדעת שדברת שקר, וכמוך כפרעה שעשאך ימלך אע"פ שהיית עבד ובנימוסי מצרים כתוב שאין עבד מולך וז"ש מה פרעה גוזר ואינו מקיים וכו' ולפי' השני א"ל אם תקניטני אהרוג אותך ואת אדונך, ויובן עפימ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל שהשבטים הרגו לאנשי שכם, לפי שלא הושיבו דיינין כי בני נח מצווין על הדינין למנות דיינים בכל פלך ופלך יעיי"ש, וכאן שהי' יוסף משנה למלך ורצה לעכב את בנימין לעבד בלי משפע, ובעלילת שקר, ע"כ אמר לו יהודה כי ע"פ הדין אתה מחוייב מיתה עם אדונך אם תעשה הדבר הזה בלו משפט, כי אתה מצווה לעשות משפט אמת בלא עוולה.

It is written in the holy sefarim that when a tzaddik encounters a rasha (wicked person), he must be very careful not to be spiritually damaged by seeing his face, and only if he has sufficient merits (zechuyot) will he be saved from him. Here, everyone knew that Binyamin was always a complete tzaddik, so how did he suddenly stumble with theft? Therefore, it must either be because he stayed one night in the neighborhood of a rasha, or the entire incident never happened and was merely a false accusation by the ruler.

This is what Yehudah meant when he said, "Is this the 'watching over' that you promised when you said you would keep your eye on him?" Meaning, the theft incident occurred only because of your influence when you set your eyes upon him - this is the meaning of the claim about "setting guilt." In any case, this proves that you do not fear God, so how could you say "I fear God"? Now we know you spoke falsely, and you are like Pharaoh who made you king even though you were a slave, and according to Egyptian law, a slave cannot become king.

This is what is meant by "Just as Pharaoh decrees and doesn't fulfill..." And according to the second interpretation, he said to him, "If you provoke me, I will kill you and your master." This can be understood based on what the Rambam wrote, that the tribes killed the people of Shechem because they didn't establish judges, as Bnei Noach (Noahides) are commanded regarding laws to appoint judges in every district.

Here, since Yosef was viceroy and wanted to keep Binyamin as a slave without justice and with false accusations, Yehudah told him that according to the law, both you and your master deserve death if you do this thing without justice, for you are commanded to execute true justice without wrongdoing.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses several important theological concepts centered around the interaction between tzaddikim (righteous individuals) and reshaim (wicked people). The text explores the spiritual danger of a tzaddik encountering a rasha, noting that only sufficient merits can protect the righteous person from being spiritually damaged by such an encounter. The passage specifically analyzes the story of Benjamin and Joseph, questioning how Benjamin, known to be completely righteous, could have been accused of theft, suggesting either it was due to staying in a wicked neighborhood or it was a false accusation. The text concludes with a discussion of justice, citing the Rambam's teaching that Noahide laws require establishing proper courts and judges, using this to criticize Joseph's apparent willingness to enslave Benjamin without proper judicial process.

hebrew_text: או"י עפימ"ש בספה"ק מעשי ה', לפרש מאמר המגיד צא ולמד מה ביקש לבן הארמי שפרעה לא גזר אלא על הזכרים ולבן ביקש לעקור את הכל, דלכאורה מקטין נס יציאת מצרים בסיפורו זה, שלבן היה רשע יותר גדול מפרעה וא"כ ההצלה ממנו הוא נס גדול יותר, ויובן עפ"י מאמה"כ ויאמר בלק לך נא אתו אל מקום אחר אשר תראנו משם אפס קצהו תראה וכולו לא תראה, דלכאורה צריך ביאור, דמה נפקא מינה אם יראה כולו או רק מקצתו ולא כולו, אמנם סיפר הכתוב כי בלק ידע כו או אפשר לקלל את כולם, כי על זה יש הבטחה מהקדוש ברוך הוא שלא יכלה זרעם, על כן רצה שיחול ח"ו עכ"פ על מקצתן כי עי"ז ימצא ח"ו מקום לחול הקללה, וזהו כוונת בעל הגדה להגדיל בזה נס יציאת מצרים, ואמר צא ולמד שלבן ביקש לעקור את הכל, וזה או אפשר במציאות ואין הנס גדול כ"כ כמו ביציאת מצרים, שפרעה לא גזר אלא על הזכרים והיה ח"ו מקום לחול גזירתו וגם מזה הצילנו השי"ת וזהו הנס הגדול (עכת"ד בעל מעשה ה'), וזה היה ג"כ אצל יהודה ואחיו שהסכימו שכולם יהיו עבדים, כי ידעו שאז מובטחים מכליה. משא"כ שבנימין ישאר לבד זהו סכנה, ומה שרצה יהודה ליכנס תחתיו כי לעצמו לא היה מתיירא כי יהודה הוא שורש מלכות בית דוד. וגם זה נכלל בהבטחת שלא יכלה זרעו שאי אפשר לישראל בלא מלכות בית דוד, ע"כ רצה הוא ליכנס תחתיו, אבל שאר האחין לא הסכימו ע"ז וחשו גם בעדו ומיאנו בדבר.

The holy sefer Ma'asei Hashem explains the statement of the Maggid regarding "Go and learn what Lavan the Aramean sought to do" - that while Pharaoh only decreed against the males, Lavan sought to uproot everything. At first glance, this seems to diminish the miracle of the Exodus from Egypt, since it suggests Lavan was a greater rasha (evil person) than Pharaoh, and thus being saved from him would be an even greater miracle.

This can be understood through the verse where Balak says "Come with me to another place from where you will see only their edge but not all of them." This requires explanation - what difference does it make whether he sees all or only part? However, the verse tells us that Balak knew it was impossible to curse all of them, as Hashem had promised they would not be completely destroyed. Therefore, he wanted the curse to affect at least some of them, thereby finding a way for the curse to take hold.

This is the intention of the Haggadah's author - to magnify the miracle of the Exodus. When it says "Go and learn that Lavan sought to uproot everything," this was impossible to actually achieve, so the miracle wasn't as great as with the Exodus from Egypt, where Pharaoh only decreed against the males, which could have taken effect, yet Hashem saved us from this too - and this was the great miracle.

This was also the case with Yehudah and his brothers, who agreed they would all be slaves, knowing this would protect them from complete destruction. However, if Binyamin remained alone, this would be dangerous. Yehudah wanted to take Binyamin's place because he wasn't afraid for himself, being the root of the Davidic kingdom. This was also included in the promise that his seed would not be destroyed, as Israel cannot exist without the Davidic kingdom. Therefore, he wanted to take Binyamin's place, but the other brothers didn't agree and were concerned for him as well, refusing the matter.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a profound theological concept regarding divine protection and the nature of threats to the Jewish people. It analyzes the Haggadah's comparison between Laban and Pharaoh, explaining that Pharaoh's decree against only the male children was actually a greater threat than Laban's attempt to destroy everything, because partial destruction could potentially circumvent God's promise of eternal Jewish survival. The text connects this to the story of Judah and Benjamin, explaining that Judah was willing to substitute himself for Benjamin because, as the root of the Davidic monarchy, he was protected by God's promise that the Jewish monarchy would never be completely destroyed. This interpretation reveals a deeper understanding of how divine protection operates - sometimes what appears to be a lesser threat (targeting only part of the nation) can actually be more dangerous than an all-encompassing threat which would automatically be nullified by God's promise of Jewish continuity.

hebrew_text: והנה השליח הרגיש שהשבטים חשבו להחריב את כל מצרים, וא"כ נתאמתו דברי יוסף שאמר להם מאז ירידתם למצרים הוא אשר דברתי אליכם מרגלים אתם". לזאת אמר להם גם עתה כדבריכם כן הוא, לפי דבריכם שכן הוא' מלשון כן בנות צלפחד ר"ל כנים ונתאמתו דברי יוסף שאמר הוא אשר דברתי וגו' שאתם מרגלים ולהחריב את מצרים באתם, והרגיש השליח שהוא סכנה גדולה אם ישיב את כולם למצרים. ע"כ א"ל כי רק בנימין יהיה לי עבד ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם, אמנם יהודה מיאן בדבר ורצה דייקא שכולם יחזרו לטעם הנ"ל ע"כ ויגש אליו לפיוס ומלחמה וכו'.

Behold, the messenger (referring to Joseph's servant) sensed that the tribes (brothers) were thinking of destroying all of Egypt. If so, this confirmed Joseph's original words to them when they first came down to Egypt: "This is what I spoke to you - you are spies." Therefore, he said to them "now also, according to your words, so it is" - meaning, according to your words, this is indeed the case (similar to the expression used regarding the daughters of Zelophehad, meaning "their words are true and correct"). This verified Joseph's words when he said "This is what I spoke, etc." - that you are spies who came to destroy Egypt. The messenger sensed that it would be a great danger to return all of them to Egypt. Therefore, he told them that only Benjamin would be his servant, and "you go up in peace to your father." However, Yehudah refused this arrangement and specifically wanted all of them to return, for the reason mentioned above. Therefore, "he approached him" for appeasement and confrontation, etc.

Note: I've preserved Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "vayigash" (he approached) and maintained the rabbinic style of exposition while making the text accessible in English.
summary:
This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the dramatic encounter between Joseph's messenger and the brothers, offering a deeper interpretation of their interaction. The key insight is that the messenger perceived the brothers' potential intention to destroy Egypt, which validated Joseph's earlier accusation of them being spies. The text suggests that this realization led the messenger to propose keeping only Benjamin as a servant while sending the others home - a diplomatic solution to prevent potential catastrophe. However, Judah's refusal to accept this arrangement and his insistence that all brothers return together demonstrates a deeper spiritual dynamic at play, leading to his confrontational "vayigash" (approaching) for both appeasement and potential conflict.

This interpretation adds layers of theological meaning to what might otherwise be seen as a straightforward narrative, highlighting themes of divine providence, redemption, and the complex interplay between human intention and heavenly design.

"And Judah approached him, etc." In the Midrash Rabbah it is written "Deep waters are counsel in the heart of man, etc." [This can be compared] to a deep well filled with cold water, and its waters were cold and beautiful, but no creature was able to drink from it. Then someone came and tied rope to rope, thread to thread, and cord to cord, and drew water from it and drank. Then everyone began drawing from it and drinking. Similarly, Judah did not cease responding to Joseph word for word until he "stood upon his heart" [understood his true feelings/intentions]. End quote. And we need to understand the meaning of the phrase "stood upon his heart."

Note: I've preserved Hebrew/religious terms like Midrash Rabbah. The translation maintains the parable-like quality of the original text while keeping the essential Hasidic interpretative style. The phrase "stood upon his heart" is translated literally to preserve its original connotation, as its deeper meaning is the subject of discussion in the text.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the encounter between Judah and Joseph using a midrashic metaphor of deep waters. The metaphor compares wisdom/truth to a deep well of cold water that was inaccessible until someone cleverly connected ropes and strings to draw from it. Just as this person made the deep water accessible to all, Judah's persistent engagement with Joseph (through carefully connected arguments and words) eventually reached Joseph's heart ("amad al libo"). The passage explores how spiritual and emotional breakthroughs often require patient, methodical effort to access deep truths that are otherwise hidden, suggesting that genuine connection and understanding come through persistent, thoughtful engagement rather than immediate confrontation.

hebrew_text: ב) במדרש תנחומא: ואת יהודה שלח לפניו זש"ה המשל ופחד עמו עושה שלום במרומיו וכו', יהודה ויוסף זה ארי וזה שור, אתמול מתנגחין זה עם זה ועכשיו הוא משלחו אצלו שנאמר ואת יהודה שלח לפניו הוי עושה שלום במרומיו עכ"ל וצ"ב.
translation:
Here's the translation of the text from Divrei Yoel:

"In Midrash Tanchuma: 'And he sent Judah ahead of him' - this is what Scripture means [when it says] 'Dominion and fear are with Him, He makes peace in His heights, etc.' Judah and Joseph - one is a lion and one is an ox. Yesterday they were goring each other, and now he sends him to him, as it is said 'And he sent Judah ahead of him' - thus [fulfilling] 'He makes peace in His heights.'" End quote. And this requires explanation.

Notes on terminology:
- The text references the verse from Job 25:2 ("Dominion and fear are with Him...")
- "זש"ה" (zeh she'amar) is an acronym meaning "this is what Scripture means"
- The lion and ox metaphor refers to the tribal symbols of Judah (lion) and Joseph (ox)
- "עכ"ל" is an acronym for "ad kan leshono" meaning "end quote"
- "וצ"ב" is an acronym for "v'tzarich biur" meaning "this requires explanation/clarification"

The Midrash is highlighting the miraculous nature of peace-making between two naturally opposing forces (represented by Judah and Joseph), comparing it to God's ability to make peace in the heavenly realms.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a Midrash Tanchuma about the verse "And he sent Judah ahead" (Genesis 46:28), connecting it to the concept of "Dominion and fear are with Him; He makes peace in His heights" (Job 25:2). The Midrash draws a profound parallel between Judah and Joseph, comparing them to a lion and an ox respectively - two naturally opposing forces that were previously in conflict. The key theological insight is how God's divine power can transform natural antagonists into peaceful allies, as demonstrated by Judah being sent to Joseph, symbolizing how apparent opposites can be reconciled through divine intervention and creating harmony from conflict.

hebrew_text: ואפ"ל בהקדם דברי החתם סופר ז"ל בביאור אמרם ז"ל מה כושי משונה בעורו כך צדיקים משונים במעשיהם. ולכאורה צ"ב הדמיון, דהרי הכושי משונה בעוחו לגנאי, וצדיקים משונים במעשיהם משאר כל אדם לשבח, וצ"ב ענין הדמיון, וביאר הוא ז"ל דהכוונה בזה דאף דלכל צדיק וצדיק יש דרך אחרת בעבודת השי"ת, אבל בפנימיות הלב כולם כאחד מייחדים את לבם לאביהם שבשמים, וזה פי' הגמרא מה כושי משונה הבעורו". כי רק בעורו משונה משאר כל אדם אבל לפנים מעורו הוא כאחד האדם, כך הצדיקים משונים זה מזה, אבל רק ש במעשיהם שכל אחד ואחד עובד השי"ת לפי מידתו ובחינתו אבל בפנימיות הלב כולם מכוונים את לבם להשי"ת ואין שום חילוק ביניהם

One can explain this by prefacing with the words of the Chasam Sofer z"l in his explanation of our Sages' statement: "Just as a Cushite is distinguished by his skin, so too are tzaddikim (righteous ones) distinguished by their deeds." At first glance, this comparison requires explanation, for the Cushite's distinction in his skin appears to be a disadvantage, while the tzaddikim's distinction in their deeds compared to other people is praiseworthy. The comparison needs clarification.

He (the Chasam Sofer) explained that the intention is that although each and every tzaddik has a different path in serving Hashem (the Divine service), in the innermost depths of their hearts, they all unite their hearts as one to their Father in Heaven. This is the explanation of the Gemara's statement "Just as a Cushite is distinguished by his skin" - because only his skin is different from other people, but beneath his skin, he is like any other person. Similarly, the tzaddikim are different from each other only in their external actions, as each one serves Hashem according to their own measure and spiritual level, but in the innermost depths of their hearts, they all direct their hearts to Hashem, and there is no difference between them.
summary:
This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a teaching from the Chasam Sofer explaining the Talmudic comparison between a Cushite (Ethiopian) and righteous individuals (tzaddikim). The core insight is that just as a Cushite's difference is only skin-deep while internally being the same as all humans, tzaddikim may appear to have different external approaches to serving God, but internally they are united in their devotion to Heaven. The passage emphasizes that while each tzaddik has their own unique path in divine service (avodas Hashem) based on their individual qualities and spiritual level, their inner essence and ultimate goal - dedicating their hearts to God - is fundamentally the same.

This teaching illustrates an important Hasidic concept about the unity underlying apparent diversity in authentic Jewish spiritual paths.

hebrew_text: ומבואר בספה"ק די"ב שבטי י"ה הם כנגד י"ב צירופי הוי', וכל צירוף מורה על מדה ובחי' אחרת, נמצא לפי"ז שעבדו השי"ת כאו"א במדה ובדרך אחרת, וז"ש המדרש ארי ושור מתווכחין זה בזה, שאין מודתם ודרך עבודתם שוה אבל עושה שלום במרומיו שלענין כבוד שמים יש שלום ביניהם בלי שום פירוד כלל וכ"א מייחד לבבו להקב"ה. וידוע שיעקב אבינו ע"ה הוה כלול מכל המידות כולן ובזה יבואר אמרם ז"ל במדרש שאמחו בניו ליעקב כשם שאין בלבך אלא אחד כך אין בלבנו' אלא אחד, פי' אף שבפעולתינו בעבודת השי"ת יש השתנות בא' מחבירו אבל בתוכיות ופנימיות הלב אין לנו אלא לב אחד, ובחי' זו נרמז בדברי המדרש כאן שיהודה לא זז משם עד שעמד על לבו, פי' שהבין פנימיות לבו של יוסף והבחין שיש שלום ביניהם וכולם לכוונה א' עובדים לייחד לבבם להקב"ה, וההשתנות שביניהם הוא חק בפעולת המעשה, וע"כ ואחר שעמד על לבו השיג שאין פירוד ביניהם כלל, השי"ת יעזור לייחד לבבנו לשמו יתברך באמת. זא

It is explained in the holy sefarim that the 12 tribes of G-d correspond to the 12 permutations of the Divine Name (Havaya), and each permutation indicates a different middah (attribute) and aspect. According to this, each one served Hashem in a different way and approach. This is what the Midrash means when it says that the lion and ox argue with each other - their middot and ways of service are not the same, but "He makes peace in His heights" means that regarding kavod shamayim (Heaven's honor), there is peace between them without any separation at all, and each one unifies their heart to the Holy One, Blessed be He.

It is known that our father Yaakov, peace be upon him, encompassed all the middot together. This explains what our Sages said in the Midrash that his sons said to Yaakov, "Just as in your heart there is only One, so too in our hearts there is only One." This means that although in our actions in serving Hashem there are differences between one and another, in the inner depths of our hearts we have only one heart.

This aspect is alluded to in the words of the Midrash here that "Yehudah did not move from there until he understood his heart," meaning he understood the inner heart of Yosef and recognized that there was peace between them, and they all served with one intention to unify their hearts to the Holy One, Blessed be He. The differences between them were only in the outer actions. Therefore, after he understood his heart, he realized there was no separation between them at all. May Hashem help us to unify our hearts to His blessed Name in truth.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a fundamental Hasidic concept regarding the twelve tribes of Israel and their relationship to the twelve permutations of God's name (YHVH). The key insight is that while each tribe served God in their own unique way (represented by different divine attributes), they were all unified in their ultimate purpose of serving Heaven. The text uses the metaphor of the lion and ox arguing to show that despite different modes of divine service, there is complete unity in their dedication to God's glory. The passage concludes by explaining that Jacob embodied all these divine attributes, and his children, though different in their external service, were united in having "one heart" in their devotion to God - a concept illustrated through the story of Judah understanding Joseph's true inner intentions.

hebrew_text: ויגש אליו יהודה וגו' ואל יחר אפך בעבדך כי כמוך כפרעה. פרש"י ז"ל מדברי המדרש סופך ללקות עליו בצרעת כמו שלקה פרעה ע"י זקנתי שחה על לילה א' שעכבה וכו', דבר אחר כי כמוך כפרעה אם תקניטני אהרוג אותך ואת אדוניך עכ"ל. ולשני הפירושים קשה דהול"ל כי אתה תהיה כפרעה, ומ"ש כו כמוך כפרעה בשני כפי"ן הדמיון צ"ב. גם קשה לפי' הראשון דמה כוחה של התראה זו, סופך ללקות בצרעת כמו שלקה פרעה ע"י זקנתי שרה, והרי שם לקה פרעה מיד ע"י דיבורה כמו שפרש"י ז"ל, וא"כ כשיראה שלא עלתה לו מדת עונש כפרעה, לא יפחוד גם מהתראת העתיד, ואיך התרה בו בדבר שאינו דומה, ולפי' השני אם תקניטני אהרוג אותך וכו', קשה מדוע תלה הריגתו באם יקניעו, וברור שלא היו השבעים עושים מעשה הריגה כי אם על פי דיני התורה, וכמו שביארו המפרשים בענין הריגת שכם כאו"א עפ"י דרכו, וא"כ ממנ"פ אם דינו להריגה, גם מבלי שיקניטו דיפא הכי, ואם אינו ראוי להריגה עפ"י הדין, גם אם יקניטו אינו ראוי שיתחייב הריגה בשביל זה, ולשני הפירושים צ"ב קישור המאמר ואל יחר אפך בעבדך, ואדרבה לסיבת התראה זו ראוי שיחר אפו עליו.

"And Yehudah approached him, etc., 'and let not your anger burn against your servant, for you are like Pharaoh.' Rashi explains, based on the Midrash, 'You will eventually be stricken with tzara'as (leprosy) just as Pharaoh was stricken because of my grandmother Sarah, who was detained for one night, etc.' Another explanation: 'for you are like Pharaoh' means if you provoke me, I will kill you and your master.

There are difficulties with both interpretations. It should have said 'for you will be like Pharaoh,' rather than 'for you are like Pharaoh' with two comparative כ's (kafs). Additionally, according to the first interpretation, what force does this warning have - that he will eventually be stricken with tzara'as like Pharaoh was through my grandmother Sarah? In that case, Pharaoh was struck immediately through her word, as Rashi explains. Therefore, when he sees that the punishment doesn't match Pharaoh's immediate punishment, he won't fear the future warning either. How could he warn him with something that isn't comparable?

According to the second interpretation - 'if you provoke me, I will kill you' - it's difficult to understand why he made the killing conditional on provocation. It's clear that the tribes wouldn't carry out an execution except according to Torah law, as the commentators explain regarding the killing of Shechem, each according to their approach. Therefore, if he deserves death according to law, he should be killed even without provocation, and if he doesn't deserve death according to law, even if he provokes, he shouldn't deserve death for that reason.

For both interpretations, the connection to the phrase 'let not your anger burn against your servant' needs explanation. On the contrary, because of this warning, it would be more fitting that his anger should burn against him."
summary: This passage from Divrei Yoel discusses the encounter between Yehuda and Yosef, specifically analyzing the phrase "כי כמוך כפרעה" ("for you are like Pharaoh") and Yehuda's request "אל יחר אפך" ("let not your anger flare up"). The text explores two interpretations from Rashi: one comparing potential divine punishment (tzara'at/leprosy) to what happened to Pharaoh with Sarah, and another suggesting a threat of violence if provoked. The key theological tension centers on the nature of justified punishment and authority, questioning whether threats of future punishment are effective deterrents and exploring the relationship between divine and human justice. The passage demonstrates the complex interplay between human authority, divine retribution, and the proper basis for administering justice according to Torah law.
