hebrew_text: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הזוה"ק ור"פ זו) ויגש אליו יהודה וגו' רבי אלעזר פתח וכו' תא חזי כד ברא קוב"ה עלמא וכו', כיון דאתא יומא שתיתאה ואצטריך למברי אדם, אתת אורייתא קמיה, אמרה האי אדם דאת בעי למברי זמין הוא לארגזא קמך, אלמלא לא תאריך רוגזא, טב לי' דלא יתברי, אמר להם קב"ה וכי למגנא אתקרינא ארך אפים וכו'. ולכאורה צ"ב קישור המאמר אל הפסוק ויגש אליו יהודה, ואפ"ל עפי"ד הגמרא ור"ה י"ז ע"ב) מלמד שנתעטף הקב"ה כשליח צבור והראה לו למשה סדר תפלה, א"ל כל זמן שישראל חוטאין יעשו לפני כסדר הזה ואני מוחל להם, וכבר חקרו הקדמונים בכוונת המאמר אי סגי בקריאת הי"ג מדות בלבד, או רק אם יקיימו אותם בפועל, כאמח"ל הדבק במדותיו יתברך מה הוא רחום וכו', ועכ"פ זהו ודאי מהני כמ"ש במדרש ד' צלך שהקב"ה מתנהג עם האדם כצל ובמדה שהוא מודד מודדין לו. ואיתא במדרש באותה שעה אחז יהודה חרבו לשלפה מתערה ואינה נשלפת לו, אמר יהודה ודאי זה ירא שמים הוא, ואולי חשב יהודה דמה שלא נלקה מיד כמו שלקה פרעה ע"ו שרה אמנו, מפני שיש לו זכיות והקב"ה מאריך אף וגבה דילי', ע"כ אמר לו כו כמוך כפרעה בשני כפי"ן הדמיון. ר"ל אדם אחר אם היה עושה כמוך ילקה כפרעה מיד, אבל אתה מפני שיש בך יראת שמים הקב"ה מאריך אפו אליך, אבל סופך ללקות עליו אם לא תשובהו. וז"ש ואל יחר אפך וגו' ר"ל אע"פ שראוי שיחר אפך, תתנהג במדת ארך אפים, ואז גם הקב"ה יתנהג עמך במידה זו ונתן טעם כו כמוך כפרעה שראוי שתלקה מיד כפרעה. אלא שהקב"ה מאריך אפו, וזהו רק אם גם אתה תתנהג במידה זו, ולפירוש הב' א"ל אם תקניטני אהרוג אותך וכו', כי באמת ראוי שתלקה מיד עבור מעשה הגזילה הזו, אלא שהקב"ה מאריך אפו אליך. אבל אם תקניטני ולא תתנהג במדת ארך אפים. אז יגיע עונשך מיד ואהרוג אותך ואת אדוניך, ולא ישמרוך מן השמים למנוע הריגתך, וא"ש קישור דברי הזוה"ק הנ"ל לדברי הפרשה, שבחינה זו המבוארת בזוה"ק היתה טענת יהודה ליוסף, והבן.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

It can be explained by first considering the words of the holy Zohar (beginning of Parshat Vayigash): "And Judah approached him, etc. Rabbi Elazar began... Come and see, when the Holy One, Blessed be He, created the world, etc. When the sixth day came and it was necessary to create man, the Torah came before Him and said: 'This man that You wish to create will anger You in the future. If You will not be patient with his anger, it would be better if he were not created.' The Holy One, Blessed be He, replied: 'Am I called Long-Suffering (Erech Apayim) for nothing?'"

At first glance, we need to understand the connection between this teaching and the verse "And Judah approached him." This can be explained according to the Gemara (Rosh Hashanah 17b) which teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, wrapped Himself like a prayer leader and showed Moses the order of prayer, saying: "Whenever Israel sins, let them perform before Me in this order, and I will forgive them."

The early authorities investigated whether merely reciting the Thirteen Attributes of Mercy is sufficient, or if one must actually embody these attributes in practice, as it is said "Cleave to His attributes - just as He is merciful, etc." In any case, it certainly helps, as the Midrash states "Hashem is your shadow" - meaning that the Holy One, Blessed be He, deals with man as a shadow, and with the measure one uses, they are measured.

The Midrash relates that at that moment, Judah tried to draw his sword from its sheath but could not. Judah said, "Surely this one (Joseph) fears Heaven." Perhaps Judah thought that the reason Joseph wasn't immediately punished (as Pharaoh was regarding Sarah our mother) was because he had merits and the Holy One, Blessed be He, was being patient with him. Therefore, he said to him "for you are like Pharaoh" with two comparative "kafs" - meaning that if another person would act as you do, they would be punished immediately like Pharaoh, but because you have fear of Heaven, the Holy One, Blessed be He, is patient with you, though you will ultimately be punished if you don't return him (Benjamin).

This is what is meant by "let not your anger burn" - although it would be appropriate for your anger to burn, conduct yourself with the attribute of patience, and then the Holy One, Blessed be He, will treat you with this same attribute. He gave the reason "for you are like Pharaoh" - that you deserve to be punished immediately like Pharaoh, but the Holy One, Blessed be He, is patient, and this is only if you too conduct yourself with this attribute.

According to the second interpretation, he said: "If you provoke me, I will kill you..." Because in truth, you deserve to be punished immediately for this act of theft, but the Holy One, Blessed be He, is patient with you. However, if you provoke me and don't conduct yourself with patience, then your punishment will come immediately and I will kill you and your master, and you won't be protected from Heaven to prevent your death.

This explains the connection between the words of the holy Zohar mentioned above and the words of the parsha, as this aspect explained in the Zohar was Judah's argument to Joseph. Understand this.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the interplay between divine patience (אריכת אפיים) and human behavior, centered on the encounter between Judah and Joseph. The key theological insight revolves around the Zoharic teaching that when God created the world, the Torah expressed concern about creating humans who would anger God, to which God responded by emphasizing His attribute of patience. The text connects this to the concept that God mirrors human behavior - when humans display patience and mercy, God responds in kind, as illustrated through Judah's realization that Joseph must be God-fearing due to his restrained response. This forms a fundamental principle in Jewish theology: that divine attributes (מידות) are both a model for human behavior and a response to it, creating a dynamic spiritual relationship between human conduct and divine governance.

hebrew_text: עוד אפ"ל במאמר הכתוב כי כמוך כפרעה, גם לבאר הדקדוקים הנ"ל, בהקדם דברי רבינו בחיי ז"ל סו"פ מקץ, וזל"ק עה"פ ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם, וע"ד הקבלה מה שנחתמה פרשה זאת בפסוק עלו לשלום אל אביכם, רמז לעשרה הרוגי מלכות אשר עלו לשלום אל אביהם שבשמים, אחר שנתלבנו ונצרפו מחטאו של יוסף וכו', ומפני זה נחתמה הפרשה ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם, והיה יכול לומר לכו לשלום לדרככם, אבל הפרשה מבוארת באחי יוסף לשעה, ורומזת לעשרה הרוגי מלכות לדורות אשר עלו לשלום אל אביהם שבשמים. עוד שם בשם פרקי היכלות, כו ר' חנינא בן תרדיון הוחלף בלפינוס קיסר, ולפינוס קיסר הוא שנשרף, וכן כל השאר, כו כן כתוב שם וכמדה זאת לכל חכמי ישראל, ושמעתי בזה כי כשם שהוחלף יצחק באיל והוקבע לו שכר כאילו הוקרב וכאילו אפרו צבור ע"ג המזבח כן הוחלפו חכמי ישראל באחרים, וכיון שטעמו טעם מיתה במה שנתפשו ונגמר דינם לכך, הם קבלו עונשם וה"ז כאילו נהרגו, עכלה"ק.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

One can further explain the verse "for you are like Pharaoh," and also clarify the aforementioned grammatical points, by first considering the words of Rabbeinu Bachya z"l at the end of Parshat Miketz. He writes on the verse "And you, go up in peace to your father": According to Kabbalah, the reason this parsha ends with the verse "go up in peace to your father" alludes to the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut) who ascended in peace to their Father in Heaven, after they were purified and refined from the sin related to [the selling of] Yosef, etc. For this reason, the parsha concludes with "and you, go up in peace to your father." It could have said "go in peace on your way," but while the parsha explicitly deals with Yosef's brothers in that moment, it also alludes to the Ten Martyrs for future generations who ascended in peace to their Father in Heaven.

Further there, citing Pirkei Heichalot: Rabbi Chanina ben Teradion was exchanged with Lupinus Caesar, and it was Lupinus Caesar who was burned, and similarly for all the others. It is written there that this measure applied to all the Sages of Israel. And I heard regarding this that just as Yitzchak was exchanged with a ram and was credited as if he had been sacrificed and as if his ashes were gathered on the altar, so too the Sages of Israel were exchanged with others. Since they experienced the taste of death when they were seized and their judgment was sealed for this, they received their punishment and it is as if they were actually killed.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a deep kabbalistic interpretation of the verse "go up in peace to your father" from the end of Parshat Miketz, connecting it to the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut). The text, citing Rabbeinu Bachya, explains that just as Isaac was substituted with a ram at the Akeidah, the Ten Martyrs were spiritually substituted with others, though they still received the merit as if they had been martyred since they experienced the fear and acceptance of death. The passage reveals a profound theological concept about vicarious atonement and spiritual substitution, suggesting that the mere willingness to sacrifice oneself for Kiddush Hashem (sanctification of God's name) can achieve the same spiritual effect as actual martyrdom.

hebrew_text: ואולי היה ענין כעסו של יהודה על יוסף על שרמז להם גזירת עשרה הרוגי מלכות דהנה הם חשבו אותו למצרי שהוא תחת ממשלת הס"מ ראש כל האומות, וחשב יהודה שהוא רוצה בקיום הגזירה כמו שרוצה הס"מ עצמו, ואף שהוא גזירה מן השמים אעפ"כ הו' מצפה אולי יעלה עוד בידם לבטלו, וכמ"ש בפייט שעלה ר' ישמעאל כה"ג ושאל מאת לבוש הבדים אם הוא גזירה מוחלטת או אולי יעלה בידם לבטלו עד שהשיב להם הקב"ה על ודי בת קול גזירה הוא מלפני, שכ"כ גברה קטרוגו של הס"מ עד שהיה הכרח בגזירה ההוא, וכתב רבינו בחיי שם שהתרו בס"מ בכמה מיני התראות ועונשים קשים ומרים בצרעת ושחין והכל קיבל עליו רק שיוגמר דין בהם עיי"ש, עכ"פ יהודה חשב עוד אולי יעלה בידם לבטל גזירה זו, וע"כ כעס על יוסף שהוא מעורר קטרוג גזירה זו עליהם באומרו ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם.

Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts and terminology:

Perhaps the reason for Yehudah's anger towards Yosef was because he [Yosef] had alluded to the decree of the Ten Martyrs [Asarah Harugei Malchut]. For they thought he was an Egyptian, who was under the dominion of the Samech Mem [Satan], the head of all nations. Yehudah thought that he [Yosef] desired the fulfillment of this decree just as the Samech Mem himself desired it. And even though it was a decree from Heaven, nevertheless, he [Yehudah] was hoping that perhaps they would still be able to nullify it, as it is written in the liturgical poem that Rabbi Yishmael the High Priest ascended and asked the One clothed in linen whether it was an absolute decree or perhaps they could nullify it, until HaKadosh Baruch Hu responded through a Heavenly voice [Bat Kol] that "it is a decree from before Me." For the prosecution of the Samech Mem had become so strong that this decree became necessary. And Rabbeinu Bachya wrote there that they warned the Samech Mem with many types of warnings and severe and bitter punishments including tzara'at and boils, and he accepted them all just so that judgment would be carried out against them, see there. In any case, Yehudah still thought that perhaps they would be able to nullify this decree, and therefore he became angry at Yosef who was arousing this prosecutorial decree against them by saying "and you go up in peace to your father."
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses Yehudah's anger towards Yosef through a mystical lens, connecting it to the future decree of the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut). The key insight is that Yehudah, believing Yosef to be an Egyptian under the dominion of the Samael (Satan), suspected him of trying to enforce this future heavenly decree against the Jewish people, similar to how Samael himself desired it. The text draws a parallel to Rabbi Yishmael Kohen Gadol's heavenly inquiry about whether this decree could be annulled, ultimately learning it was an irrevocable divine decision despite Samael's harsh conditions being met. The passage reveals a deep theological perspective on how historical events in the Torah connect to future spiritual decrees, and how even seemingly unalterable heavenly judgments were subject to attempted negotiation by Jewish leaders.

hebrew_text: וזה ויגש אליו יהודה וגו' כי כמוך כפרעה, הנה לפי' הראשון של רש"י עפ"י פשוטו ירמוז על אותו זמן. וא"ל חשוב אתה בעיני כמלך ע"כ אנו מדבר תחנונים אליך, ולפי' האחרים רמז על העתידות כי כמוך כפרעה סופך ללקות עליו בצרעת, ר"ל במה שאתה מעורר עלינו קטרוג זו. תקבל ע"ז עונש קשה וסופך ללקות בצרעת כמו שהובא לעיל שזה יהי' מדת עונשם, ויהודה חשב על יוסף שהוא משרי הס"מ וחיילותיו ע"כ א"ל במה שאתה מעורר עלינו גזירה זו ורוצה אתה בקיומו. תלקה בצרעת ועונשים קשים ומרים, ד"א מה פרעה גוזר ואינו מקיים וכו' דמצינו כמה גזירות של פרעה שלא נתקיימו, כגון גזירת כל בן הילוד היאורה תשליכהו לא נתקיים שכולם ניצולו מן המים כאמרתז"ל, וכן מ"ש את ישראל לא אשלח לא נתקיימה והיה מוכרח לשלחם. כמו"כ מה שאתה מעורר עלינו גזירת עשרה הרוגי מלכות לא יתקיים אבל יתבטל כמו גזירותיו של פרעה, ד"א אם תקניטני אהרוג אותך ואת אדונך, פו' שלא יוגמר הדין בנו, כ"א יתחלף הדין בך ובאדונך שרים של האומות וכמו שנתחלף לופינוס קיסר בר' חנינא בן תרדיון וכן כל השאר נתחלפו בשרי האומות ויהרגו אותך ואת אדוניך ובזה יובן הלשון כמוך כפרעה בשני כפין הדמיון, שלא היה יהודה יודע בבירור אם יתעורר הגזירה בימיהם או בדורות של אחריהם, ולז"א כי כמוך כפרעה ר"ל שרים כמוך וכפרעה, דאם לא יתקיים הגזירה בימיך, יתקיים בשרים שיהיו אחריך כמוך וכפרעה, שיתחלפו בחכמי ישראל שבדורם ויתקיים בהם גזר הדין.

"And this is [regarding the verse] 'Then Judah approached him...' 'for you are like Pharaoh.' According to Rashi's first explanation, based on the simple meaning, it refers to that time. He said to him, 'You are as important in my eyes as a king, therefore we speak pleadingly to you.' According to other explanations, it hints to future events - 'for you are like Pharaoh' means you will ultimately be struck with tzara'at (spiritual leprosy), meaning that because you are arousing this prosecution against us, you will receive severe punishment and ultimately be afflicted with tzara'at, as mentioned above that this would be their measure of punishment.

Judah thought that Joseph was one of the ministers of the Samael and his forces, therefore he said to him that because you are arousing this decree against us and desire its fulfillment, you will be struck with tzara'at and severe, bitter punishments.

Another explanation: Just as Pharaoh makes decrees but doesn't fulfill them, etc., as we find several of Pharaoh's decrees that were not fulfilled, such as the decree 'every son that is born shall be cast into the river' which was not fulfilled as they all were saved from the water, as our Sages said. Similarly, when he said 'I will not let Israel go' was not fulfilled and he was forced to send them. So too, what you are arousing against us - the decree of the Ten Martyrs - will not be fulfilled but will be nullified like Pharaoh's decrees.

Another explanation: 'If you anger me, I will kill you and your master' means that the judgment will not be completed against us, rather the judgment will be exchanged to you and your master, the ministers of the nations, just as it was exchanged for Lupinus Caesar instead of Rabbi Chanina ben Teradion, and similarly all others were exchanged for ministers of the nations, 'I will kill you and your master.'

This explains the language 'like you, like Pharaoh' with two comparative terms, as Judah didn't know for certain if the decree would be aroused in their days or in later generations. Therefore it says 'for you are like Pharaoh' meaning ministers like you and like Pharaoh - if the decree isn't fulfilled in your days, it will be fulfilled through ministers who will come after you, like you and like Pharaoh, who will be exchanged for the Jewish sages of their generation, and the decree will be fulfilled through them."
summary:
This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the confrontation between Yehudah and Yosef, specifically analyzing the phrase "ki kamocha k'Pharaoh" (for you are like Pharaoh). The text presents multiple layers of interpretation, connecting this biblical moment to the future martyrdom of the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut) and the concept of spiritual decrees being transferred or transformed. A key theological insight is that harsh decrees against the Jewish people, while seemingly fixed, can be redirected or transformed - just as Pharaoh's decrees were ultimately nullified, suggesting that divine justice operates through complex channels where the intended targets of harsh judgments might be replaced by others (specifically, the heavenly ministers of the nations rather than the Jewish sages).

The passage reflects deep Hasidic thought about the interconnectedness of biblical events with future Jewish suffering and redemption, while also exploring the mystical dynamics of how divine decrees can be mitigated or redirected through spiritual mechanisms.

hebrew_text: או ירצה שרמז לו בזה דלעתיד לבא יבא הקב"ה וישחוט למלאך המות וכל חיילותיו יתבטלו וזה שרמז לו באומרו אהרוג אותך ואת אדוניך, הוא הס"מ שהוא מושל על שרו אומות העולם ולעתיד לבא יהרגו אותו ואת כל השרים שלו, וכל דבריו אלו תשובה על דברי יוסף שהזכיר להם ענין עשרה הרוגי מלכות, באומרו ואתם עלו לשלום אל אביכם, וז"פ המדרש מה אופן זה מראה פנים לכל צד, כך דבריו של יהודה מראים פנים לכל צד, פי' שרמז בדבריו תשובה ליוסף לפי פשוטו על אותו הזמן, וגם רמז על העתידות בגזירת עשרה הרוגי מלכות. שהשיג בדברי יוסף מה שיש בלבו, ומה שמרמז בדבריו על גזירה זו באומרו עלו לשלום אל אביכם, ועל כל דבריו ורמזיו השיב לו יהודה באומחו כו כמוך כפרעה ככל הפירושים שפירש"י, וז"ש במדרש שעמד על לבו של יוסף ר"ל שהשיג גם מה שלא אמר יוסף בפי' אלא שהיה הדבר טמון בסתרי לבו.

Or it can be explained that he [Yehudah] hinted to him [Yosef] that in the future, the Holy One Blessed be He will come and slaughter the Angel of Death, and all his forces will be nullified. This is what he hinted at by saying "I will kill you and your master" - referring to the Samech Mem [Satan] who rules over the ministering angels of the nations of the world. In the future, he and all his ministering angels will be killed.

All these words were a response to Yosef's words when he mentioned the matter of the Ten Martyrs [Asarah Harugei Malchut] by saying "Go up in peace to your father." This explains the Midrash that says "Just as this wheel shows faces to every side, so too Yehudah's words showed faces to every side." This means that his words contained a straightforward response to Yosef regarding that moment, but also hinted at future events concerning the decree of the Ten Martyrs.

He perceived what was in Yosef's heart and what he was hinting at in his words about this decree when he said "Go up in peace to your father." To all of Yosef's words and hints, Yehudah responded by saying "for you are like Pharaoh," according to all the interpretations that Rashi explains. This is what the Midrash means when it says he "understood Yosef's heart" - meaning he perceived even what Yosef didn't say explicitly but rather what was hidden in the secrets of his heart.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a deep mystical interpretation of the dialogue between Yehudah and Yosef, focusing on eschatological themes. The key insight is that Yehudah's response contained both an immediate meaning and a prophetic allusion to the future, when God will "slaughter" the Angel of Death (Malach HaMavet) and nullify all his forces, including the Samael and the celestial ministers of the nations. The text connects this to Yosef's subtle reference to the Ten Martyrs (Asarah Harugei Malchut) when he told his brothers to "go up in peace to your father," showing how Yehudah understood both the plain meaning and the hidden implications in Yosef's words, demonstrating the multi-layered nature of their exchange.

"And this is what is meant by 'Now also according to your words, so it is' - for behold, this kitrug (heavenly prosecution) regarding the selling of Yosef was already aroused in the days of the holy Shevatim (tribes). However, the Samech Mem (Satan) did not have the power to complete the matter then, as explained in the holy Zohar that he could not bring judgment against them because their spiritual strength was too powerful. Therefore, he waited for a later generation that was not as great as the holy seventy [souls]. This is what was hinted at by 'Now also according to your words, so it is' - that they were all caught up in the matter. Meaning that the kitrug was aroused from that time to execute judgment against you for the sin of selling Yosef, but 'God forbid that I should do this' - that through me this punishment should come upon you, rather it would be postponed to a later generation."

Note: I've kept Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "kitrug," "Shevatim," and "Samech Mem" in their original form as they carry specific spiritual and mystical connotations in Hasidic thought.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the spiritual consequences of the sale of Joseph (mechiras Yosef) and its long-term impact. The key insight is that while the heavenly prosecution (kitrug) against the tribes began during their lifetime, the Satan (S"M) was unable to fully execute judgment then because the holy tribes were too spiritually powerful. The text explains that the prosecution had to wait for a later generation that wasn't as spiritually elevated as the original tribes to exact its punishment. This interpretation is based on the verse "even now it is as you say," suggesting that while the accountability for the sale of Joseph remained active, the actual judgment was postponed to a later time.

hebrew_text: באופן אחר יתבאר, בהקדם להעיר עוד במאמר הכתוב אדוני שאל את עבדיו וגו'. הקשה הרמב"ן ז"ל, וזלה"ק לא ידעתי טעם לאריכות דברי יהודה בסיפור מה שהיה כבר ביניהם, ומה שאמרו רז"ל וכו זו היא שימת עון שאמרת לשום עינך עליו אינה טענה, כו המושל שיצוה להביא אדם לפניו, לא יעשה על מנת לפטור אותו מן הרעות שיעשה, וכ"ש על הגניבה שיגנוב מבית המלך הגביע אשר ישתה בו, ומתחילה כבר שם עינו עליו לטובה וקרא לו לשלום וכבוד וכו' ומה לעשות לו, עכ"ד.

It can be explained in another way, by first noting an observation regarding the verse "My lord asked his servants, etc." The Ramban z"l raised a difficulty, and these are his holy words: "I do not understand the reason for Yehudah's lengthy retelling of what had already transpired between them. And what our Sages said that 'this is the attribution of sin that you said you would set your eyes upon him' is not a valid argument, for when a ruler commands that a person be brought before him, it is not done with the intention of exempting him from the wrongdoings he commits, and certainly not regarding theft - stealing the goblet from which the king drinks from the king's house. Initially, he had already set his eyes upon him for good, and called him in peace and honor, etc., so what is to be done with him?" These are his words.

Note: I've maintained Hebrew terms like "z"l" (of blessed memory) and kept the reference to the Ramban (Nachmanides) as is, since these are standard rabbinic terminology. The translation preserves the formal style characteristic of rabbinic discourse while making the meaning accessible in English.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses Ramban's commentary on Yehuda's lengthy speech to Yosef regarding Binyamin. The key theological question centers on why Yehuda needed to recount at length what had already transpired between them and Yosef. The Ramban questions the Midrashic interpretation that suggests Yosef was somehow at fault for "setting his eyes" on Binyamin, noting that a ruler has every right to summon someone and punish them for theft, especially when that person had initially been treated with honor and respect. The passage reflects deeper themes about divine providence, justice, and the complex relationship between authority and responsibility in Jewish thought.

hebrew_text: ב) ואשימה עיני עליו. כתב הרמב"ן ז"ל אמר ר' אברהם הטעם שאראה אותו, ולא מצאתי בכתוב שימת עין על הראיה בלבד וכו' עכ"ל. ומצינו שדרשו רז"ל (סנהדרין ז') עה"פ ואלה המשפטים אשר תשים וגו' אלו כלי הדיינים, וכמו"כ דרשו ז"ל (קידושין ל') ושמתם את דברי אלה וגו' סם תם, נמשלה תורה כסם חיים וכו' וטעם דרשות אלו מפני דלא יתכן לשון שימה על המשפטים ועל הדברים ומוכרח לדרשא, וכמו"כ לענינינו כיון דלא יתכן שימת עין על הראיה בלבד, מוכרח שיש בזה עוד כוונה נוספת לבד מפשוטו וצ"ב.
translation:
Here's the translation:

"And I will set My eyes upon him." The Ramban (of blessed memory) wrote that Rabbi Abraham explained the reason as "that I shall see him," but [the Ramban noted that] "I have not found in Scripture the expression of 'setting eyes' referring to mere seeing alone," etc.

We find that our Sages (Sanhedrin 7) interpreted the verse "And these are the ordinances that you shall set [before them]" as referring to the judges' implements. Similarly, our Sages (Kiddushin 30) interpreted "And you shall set these words" as "sam tam" (perfect medicine), comparing Torah to a life-giving medicine, etc.

The reason for these interpretations is because the language of "setting" (simah) cannot simply refer to ordinances and words [in their plain meaning], and therefore must be interpreted homiletically. Similarly, in our matter, since the expression "setting eyes" cannot merely refer to seeing alone, there must be an additional intention beyond its simple meaning, and this requires further examination.

Note: I've preserved Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "Ramban," "sam tam," and maintained the references to Talmudic sources (Sanhedrin, Kiddushin) as they appear in the original text.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the deeper meaning of the phrase "va'asima einai alav" ("and I will set My eyes upon him"). The text builds on Ramban's observation that the term "simat einayim" (setting of eyes) in Torah typically implies more than just physical seeing. Drawing parallels to how Chazal interpret similar phrases in other contexts (like "asher tasim" regarding laws and "vesamtem" regarding Torah study), the author suggests that when the Torah uses the language of "sima" (placing/setting), it often points to a deeper spiritual or conceptual meaning beyond the literal interpretation. The passage concludes that there must be additional layers of meaning to explore in this phrase beyond its simple understanding of visual observation.

hebrew_text: ג) במד"ר (פ' צ"ג ה') בי אדוני בייא את מעביר עלינו. אתמול אמרת לנו הורידוהו אלי ואשימה עיני עליו, זו היא שימת עין נהפך הדבר לסמיות עינים, א"ר סימון בנימוסות שלנו כתיב ואם אין לו ונמכר בגנבתו וזה יש לו לשלם, עכ"ד המדרש. וצ"ב דאיך יטען יהודה נגדו שכך כתיב בתורה, וכי המושל במצרים מתחייב לקיים מה שכתוב בתורה, גם לא היה אז בעולם מי שהשיג משפטי התורה זולת האבות הקדושים והשבטים הקדושים ואיך יבוא בטענה זו לעומתו שיתנהג במשפטי התורה הקדושה.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the religious terminology:

The Midrash Rabbah (Parsha 93:5) [discusses]: "By my master (Bi Adoni)" - You are bringing this upon us. Yesterday you said to us "Bring him down to me that I may set my eyes upon him" - is this what you meant by "setting eyes"? The matter has turned into a blindness of eyes. Rabbi Simon said: In our laws it is written "if he has nothing, then he shall be sold for his theft," but this one (Benjamin) has the means to pay! These are the words of the Midrash.

This requires explanation: How could Yehudah argue against him (the Egyptian ruler) that this is what is written in the Torah? Did the ruler of Egypt have any obligation to uphold what is written in the Torah? Furthermore, at that time there was no one in the world who comprehended the laws of the Torah except for the holy Patriarchs and the holy Tribes, so how could he come with this argument expecting him to conduct himself according to the laws of the holy Torah?

Note: I've maintained Hebrew/religious terms like "Torah," "Midrash," and proper names. The text is discussing the interaction between Yehudah and Yosef (when Yosef was disguised as the Egyptian ruler) regarding Benjamin's alleged theft of the goblet.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a Midrash about the interaction between Yehuda and Yosef (when Yosef was disguised as the Egyptian viceroy). The key theological tension centers on Yehuda's argument invoking Torah law regarding theft and servitude - specifically questioning how Yehuda could expect an Egyptian ruler to follow Torah law when the Torah had not yet been given. The deeper insight appears to be about the universal nature of certain moral principles that existed even before the formal giving of the Torah, and how the Avot (Patriarchs) and Shevatim (Tribes) had special access to these divine truths even before Sinai.

hebrew_text: ד) וישלחני אלקים לפניכם לשום לכם שארית בארץ להחיות לכם לפליטה גדולה, גם כאן צ"ב לשון שימה כנ"ל, גם יל"ד דרישא לאו סיפא דהתחיל אומר לשום לכם שארית בארץ דהיינו בחי' שיריים, וכמו שדרשו ז"ל (ר"ה י"ז) נושא עון ועובר על פשע לשארית נחלתו למי שמשים עצמו כשיריים, וקיי"ל בכ"מ שיריים הוו פחות מחצי', ומסיים דבריו להחיות לכם לפליטה גדולה, והוא דבר והיפוכו.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

"And God sent me before you to establish for you a remnant in the land, to sustain you as a great deliverance." Here too, we need to understand the language of "establishment" (simah) as mentioned above. Also, we need to analyze that the beginning doesn't seem to match the end, as it starts by saying "to establish for you a remnant in the land," which implies the concept of "remnants" (shirayim), as our Sages of blessed memory interpreted (Rosh Hashanah 17) "Who bears iniquity and overlooks transgression for the remnant of His heritage" - this refers to one who makes himself like remnants (shirayim). And we have an established principle that "remnants" everywhere implies less than half, yet he concludes his words "to sustain you as a great deliverance," which seems to be a contradiction.

Note: I've preserved terms like "shirayim" which has special significance in Hasidic thought, often referring to both literal remnants and a spiritual concept of humility and self-nullification.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses an apparent paradox in Yosef's statement to his brothers. It explores the concept of "she'eirit" (remnant/leftovers), connecting it to the Talmudic teaching that God forgives those who make themselves like "leftovers" (humble themselves). The key tension identified is between the seemingly contradictory phrases "to establish for you a remnant" (implying smallness and humility) and "for a great deliverance" (implying greatness). This creates a profound theological insight about how true spiritual greatness comes through humility - when one makes oneself small like "leftovers" (less than half), paradoxically this leads to "great deliverance."

hebrew_text: ונר"פ בהקדם דברי רז"ל הובא ברש"י ז"ל עה"פ כו כמוך כפרעה, אם תקניטני אהרוג אותך ואת ואדונך, ובתרגום ירושלמי אמר יהודה הלא אנא משתבע בחיי רישי' דאבא ולית אנא משקר, דאין שליף אנא חרבי מן גו תיקא, לות אנא מחזיר יתה לתיקא, עד זמן דנימלי כל ארעא דמצרים קטולין וכו', דנעביד כל ארעא דמצרים צדון וכו', ובמד"ר אמר יהודה לנפתלי לך וראה כמה שווקים במצרים, קפץ וחזר ואמר לי' י"ב, אמר יהודה לאחיו אני אחריב מהם ג', וטלו כאו"א אחד אחד ולא נשאיר בהם איש וכו' עכ"ד המדרש. ולכאורה ראוי להבין איך הותר להם להרוג את כל מצרים, ומצינו בהריגת אנשי שכם שנדחקו המפרשים למצוא פתרון האיך הותר להם הריגתם. וביארו כאו"א עפ"י דרכו שדנו בהם דון תורה עיי"ש, ואף הכא טעמא בעי.
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving the religious terminology:

Let us explain by first considering the words of our Sages, brought down by Rashi z"l on the verse "ki kamocha k'Pharaoh" ("for you are like Pharaoh"): "If you provoke me, I will kill you and your master." And in the Targum Yerushalmi, Yehuda said, "I swear by my father's life, and I do not lie, that if I draw my sword from its sheath, I will not return it until all the land of Egypt is filled with corpses," and "until we make all the land of Egypt a wasteland."

And in the Midrash Rabbah, Yehuda said to Naftali, "Go and see how many marketplaces are in Egypt." He jumped and returned saying, "Twelve." Yehuda then said to his brothers, "I will destroy three of them, and each of you take one, and we will not leave anyone alive," etc., thus concludes the Midrash.

At first glance, it is necessary to understand how it was permitted for them to kill all of Egypt, as we find regarding the killing of the people of Shechem, where the commentators struggled to find a justification for how their killing was permitted. Each commentator explained according to their approach that they judged them according to Torah law, see there. Here too, we need to understand the reason.

Note: I've maintained Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "z"l" (of blessed memory) and kept the references to traditional Jewish sources (Rashi, Midrash Rabbah, etc.) in their original form.
summary:
This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the encounter between Yehuda and the Egyptian viceroy (Joseph, though unrecognized), focusing on Yehuda's threat to destroy Egypt if Benjamin is not released. The text explores the theological tension between Yehuda's violent threat to kill Egyptians and the general prohibition against murder, comparing it to the earlier incident with Shechem. The key theological insight centers on the question of when forceful action might be justified in defense of Jewish lives, with the text suggesting that, like the Shechem incident, there must have been a legitimate halachic basis ("din Torah") for such threats, though the specific justification requires further examination.

Note: I aim to maintain respect for the sacred nature of the text while providing an academic analysis of its theological concepts.

hebrew_text: ונקדים דברי הרמב"ם ז"ל (בה' מלכים פ"ט) שנתן טעם להריגת אנשי שכם, לפי שבני נח מצווים על הדינים, והוא להושיב דיינים בכל פלך ופלך לדון בשבע מצות שלהם, ובן נח שעבר על אחת מהן נהרג בסייף, ראה אחד שעבר על אחת מהן ולא דנוהו להרגו הרי זה הרואה יהרג בסייף, ומפני זה נתחייבו כל בעלי שכם הריגה, שהרי שכם גזל והם ראו וידעו ולא דנוהו עכ"ל, והרמב"ן ז"ל בפ' וישלח דוחה תירוצו של הרמב"ם ז"ל, גם חולק על פסקו וס"ל דאין בנו נח נהרגין אם נמנעו להושיב דיינים שזו מצות עשה בהם, ומה שאמרו רז"ל אצל בן נח אזהרה שלהם זו היא מיתתן, לא אמרו אלא אזהרה ולא תקרא אזהרה אלא המניעה בלאו וכו', וכ"ש שלא יהרג כשלא יעשה עצמו קצין שוטר ומושל לשפוט את אדוניו, והוא ז"ל תירץ שהיו אנשי שכם מחוייבים מיתה בלאו הכי, שכולם היו עובדי עבודה זרה ומגלי עריות ועושין כל תועבת ה', אלא שאין הדבר מסור ליעקב ובניו לעשות בהם דין, ובעבור שהיו אנשי שכם רשעים ודמם חשוב להם כמים רצו להנקם מהם בחרב נוקמת וכו' עכ"ד ז"ל. והאור חיים הקדוש לא נראה לו תירוצו של הרמב"ן וכתב עליו שדבריו ז"ל צריכין ערב עיי"ש, ועל תירוצו של הרמב"ם הוסיף להקשות דמי אמר להרב שחייבים לדון האלם עליהם מלך וכיוצא בו. והלא גם בדיני ישראל פטורים כיוצא בזה, שארז"ל המלך לא דנים ולא מעידין אותו, והוא ז"ל תירץ כי בני יעקב לא היה בדעתם להרוג אלא בעלי עבירה. אלא שכל בני העיר רצו להעמיד בפרץ כנגדם לבל יהרגו מלכם, אשר על כן הרגום בדין רודף וכו', ובזה השיגו להרוג את חמור ואת שכם, וזולת זה לא היו יכולים לנקום נקם מהמחויוב להם מיתה, עכ"ל
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the religious terminology:

We will preface with the words of the Rambam z"l (in Hilchos Melachim Ch. 9) who gave a reason for the killing of the people of Shechem, because Bnei Noach (Children of Noah) are commanded regarding dinim (laws), which means to establish judges in every district to judge their seven mitzvos (Noahide laws). A Ben Noach who transgresses one of them is executed by sword, and if someone sees another person transgress one of them and doesn't judge them for execution, this witness should be executed by sword. For this reason, all the people of Shechem were liable for death, as Shechem committed theft and they saw and knew but didn't judge him.

The Ramban z"l in Parshas Vayishlach rejects the Rambam's explanation and disagrees with his ruling, holding that Bnei Noach are not executed for failing to establish judges, as this is a positive commandment for them. When Chazal said regarding a Ben Noach that "their warning is their death," they only meant actual prohibitions, not positive commands, and certainly one shouldn't be killed for not making himself an officer, guard, or ruler to judge his master.

The Ramban explains that the people of Shechem were liable for death anyway, as they were all idol worshippers, committed sexual immorality, and performed all the abominations that Hashem hates. However, it wasn't given to Yaakov and his sons to execute judgment on them, but because the people of Shechem were wicked and their blood was considered like water, they wanted to take revenge with an avenging sword.

The Or HaChaim HaKadosh didn't accept the Ramban's explanation and wrote that his words need a guarantor. Regarding the Rambam's explanation, he further questioned who told the Rav that they are obligated to judge someone who is powerful over them like a king or similar. Even in Jewish law, we are exempt in such cases, as Chazal said that we don't judge or testify against a king. He explains that the sons of Yaakov only intended to kill the transgressors, but all the townspeople tried to stand against them to prevent them from killing their king. Therefore, they killed them under the law of rodef (pursuer), and through this they were able to kill Chamor and Shechem, without which they wouldn't have been able to take revenge against those deserving death.
summary: This passage discusses the halachic debate regarding the killing of the people of Shechem by Jacob's sons. The Rambam justifies it based on the Noahide obligation to establish courts and execute justice, arguing that the people of Shechem were culpable for failing to judge Shechem for his crime. The Ramban disagrees with this reasoning, suggesting instead that the people of Shechem were liable for death due to their idolatry and general wickedness, while the Or HaChaim offers a third perspective - that they were killed under the law of "rodef" (pursuer) when they tried to protect their king from justified punishment. This discussion reflects deeper theological themes about justice, collective responsibility, and the relationship between Jewish and Noahide law.

hebrew_text: והנה גם דבריו ז"ל צ"ב, דהרי מעשה זו עשו ביום שלישי למילתם בהיותם כואבים. וכתיב ויבואו על העיר בטח, וא"כ לא היה עליהם פחד אנשי העיר כלל, והיו יכולים להרוג את חמור ושכם בלבד, ואיך דנו כל אנשי העיר בדין רודף, ואף אם תמצא לומר שהי' היכולת ביד אנשי שכם למנוע מלהרוג את מלכם, מ"מ עדיין אין זה טעם מספיק להרוג את כל אנשי העיר מדין רודף, דהרי אם ניתן להציל את הנרדף באחד מאבריו של הרודף אסור להרגו וחייבים מיתה על הריגתו, א"כ אחר שהרגו את רוב אנשי העיר ולא נשארו רק מתי מספר שאין בכוחם למנוע מלהרוג את מלכם, ודאי שאין עוד היתר להרוג גם את אלו, ואי אפשר לדון בזה אחר רובו דאין הולכין בדיני נפשות אחר הרוב, ועכ"פ להרוג את כולם מבלתי השאיר שריד ודאי שאין טעם מספיק לזה מדין רודף שניתן להצילו בנפשו.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving relevant terminology:

And behold, his words (z"l) require explanation, for this deed was done on the third day after their circumcision when they were in pain. And it is written "they came upon the city confidently," and if so, they had no fear of the townspeople at all, and they could have killed only Chamor and Shechem alone. So how did they judge all the townspeople under the law of rodef (pursuer)?

And even if you were to say that the people of Shechem had the ability to prevent the killing of their king, nevertheless this is still not sufficient reason to kill all the townspeople under the law of rodef. For if it is possible to save the pursued person by [injuring] one of the limbs of the rodef, it is forbidden to kill him, and one who kills him is liable for the death penalty.

If so, after they killed most of the townspeople and only a few remained who didn't have the power to prevent the killing of their king, certainly there was no longer permission to kill these ones as well. And one cannot judge this based on the majority, for we do not follow the majority in capital cases. And in any case, to kill all of them without leaving a survivor certainly has no sufficient justification under the law of rodef where saving the pursued person could have been accomplished through other means.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the complex halachic and moral implications of Shimon and Levi's actions against the city of Shechem. The key theological question centers on whether their killing of all the city's men can be justified under the law of "rodef" (pursuer law), which permits killing in self-defense. The author challenges this justification, noting that since the men were weakened from circumcision and since Jewish law requires using minimal force to stop a pursuer (if possible by injuring rather than killing), the wholesale slaughter seems difficult to justify legally. The passage reflects a deeper theological tension between zealous action in defense of family honor and the precise requirements of Jewish law regarding proportional force and preservation of life.

hebrew_text: ומה שהקשה על הרמב"ם ז"ל דבדיני ישראל ג"כ פטורין מלדון את המלך דלא דנים ולא מעידין אותו, איני מבין קושיתו בזה, דהלא זה התקנה נעשה רק בימי שמעון בן שטח, וכדאיתא בגמרא (סנהדרין וי"ט) משום מעשה שהיה שם בינאי המלך, באותה שעה אמרו מלך לא דן ולא דנין אותו לא מעיד ולא מעידין אותו, אם כן זה הוא מתקנת חכמים, אבל מדאורייתא אין חילוק בין מלך ובין שאר העם, ומהיכי תיתי יהיו פטורים אנשי שכם מלדון את מלכם, אלא שדברי הרמב"ם ז"ל קשים להבין מטעם אחר, דאיך אפשר מציאות כזה להושיב בי"ד ולדון את המלך נגד רצונו, דתקנת שמעון בן שטח שאין דנין את המלך. היה אף באופן שהמלך מרוצה להיות נידון, אעפ"כ אמרו שלא דנין אותו מפני יראת המלכות, אבל כשהמלך מתנגד להיות נידון מי יוכל לדון עם שתקיף ממנו, ומצינו בימי מלכי ישראל שהיו מהם עובדי ע"ז, ולא הושיבו בי"ד לדון אותם, אף שהיו הרבה צדיקים ונביאים באותן הדורות, דמי יוכל לדון את המלך נגד רצונו כיון שוד המלך תקיפה על העם, ואיך אפשר לומר שכל אנשי שכם היו חייבים מיתה על שלא דנו את מלכם שהוא דבר שאינו במציאות כלל
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving relevant terminology:

He questions the Rambam's position regarding why the people of Shechem were culpable, noting that in Jewish law we also exempt the king from judgment, as we neither judge nor testify against him. I don't understand his difficulty with this, because this enactment was only made in the time of Shimon ben Shetach, as mentioned in the Gemara (Sanhedrin 19) due to an incident with Yannai HaMelech. At that time they said, "A king cannot judge and cannot be judged, cannot testify and cannot be testified against." Therefore, this was a rabbinic enactment, but according to Torah law there is no distinction between a king and other people.

So why would the people of Shechem be exempt from judging their king? However, the Rambam's words are difficult to understand for a different reason: How could such a situation be possible - to convene a Beis Din (court) and judge the king against his will? The enactment of Shimon ben Shetach that we don't judge the king applied even when the king was willing to be judged. Nevertheless, they said we don't judge him due to fear of the monarchy. But when the king opposes being judged, who can judge someone more powerful than themselves?

We find that during the times of the Kings of Israel, some were idol worshippers, yet no Beis Din was convened to judge them, even though there were many tzaddikim (righteous ones) and nevi'im (prophets) in those generations. For who could judge the king against his will, since the king's authority over the people is absolute? How can one say that all the people of Shechem deserved death for not judging their king, when such a thing is not practically possible at all?
summary: This passage discusses a complex legal-theological debate regarding the status of kings in Jewish law, centered on Rambam's position. The key discussion revolves around when the exemption of kings from being judged was instituted - whether it was a biblical law or a later rabbinic enactment by Shimon ben Shetach following an incident with King Yannai. The text questions the practical feasibility of forcing a king to stand trial against his will, using this to challenge the notion that the people of Shechem were culpable for not judging their king. The passage ultimately points to a deeper theological tension between ideal justice and practical governance, noting historical examples where even righteous prophets did not attempt to judge idolatrous kings of Israel due to the practical limitations of royal power.

hebrew_text: אמנם נראה ביאור הענין עפ"י דרכו של האוה"ח הק' ולאו מטעמיה, ויבואר עפ"י דברי מהר"ש אלקבץ זלל"ה בספרו מנות הלוי לפרש דברי הגמרא מגילה (דף י"ג ע"ב) ליכא מאן דידע לישנא בישא כהמן. א"ל תא ניכלינהו אמר לי' מסתפינא מאלוקיהון דלא ליעבד בי כדעבד בקמאי, א"ל ישנו מן המצות, א"ל אית בהו רבנן דאבעי עלי' רחמי, א"ל עם אחד הן, וביאר הענין עפ"י מאמרם ז"ל בגמרא ושמתי אני את פנו באיש ההוא ובמשפחתו, אם הוא חטא משפחתו מה חטאת, לומר לך אין משפחה שיש בה מוכס שאין כולה מוכסים, ושיש בה לסטים שאין כולה לסטים מפני שמחפים עליו, מבואר מזה כי על הבלתי מוחים אמר וכשלו איש באחיו והוא מכשול לבד על שאינם מוחים וגם אינם מחפים. ועל המחפום אמר ושמתי אני את פני באיש ההוא ובמשפחתו כו הם כעוברי עבירה, אחר שלא די שלא מיחו אלא שחיפו, וזהו עם אחד הן, עיי"ש.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

However, it appears that the explanation of this matter can be understood according to the approach of the Holy Ohr HaChaim, though not for his reasons. It can be explained based on the words of Maharash Alkabetz z"l in his sefer Manot HaLevi, explaining the Gemara in Megillah (13b) which states that "No one knows how to speak lashon hara (evil speech) like Haman." He [Haman] said to him [Achashverosh], "Let us destroy them." He replied, "I fear their G-d, lest He do to me as He did to my predecessors." He [Haman] said, "They are sleeping from the mitzvos." He replied, "They have rabbis who will pray for mercy." He [Haman] said, "They are one people."

He explained this based on Chazal's statement in the Gemara regarding the verse "I will set My face against that man and his family." If he sinned, what did his family do wrong? This teaches that there is no family with a tax collector that isn't entirely tax collectors, and no family with a thief that isn't entirely thieves, because they cover up for him.

This demonstrates that regarding those who do not protest, the verse states "they shall stumble one over another," which refers only to the stumbling block of not protesting and not covering up. But regarding those who do cover up, the verse states "I will set My face against that man and his family," for they are like transgressors themselves, since not only did they not protest, but they covered up. This is the meaning of "they are one people."
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of collective responsibility within Jewish thought, using the story of Haman from the Megillah as its basis. The text explores the Talmudic principle that when one member of a community sins and others either fail to protest or actively cover up the wrongdoing, the entire community becomes culpable. Drawing on the interpretation of Rabbi Shlomo Alkabetz (author of Manot HaLevi), it explains that Haman's statement "they are one people" refers to this collective responsibility - when Jews fail to rebuke wrongdoing or worse, defend it, they become unified in guilt. This teaching emphasizes the deep interconnectedness of the Jewish people and their mutual responsibility for maintaining proper religious and moral conduct.

hebrew_text: ומבואר בגמרא (גיטין ס"א) בענין מחזיקין ידי נכרים בשביעית אבל לא ידי ישראל, שבהחזקת מילי בעלמא הוו מחזיק ידי עוברי עבירה עיי"ש בגמרא, וכבר ביארתי בספרי ויואל משה גודל חומר העון של מחזיקי ידי עוברי עבירה, כי עפ"י הרוב בני אדם נמנעין מלעשות עבירה בגלוי מחמת הבושה, במ"ש הרמב"ם ז"ל בפי' המשנה (פ' חלק) וז"ל: הרבה בני אדם מתרחקים מן הגדול שבתענוגי הגוף, מיראתו שתשיגהו מזה חרפה ובושה מבני אדם. ובחובת הלבבות (שער הבחינה פ"ה) האריך במידת הבושה שהרבה תועלתה ותקנתה, ולולא היא לא היו נמנעים מהרבה עבירות עיי"ש, והנה ע"ו שמחזיקין בעוברי עבירה אפילו בהחזקת מילי לחוד, נסתלק מדת הבושה מבני אדם, כיון שמחזיקין בידם ומסייעים עמהם, ובזה גורמים להיות העבירה נעשית, א"כ דון הוא שמגיע להמחזיקים עונש כמו העובר עבירה בפועל ממש ועוד יותר ממנו, דלולא המחזיקים ביד עוברי עבירה היו בני אדם נמנעים מחמת הבושה, ולפי זה המחזיק ביד עוברי עבירה אפילו בהחזקת מילי אין זה עבירה בשב ואל תעשה לחוד. אלא נחשב כעושה מעשה עבירה בקום ועשה, וכמבואר במנות הלוי הנ"ל שהמחפים הם כעוברי עבירה עצמם.

It is explained in the Gemara (Gittin 61) regarding supporting gentiles during the Shemittah year but not supporting Jews [who violate it], that even merely verbal support constitutes strengthening the hands of sinners, as explained there in the Gemara. I have already explained in my sefer Vayoel Moshe the severe gravity of the sin of supporting transgressors. For generally, people refrain from committing sins openly due to shame, as the Rambam writes in his commentary on the Mishnah (Perek Chelek): "Many people distance themselves from the greatest physical pleasures out of fear that they will receive disgrace and shame from others."

And in Chovot HaLevavot (Sha'ar HaBechina, Chapter 5), he elaborates on the trait of shame, its many benefits and its corrective nature, and without it, people would not refrain from many sins. Now, through supporting transgressors, even with mere verbal support alone, the quality of shame is removed from people, since they are supporting and assisting them, thereby causing the sin to be committed.

Therefore, it follows that those who provide support deserve punishment like one who actively commits the sin himself, and even more so, because if not for those who support the transgressors, people would refrain from sinning due to shame. According to this, one who supports transgressors, even with mere verbal support, is not merely committing a passive sin (shev v'al ta'aseh), but is considered as actively committing the transgression (kum v'aseh), as explained in the Manot HaLevi mentioned above, that those who provide cover for sinners are considered like the transgressors themselves.
summary: This passage from Divrei Yoel discusses the serious transgression of supporting or enabling those who commit sins (machzikei yedei ovrei aveirah). The key theological insight is that most people naturally refrain from public sins due to shame (bushah), as noted by both the Rambam and Chovot HaLevavot. When one supports or encourages sinners, even just verbally, they effectively remove this natural barrier of shame, making them equally or more culpable than the actual sinner since they've enabled multiple future transgressions. The text emphasizes that such enablement isn't merely a passive sin of omission but is considered an active transgression (kum v'aseh), as those who provide cover for sinners are considered as if they committed the sins themselves.

hebrew_text: והנה כתב רש"י ז"ל עה"פ וכן לא יעשה, לענות את הבתולות שהאומות גדרו עצמן מן העריות ע"ו המבול, נמצא ששכם פרץ הגדר ונעשה הדבר כהיתר על ידו, ולפי שאנשי שכם היו מחפים על מעשיו ומחזיקים בידו, עי"ז נחשב להם כאילו כולם עשו העבירה בפועל וחייבים עלי' מיתה, וכל זה נכלל במה שהם מצווים על הדינים, ואף שלא הי' בידם למחות ביד מלכם ולהושיבו בדיינים, עכ"ז לחפות על מעשיו ולהחזיק בידו ודאי שלא היו רשאים. ועכ"פ לא ימחו ולא יחפו, דאז לא היתה בידם אלא שב ואל תעשה ולא הי' מגיע להם עונש מיתה, ואולי היו נחשבים כאנוסים בזה, כי א"א למחות ביד המלך והוא עושה מה שברצונו לעשות, אבל לפי שהיו מחפום עליו ומחזיקים בידו הרי יש בידם עבירה בקום ועשה, שהרי המחזיק נידון כעובר עבירה עצמו, וע"כ חייבים מיתה, וא"ש דברי הרמב"ם ז"ל

Rashi ז"ל writes on the verse "such a thing must not be done" regarding the violation of virgins, that the nations had made protective fences against forbidden relations after the Flood. Thus, Shechem breached this fence and made the matter appear permissible through his actions. Since the people of Shechem covered up his deeds and supported him, it was considered as if they all actively committed the transgression and were liable for death.

All this is included in their obligation regarding dinim (laws). Even though they weren't able to protest against their king or bring him to judgment, they nevertheless had no right to cover up his actions and support him. At the very least, they should not have protested nor covered up [his actions]. In that case, they would have only been passive [in their transgression] and would not have deserved the death penalty. Perhaps they would have been considered as acting under duress, as it's impossible to protest against the king who does as he pleases.

However, since they covered up for him and supported him, they committed an active transgression, for one who supports [a transgressor] is judged as if they committed the transgression themselves. Therefore, they deserved death, and this aligns well with the words of the Rambam ז"ל.
summary: This passage discusses the moral and legal culpability of the people of Shechem regarding Shechem's assault of Dinah, based on Rashi's commentary. The key theological insight is that while the citizens couldn't prevent their king's actions, their active support and covering up of his sins made them equally culpable as if they had committed the transgression themselves. The text emphasizes that even when one cannot actively prevent wrongdoing by those in power, there remains a moral obligation to at least refrain from supporting or justifying such actions - the principle of "shev v'al ta'aseh" (passive non-participation) would have been preferable to active enablement. This teaching illustrates the Hasidic concept that moral responsibility extends beyond direct actions to include how we respond to and position ourselves in relation to others' transgressions.

hebrew_text: וראיה לדבר שהיו מחפים עליו ומחזיקים בידו לעשות הנבלה ההוא. ממה שהסכימו כל בנו העיר למול את עצמם. ובודאי השיגו תכלית כוונתו שהוא לעבירה, והראיה שלא ביקש מאתם מעולם לעשות אחדות עם בני יעקב כמ"ש עכשיו אחר מעשה הרע ההוא וישבו אתנו בארץ ויסחרו אותה, ומזה הבינו תכלית כוונתו ואעפ"כ הסכימו כולם למול, הרי מוכרח מזה שהיו מחפים עליו כולם מגדול ועד קטן, וזה נתן לו חיזוק ואומץ להיות מחזיק בעבירה, ע"כ כולם חייבים מיתה מדין מחזיק ביד עובר עבירה, ומקור הדין הוא ממה שחייבין ומצווים על הדינים והוא להושיב דיינים ולדון בשבע מצות שלהם ולמחות ביד העובר עליהן, וק"ו שחייבים המחפים ומחזיקים ביד העובר.

And there is proof that they were covering for him and supporting him in committing this disgraceful act. This can be seen from the fact that all the people of the city agreed to circumcise themselves. They surely understood his ultimate intention, which was for sin, and the proof is that he never asked them before to unite with the children of Jacob, as he said only after that evil deed "Let them dwell with us in the land and trade in it." From this, they understood his ultimate intention, and nevertheless, they all agreed to circumcise themselves. This necessarily proves that they were all covering for him, from the greatest to the smallest, and this gave him strength and courage to persist in the sin. Therefore, they all deserve death under the law of supporting a transgressor, and the source of this law is from their obligation regarding the dinim (laws), which requires them to appoint judges and adjudicate their seven mitzvot (Noahide laws) and protest against those who violate them. All the more so are those who cover up and support the transgressor liable.

Note: This text appears to be discussing the biblical episode of Shechem and Dinah, analyzing the culpability of the city's inhabitants.
summary:
This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the moral culpability of an entire city that enabled wrongdoing. The text analyzes how the residents of Shechem agreed to circumcision not out of genuine spiritual motivation, but rather to enable Shechem's improper intentions toward Dinah. The key theological insight is that those who enable or cover up sin (מחפים על העבירה) share in the guilt and liability, as there is a universal obligation (even among non-Jews through the Noahide laws) to establish justice and protest wrongdoing. The passage emphasizes collective responsibility and the serious religious duty to actively oppose sin rather than passively allowing or enabling it.

hebrew_text: מכל הלין נוכל להבין חומר האיסור מלהחזיק בידי עוכרי ישראל שבימינו שהקימו מלכות רשעה על ישחאל, וכולהו איתנייהו בהו ע"ז ג"ע ושפ"ד, והעולה על כולנה כפירה ומינות ל"ע, ואין שייך אמתלא בזה, לומר שאי אפשר למחות ביד המלוכה, דזה מועיל רק לענין מחאה ולאפוקי נפשי' מחיוב הוכח תוכיח, לזה מועיל תו' זה שאי אפשר למחות נגד המלוכה, אבל להיות מחפין עליהם ולהחזיק בידם אפילו בהחזקת מילי לחוד. אין לזה שום אמתלא כמו שלא הועיל תירוץ זה לאנשי שכם, וידוע שכל אותן הלוקחים חלק ותועלת אפילו אפס קצהו ממלכות ההוא, מוכרחין להיות מחפין על מעשיהן ונותנים בזה חיזוק לכל תועבותיהם. ובוודאי יהיו נדונים כמוהם ממש כמ"ש במנות הלוי הנ"ל.

From all of this we can understand the severity of the prohibition against supporting those who trouble Israel in our days, who have established a wicked kingdom over Israel. They embody all [the sins of] avodah zarah (idolatry), giluy arayot (forbidden relations), and shefichut damim (bloodshed), and above all, kefirah (heresy) and minut (apostasy), may Heaven protect us. There can be no excuse in this matter, to say that it's impossible to protest against the government, for such [an argument] only works regarding the obligation to protest and to exempt oneself from the duty of "you shall surely rebuke." For this, the excuse that it's impossible to protest against the government might work, but to cover up for them and support them, even just through verbal support alone - there is no excuse for this, just as this excuse did not help the people of Shechem. And it is known that all those who take part and benefit, even minimally, from that government, are compelled to cover up their actions and thereby strengthen all their abominations. And certainly, they will be judged exactly like them, as written in the Manot HaLevi mentioned above.

Note: I've preserved certain Hebrew terms in transliteration where they represent specific religious or theological concepts that don't have precise English equivalents.
summary:
This passage from Divrei Yoel discusses the serious prohibition against supporting or cooperating with those who are seen as undermining traditional Jewish life and values. The author argues that one cannot use the excuse of being unable to protest against authority as justification for actively supporting or benefiting from such leadership, comparing it to the biblical story of the people of Shechem. The text emphasizes that even minimal participation or benefit from such governance makes one complicit in their actions, and those who provide such support will be judged accordingly. The passage reflects a strong theological position common in certain Hasidic thought that emphasizes maintaining complete separation from secular authority structures that are viewed as contradicting traditional Jewish values.

I aim to present this summary respectfully while acknowledging that these views represent a particular theological perspective within Judaism.

hebrew_text: ועד"ז יובן דברי המדרש שאמר יהודה ליוסף בייא את מעביר עלינו, בנימוסות שלנו כתיב ואם אין לו ונמכר בגניבתו וזה יש לו לשלם, ואין כוונת טענה זו שהמושל במצרים מוכרח להתנהג עפ"י חוקי התורה, דזה דבר שאין לו שחר, אך אמר יהודה כן על דרך התראה ליוסף. על מ"ש כי כמוך כפרעה אם תקניטני אהרוג אותך ואת אדוניך ואת כל מצרים כמבואר במדרשים, ולכאורה איך יוכל להתרות בדבר שהוא נגד התורה, דעל פי התורה אין היתר להרוג שום איש על לא חמס בכפו. ואם כן יבין יוסף שדיבורו והתראתו אין בו ממש, כי ידע שלא יעשו דבר נגד התורה כמ"ש שאמר פרע להם בית השחיטה ועול גיד הנשה בפניהם, וכל העולם כולו ידעו בזרע אברהם ובית יעקב שמחזיקים במצות השי"ת, ולזה הקדים אליו בטענה זו כי בנימוסות שלנו כתיב ואם אין לו ונמכר בגניבתו וזה יש לו לשלם, ואם אעפ"כ רוצה יוסף להחזיקו לעבד. ה"ה נחשב בדיני התורה לגונב נפשות, וגזילה הוא משבע מצות שבני נח מוזהרין עלי' והתראתן זו היא מיתתן, וכמו"כ כל מצריים חייבין הריגה לטעם הנ"ל, דבוודאי יחפו ויחזיקו ביד מלכם, א"כ עפ"י התורה מותר הריגתם בשביל הצלת נפשם, וא"ש גם לפי דרכו של האוה"ח בנידון שכם שהיו חייבין מדין רודף, דכאן לא היו המצריים חולים וכואבים, ובודאי ימנעו כולם וירדפו אחריהם, נמצא שעפ"י דין התורה חייבין כל מצרים הריגה, ובזה הבין יוסף שהתראתו הוא התראה גמורה וצודקת עפ"י חוקי התורה הקדושה.

Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

In this way, we can understand the words of the Midrash where Yehudah said to Yosef, "How unfair you are being to us! In our laws it is written 'if he has nothing, then he shall be sold for his theft,' but this one [Binyamin] has the means to pay!" The intent of this argument was not to suggest that the ruler of Egypt was obligated to conduct himself according to Torah law, as this would be nonsensical. Rather, Yehudah said this as a warning to Yosef.

Regarding what is written "for you are like Pharaoh" - meaning "if you provoke me, I will kill you, your master, and all of Egypt," as explained in the Midrashim. At first glance, how could he threaten something that goes against the Torah, as according to Torah law there is no permission to kill any person who has not committed a violent crime? If so, Yosef would understand that his words and warning were meaningless, knowing they wouldn't do anything against the Torah, as it states that they showed them the place of shechitah (ritual slaughter) and the gid hanasheh (sciatic nerve), and the whole world knew that the descendants of Avraham and the House of Yaakov upheld Hashem's mitzvos.

Therefore, he prefaced with this argument that "in our laws it is written 'if he has nothing, he shall be sold for his theft,' but this one has the means to pay." If despite this, Yosef wants to keep him as a slave, he would be considered a kidnapper according to Torah law. Theft is one of the seven Noahide laws that gentiles are commanded to observe, and their warning is their death sentence. Similarly, all Egyptians would be liable to death for the above reason, as they would certainly support and strengthen their king's hand. Thus, according to Torah law, killing them would be permitted for self-preservation.

This also aligns with the Or HaChaim's approach regarding the incident of Shechem, where they were liable as pursuers (rodfim). Here, the Egyptians were not sick and in pain [unlike the people of Shechem after their circumcision], and they would surely all prevent [their escape] and pursue them. Thus, according to Torah law, all Egyptians were liable to death. Through this, Yosef understood that the warning was a complete and justified warning according to the laws of the holy Torah.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the confrontation between Yehuda and Yosef, specifically analyzing Yehuda's threat to kill Yosef and all of Egypt. The key theological insight is that Yehuda wasn't merely making an empty threat, but rather constructing a legal argument based on Torah law: since Benjamin had the means to pay for the alleged theft, attempting to enslave him would constitute kidnapping, which violates one of the Seven Noahide Laws. The passage explains that this would make Yosef and the Egyptians who would support him into "pursuers" (rodfim), theoretically justifying defensive lethal force according to Jewish law. This interpretation demonstrates how even in moments of intense confrontation, the biblical figures were operating within a sophisticated legal-theological framework, with their actions governed by Torah principles rather than mere emotion.

hebrew_text: ולזה אמר כי כמוך כפרעה, דר"ל כל מי שיסייע לך ויחפה על מעשיך יהיה נידון כמוך וכפרעה, ורמז על דרשתם ז"ל אם תקניטני אהרוג אותך ואת אדוניך ואת כל מצרים כמובא במדרשים, ומטעם זה אמר כמוך כפרעה בשני כפי"ן הדמיון, שהכוונה הוא על כל מצרים שיסייעו ויחפו ויחזיקו בידך, כולם יהיו נידונים כמוך וכפרעה ויתחייבו הריגה על פי התורה.

And for this he said "for you are like Pharaoh," which means that anyone who assists you and covers up your actions will be judged like you and like Pharaoh. This alludes to our Sages' interpretation of "if you provoke me, I will kill you, your master, and all of Egypt" as brought in the Midrashim. For this reason, he said "like you, like Pharaoh" with two comparative "kafs" [the Hebrew letter כ meaning "like"], indicating that this refers to all Egyptians who would assist and cover up and support you - they would all be judged like you and like Pharaoh, and would be liable for execution according to the Torah.

Note: The text maintains the traditional rabbinic interpretative style, referencing Midrashic sources and making specific note of the Hebrew grammatical construction (the double use of כ/kaf) to derive its meaning.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of shared responsibility and divine judgment, focusing on the phrase "for you are like Pharaoh." The key theological insight is that anyone who assists or covers up for wrongdoing shares in the guilt and punishment of the primary wrongdoer, just as the Egyptians who supported Pharaoh shared in his fate. The text emphasizes this through a careful analysis of the double usage of the comparative letter "kaf" (כ) in "kamocha k'Pharaoh" (כמוך כפרעה), suggesting that those who enable evil are judged as harshly as the evildoer himself, and according to Torah law, they all become liable for the same punishment.

hebrew_text: עוד לאלוקי מילין בביאור דברי המדרש הנ"ל, עפי"מ דאיתא במד"ר (פ' משפטים) הה"ד מלך במשפט יעמיד ארץ ואיש תרומות יהרסנה אלו דור המבול. שלא היו עושין את הדין, א"ל הקב"ה מי גרם לכם שתאבדו מן הערב של העולם הזה ומן הבוקר של העולם הבא, מפני שלא קבלתם את התורה שיש בה דין, שנאמר (איוב ד') מבוקר לערב יוכתו, למה מבלי משים לנצח יאבדו, ואין משים אלא דיינים שנאמר ואלה המשפטים אשר תשים לפניהם ע"כ, הרי שדרשו חז"ל בגזירה שוה דלשון שימה רומז על דיני התורה, ממה דכתיב אשר תשים לפניהם, ועד"ז יל"פ לענינינו דמה שאמר להם יוסף ואשימה עיני עליו. רמז להם שיתנהג עמהם עפ"י דיני התורה, והם השיגו הרמז שבדבריו, וכמ"ש בתרגום יוב"ע בריש הפרשה שאמר יהודה ליוסף ארום מן שעתא דאתינן לוותך, הות אמר לן מן קדם ה' אנא דחיל וכו', ואולי הכירו בשרטוטי פניו כי הוא אדם גדול, שהיה זיו איקונין שלו דומה ליעקב, וכתב הרמב"ן ז"ל (בפרשת בראשית) בש"ר שרירא גאון ז"ל שמסרו חכמים א' לחבירו הכרת פנים וסדרי שרטוטין וכו', ובוודאי שהשיגו השבטים הק' חכמה זו. אלא שהיתה סיבה מאת ה' שלא יכירו בו שהוא יוסף אבל יתכן שהכירו בחכמתו וגדולתו

I have more to say regarding the explanation of the aforementioned Midrash, based on what is written in Midrash Rabbah (Parshat Mishpatim): This is what is meant by "A king through justice establishes the land, but one who imposes heavy taxes destroys it" - this refers to the generation of the flood. They did not execute justice, so the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to them: "What caused you to be lost from the 'evening' of this world and from the 'morning' of the World to Come? Because you did not accept the Torah which contains justice, as it is said (Iyov 4) 'From morning to evening they are destroyed.' Why? 'Without anyone paying attention, they perish forever.' And 'paying attention' refers to judges, as it is said 'And these are the ordinances that you shall place before them.'"

Thus, Chazal interpreted through a gezeirah shavah that the language of "placement" (simah) alludes to the laws of the Torah, as it is written "that you shall place before them." Similarly, we can explain regarding our matter that when Yosef said to them "I will place (v'asimah) my eye upon him," he was hinting to them that he would conduct himself with them according to the laws of the Torah. They understood the hint in his words, as the Targum Yonatan ben Uziel writes at the beginning of the parshah that Yehudah said to Yosef, "From the time we came to you, you have been saying 'I fear Hashem,'" etc.

Perhaps they recognized from the features of his face that he was a great person, as his facial appearance resembled Yaakov's. The Ramban writes (in Parshat Bereishit) in the name of Rav Sherira Gaon that the Sages transmitted to each other the wisdom of facial recognition and the patterns of facial features, etc., and certainly the holy tribes possessed this wisdom. However, it was decreed by Hashem that they should not recognize him as Yosef, though they may have recognized his wisdom and greatness.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses a Midrashic interpretation connecting judicial righteousness with Divine providence. The key insight revolves around Yosef's statement "I will set my eyes upon him" (ואשימה עיני עליו), which is interpreted as a subtle hint that he would deal with his brothers according to Torah law, linking to the broader concept that proper judgment sustains the world. The text suggests that while the brothers couldn't recognize Yosef due to Divine intervention, they did perceive his spiritual greatness through his facial features (זיו איקונין) which resembled Yaakov's, drawing on the tradition that the sages possessed wisdom to read character through facial features. This creates a sophisticated theological framework connecting proper judgment, Divine providence, and the transmission of spiritual wisdom.

hebrew_text: ויבואר בזה אמרם ז"ל במסכת מגילה (ט"ז ע"ב) לכולם נתן לאיש חליפות שמלות ולבנימין נתן חמש חליפות, אפשר דבר שנצטער אותו צדיק יכשל בו, דאמר רבא בר מחסיא אמר רב בשביל משקל ב' סלעים מילת, שהוסיף יעקב ליוסף משאר אחיו נתגלגל הדבר וירדו אבותינו למצרים א"ר בנימין בר יפת רמז לו שעתיד בן לצאת ממנו, שיצא מלפני המלך בחמשה לבושי מלכות שנאמר ומרדכי יצא בלבוש מלכות תכלת וגו'. ולכאורה עדיין אינו מיושב הקושיא דבר שנצטער בו אותו צדיק יכשל בו, דהרי מה שרמז לו שעתיד מרדכי לצאת ממנו לא יספיק, דאולי לא יבינו רמז הנבואה ולא יסור הקנאה מלבם, והדרא קושיא לדוכתא איך גרם קנאה בין האחים, אלא בע"כ שהכיר יוסף בהם שהבינו הרמוז במעשיו. וע"כ נא הוה מקום לקנאה בין האחים כיון שעשה בזה רמז לדורות ישראל, עכ"פ מבואר שהשיגו וראו בו ביוסף שהוא אדם גדול, והאמת הוא שכל מעשה יוסף היה לפועל דמיוני על דורות העתידים, ובזה המשיך הדבר להיות יוצא מכח ואל הפועל וכמו שהסביר הרמב"ן ז"ל (פ' לך) שכל מעשה האבות הקדושים היה על זה הדרך עיי"ש.

This explains the statement of our Sages in Tractate Megillah (16b) regarding "To each of them he gave changes of clothing, but to Benjamin he gave five changes." Could it be possible that the very matter which caused that tzaddik (Joseph) such pain, he would stumble in it himself? For Rava bar Mechasia said in the name of Rav: Because of the weight of two sela'im of fine wool that Jacob gave to Joseph more than his brothers, the matter evolved and our forefathers descended to Egypt. Rabbi Benjamin bar Yefet said: He hinted to him that a descendant would come from him who would appear before the king in five royal garments, as it is said, "And Mordechai went forth in royal apparel of techelet (blue)..."

However, the question still seemingly remains unresolved - how could Joseph stumble in something that caused him such pain? For even if he hinted about Mordechai's future emergence from Benjamin, this wouldn't suffice, as perhaps they wouldn't understand the prophetic hint and jealousy wouldn't be removed from their hearts. Thus the question returns: how could he cause jealousy among the brothers?

Rather, we must say that Joseph recognized in them that they understood the hints in his actions. Therefore, there was no place for jealousy among the brothers since he was making an allusion for future generations of Israel. In any case, it is clear that they perceived and saw in Joseph that he was a great person, and the truth is that all of Joseph's actions were symbolic representations for future generations. Through this, he drew the matter from potential into actuality, as the Ramban explains (in Parshat Lech Lecha) that all the actions of the holy forefathers were in this manner, see there.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the deeper significance of Joseph giving Benjamin five changes of clothes while giving only one to each of his other brothers. The text resolves the apparent contradiction of Joseph risking brotherly jealousy (similar to what he experienced) by explaining that both Joseph and his brothers understood these actions as prophetic symbolism, specifically foreshadowing Mordechai (Benjamin's descendant) wearing five royal garments. The key theological insight is that the actions of the forefathers (particularly Joseph) weren't merely historical events but rather served as spiritual prototypes that actively shaped future Jewish history, a concept the text supports by referencing Ramban's teaching that all actions of the Patriarchs were prophetic deeds that created spiritual patterns for future generations.

hebrew_text: ובזה נ"ל ליישב קושית המפרשים בגמרא (שבת קל"ט ע"א) מיום שפירש יוסף מאחיו לא טעם טעם יין דכתיב ולקדקד נזיר אחיו, ריב"ח אומר אף הם לא טעמו טעם יין דכתיב וישתו וישכרו עמו. מכלל דעד האידנא לא, והק' המהרש"א והמפרשים ז"ל דבשלמא יוסף שהכירם שהם אחיו ניחא שהותר לו הנדר, אבל הם שלא ידעו עדיין שהוא יוסף, איך הותר היום נדרם יותר מכל הימים שהי' יוסף פרוש מהם, ונדחק לתרץ דבשביל אימת המלכות התירו היום נדרם עיי"ש, ולדרכינו י"ל דהנה תחלת הכתוב שם ותרב משאת בנימין ממשאת כולם חמש ידות וישתו וישכרו עמו, ולפי מה שדרשו בגמרא הנ"ל שיוסף נתן לו חמש חליפות שמלות לרמוז על מרדכי שיצא בחמש לבושי מלכות, ועשה בזה פועל דמיוני להמשיך כח הנס של פורים, נמצא שאותה הסעודה הי' בחינת פועל דמיוני כסעודת פורים. ובסעודת פורים ארז"ל (מגילה ז') מיחיוב אינש לבסומי בפוריא וכו', ע"כ על אותו היום לא חל נדרם כיון שיש חיוב שתי' בסעודת פורים, ומהאי טעמא וישתו וישכרו עמו.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts and terminology:

With this, it seems possible to resolve the question raised by the commentators on the Gemara (Shabbat 139a) which states that from the day Joseph separated from his brothers, he did not taste wine, as it is written "and to the crown of the nazir of his brothers." Rabbi Yochanan says that they too did not taste wine, as it is written "and they drank and became intoxicated with him," implying that until then they had not drunk.

The Maharsha and other commentators asked: While it's understandable for Joseph, who recognized them as his brothers, that his vow was permitted, but for the brothers who didn't yet know he was Joseph, how was their vow permitted on that day more than all the other days since Joseph had separated from them? They were forced to explain that they permitted their vow that day due to fear of the monarchy.

Following our approach, we can explain: The beginning of the verse states "And Benjamin's portion was five times as large as any of theirs, and they drank and became intoxicated with him." According to what the Gemara interpreted, that Joseph gave him five changes of clothing to allude to Mordechai who would later go out in five royal garments, he was creating a symbolic action to draw down the miraculous power of Purim. Therefore, that feast was like a symbolic enactment of the Purim feast.

Regarding the Purim feast, our Sages said (Megillah 7a) that a person is obligated to become intoxicated on Purim. Therefore, their vow did not apply on that day since there is an obligation to drink at the Purim feast, and for this reason "they drank and became intoxicated with him."
summary:
This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the Talmudic teaching that Joseph and his brothers abstained from wine after their separation, but later drank together when reunited (though the brothers didn't yet know it was Joseph). The text resolves a classic difficulty raised by the Maharsha: how could the brothers break their abstinence before knowing Joseph's identity? The innovative resolution suggests that Joseph's giving Benjamin five changes of clothes was a prophetic allusion to Mordechai's five royal garments in the Purim story, effectively making their feast a prototype of the future Purim feast. Since drinking is obligatory at a Purim feast (ad d'lo yada), their vow of abstinence was temporarily suspended for this meal which carried the spiritual character of a Purim celebration, even though Purim hadn't yet occurred historically.

This interpretation beautifully weaves together multiple layers of Jewish thought - connecting Biblical narrative, prophetic foreshadowing, and the mystical concept of actions in the past affecting future events through spiritual resonance.
