hebrew_text: עוד י"ל טעם אחר למה לא רצה יע"א לבוא למצרים באותן העגלות אשר שלח פרעה, עפי"מ דאיתא במד"ר קהלת ופ"א סימן ה') חנינא בן אחי ר"ו אזל להדין כפר נחום, ועבדין לי' מינאה מלה, ועלון ותי' רכיב חמרא בשבתא, אזל לגבי ר' יהושע חביבי' ויהיב עלי' משח ואיתסי, א"ל כיון דאיתער בך חמרא דההוא רשיעא, לית את יכיל שרו בארעא דישראל, נחית לי' מן תמן לבבל ודמך תמן בשלמי', מבואר מזה דבשביל שעלה לא"י על חמורו של רשע לא מצא לו ר' יהושע תקנה רק לצאת מא"י, ואיתא בזוה"ק כשירד יעקב אבינו למצרים ירדה עמו השכינה הקדושה והי' שם אוירא דא"י, נמצא שבהליכתו למצרים הלך יעקב אבינו לארץ ישראל. ולפי דברי המדרש הנ"ל מבואר דאסור לילך לא"י באמצעות ובסיוע רשעים, פ"כ לא הלך יעקב באותן העגלות אשר שלח פרעה. ובאותן העגלות ששלח יוסף לא השתמש בהן, לפי שגם הם היו עפ"י פרעה וברשותו, כמ"ש ואתה צויתה זאת עשו קחו לכם עגלות וגו', פירש"י ואתה צוותה מפי לומר להם. שלא היו רשאים להוציא עגלות ממצרים רק ברשות פרעה, ויעקב אבינו לגודל קדושתו הקפיד גם על זה, ולכך הוצרכו השבטים הק' לשאת את יעקב אבינו על כתפיהם דייקא.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Another reason can be given for why Yaakov Avinu did not want to come to Egypt in the wagons that Pharaoh sent, based on what is written in Midrash Rabbah Kohelet (Chapter 1, Section 5): Chanina ben Achi R' Yehoshua went to Kfar Nachum, and the heretics did something to him, and they made him ride a donkey on Shabbos. He went to his beloved R' Yehoshua who applied oil to him and he was healed. He said to him, "Since the donkey of that wicked one has awakened within you, you cannot dwell in Eretz Yisrael." He went down from there to Bavel and passed away there in peace.

From this it is clear that because he rode to Eretz Yisrael on a wicked person's donkey, R' Yehoshua found no remedy except to leave Eretz Yisrael. The holy Zohar states that when Yaakov Avinu went down to Egypt, the holy Shechinah descended with him and there was the air of Eretz Yisrael there. Thus, when going to Egypt, Yaakov Avinu was essentially going to Eretz Yisrael.

According to the aforementioned Midrash, it is forbidden to go to Eretz Yisrael through the means and assistance of wicked people. Therefore, Yaakov did not travel in the wagons that Pharaoh sent. And he didn't use the wagons that Yosef sent either, because they too were under Pharaoh's authority and permission, as it is written "And you are commanded to do this: take wagons, etc." Rashi explains "And you are commanded" means to tell them from my mouth, as they were not permitted to take wagons from Egypt except with Pharaoh's permission. Yaakov Avinu, due to his great holiness, was particular even about this, and therefore the holy tribes needed to carry Yaakov Avinu specifically on their shoulders.
summary: This passage discusses why Jacob (Yaakov Avinu) refused to use the wagons sent by Pharaoh to travel to Egypt. The key theological concept centers on the principle that one should not enter the Land of Israel through means provided by wicked people, as demonstrated by a Midrashic story about Rabbi Yehoshua's nephew who had to leave Israel after riding a heretic's donkey. Since the Divine Presence (Shechina) descended with Jacob to Egypt, creating an atmosphere of Eretz Yisrael there, Jacob's journey to Egypt was spiritually equivalent to entering the Holy Land - thus he refused to use Pharaoh's wagons or even those sent by Joseph (since they were authorized by Pharaoh), requiring his sons to carry him instead. This demonstrates an extremely high level of spiritual sensitivity and the importance of maintaining complete spiritual purity when engaging with holy matters.

hebrew_text: וישלח את אחיו וילכו ויאמר אליהם אל תרגזו בדרך, בגמרא תענית (י' ע"ב) א"ר אלעזר א"ל יוסף לאחיו אל תתעסקו בדבר הלכה וכו' איני והא"ר אלעאי ב' ת"ח שמככום בדרך ואין ביניהם דברי תורה ראויין לישרף וכו', לא קשיא הא למיגרס הא לעיוני, פרש"י למגרס מבעי' לי' באורחא, אבל במילתא דמבעי' לעיוני לא, ובתוס' כתבו ווש מדרש אל תפסיקו מדבר הלכה עכ"ל, וכן הוא במדרש רבה שלפניו אל תרגזו בדרך אמר להם אל תפסיעו פסיעה גסה ואל תטמידו עצמכם מדברי תורה, פי' במתנות כהונה אל תפסוקו מד"ת, והוא סתירה לכאורה לדברי הגמ' הנ"ל אף דאפשר לחלק הא למיגרס והא לעיוני כמו שחילקו בגמ', מ"מ צ"ב איך דרשו רז"ל מפסוק א' דבר והיפוכו, שבגמ' דרשוהו שצוה להם יוסף למנוע בדרך מלעסוק בדבר הלכה, ובמדרש דרשו להיפך שצום שלא להפסיק מד"ת, ולשני הדרשות צ"ב מדוע רמז הכתוב לזה בלשון אל תרגזו, ולא מצינו בשום מקום דוגמתו, שישתמש הכתוב בלשון רוגז מעל העסק בד"ת ולא על התבטלות מד"ת.

Here's the English translation, preserving the Hebrew/Aramaic terminology:

"And he sent his brothers away, and they departed; and he said to them, 'Do not become agitated on the way.' In the Gemara Taanis (10b), Rabbi Elazar said that Yosef told his brothers not to engage in matters of halacha, etc. But is this so? Didn't Rabbi Ilai say that two Torah scholars who travel together and don't discuss divrei Torah deserve to be burned, etc.? This is not a contradiction - one refers to reviewing (migras), the other to in-depth analysis (iyun). Rashi explains that reviewing is required while traveling, but deep analysis is not.

The Tosafos wrote that there is a Midrash stating 'don't stop discussing halacha.' This is also found in the Midrash Rabbah before it: 'Do not become agitated on the way' - he told them not to take large steps and not to stop themselves from divrei Torah. The Matnos Kehuna explains this to mean 'don't cease from divrei Torah.'

This appears to contradict the aforementioned Gemara, although one could differentiate between reviewing and analysis as the Gemara does. Nevertheless, it requires explanation how Chazal derived opposite interpretations from the same verse - in the Gemara they interpreted that Yosef commanded them to refrain from engaging in halachic matters while traveling, while in the Midrash they interpreted the opposite, that he commanded them not to cease from divrei Torah. Both interpretations require explanation as to why the verse hints at this with the language of 'do not become agitated' (al tirgezu), as we don't find anywhere else where Scripture uses the language of 'rogez' (agitation) either regarding engagement in divrei Torah or cessation from divrei Torah."
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses an apparent contradiction in how different rabbinic sources interpret Joseph's instruction to his brothers "אל תרגזו בדרך" ("do not become agitated on the way"). The Talmud in Ta'anit understands this as a warning against engaging in deep Torah study while traveling, while the Midrash interprets it as an admonition not to cease from Torah study. The text grapples with how these seemingly opposite interpretations can be derived from the same verse, and questions why the Torah uses the specific language of "רוגז" (agitation/anger) to discuss Torah study. The resolution hinges on distinguishing between different types of Torah study - basic review (מיגרס) versus deep analysis (עיוני) - suggesting a balanced approach to Torah study that considers both spiritual growth and practical circumstances.

hebrew_text: ב) וירא את העגלות אשר שלח יוסף וגו' פרש"י סימן מסר להם, במה הי' עוסק כשפירש ממנו, בפ' עגלה ערופה, זהו שנאמר וירא את העגלות אשר שלח יוסף וכו', ובבעלי התוס' כתבו ע"ד רש"י ז"ל וצריך פי' לפירושו, ע"כ פי' כי כשפירש יעקב מאביו הי' מלוה אותו, כדכתיב וישלחהו שהוא לשון לויה וכו', וא"ל יוסף חזור בך. וא"ל יעקב בני גדולה מצות לויה שעליה נתוספה פרשה אחת בתורה דכתיב ידינו לא שפכה, וכי תעלה על דעתך שבי"ד שופכי דמים, אלא לא ראינוהו ופטרונוהו בלא לויה, הא אם ראוהו ולא לווהו מעלה עליהם כאילו שפכו דמים, והיינו פרשת עגלה ערופה שהי' עסוק בה, וקשה לשני הפירושים לפרש עגלות לשון עגלה וכו' עכ"ד בעה"ת, גם ראוי להבין ענין הרמז מה הוא, ומדוע שלח יוסף סימנים אלו דייקא, ואיך מתחילה ויפג לבו כי לא האמין להם, וע"י הרמז בסימנים אלו כתיב ותחי רוח יעקב, ואיך נתברר אליו אמיתת דבריהם פ"י הרמז בסימנים האלו.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

"And he saw the wagons (agalot) that Yosef had sent, etc." Rashi explains that he gave them a sign regarding what they were studying when they separated - the passage of the eglah arufah (broken-necked heifer). This is what is meant by "and he saw the wagons that Yosef had sent."

The Baalei HaTosafot wrote regarding Rashi's explanation that it needs further clarification. They explained that when Yaakov separated from his father, he accompanied him, as it is written "and he sent him," which refers to accompaniment (levayah). Yosef said to him, "Return," and Yaakov replied, "My son, the mitzvah of accompaniment is so great that an entire passage was added to the Torah because of it, as it is written 'our hands did not spill this blood.' Would you think that the Beit Din are murderers? Rather, [it means] we didn't see him and dismiss him without accompaniment. Thus, if they saw him and didn't accompany him, it is considered as if they spilled blood." This is the passage of eglah arufah that they were studying.

It is difficult according to both explanations to interpret "agalot" (wagons) as relating to "eglah" (heifer), etc., as the Baalei HaTosafot conclude. It is also important to understand the nature of this hint, why Yosef sent these specific signs, and why initially "his heart grew faint because he did not believe them," but through these signs it says "the spirit of Yaakov was revived," and how the truth of their words was verified through these hints and signs.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the profound significance of the wagons (agalot) that Yosef sent to his father Yaakov, focusing on the deep connection to the mitzvah of escort (levayah) and the ritual of the eglah arufah (broken-necked heifer). The text explores why Yosef specifically chose these symbols as proof of his identity to Yaakov, connecting it to their last shared Torah study about the importance of properly escorting travelers. The passage raises the theological question of how these specific signs revived Yaakov's spirit (vatechi ruach Yaakov), suggesting that the spiritual connection through Torah study between father and son served as a deeper verification than mere physical evidence could provide.

According to the Midrash, when Yaakov saw these wagons, he declared with certainty that he now knew Yosef had not sinned with Potiphar's wife. hebrew_text: וגבוא אל הביאור ותחלה נפרש בדרך פשוטו דע"י שראה יע"א העגלות אשר שלח יוסף נתברר לו שעוד יוסף חי ושעומד בצדקתו, דהנה כלל גדול הוא שכח הפועל בנפעל, ורז"ל אמרו בהמה וכלים הרי הם כרגלי הבעלים, וראי' ברורה לזה מחמורו של ר"פ בן יאיר דלפי שהי' ברשותו של ר"פ בן יאיר, הי' בו מכח הבעלים, עד שאמרו חכז"ל בדור האמוראים (שבת קי"ב ע"ב) אם הראשונים בני מלאכים אנו בני אנשים, ואם ראשונים בני אנשים אנו כחמורים ולא כחמורו של ר"פ בן יאיר אלא כשאר חמורים, וכמו"כ מצינו בגמליו של אאע"ה, דאיתא במדיר ויפתח הגמלים התיר זמומיהם, ר"ה ור"י שאלו לר"ח ב"ר לא היו גמליו של א"א דומים לחמורו של של ר"פ בן יאיר וכו', ופי' במתנות כהונה בשם הרמב"ן ז"ל שהוא תמי' קיימת, וס"ל שהפסוק ויפתח קאי על קשרי האוכף ולא על הזממים, שלא הי' להם זממים עיי"ש, ואף שאין לבהמה דעת להבחין בין טוב לרע, עכ"ז ע"ו שהיא ברשותו של צדיק יש לו כח הבעלים לטובה, ועד"ז אם היא ברשותו של רשע יש לו כח רע של הבעלים, כדאיתא במד"ר (קהלת א' כ"ה) חנינא בן אחי ר"י אזל להדי' כפר נחום ופבדוו לי' מינאה מלה (פי' כישוף) ועלון יתי' רכיב חמרא בשבתא, אזל לגבי' יהושע חביבי' ויהב עלי' משח ואיתסי, א"ל כיון דאיתער בך חמרא דההוא רשיעא לית את יכול שרו בארעא דישראל, נחת לי' מן המן לבבל ודמך תמן בשלמי' ע"כ, מבואר דבשביל שפגע בו חמורו של רשע נגרם לו פגם גדול כ"כ עד שהוכרח לצאת מארץ ישראל לחו"ל
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving relevant Hebrew/Hasidic terminology:

Let us come to the explanation, and first we will explain according to the simple meaning that when Yaakov Avinu saw the wagons that Yosef sent, it became clear to him that Yosef was still alive and standing firm in his righteousness. For there is a great principle that the power of the doer is in what is done, and our Sages said that animals and vessels follow the status of their owners. Clear proof of this is from the donkey of Rabbi Pinchas ben Yair, for since it was in his possession, it had the power of its owner, to the extent that our Sages said in the generation of the Amoraim (Shabbat 112b): "If the earlier ones were like angels, we are like humans; if the earlier ones were like humans, we are like donkeys - and not like the donkey of Rabbi Pinchas ben Yair, but like other donkeys."

Similarly, we find regarding the camels of Avraham Avinu, as it states in the Midrash regarding "and he unmuzzled the camels." Rav Huna and Rabbi Yirmiyah asked Rabbi Chiya bar Rav: "Were not Avraham Avinu's camels similar to the donkey of Rabbi Pinchas ben Yair?" And the Matanot Kehuna explains in the name of the Ramban that this is a standing question, and holds that the verse "and he unmuzzled" refers to the saddle straps and not to muzzles, as they didn't have muzzles.

And even though an animal has no intelligence to distinguish between good and evil, nevertheless, through being in the possession of a tzaddik, it has the positive power of its owner. And similarly, if it is in the possession of a wicked person, it has the negative power of its owner, as brought in Midrash Rabbah (Kohelet 1:25) about Chanina ben Achi Rabbi Yehoshua who went to Kfar Nachum where heretics performed sorcery on him, making him ride a donkey on Shabbat. He went to his beloved Yehoshua who applied oil and he was healed. He said to him, "Since the donkey of that wicked person affected you, you cannot remain in Eretz Yisrael." He went down to Bavel and passed away there in peace. This shows that because he was affected by a wicked person's donkey, it caused such a great spiritual blemish that he had to leave Eretz Yisrael for outside the Land.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses an important Hasidic concept about the spiritual connection between owners and their possessions, particularly through the lens of the story of Joseph's wagons sent to Jacob. The key theological insight is that objects and animals take on the spiritual qualities of their owners - a principle demonstrated through stories about the donkey of Rabbi Pinchas ben Yair and Abraham's camels, which exhibited special qualities due to their righteous owners. The text explains that even though animals lack moral discernment, when owned by a tzaddik (righteous person) they acquire positive spiritual qualities, while those owned by a rasha (wicked person) can transmit negative spiritual influences. This concept illustrates the Hasidic understanding that holiness and spiritual qualities can permeate even the physical world, affecting and transforming the nature of material possessions.

hebrew_text: וכתב בספה"ק אגרא דכלה עה"פ ואתה לא כן נתן לך ה' אלקיך, דהממון מאינשי דלא מעלי מזיק מאוד לבחי' הנפש המקבלם לפי שוש בו כח הפועל של הבעלים הנותנים עיי"ש, ויתכן לומר שלטעם זה שלח פרעה עגלות בעצמו ומשלו, אף שכל התנהגות המלוכה הי' ע"ו יוסף, מפני שחשב דלפי שכח הפועל בנפעל, יפגם ח"ו במקצת את קדושת יע"א ובניו הק"נ ע"ו שיבואו למצרים בעגלות אשר שלח, וכתב הרמ"ע מפאנו זלה"ה עה"פ והפלה ה' בין מקנה ישראל ובין מקנה מצרים, דזכי הראות הכירו בבהמה אם הוא קנינו של צדיק או של רשע, וכן בכל החפצים בדצ"ח הכירו צדיקים אמיתיים, אם הם משורש הקדושה או להיפוך עכת"ד, ובזה יתבאר דברי המדרש כשראה יעקב את העגלות ששלח יוסף, אמר בודאי אני יודע שלא חטא יוסף באשת פוטיפר דוודאי שיע"א הי' מכיר בחפצים של כל אדם בחינתו של הבעלים, וע"כ כשראה את העגלות הכיר בהם בחי' קדושתו של יוסף וע"כ אמר יודע אני שלא חטא יוסף באשת פוטיפרע.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

The holy sefer Agra D'Kallah writes on the verse "But Hashem your G-d has not permitted you to do so," that money received from unworthy people is very harmful to the nefesh (soul) of those who receive it, because it contains the spiritual force of its original owners.

Based on this reasoning, one could say that this is why Pharaoh sent wagons personally and from his own possession, even though all royal affairs were handled through Yosef. He thought that since the spiritual force of the actor affects the recipient, he might somehow damage the kedushah (holiness) of Yaakov Avinu and his holy sons through the wagons he sent, causing them to come to Egypt in these wagons.

The RaMa"A of Pano writes regarding the verse "And Hashem will distinguish between the livestock of Israel and the livestock of Egypt," that those with refined spiritual vision could recognize whether an animal belonged to a tzaddik (righteous person) or to a rasha (wicked person). Similarly, true tzaddikim could recognize in all objects - whether inanimate, vegetative, or living - if they were from the root of kedushah or its opposite.

This explains the Midrash that when Yaakov saw the wagons that Yosef sent, he said, "Now I know for certain that Yosef did not sin with Potiphar's wife." This is because Yaakov Avinu could recognize in any object the spiritual nature of its owner. Therefore, when he saw the wagons, he recognized in them Yosef's kedushah, and thus declared, "I know that Yosef did not sin with Potiphar's wife."
summary: This passage discusses an important Hasidic concept regarding the spiritual nature of physical objects and their connection to their owners. The key insight is that objects carry within them the spiritual essence (koach ha-po'el) of their owners, which can affect those who receive or use them. The text specifically analyzes why Pharaoh sent his own wagons to transport Jacob's family, suggesting that righteous individuals (tzaddikim) could discern the spiritual source of objects - whether they came from a holy or unholy source. This concept is then applied to explain how Jacob knew Joseph remained righteous when he saw the wagons sent for him, as he could spiritually discern their holy nature, confirming that Joseph had maintained his spiritual purity despite his trials in Egypt.

hebrew_text: ומעתה נפרש עפ"י דרכם של בעה"ת, שרמז יוסף בסימן העגלות על מצות לויה ויתבאר בהקדם מה שהקשה בספר באר שבע בחידושיו (עמ"ס סוטה) דמצינו שחז"ל הפליגו בשבח מצות לוי' כ"כ, ומדוע בטור ושו"ע השמיטו הלכה זו וטעמא בעי, ונדחק לתרץ משום שעכשיו כל הדרכים בחזקת סכנה הם ואין חיוב לסכן א"ע בשביל מצוה של לויה, וכעין שכתבו התוס' כתובות (ק"ו ע"ב) גבי הוא אומר לעלות והיא אומרת שלא לעלות כופין אותה לעלות, דאינו נוהג בזמה"ז דאיכא סכנת דרכים עכת"ד הבאר שבע. אמנם אין תירוץ זה מספיק ואין ראי' מדברי התוס' אלו דהתם איכא סכנת ימים ומדברות וכדומה, אבל מצות לויה דאפשר לקיימה גם במקום ישוב בנ"א בעיר, ומעיר לעיר במקום דליתא חשש סכנה, ואין סברא דמה"ט תבטל מצות לוי' בכל מקום, משום דלפעמים איכא חשש סכנה.
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Now we will explain according to the approach of the Ba'alei HaTosafot, that Yosef hinted through the sign of the wagons about the mitzvah of levayah (escorting guests). This will be explained by first addressing what the Be'er Sheva questioned in his novellae (on Masechet Sotah), that we find that Chazal greatly praised the mitzvah of levayah, so why did the Tur and Shulchan Aruch omit this halachah? This requires explanation. He struggled to answer that it's because nowadays all roads are presumed dangerous, and there is no obligation to endanger oneself for the mitzvah of levayah, similar to what Tosafot wrote in Ketubot (106b) regarding when he wants to make aliyah and she doesn't want to, that we compel her to go up - that this doesn't apply nowadays due to the danger of travel, these are the words of the Be'er Sheva.

However, this answer is insufficient, and there is no proof from these words of Tosafot, for there they were discussing dangers of seas and deserts and the like, but the mitzvah of levayah can be fulfilled even in inhabited places within a city, and from city to city where there is no concern of danger. It doesn't make sense that the mitzvah of levayah should be nullified everywhere just because sometimes there might be a concern of danger.
summary:
This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the mitzvah (commandment) of levayah (escorting travelers), focusing on a fundamental question raised by the Be'er Sheva regarding why this mitzvah, despite being highly praised by the Sages, was omitted from the Tur and Shulchan Aruch. The Be'er Sheva suggests that the omission was due to the dangerous nature of travel in later times, similar to the Tosafot's ruling about the obligation to move to Israel. However, the author challenges this explanation, arguing that unlike long-distance travel involving seas and deserts, the mitzvah of levayah can still be performed safely within cities and between nearby locations, and therefore shouldn't be entirely nullified just because some situations might be dangerous.

The theological depth here centers on the enduring relevance of mitzvot across changing historical circumstances and the importance of finding ways to maintain religious obligations even in challenging times.

hebrew_text: ואפשר לתרץ קושיתו עפימ"ש בספה"ק טועם אלימלך זלה"ה עה"פ ויהי בשלח פרעה את העם וזל"ק: ונ"ל ליתן טעם על מצות לויה, כשהצדיק מלוה את חבירו, הם מתקשרים זב"ז בקדושתם ונעשים כא' וקדושתו של זה הצדיק העוסק בתורה בביתו, הוא משמר את חבירו בדרך כאילו הוא עצמו עוסק בתורה מחמת התקשחותם וכו', זהו כשהצדיק הוא המלוה, אבל אם הוא איש נעצב וריקן, אין תועלת לזה במה שזה מלוהו. ואדרבה הוא מכניס בו עצבותו ומפסיקו יותר מקדושתו שיש בו, וזהו ויהי בשלח פרעה, ר"ל מחמת שפרעה שלח את ישראל וכו' ולכן לא נחם וגו' עכדה"ק.
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

One can resolve his question based on what is written in the holy sefer "Noam Elimelech" on the verse "And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent forth the people," and these are his holy words:

"It appears to me to give a reason for the mitzvah of levayah (accompaniment). When a tzaddik accompanies his fellow, they become connected to each other in their kedushah (holiness) and become as one. The kedushah of this tzaddik who engages in Torah study in his home protects his fellow on the journey as if he himself were studying Torah, due to their connection, etc. This is when the tzaddik is the one doing the accompanying. However, if the person accompanying is sad and empty [of spiritual content], there is no benefit to the one being accompanied. On the contrary, he transmits his sadness to him and distances him further from the kedushah that he possesses. This is the meaning of 'And it came to pass when Pharaoh sent forth' - meaning, because Pharaoh was the one who sent forth Israel, etc., therefore 'He did not lead them,' etc." These are his holy words.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the spiritual concept of "levayah" (accompaniment) based on teachings from the Noam Elimelech. The core insight is that when a tzaddik (righteous person) accompanies another person, they become spiritually connected, and the tzaddik's Torah study and holiness protect the traveler as if they themselves were studying Torah. However, the passage warns that if the person doing the accompanying is spiritually empty or depressed, not only is there no benefit, but they may actually transmit their negative spiritual state to the other person and diminish their holiness. This concept is connected to Pharaoh's sending away of the Jewish people, suggesting that his negative spiritual influence affected how their journey began.

hebrew_text: ועפי"ד הק' נבין במאמה"כ בפרשת עגלה ערופה ונגשו הכהנים בני לוו כ' בם בחר ה"א לשרתו ולברך בשם ה' ועל פיהם יהי' כל ריב וכל נגע וענו ואמרו ידינו לא שפכו וגו', ולכאורה הרי הרבה פעמים הזכיר הכתוב הכהנים, כמו בפרשת תרומה ובעבודה ובשום מקום אינו מספר עליהם שבח זה כי בם בחר ה"א לשרתו וגו' ולמה דוקא בעגלה ערופה הזכיר שבח זה, ויובן עפ"י דברי הנוע"א זלה"ה דלפי שהצריכם התוה"ק לומר ידינו לא שפכו את הדם הזה ודרשו רז"ל לא פטרנוהו בלא לויה, לזה הקדים לומר כי בם בחר הי, משא"כ המחקן מבחי' קדושה טוב יותר שלא ילוה, שאין תועלת להמתלוה אם המלוה הוא איש נעצב וריקן.
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Based on these holy words, we can understand the verse regarding the Eglah Arufah (broken-necked heifer), "And the Kohanim, the sons of Levi, shall approach, for them Hashem your G-d has chosen to serve Him and to bless in Hashem's name, and by their word shall be every dispute and every plague. And they shall answer and say 'Our hands did not spill [this blood]', etc."

At first glance, the Torah mentions the Kohanim many times, such as in Parshat Terumah and regarding the Temple service, but nowhere else does it describe this praise that "them Hashem your G-d has chosen to serve Him, etc." Why specifically regarding the Eglah Arufah does it mention this praise?

This can be understood according to the words of the Noam Elimelech, of blessed memory, that since the Torah requires them to say "our hands did not spill this blood," which our Sages interpreted as "we did not send him away without escort (levayah)," therefore it prefaces by saying that "them Hashem has chosen." This is different from one who is detached from holiness - it would be better if such a person did not escort others, as there is no benefit to the one being escorted if the escort is a depressed and empty person.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the unique mention of the Kohanim's (priests') divine selection in the context of the Eglah Arufah (broken-necked heifer) ceremony. The text questions why specifically here the Torah emphasizes that "God chose them to serve Him," when this praise isn't mentioned in other priestly contexts. The answer lies in the connection to the concept of levayah (accompaniment/escort) - the priests must declare they didn't send the victim away without proper escort. The passage concludes with a profound insight: the Torah specifically mentions the priests' divine selection here to emphasize that true spiritual accompaniment must come from those who are themselves elevated and filled with holiness, as opposed to those who are spiritually empty, for escorting by one who is spiritually lacking provides no benefit to the accompanied.

hebrew_text: ובזה יתורץ קושית הבאר שבע מדוע השמיטו בטור ושו"ע הלכה זו. מפני שנתמעטו הלבבות בדורות אחרונים, ואין בידינו להבחין מי הוא הראוי למצוה זו, וכל איש דרכו ישר בעיניו, ע"כ לא פסקוהו להלכה שיהי' נוהג בכל אדם ובכל זמן והכל לפי הבחי'.

Here's the translation:

"This resolves the question raised by the Be'er Sheva regarding why the Tur and Shulchan Aruch omitted this halacha. [The reason is] because the hearts have diminished in later generations, and we are not capable of discerning who is truly worthy of this mitzvah, and every person considers their own way to be right in their eyes. Therefore, they did not establish it as a definitive halacha that would apply to every person and in every time period, as everything depends on proper discernment."

Note: The phrase "נתמעטו הלבבות" (nitma'atu halevavot - "the hearts have diminished") is a common concept in Hasidic and rabbinic literature referring to the spiritual decline of later generations compared to earlier ones. The text reflects the Hasidic emphasis on proper spiritual discernment (בחינה - bechinah) and the recognition of different spiritual levels among individuals.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel addresses why the Tur and Shulchan Aruch omitted a certain halacha (law), responding to the question raised by the Be'er Sheva. The key insight is that in later generations, there has been a spiritual decline ("nitma'atu halevavot") making it difficult to discern who is truly worthy of fulfilling this particular mitzvah. Since every person tends to view their own path as correct ("kol ish darko yashar be'einav"), the codifiers deliberately didn't establish this as a universal halacha that would apply to everyone at all times. This reflects a deeper Hasidic concept about the relationship between spiritual levels and halachic practice, suggesting that certain spiritual practices should be calibrated to the individual's spiritual capacity and level of discernment.

hebrew_text: עכ"פ גדולה מצות לויה אם המלוה הוא צוית שעי"ז מתקשרים זב"ז וקדושתו של זה הצדיק העוסק בתורה בביתו, הוא משמר את חבירו וכו' כמ"ש בנוע"א זלל"ה, וכעין בחי' זו יש עוד סגולה לשמירה בדרך, להזכיר שמועה מפי צדיק, דעי"ז מתקשר בקדושתו ויגן עליו זכותו להנצל מכל רע, וע"ד מ"ש הרי"ף בעין יעקב לפרש אמרם ז"ל אל יפטר אדם מחבירו אלא מתוך דבר הלכה שמתוך כך זוכרהו, הכוונה שלהיות הדרכים בחזקת סכנה, והיוצא לדרך צריך לתפלת עצמו וזכות אחרים, וכשנפטר ממנו מתוך ד"ת, כשאותו אדם הוא זוכר אותו ד"ת ששמע ממנו, ה"ה כאילו אותו אדם מהלך עמו, וכאילו הוא מדבר אתו ד"ת, וזה ק"ו מהמתים שאומרים דבר הלכה מפיהם ששפתותיהם דובבות בקבר, ונמצא כי מתוך ד"ת שזכר בנסיעתו זוכרהו אותו אדם שנשאר כאן, ויהי' זכרונו לרצון ולטובה לההולך בדרך מתוך ד"ת שאמר מפיו עכ"ד, ומובן שזהו דוקא אם הוא אדם כשר, דאל"כ כמו שהלוי' שלו מזיק כנ"ל, כמו"כ מה שמזכירים שמועותיו לא יועיל למי שאומרו, והוא בחי' א' עם לויה, ושניהם סגולה אחד להם.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

In any case, the mitzvah of levayah (escorting) is great when the one being accompanied is a tzaddik, for through this they become connected to each other, and the kedushah (holiness) of this tzaddik who engages in Torah study in his home protects his fellow, etc., as mentioned in No'am Elimelech, of blessed memory. Similar to this concept, there is another segulah (spiritual remedy) for protection while traveling: to mention a teaching in the name of a tzaddik. Through this, one becomes connected to his kedushah, and his merit will protect them from all evil.

This is similar to what the Rif writes in Ein Yaakov, explaining the Sages' statement that "one should not depart from their fellow except with a matter of halachah, for through this they will remember them." The intention is that since roads are presumed dangerous, and one who travels needs both their own prayers and the merit of others, when they part with words of Torah, when that person remembers the Torah teaching they heard from them, it is as if that person is walking with them, as if they are discussing Torah together.

This is all the more so [kal v'chomer] from the deceased, of whom it is said that when their Torah teachings are quoted, their lips move in the grave. Thus, through the words of Torah remembered during the journey, that person who remained behind remembers them, and their memory will be for favor and good for the traveler through the Torah words spoken from their mouth.

It is understood that this only applies if the person is kosher (upright). If not, just as their levayah can be harmful as mentioned above, similarly, mentioning their teachings will not benefit the one who quotes them. This is of the same nature as levayah, and both share the same segulah (spiritual remedy).
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the spiritual significance of levayah (accompanying travelers) and sharing Torah teachings. The key concept is that when one shares or remembers Torah teachings from a righteous person (tzaddik), it creates a spiritual connection that provides protection during travel, similar to how the deceased's lips move in their grave when their Torah teachings are repeated. The text emphasizes that this protective power only works when the Torah is shared by or remembered from a worthy person (adam kasher), as teachings from an unworthy person could actually cause harm. The passage draws a parallel between physical accompaniment (levayah) and spiritual accompaniment through Torah teachings, suggesting they share the same spiritual protective quality for travelers.

hebrew_text: והנה כתיב ויהי כהיום הזה ויבא הביתה לעשות מלאכתו וגו', פרש"י רב ושמואל ח"א מלאכתו ממש, וח"א לעשות צרכיו עמה, אלא שנראית לו דמות דיוקנו של אביו וכו', ולכאורה לא יתכן לומר על יוסף הצדיק שנכנס לעשות עבירה ח"ו, ובמדרש ילקוט ויבא הביתה לעשות מלאכתו, רא"א שבת הי' דכתיב כי בו שבת מכל מלאכתו, ומה מלאכה היתה לו שונה וקורא מה שלמדו אביו, ונל"פ דב' המימרות הא בהא תליין, עפי"מ שפירשתי בפסוק ויוסף הורד מצרימה פרש"י כדי לסמוך מעשה אשתו של פוטיפר למעשה תמר, לומר לך מה זו לש"ש אף זו לש"ש שראתה באצטרלוגין שלה שעתידה להעמיד בנים ממנו ואינה יודעת אם ממנה אם מבתה, ע"כ דברי רש"י ז"ל ואפשר דזה הכניס ספק בלבי של יוסף אולי הדין עמה כמו שמראה האצטגנינות, עד שיצא חוץ למזלות ושם ראה האמת, ובזה פירשתי מאמה"כ וינס ויצא החוצה עיי"ש, ולדרכנו אפ"ל דהנה כלל זה בכל אדם אם יעלה ספק בלבו בעשיית איזה דבר אם הורשה עפ"י התורה לעשותו או מצווה למנוע ממנו, צריך לראות דרכי אבותינו הק', כמ"ש צאו לך בעקבי הצאן, וע"כ יוסף שנכנס ספק בלבו כנ"ל, נתן עצה לנפשו לפשוט ספיקו וקרא ושנה מה שלמדו אביו, ועי"ז ניצול מן העבירה.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts and terminology:

It is written "And it came to pass on this day, that he came into the house to do his work, etc." Rashi explains that Rav and Shmuel [disagree]: one says it was actual work, and one says he came to fulfill his desires with her, but then the image of his father's likeness appeared to him, etc. At first glance, it would be impossible to say about Yosef HaTzaddik that he entered to commit a sin, Heaven forbid. In the Midrash Yalkut, "he came into the house to do his work" - Rabbi Eliezer says it was Shabbos, as it is written "for on it He rested from all His work," and what work did he have? He was reviewing and studying what his father had taught him.

It can be explained that these two statements are interconnected, based on what I explained on the verse "And Yosef was brought down to Egypt." Rashi explains that this is written to connect the incident of Potiphar's wife to the incident of Tamar, to tell you that just as Tamar's actions were for the sake of Heaven (l'shem Shamayim), so too were her actions for the sake of Heaven, as she saw in her astrological signs that she was destined to have children from him, but didn't know if it would be through her or through her daughter.

It's possible that this created doubt in Yosef's heart, that perhaps she was right as the astrological signs indicated, until he went beyond the influence of the zodiac signs and there saw the truth. With this, I explained the verse "and he fled and went outside."

Following our approach, we can say that this is a general principle for every person: if doubt arises in their heart about doing something - whether it is permitted according to the Torah or whether one is commanded to refrain from it - one needs to look at the ways of our holy ancestors, as it is written "Go forth in the footsteps of the flock." Therefore, when doubt entered Yosef's heart as mentioned above, he gave himself advice to resolve his doubt by reading and reviewing what his father had taught him, and through this he was saved from sin.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the episode of Joseph and Potiphar's wife, offering a profound theological interpretation. The key insight centers on how Joseph dealt with moral uncertainty - when faced with Potiphar's wife's claim that their union was divinely ordained (based on astrological signs), Joseph turned to Torah study and the teachings of his father Jacob to resolve his doubt. The text teaches that when faced with spiritual or moral uncertainty, one should look to the ways of our holy ancestors ("darkei avoseinu hakedoshim") and Torah study as a guide. This interpretation transforms what could be seen as a simple story of temptation into a deeper lesson about how to resolve religious doubt through connection to tradition and Torah learning.

hebrew_text: ואפ"ל עוד עפימ"ד בירושלמי (שקלים פ"ב ה"ה) ר"ג אמר האומר שמועה בשם אומרו, יראה בעל שמיעה כאילו עומד לנגדו שנאמר אך בצלם יתהלך איש וכו', ואיש אמונים מי ימצא זה ר' זעירא, דא"ר זעירא ליתנן צריכין חששין לשמעתי' דרב ששת דהוא גברא מפתחא, פו' בפני משה שעיניו סתומות וכיון שאינו יכול לראות האנשים ששומע מפיהם ואפשר שמא אינש אחרינא הוא, והוא טועה בטביעת קלא, ובקרבן העדה פי' ול"נ כיון שאינו רואה אינו יכול לכוון הדברים, שהרי אי אפשר לו לאמרה כאילו בעל השמועה עימד לנגדו, שהרי לא ראה אותו מעולם, הלכך אין סומכין עליו בזה עכ"ל, והביאו שם בירושלמי כמה מימרות שא"ל ר"ז לר"א חכים ר' לרב דאת אמר שמעתתא משמי' עיי"ש, וע"כ יוסף הצדיק שהי' מסופק בדבר אם הדין עמה ומה"ט קרא ושנה מה שלמדו אביו וראה בעל השמועה כאילו עומד לנגדו, ונראתה לו דמות דיוקנו של אביו ע"י שצייר תמונת אביו נגד עיניו, ועי"ז הי' לו כח לעמוד על האמת וניצול מהעבירה. וזה ששלח יוסף לאביו סימן שלמד עמו פ' עגלה ערופה, לרמוז אליו שהיו לו ב' סגולות אלו לשמירה, מה שליוהו אביו בצאתו ממנו שנרמז בפ' עגלה ערופה, והב' ע"ו שזכר שמועותיו שלמד ממנו ועי"ז ניצול מעבירה.

One can further explain based on what is said in the Yerushalmi (Shekalim 2:5): Rabbi Gamliel said that one who says a teaching in the name of its originator should envision the one who originally said it as if standing before him, as it is written "But in an image walks man," etc. And "Who can find a faithful man?" - this refers to Rabbi Zeira. For Rabbi Zeira said we need not be concerned about the teachings of Rav Sheshet since he was blind. The Pnei Moshe explains that since his eyes were closed and he couldn't see the people from whom he heard teachings, it's possible it was someone else and he was mistaken in identifying the voice. The Korban HaEdah explains that since he cannot see, he cannot properly focus the words, as it's impossible for him to say it as if the original teacher is standing before him, since he never saw him, therefore we don't rely on him in this matter.

The Yerushalmi brings several instances where Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Elazar, "The Rabbi knows Rav well, as you say teachings in his name." Therefore, Yosef HaTzaddik, who was uncertain about the matter if the law was with her [Potiphar's wife], for this reason he reviewed what his father had taught him and saw the original teacher as if standing before him. The image of his father appeared to him because he visualized his father's image before his eyes, and through this he had the strength to stand firm in truth and was saved from sin.

This is what Yosef sent as a sign to his father - that he had studied with him the passage of the Eglah Arufah (broken-necked heifer), hinting that he had these two protective merits: first, that his father had accompanied him when he left (which is alluded to in the passage of Eglah Arufah), and second, that he remembered the teachings he had learned from him, and through these he was saved from sin.
summary: This passage discusses an important concept from the Jerusalem Talmud about the spiritual power of transmitting Torah teachings in the name of their original speaker. The text specifically focuses on how Yosef HaTzaddik was saved from sin by visualizing his father Yaakov's image, which was made possible through his careful review of the Torah his father had taught him. The passage connects this to the principle that when one says a teaching in the name of its author, it's as if that person is standing before them - this spiritual visualization serves as a protective force. The text concludes by explaining that this is alluded to in Yosef's sending the sign of Eglah Arufah to his father, representing both the protection of his father's accompaniment and the merit of remembering his father's teachings.

hebrew_text: ובזה יובן דברי המדרש כשראה יעקב את העגלות אשר שלח יוסף אמר בוודאי אני יודע שלא חטא באשת פוטיפר שרמז לו בהן ב' סגולות של שמירה, כח הלוי' ומה שהזכיר שמועותיו וצייר דמות דיוקנו בשעה שקרא ושנה מה שלמדו אביו וכמו"כ בהעגלות כפשוטן ראה קדושת הבעלים כנ"ל, ולזה כשראה את העגלות אמר יודע אני וכו' שלא חטא וכו' הן לפי פשוטו והן לפי מדרשו.

"This explains the words of the Midrash: When Yaakov saw the wagons (agalot) that Yosef sent, he said 'I know with certainty that he did not sin with Potiphar's wife,' because [Yosef] hinted to him through them two protective segulot [spiritual remedies]: the power of accompaniment [levaya], and that he recalled their learning together and visualized his father's image (dyukan) at the time when he read and reviewed what his father had taught him. Similarly, in the literal wagons, he saw the holiness of their owners as mentioned above. Therefore, when he saw the wagons, he said 'I know, etc.' that he did not sin, etc. - both according to its simple meaning and according to its midrashic interpretation."

Note: I've preserved Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "segulot," "levaya," and "dyukan" as they carry specific spiritual and cultural connotations in Hasidic literature that might be lost in direct translation.
summary:
This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses Yaakov's reaction to seeing the wagons (agalot) sent by Yosef, explaining that these wagons served as a spiritual sign that Yosef maintained his righteousness in Egypt. The wagons symbolized two protective spiritual forces: the power of Levitical accompaniment and Yosef's continued Torah study/connection to his father's teachings through visualizing Yaakov's image. When Yaakov saw these wagons, he understood both their literal and deeper spiritual significance, confirming that Yosef had remained pure and resisted sin with Potiphar's wife, as these spiritual protections had safeguarded him.

The key Hasidic concept emphasized here is the power of maintaining spiritual connections (through Torah study and holy visualizations) as a protection against sin, as well as the idea that physical objects can contain deeper spiritual meanings (the wagons both literally and metaphorically representing spiritual protection).

hebrew_text: ובזה נבוא לבאר במאמה"כ אל תרגזו בדרך, דהנה לפי האמת הי' ראוי להם לסגולת שמירת הדרך להזכיר שמועותיו שאמר להם בעת הפרדתם, ע"ד שאמרז"ל אל יפטור אדם מחבירו אלא מתוך דבר הלכה שמתו"כ זוכרהו, וכפי' הרי"ף שזה שמירה וסגולה בדרך, אולם לפי שיטתם שהי' להם רוגז עם יוסף הצדיק וחשדו אותו לפי שיטתם בעובר על ד"ת, דהרי רצו להורגו ודנו אותו עפ"י דיני התורה כמחויב מיתה כמבואר בדברי המפרשים, א"כ לפי שיטתם אסור להם לומר שמועות מפיו כנ"ל והנה איתא לפרש במה שמברכין אק"ב וצונו לעסוק בדברי תורה, שהכוונה הוא לחדש ד"ת, ולא סגי במה שלומד שמועות מפי אחרים, וזהו לשון עסק, וז"ש להם יוסף אל תרגזו בדרך, שתעזבו את הרוגז שיש לכם עלי, ואז טוב לכם להזכיר שמועות מפי ואין לכם צורך לעסוקי בד"ת פי' לחדש חידושי תורה על הדרך דלעיוני לאו שפיר דמי כמ"ש בגמ'.
translation:
Here is the English translation, preserving relevant Hebrew/Hasidic terminology:

With this we can explain the verse "Do not become agitated on the way." In truth, as a protection (segulah) for safety on the journey, they should have recalled the Torah teachings he told them when they parted, as our Sages taught that one should not depart from his fellow except with a matter of halachah, through which he will remember him. As the Rif explains, this serves as protection and a segulah on the journey.

However, according to their perspective, since they harbored anger toward Yosef HaTzaddik and suspected him (according to their view) of transgressing divrei Torah, as they had wanted to kill him and judged him according to Torah law as deserving death, as explained by the commentators - therefore according to their view, it was forbidden for them to repeat teachings in his name as mentioned above.

Now, there is an explanation regarding the blessing we make "...who has commanded us to engage in divrei Torah" - that the intention is to create novel Torah insights, and it is not sufficient to merely study teachings heard from others. This is the meaning of the term "engage."

This is what Yosef was telling them: "Do not become agitated on the way" - meaning, abandon the anger you have toward me, and then it will be good for you to recall teachings in my name, and you won't need to "engage" in divrei Torah, meaning to create novel Torah insights while traveling, as deep analysis is not appropriate [while traveling] as stated in the Gemara.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the deeper meaning behind Joseph's instruction to his brothers "do not become agitated on the way" (אל תרגזו בדרך). The key insight is that normally, travelers should protect themselves spiritually by discussing Torah teachings they heard during their farewell, but the brothers couldn't do this with Joseph's teachings because they had considered him a transgressor and had wanted to kill him. Joseph was telling them to let go of their anger towards him so they could safely discuss his Torah teachings on their journey, rather than having to generate new Torah insights themselves (which is difficult while traveling). This interpretation connects the practical aspects of safe travel with deeper spiritual protection through Torah study and the healing of relationships.

hebrew_text: ומ"ש במדרש אל תעמידו עצמכם מד"ת, ר"ל שלא ימנעו מלהזכיר ד"ת שאמר להם יוסף בעת שליוה אותם, דכתיב וישלח את אחיו וילכו אין שילוח אלא לשון לויה ואל יפטר אדם מחבירו אלא מתוך דבר הלכה ובוודאי שליוה אותם מתוך דברי תורה, ואם עדיין רוגז שלהם במקומה עומדת ימנעו בהכרח מלהזכיר שמועותיו, ולזה אמר להם אל תרגזו בדרך פי' תניחו רוגז שיש לכם עלי, וממילא אל תעמידו עצמכם מד"ת שאמרתי לכם ולא תעסקו בד"ת, פי' לחדש דברים חדשים דלעיוני לאו שפיר דמי, ולפי"ז הגמרא והמדרש שניהם לדבר אחד נתכוונו ואו"א דא"ח והכל הולך אל מקום אחד אלא שנאמרו בשינוי לשונות אבל שניהם נתכוונו לזה שהזהירם יוסף הצדיק להזכיר שמועותיו וזה יועיל לשמירת הדרך ושניהם דרשוהו מהפסוק אל תרגזו בדרך.
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

And regarding what is written in the Midrash "do not withhold yourselves from divrei Torah (words of Torah)," it means they should not refrain from mentioning the divrei Torah that Yosef told them when he accompanied them, as it is written "and he sent his brothers and they went" - the word "sending" here implies accompanying, as a person should not depart from his fellow except with a matter of halacha (Jewish law). Certainly, he accompanied them with divrei Torah. If their anger was still in place, they would necessarily refrain from mentioning his teachings. Therefore, he told them "do not become agitated on the way," meaning, "set aside the anger you have towards me." Consequently, "do not withhold yourselves from the divrei Torah that I told you, and do not engage in [new] divrei Torah," meaning, to innovate new insights, for deep analysis is not appropriate [at this time].

According to this, both the Gemara and the Midrash intended the same thing, and each one speaks truth, and everything goes to one place, just that they were expressed with different wording. But both intended to convey that Yosef HaTzaddik (the righteous) warned them to remember his teachings, and this would help protect them on their journey. Both derived this from the verse "do not become agitated on the way."
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses Yosef's parting message to his brothers "אל תרגזו בדרך" (do not become agitated on the way) through a unique Hasidic lens. The key insight is that Yosef wasn't merely warning them against physical arguments, but was encouraging them to maintain their spiritual connection by continuing to discuss the Torah teachings he had shared with them during their farewell escort (levaya). The text suggests that if they remained angry with Yosef, they might refrain from repeating his Torah insights, so he urged them to let go of their anger (rogez) specifically so they could continue engaging with his teachings, which would serve as spiritual protection on their journey. This interpretation beautifully harmonizes different Midrashic and Talmudic readings of the verse, showing how they all point to the same fundamental idea about the protective power of Torah study and the importance of maintaining peaceful relationships to enable proper Torah transmission.

hebrew_text: השי"ת יעזור לנו שנזכה לילך בדרך האמת וזכותם של הצדיקים הקודמים יגן עלינו להנצל מדרך שקר, ונזכה להיות דבוק בדרך התוה"ק והשי"ת יציל אותנו מכל צרה וצוקה, ובמהרה נזכה לראות בישועה האמיתית והגאולה שלימה בהתרוממות קרן התורה וישראל ובהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation:
Here's the translation, preserving Hasidic terminology:

"May Hashem Yisborach help us merit to walk in the path of truth, and may the merit of the previous tzaddikim protect us to be saved from the path of falsehood. May we merit to cleave to the path of the holy Torah, and may Hashem Yisborach save us from all trouble and distress. May we speedily merit to see the true salvation and complete redemption, with the elevation of the glory of Torah and Israel, and with the revelation of Heaven's glory upon us, speedily in our days, Amen."

Notes on specific terms:
- השי"ת (Hashem Yisborach) - refers to God
- צדיקים (tzaddikim) - righteous ones
- תוה"ק (Torah HaKedosha) - the Holy Torah
- גאולה שלימה (geulah shleimah) - complete redemption
- קרן התורה (keren haTorah) - glory/pride of Torah
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel expresses several core Hasidic concepts. The primary theme is a prayer for divine assistance to walk on the path of truth (derech ha'emes), with the protective merit of previous tzaddikim (righteous ones) guarding against falsehood. It emphasizes the importance of cleaving to the path of Torah, seeking divine protection from troubles, and culminates in the anticipation of true salvation and complete redemption. The passage concludes with the classic Hasidic aspiration for the elevation of Torah's glory and the revelation of Heaven's honor, reflecting the movement's focus on both personal spiritual authenticity and collective messianic hope.
keywords: השי"ת (HaShem Yitbarach) ,צדיקים (Tzaddikim) ,דרך האמת (Derech HaEmet) ,תוה"ק (Torah HaKedoshah) ,ישועה (Yeshuah) ,גאולה שלימה (Geulah Shleimah) ,קרן התורה (Keren HaTorah) ,כבוד שמים (Kavod Shamayim) ,דבוק (Davuk) ,זכות (Zechut)

hebrew_text: במד"ר ויאמר ישראל רב עוד יוסף בני חי רב כחו של יוסף בני, שכמה צרות הגיעוהו ועדיין הוא עומד בצדקו, הרבה ממני שחטאתי שאמרתי נסתרה דרכי מה"ג ובטוח אני שיש לי במה רב טובך אשר צפנת, עכ"ד המדרש, וצ"ב.
translation:
Here's the translation of the text from Divrei Yoel:

"In Midrash Rabbah [it states]: 'And Israel said: "It is enough (rav), my son Joseph is still alive."' [This means] great (rav) is the strength of my son Joseph, for many troubles befell him and yet he still stands in his righteousness. [This is] much more than me, for I sinned when I said 'my way is hidden from Hashem.' And I am confident that I have [a portion] in 'How great (rav) is Your goodness that You have stored away.' These are the words of the Midrash, and this requires explanation."

Notes on terminology:
- במד"ר = Midrash Rabbah
- צדקו = his righteousness
- מה"ג = from Hashem
- עכ"ד = these are the words
- וצ"ב = and this requires explanation/clarification

The text is discussing the multiple meanings of the word "rav" (enough/great) and connecting it to Yaakov's reaction to learning that Yosef was alive, while drawing parallels between their respective spiritual levels and trials.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses Yaakov's reaction to learning that Yosef was still alive. The Midrash interprets Yaakov's words "rav" (enough/great) as expressing amazement at Yosef's spiritual strength (koach) in maintaining his righteousness despite enduring many hardships. The key theological insight is the contrast Yaakov draws between himself and Yosef - while Yaakov had momentarily doubted Divine providence by saying "my way is hidden from God," Yosef maintained his faith throughout his trials. This teaches about the power of unwavering faith and highlights how God's goodness (tuv) is preserved for those who maintain their spiritual integrity even in difficult circumstances.

hebrew_text: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי היערות דבש (ח"א דרוש י"א) לבאר אמרם ז"ל (ברכות ז' ע"ב) מזמור לדוד בברחו מפני אבשלום בנו קינה לדוד מבעי' לי', אר"ש בן אבשלום מלה"ד לאדם שיצא עליו שטר וכו', אף כן דוד כיון שא"ל הקב"ה הנני מקים עליך רעה מביתך הי' עצב, אמר שמא עבד או ממזר הוא דלא חייס עלו, כיון דחזא דאבשלום הוא שמח משום הכי אמר מזמור עכ"ד הגמרא. ויש להבין דאדרבה הוא ראה שאבשלום רדפו עד נפש ונהג בו אכזריות יותר מכל עבדים ואכזרים וכו', ותוכן תירוצו לבאר דיש ב' מיני עונשין, אופן א' אם העונש מגיע לאדם בכוונה מה' לענשו על חטאיו ולהטובו באחריתו, ואופן הב' הוא כי הוא מזלו רע וכפי מולד כוכבי השמים הוא לרוע, רק ה' מגן בעדו וכו', וכאשר יחטא מסלק השי"ת השגחתו ממנו ומניחו למנהגו ושל עולם תחת כוכבי השמים וכסיליהם וכו', וההבדל בין זה לזה דבאופן הראשון ינקה מעונו ומקבל תשלום פרי חטאתו ואז טוב לו לעולם הבא, אבל באופן השני אין כאן עונש רק סילוק השגחת אלקים והוא כפי מזלו וטבעו וכו' וענשו עדיין בשלימות ליום הגמול, וזהו כי מתחילה חשב דוד להיות כי כפי המזלות וכוכבי השמים היה במערכה רעה למאוד, רק ה' מגן בעדו וכו' ועכשיו שאמר הקב"ה להקים לו רעה, חשב שיסלק השגחה הפרטית ויהיה תחת מזלו אשר הוא לרוע וכו', אבל בראותו כי בנו רודפו אמר הלא מטבע הבן לחוס על אבא, א"כ אילו היה מפאת הטבע או מקרה, לא יתכן שיהיה בנו רודפו שהוא בטבע חס על אביו, וע"כ שהוא בהשגחה מבעל המשלם גמול, ובזה מקבל עונשו ונפטר מחטאתו ולכן שר מזמור את"ד ז"ל.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts and terminology:

It can be explained by first considering the words of the Yaarot Devash (Part 1, Drush 11) explaining the statement of our Sages (Berachot 7b) regarding "A psalm of David when he fled from his son Absalom" - it should have been called "A lamentation of David." Rabbi Shimon ben Avshalom offered a parable about a person who had a debt note issued against him, etc. Similarly, when David was told by the Holy One, Blessed be He, "Behold, I will raise up evil against you from your own house," he was distressed. He said, "Perhaps it will be a servant or a mamzer (illegitimate child) who will have no mercy." When he saw it was Absalom, he rejoiced, and therefore said "A psalm."

One must understand: on the contrary, he saw that Absalom pursued him to death and acted more cruelly than any servant or cruel person would. The essence of his answer explains that there are two types of punishments:

1. The first type is when punishment comes to a person intentionally from Hashem to punish him for his sins and ultimately benefit him.

2. The second type is when one's mazal (fortune) is bad according to the constellation of stars, and Hashem merely protects him from it.

When one sins, Hashem removes His direct supervision and leaves him to the natural course of the world under the stars and constellations. The difference between these two types is that in the first case, one is cleansed of his sin and receives atonement for his transgression, ensuring good in the World to Come. But in the second case, it's not a punishment per se, rather a removal of Divine supervision, leaving one to his natural fate, with the real punishment still awaiting on the Day of Judgment.

Initially, David thought that according to the stars and constellations, he was in a very bad position, but Hashem was protecting him. When Hashem said He would raise up evil against him, David thought He would remove His particular supervision and leave him to his bad mazal. However, when he saw that his son was pursuing him, he reasoned: it's natural for a son to have mercy on his father. Therefore, if this was due to natural causes or chance, it wouldn't be possible for his son to pursue him since a son naturally has mercy on his father. Thus, this must be through Divine providence from He who repays measure for measure, and through this he would receive his punishment and be absolved of his sin - therefore he sang a psalm.
summary:
This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses King David's seemingly paradoxical reaction of singing praise (mizmor) when fleeing from his son Absalom. Based on the Yearot Devash's explanation, it presents two types of divine punishment: direct punishment from God intended for spiritual rectification, and the natural consequences that occur when God removes His direct supervision (hashgacha). When David realized that his son Absalom was pursuing him - something that goes against natural filial love - he understood this was direct divine punishment rather than natural consequences, and he rejoiced because this meant his sins would be atoned for through this suffering rather than facing worse judgment later.

This interpretation reveals deep theological concepts about divine providence, the nature of suffering, and the relationship between natural law and divine intervention in Jewish thought.

hebrew_text: ועד"ז אפ"ל ביעקב אבינו ע"ה דמתחילה חשב כי טרוף עורף יוסף חי' רעה אכלתהו, וא"כ הוא עונש בדרך הטבע וה"ה סילוק השגחתו יתברך, וע"כ אמר נסתרה דרכי מה' שהוא בבחינת הסתרת פנים ואין מדת עונש זה למרק חטאתו, אבל כששמע שאחיו מכרוהו אין זה בדרך הטבע, וע"כ שהוא בהשגחה מבעל המשלם גמול להטיבו באחריתו, ולכן אמר בטוח אנו שיש לי במה רב טובך ואשר צפנת, וכו בהצרות עצמם צפונה הטובה והחסד.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts:

One can explain regarding our father Yaakov, peace be upon him, that initially he thought that Yosef had been torn apart [by a wild animal] - that an evil beast had devoured him. If so, this was a punishment through natural means, meaning a withdrawal of Hashem's direct providence. Therefore he said "my way is hidden from Hashem," which refers to the concept of hester panim (concealment of [Divine] countenance), and this type of punishment was not meant to cleanse his sins. However, when he heard that Yosef's brothers had sold him, this was not through natural means. Therefore, it must have been through Divine providence from the One who rewards, in order to benefit him in the end. Thus he said he was confident that there was "how great is Your goodness that You have hidden away." For within the troubles themselves, goodness and kindness are concealed.

Note: I preserved Hebrew/Aramaic terms like "hester panim" and concepts specific to Hasidic thought regarding Divine providence (hashgacha) and the idea that within suffering itself lies hidden good.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses Ya'akov Avinu's shifting perspective regarding Yosef's disappearance. Initially, when Ya'akov thought Yosef was killed by a wild animal, he viewed it as a natural punishment and a withdrawal of divine providence (hester panim). However, upon learning that Yosef was actually sold by his brothers - an unnatural occurrence - Ya'akov understood this was direct divine intervention with a deeper purpose. The key theological insight is that what appears as suffering often contains hidden divine blessing; Ya'akov came to recognize that within the troubles themselves lay concealed goodness (tovah) and kindness (chesed) that would eventually be revealed for a greater purpose.

hebrew_text: ויאמר אלקים לישראל במראות הלילה וגו' אנכי הארל אלקי אביך אל תירא מרדה מצרימה כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם אנכי ארד עמך מצרימה ואנכי אעלך גם עלה ויוסף ישית על עיניך, לכאורה ראוי להבין ענין נחמה זו שא"ל יתברך אל תירא מרדה מצרימה כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם, ואין בזה טעם מספיק שתפוג יראתו, גם מ"ש לו ויוסף ישית ידו על עיניך. צ"ב מה טובה של נחמה זו וכבר הבטיחו אנכי ארד עמך וגו', והרי יהיה מושגח מאתו יתברך ומה צורך להשגחת בשר ודם.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

"And Elokim said to Yisrael in the visions of the night, etc.: 'I am the God, the God of your father. Do not fear going down to Mitzrayim, for I will make you into a great nation there. I will go down with you to Mitzrayim, and I will surely bring you up; and Yosef will place his hand upon your eyes.'

At first glance, it is worthy to understand the nature of this consolation that Hashem blessed be He told him 'Do not fear going down to Mitzrayim for I will make you into a great nation there.' This doesn't seem to provide sufficient reason for his fear to be allayed. Also, regarding what He told him 'and Yosef will place his hand upon your eyes' - this requires explanation: what kind of consolation is this, when He had already promised 'I will go down with you, etc.'? After all, he would be under Divine providence (hashgacha), so what need was there for the providence of flesh and blood?"

Note: I've maintained Hebrew/Yiddish terms like "Mitzrayim" (Egypt), "Elokim" (God), "hashgacha" (Divine providence), and proper names as they appear in the original text to preserve the religious and cultural context.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses God's nighttime revelation to Israel (Jacob) before descending to Egypt. The text raises a fundamental question about the nature of God's comfort to Jacob, specifically questioning why God's promise to make him into a great nation in Egypt would be sufficient to allay his fears. The deeper theological puzzle centers on why God mentions that Joseph would close Jacob's eyes (upon death), when God had already promised to accompany Jacob Himself - suggesting a tension between divine and human care. The passage ultimately points to the complex relationship between divine providence (hashgacha) and human intermediaries, questioning why physical human comfort would be necessary when direct divine supervision was already promised.

hebrew_text: ויתבאר הענין בהקדם מאמר הכתוב וישימני לאב לפרעה וגו' ומושל בכל ארץ מצרים מהרו ועלו אל אבי ואמרתם אליו כה אמר בנך יוסף שמני אלקים לאדון לכל מצרים רדה אלו אל תעמוד, ולהלן ויגידו לו לאמר עוד יוסף חי וכי הוא מושל על כל ארץ מצרים, וראוי להבין ענין שבק וגדולה הזה מה טובה, ולמה הוא נחשב בערך קדושתם של יוסף ויעקב אבינו ע"ה, ומדוע שלח אליו כדברים האלה, ויתבאר עפ"י דברי הגמרא (כתובות ק"י ע"ב) כל הדר בחו"ל כאילו עובד ע"ז, וכן בדוד הוא אומר, (שמואל א' כ"ו) כי גרשוני היום מהסתפח בנחלת ה' לאמר לך עבוד ע"ז. וכי מי אמר לו לדוד לך עבוד ע"ז. אלא לומר לך כל הדר בחו"ל כאילו עובד עבודה זרה עכ"ד הגמרא. וביארתי בספרי ויואל משה (מאמר א' ס"ה) דנראה ברוב המפרשים דעיקר הטעם מפני שמכניס עצמו תחת שעבוד ממשלת עובדי ע"ז, ה"ה כעובד עבודה זרה בעצמו, כמ"ש רש"י ז"ל (פרשת ואתחנן) עה"פ ועבדתם שם אלהים וגו', משאתם עובדים לעובדיהם כאילו אתם עובדים להם וכן פי' התרגומים שם, וכן פי' בתרגום יונתן עה"פ הנ"ל כו גרשוני היום וגו'. אזיל דוד ביני עממיא פלחי טעוותא עיי"ש, וא"כ אין זה נוהג אלא ביוצא מא"י בזמן הבית, עיי"ש,

The matter will be explained by first considering the verse "And He made me a father to Pharaoh... and ruler over all the land of Egypt. Hurry and go up to my father, and say to him, 'Thus says your son Joseph: God has made me lord of all Egypt; come down to me, do not delay.'" And later it states, "And they told him, saying, 'Joseph is still alive, and he is ruler over all the land of Egypt.'"

It is worthy to understand what benefit there was in this authority and greatness, and why it was considered valuable in relation to the holiness of Joseph and our father Jacob, peace be upon him, and why did he send such words to him?

This can be explained according to the words of the Gemara (Ketubot 110b) which states that "Anyone who lives outside of Eretz Yisrael is considered as if they worship avodah zarah (idolatry)." And similarly regarding David, it states (Shmuel I 26), "For they have driven me out today from sharing in the inheritance of Hashem, saying, 'Go serve other gods.'" But who told David to go serve avodah zarah? Rather, this teaches that anyone who lives outside of Eretz Yisrael is considered as if they worship avodah zarah, as stated in the Gemara.

I explained in my sefer Va'Yoel Moshe (Discourse 1:65) that it appears from most commentators that the main reason is because one places themselves under the subjugation of idol-worshipping governments, it is as if they themselves are worshipping avodah zarah, as Rashi explains (Parshat Va'etchanan) on the verse "And you shall serve there other gods..." - when you serve their worshippers, it is as if you are serving them [the gods]. This is also how the Targumim explain it there, and similarly the Targum Yonatan explains the above verse about David being driven out... that David went among idol-worshipping nations. Therefore, this only applies to one who leaves Eretz Yisrael during the time of the Beit HaMikdash.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the complex relationship between living in the diaspora (outside of Israel) and spiritual status, using the biblical narrative of Joseph in Egypt as a starting point. The text explores the Talmudic statement (Ketubot 110b) that living outside of Israel is comparable to idol worship, explaining through various commentaries that this is primarily because one places themselves under the governance of idol worshippers. The key theological insight centers on how being under foreign rule creates a spiritual compromise, with the text using Rashi's commentary on Deuteronomy to explain that serving those who serve idols is tantamount to serving the idols themselves. The passage suggests this concept was particularly relevant during the time of the Temple's existence, using King David's exile as an illustrative example.

hebrew_text: והנה באותו הזמן היתה ממשלת עובדי עבודה זרה בארץ ישראל, הגם שבני יעקב היו מלכים ושרים בארץ, אבל הממשלה והמלוכה היתה ביד הכנענים. כמשה"כ והכנעני והפריזי אז יושב בארץ, ולא זכו בה ישראל עדיין, אמנם במצרים הי' אז יוסף הצדיק המושל כמ"ש מבלעדוך לא ירים איש את ידו ואת רגלו בכל ארץ מצרים, נמצא הי' שם ממשלה דקדושה, וזה ששלח יוסף לאביו שמני אלקים לאדון לכל מצרים רדה אלו אל תעמוד, ואין לך לחוש מלצאת מא"י לחו"ל, דמ"ש רז"ל היוצא מא"י לחו"ל כאילו עובד ע"ז און זה כ"א ביוצא מא"י לחו"ל בזמן הבית כשיש שם מלכות דקדושה, משא"כ בזמן ההוא שהכנענים היו מושלי הארץ ואדרבה במצרים יש ממשלה דקדושה. כי שמני אלקים לאדון לכל מצרים, וז"ש לו הבוו"ת בהבטחתו אל תירא מרדה מצרימה וגו' ויוסף ישית ידו על עיניך שהוא המושל ושליט במצרים, ולא תהי' תחת שעבוד ממשל עובדי ע"ז. .(צ
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts and terminology:

At that time, the government in Eretz Yisrael was under idolaters (ovdei avodah zarah). Although the children of Yaakov were kings and ministers in the land, the actual governance and kingship was in the hands of the Canaanites. As it is written, "And the Canaanite and the Perizzite were then dwelling in the land," and Israel had not yet merited it. However, in Egypt, Yosef HaTzaddik was the ruler, as it is written "Without your consent no man shall lift his hand or foot in all the land of Egypt." Thus, there was a holy governance (memshalah d'kedushah) there.

This is why Yosef sent word to his father, "God has made me master of all Egypt - come down, do not delay." You need not be concerned about leaving Eretz Yisrael for outside the Land (chutz la'aretz), for what our Sages said that "one who leaves Eretz Yisrael for chutz la'aretz is as if he worships idols" only applies to one who leaves Eretz Yisrael for chutz la'aretz during the time of the Temple, when there is holy sovereignty there. This was not the case at that time, when the Canaanites were ruling the land, and conversely, in Egypt there was holy governance, "for God has made me master of all Egypt."

This is what the Holy One, Blessed be He, promised him: "Fear not to go down to Egypt... and Yosef shall place his hand upon your eyes," for he is the ruler and authority in Egypt, and you will not be under the subjugation of idolatrous rule.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the complex spiritual dynamics of Yaakov's descent to Egypt, offering an important theological insight about sacred sovereignty (memsheles d'kedusha). The text explains that while Canaan was technically the Holy Land, it was under idolatrous control at that time, whereas Egypt, through Yosef's leadership, had established a form of holy governance. The author uses this to explain why Yaakov was permitted and even encouraged to leave Eretz Yisrael for Egypt, contrary to the general prohibition of leaving the Holy Land - because in this unique situation, Egypt actually contained more spiritual potential under Yosef's righteous leadership than the Land of Israel under Canaanite rule. This interpretation provides a sophisticated understanding of how divine providence can operate through unexpected channels and how spiritual authority isn't always bound to physical location.

hebrew_text: ומ"ש כו לגוי גדול אשימך שם, יתבאר ג"כ עפ"י דרכנו הנ"ל, דהנה ע"ו זכות התורה נקראו ישראל גוי גדול, כמ"ש ומי גוי גדול אשר לו חקים ומשפטים צדיקים ככל התורה הזאת וגו', וישראל במצרים עסקו בתורה כמשרז"ל ואת יהודה שלח לפניו וגו' לתקן בית תלמוד שמשם תצא הוראה, ואמרו ז"ל עמרם זקן ויושב בישיבה הי', גלו במצרים ישיבה עמהם, וזהו כו לגוי גדול אשימך שם, שהבטיחו ית' שיעסקו בניו בתורה במצרים וראויים להקרא גוי גדול, ומעתה יהי' למקום ההוא קדושת א"י, ועפימ"ש המהרש"א ז"ל בביאור דברי הגמ' (ברכות ח' ע"א) א"ל לר' יוחנן איכא סבי בבבל תמה ואמר למען ירבו ימיכם וגו' על האדמה כתיב אבל בחו"ל לא, כיון דאמרי לי' מקדמי ומחשכי לבי כנישתא אמר היינו דאהני להו. וביאר המהרש"א ז"ל עפי"ד גמ' (מגילה כ"ט ע"א) עתידין בתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשות שבבבל שיקבעו בא"י וכו' א"כ ה"ה מכלל א"ו שיקבעו שם לעתיד עיי"ש, וז"ש לו ית' אל תירא מרדה מצרימה, ולצאת לחו"ל, כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם ויהי' למקום ההוא קדושת אזי,
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

And regarding what is written "there I will make you into a great nation," it can also be explained according to our aforementioned approach. For behold, through the merit of Torah, Israel is called a "great nation," as it is written "What great nation has righteous statutes and laws like this entire Torah, etc." The Jewish people in Egypt engaged in Torah study, as our Sages of blessed memory explained on the verse "And he sent Judah ahead" - to establish a house of study from which instruction would emerge. And our Sages said that Amram was an elder who sat in the yeshiva; when they went into exile in Egypt, a yeshiva went with them.

This is the meaning of "there I will make you into a great nation" - that Hashem promised that his children would engage in Torah study in Egypt and would be worthy to be called a "great nation." From then on, that place would have the sanctity of Eretz Yisrael. This follows what the Maharsha explains regarding the Gemara (Berachos 8a) where they told Rabbi Yochanan there were elderly people in Bavel. He was surprised and said "That your days may be lengthened etc." is written regarding "the Land," but not outside the Land. When they told him that these people came early and stayed late in the synagogue, he said "that is what helped them."

The Maharsha explains based on the Gemara (Megillah 29a) that in the future, the synagogues and study halls of Bavel will be established in Eretz Yisrael. Therefore, they are considered part of Eretz Yisrael since they will be established there in the future. This is what Hashem told him: "Do not fear going down to Egypt" and leaving for outside the Land, because "there I will make you into a great nation" and that place will have the sanctity of Eretz Yisrael.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of "goy gadol" (great nation) in relation to the Jewish people's descent to Egypt. The key theological insight is that the greatness of Israel is tied to Torah study, as evidenced by the phrase "Which great nation has righteous laws and statutes like this Torah." The text explains that even in Egypt, the Jews maintained their Torah study through established yeshivot (academies), and this transformed their place of exile into a space with some of the spiritual qualities of Eretz Yisrael. The passage concludes by drawing a parallel to the Talmudic teaching that synagogues and study halls in exile will eventually be transplanted to the Land of Israel, suggesting that dedicated Torah study can elevate even a place of exile to a level of sanctity.

hebrew_text: או אפ"ל עפ"י אמרם ז"ל (יבמות ס"ד ע"א) שאין השכינה שורה על פחות מב' אלפים וב' רבבות, ואמרז"ל במדרש לא נסתלק יעקב אבינו עד שראה ס' רבוא מיוצאי חלציו. ואותן הס' רבוא היו שורשי נשמות ישראל שבכל הדורות ושורש כללות התורה, כידוע, דס' רבוא אותיות לתורה וכ"א מישראל יש לו אחיזה באות א' בתוה"ק, על כן הבטיחו ית' אל תירא מרדה מצרימה לצד העדר השראת השכינה, כי לגוי גדול אשימך שם ותזכה להשראת השכינה ובחי' א"י, וז"ש אנכי ארד עמך מצרימה שיהי' שם השראת השכינה, ואנכי אעלך גם עלה דרשו רז"ל גם עלה לרבות שאר גליות שיצ"מ שורש כל הגאולות והכל הוכן בכח האבוה"ק ויוסף הצדיק, ובזכותם יוסיף ה' ידו ויגאלנו אחרית כראשית בב"א. אי

One can also explain according to what our Sages said (Yevamot 64a) that the Shechinah (Divine Presence) does not rest upon less than 2,000 and 20,000 [people]. And our Sages said in the Midrash that Yaakov Avinu did not pass away until he saw 600,000 descendants. Those 600,000 were the root souls of Israel throughout all generations and the root of the entirety of the Torah, as is known, for there are 600,000 letters in the Torah, and each Jew has a connection to one letter in the Holy Torah. Therefore, Hashem promised him "Do not fear going down to Egypt" regarding the concern about the absence of the Divine Presence, "for I will make you into a great nation there" and you will merit the Divine Presence and the aspect of Eretz Yisrael. This is what is meant by "I will go down with you to Egypt" - that the Divine Presence will be there. And "I will surely bring you up" - our Sages interpreted "surely bring you up" as including all other exiles, for the Exodus from Egypt is the root of all redemptions, and everything was prepared through the power of the holy forefathers and Yosef HaTzaddik. In their merit, may Hashem extend His hand again and redeem us, the end like the beginning, speedily in our days, Amen.
summary: This passage discusses the relationship between Divine Presence (Shechina), the Jewish people, and redemption. It explains that the Divine Presence requires at least 22,000 people to rest upon Israel, and Jacob didn't pass away until he saw 600,000 descendants, who represent both the root souls of all future Jewish generations and correspond to the 600,000 letters of the Torah (with each Jew having a connection to one letter). The text connects this to God's promise to Jacob about going down to Egypt, explaining that despite the exile, the Divine Presence would remain with the Jewish people because they would become a "great nation" there, and this Egyptian exile/redemption serves as the root pattern for all future redemptions. The passage concludes with the idea that through the merit of the Patriarchs and Joseph, the final redemption will mirror the first.

hebrew_text: ואת יהודה שלח לפניו וגו' להורות לפניו גושנה, איתא בתנחומא ילמדנו רבינו אימתי מברכין על הנר במוצאי שבת, כך שנו רבותינו אין מברכין על הנר עד שיאותו לאורו. ומנין למדו מן הקב"ה שנאמר וירא א' את האור כי טוב ואח"כ ויבדל אלקים בין האור ובין החושך, ר' זעירא בר אבהו אמר מכאן שמברכין על הנר במוצ"ש משיאותו לאורו עכ"ד המדרש. וצ"ב דאיך נלמד מפסוק זה דאין מברכין על הנר עד שיאותו לאורו, והרי בפסוק לא נזכר מענין הברכה שום רמז ורמיזא, גם צ"ב קישור הלכה זו אל הפסוק ואת יהודה שלח לפניו וגו'

"And he sent Yehudah before him, etc., to direct before him to Goshen." It is brought in the Tanchuma: "Our Rabbi, teach us: when do we make the blessing over the light at Motzaei Shabbos (Saturday night)? Thus our Rabbis taught: We don't make the blessing over the light until we can benefit from its light. And from where did they learn this? From HaKadosh Baruch Hu (the Holy One, Blessed be He), as it is said: 'And Hashem saw the light that it was good,' and afterward, 'And Elokim separated between the light and the darkness.' Rabbi Zeira bar Abahu said: From here we learn that we make the blessing over the light on Motzaei Shabbos when we can benefit from its light." These are the words of the Midrash.

This requires explanation: How do we learn from this verse that we don't make the blessing over the light until we can benefit from its light, when the verse makes no mention or hint about blessing? Also, we need to understand the connection between this halacha and the verse "And he sent Yehudah before him, etc."
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the Midrash Tanchuma's interpretation connecting the verse "And he sent Judah ahead" (regarding Jacob sending Judah to Egypt) with the laws of blessing over fire at Havdalah. The key theological insight centers on the parallel between God's assessment of light during Creation ("And God saw that the light was good") and our requirement to benefit from the light before reciting the blessing at Havdalah. The text raises a question about this connection, noting that the Creation verse doesn't explicitly mention blessings, suggesting a deeper metaphysical link between our ritual actions and divine patterns. This represents a classic Hasidic approach of finding spiritual and mystical significance in the connection between seemingly unrelated biblical verses and practical Jewish law (halakha).

hebrew_text: ויתבאר בהקדם דברי הלבוש באו"ח (סימן רצ"ח ס"א) מברך על הנר במוצ"ש אם יש לו וכו', דעיקר תקון ברכה זו לזכר שנברא האור במוצאי שבת דהיינו ביום ראשון דכתיב ויאמר אלקים והי אור וגו', והקשה עליו באלי' זוטא דליתא, דאור דקרא שנברא ביום ראשון דיממא הוא אבל אור של מוצ"ש לא זהו אור של יום ראשון כדאיתא בירושלמי פסחים (נ"ג) ובב"ר (פ' י"א ס"ב) במוצאי שבת זימן לו הקב"ה ב' רעפים והקישן זל"ז ויצא מהן אור ובירך עלי' וכו', מה בירך עליו בורא מאורי האש, אתי' כשמואל דאמר שמואל מפני מה מברכין על האור במוצ"ש מפני שהיא תחלת בריאתה עכ"ד המדרש. ועוד שהלבוש גופי' (בסימן תרכ"ד) כתב שהטעם שמברכין במוצ"ש על הנר משום דתחלת בריאתו היתה במוצ"ש שזימן הקב"ה לאדה"ר ב' רעפים וכו', הרי סותר דברי עצמו שבכאן כתב ע"ש האור שנברא ביום ראשון עכת"ד הא"ז ביתר ביאור.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the religious terminology:

It can be explained by first considering the words of the Levush in Orach Chaim (Section 298:1) regarding the blessing over fire at Motzaei Shabbos [Saturday night] if one has it, etc. The main reason for this blessing was established as a remembrance of the light that was created on Motzaei Shabbos, meaning on the first day, as it is written "And God said, 'Let there be light,' etc."

The Eliyah Zuta challenges this, saying it is incorrect, because the light mentioned in the verse that was created on the first day refers to daylight, but the light of Motzaei Shabbos is not the same as the light of the first day. As it states in the Yerushalmi Pesachim (53) and Bereishit Rabbah (Chapter 11:2), on Motzaei Shabbos, HaKadosh Baruch Hu [the Holy One, Blessed be He] provided Adam with two stones, and he struck them together, producing fire, and he made a blessing over it. What blessing did he make? "Borei Me'orei Ha'Esh" [Who creates the illuminations of fire]. This follows Shmuel's opinion, who said that we make the blessing over fire on Motzaei Shabbos because that was when it was first created.

Furthermore, the Levush himself (in Section 624) wrote that the reason we make the blessing on Motzaei Shabbos over fire is because that was when it was first created, when HaKadosh Baruch Hu provided Adam HaRishon with two stones, etc. Thus, he contradicts his own words, as here he wrote it was because of the light created on the first day. These are the words of the Eliyah Zuta with additional explanation.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the blessing over fire during Havdalah (at the conclusion of Shabbat), exploring a theological debate about its significance. The text presents a contradiction between the Levush, who initially connects the blessing to the primordial light created on the first day of Creation, and the Elya Zuta's challenge based on the Yerushalmi and Midrash, which state that fire was actually first created on Motzaei Shabbat when God taught Adam to strike two stones together to create fire. The passage points out that the Levush himself later contradicts his first explanation by agreeing with the Midrashic account in a different section, highlighting a fundamental discussion about the nature of fire as a divine gift to humanity and its relationship to both Creation and human innovation.
