hebrew_text: אמנם נראה להצדיק דברי הלבוש ז"ל ול"ק מה שתפש עליו הא"ז, דבאמת מבואר בפסוק דאור הראשון של ששת ימי בראשית נברא בתחילת לילה ראשונה של ששת ומי בראשית, שנאמר ויאמר אלקים והי אור וגו' וירא אלקים את האור כי טוב ויבדל וגו' ואח"כ ויהי ערב ויהי בקר יום ראשון, שקודם הוה לילה ואח"כ יום ושניהם אחרי הויית האור. והרמב"ן ז"ל כתב בפסוק זה שאמרו קצת המפרשים, כו האור הזה נברא לפניו של הקב"ה, כלומר במערב. ושקעו מיד כדי מדת לילה ואח"כ האיר כדי מדת יום וכו' ואיננו נכון כלל פן יוסיפו על ששת ימי בראשית יום קצר, אבל יתכן כין האור נברא לפניו יתברך ולא נתפשט ניסירוה] הנזכרים. והבדיל בינו ובין החשך שנתן לשניהם מידה, ועמד לפניו כמדת לילה ואח"כ הזריח אותו על היסודות, והנה קדם הערב לבקר עכ"ל הרמב"ן ז"ל עכ"פ נברא אור הראשון במוצאי שבת, וזו היתה תחילת בריאתה של אור ביום הראשון של מעשה בראשית, ומעתה יצדקו דברי הלבוש דניתקן ברכה זו לזכר האור שנברא בליל הראשון למע"ב, דגם אור דיממא, בתחילת לילה ראשונה של ששת ימי בראשית נברא וזו תחלת בריית האור, ומסתבר יותר שראוי לעשות זכר לאור הראשון שנברא ע"י הקב"ה לבדו.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the religious terminology:

However, it appears that we can justify the words of the Levush z"l, and the criticism of the Elya Zuta is not difficult, because it is truly explained in the verse that the first light of the Six Days of Creation was created at the beginning of the first night of the Six Days of Creation, as it is written "And God said, 'Let there be light,' etc... and God saw the light that it was good, and He separated, etc." And afterward, "And there was evening and there was morning, one day" - meaning that first there was night and then day, and both came after the creation of light.

The Ramban z"l wrote on this verse that some commentators said that this light was created before Hakadosh Baruch Hu (the Holy One, Blessed be He), meaning in the west. It immediately set for the duration of night, and afterward it shone for the duration of day, etc. But this is not correct at all, lest they add a short day to the Six Days of Creation. Rather, it is possible that the light was created before Him, blessed be He, and did not spread [in the directions] mentioned. And He separated between it and the darkness by giving both of them a measure, and it stood before Him for the measure of night, and afterward He caused it to shine upon the elements, and thus evening preceded morning, end quote from the Ramban z"l.

In any case, the first light was created on Motzaei Shabbat (Saturday night), and this was the beginning of the creation of light on the first day of Creation. From this, the words of the Levush are justified, that this blessing was established to commemorate the light that was created on the first night of Creation, for even the light of day was created at the beginning of the first night of the Six Days of Creation, and this was the beginning of the creation of light. It makes more sense that we should commemorate the first light that was created by Hakadosh Baruch Hu alone.
summary: This passage discusses the creation of light on the first day of Creation, focusing on reconciling the view of the Levush with other commentators. The key theological point is that the first light was created at the beginning of the first night of Creation, before the distinction between day and night was fully established. The text, drawing on the Ramban's commentary, emphasizes that this primordial light was created before God's presence (in the west) and was initially contained before being distributed, establishing the pattern of evening preceding morning. The passage concludes that the blessing over fire during Havdalah specifically commemorates this original divine light created directly by God alone, rather than subsequent forms of light, highlighting the unique spiritual significance of the first created light.

hebrew_text: ומה שהקשה עוד הא"ז דהלבוש ז"ל סותר ד"ע, ממ"ש בסימן תרכ"ד שטעם ברכת האור במו"ש ע"ש האור שנברא ע"י אדם הראשון שהקיש ב' רעפים וכו', וכן איתא בירושלמי פרק אלו דברים ובב"ר פי"א הנ"ל. אמנם ל"ק שהרי דייק הלבוש בלשונו דעיקר תקון ברכה זו לזכר האור שנברא בראשון למע"ב, ומדכתב עיקר תיקון ברכה זו, וכו' משמע מדבריו, דאיכא עוד טעם לתיקון ברכה זו, אלא שזו היא טעם העיקרי, ויתבאר עפימ"ש הרמב"ן ז"ל דמאורות שנבראו ביום ד' נאצלו מן האור הראשון שנברא ביום א', ולפי שלא היה העולם ראוי להשתמש באור ההוא בלי אמצעית, גנזו לצדיקים לעולם הבא, ושמשו מנובלת אורה של מעלה מיום הרביעי ואילך. ומבואר יותר בדברי הכלי יקר עה"פ ויאמר אלקים יהי אור, וז"ל מצינו לרז"ל שאמרו אור שנברא ביום ראשון נגנז ואיתא למאן דאמר הן הן המאורות שנבראו ביום א' ולא נתלו עד יום רביעי, ונראין ב' מדרשים אלו כסותרים זא"ז, והאמת אינו כן. כי הכל מודים שאור של יום ראשון היה אור גדול ונגנז, ואלו המאורות שנתלו ביום ד' אינם עצם האור, אלא שקבלו אורם מן ניצוץ אור העליון שנברא ביום ראשון, לכך ביום הראשון הזכיר בו לשון אור, כי הוא עצם האור, אבל במאורות של יום ד' הזכיר בכ"א מאור בתוספות מ"ה, להורות שקבלו אורם מן אור גדול מהם וכו' עיי"ש.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

And regarding what the A"Z (my ancestor) further questioned, that the Levush seemingly contradicts himself from what he wrote in Siman 624 that the reason for the blessing over light on Motzaei Shabbos is because of the light that Adam HaRishon created by striking two stones together, etc., as is found in the Yerushalmi Perek Eilu Devarim and in Bereishis Rabbah Chapter 11 mentioned above.

However, this is not difficult, as the Levush was precise in his language when he wrote that the main establishment of this blessing was to commemorate the light that was created on the first day of Creation. By writing "the main establishment of this blessing," etc., it implies from his words that there is another reason for establishing this blessing, but this is the primary reason.

This can be explained based on what the Ramban wrote, that the luminaries created on the fourth day emanated from the original light created on day one. Since the world was not worthy to use that light directly, it was hidden away for the tzaddikim in the World to Come, and from the fourth day onward, they used a diminished form of the supernal light.

This is explained more clearly in the words of the Kli Yakar on the verse "And G-d said, 'Let there be light,'" where he writes: We find that our Sages said the light created on the first day was hidden away, and there is an opinion that says these are the same luminaries that were created on day one but were not hung until day four. These two midrashim appear to contradict each other, but in truth, this is not so. For all agree that the light of the first day was a great light and was hidden away, and these luminaries that were hung on day four are not the essence of that light, but rather they received their light from a spark of the supreme light created on the first day. Therefore, on the first day, the term "ohr" (light) is used, as it refers to the essence of light, but regarding the luminaries of day four, the term "ma'or" (luminary) is used with an additional "mem," indicating that they received their light from a light greater than themselves, etc.
summary: This passage discusses the relationship between different types of light in Creation, particularly focusing on the blessing over light during Havdalah. The text reconciles an apparent contradiction between the light created on Day One of Creation and the luminaries created on Day Four, based on the teachings of the Ramban and Kli Yakar. The core theological insight is that the original light of Day One was a supreme, spiritual light that was later hidden away for the righteous in the World to Come, while the physical luminaries created on Day Four (sun, moon, stars) merely receive and reflect a diminished form of that original divine light. This concept illustrates the Hasidic principle of higher and lower spiritual realms, where physical manifestations are merely vessels for containing and expressing more elevated spiritual forces.
keywords: אור הראשון (Or HaRishon) ,מעשה בראשית (Ma'aseh Bereishit) ,גנזו לצדיקים (Ganzo LaTzaddikim) ,עולם הבא (Olam HaBa) ,אור העליון (Or HaElyon) ,מאורות (Me'orot) ,ניצוץ (Nitzotz) ,נאצלו (Ne'etzalu) ,אור גנוז (Or Ganuz) ,נובלת אורה (Novlot Orah)

hebrew_text: ומעתה נבין דברי הלבוש בטעמו דכל אור שבעולם משורש אור הגנוז. והיא עיקרה ותחלת בריאתה של האור, וע"כ כתב דעיקר תקון ברכה זו לזכר האור הראשון. שהוא שורש כל אור שיש במציאות בעולם, וכולם הם חלק ממנה. והחלק הוא נכלל בהכלל שיצא ממנה, ומ"ש הלבוש (בסימן תרכ"ד) דטעם הברכה במוצאי שבת על שזימן הקב"ה לאדם הראשון אור במוצ"ש, וכן איתא בב"ר הנ"ל. גם טעם זה אמיתי שתקנו רז"ל לברך לזכר שבירך אדה"ר ברכת מאורי האש בשעה שזימן לו השי"ת אור במוצ"ש, אבל עיקר התקנה ע"ש האור שנברא ביום ראשון, כי הוא שורש האור כנ"ל, ומוכח כדברי הלבוש מדברי הב"ר הנ"ל. וכן איתא בירושלמי פרק אלו דברים שלמדו דאין מברכין על הנר עד שיאותו לאורו מהאי קרא וירא אלקים כי טוב ויבדל וגו', ופסוק זה נאמר על בריאת אור של יום ראשון. משמע דעיקר הברכה נתקנה לזכר האור של יום הראשון וכדברי הלבוש ז"ל
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Now we can understand the words of the Levush regarding his reasoning that all light in the world stems from the root of the Or HaGanuz (Hidden Light). This is the essential and initial creation of light, and therefore he wrote that the main purpose of this blessing is in remembrance of the Original Light, which is the root of all light that exists in reality, and all lights are parts of it. The part is included in the whole from which it emerged.

And regarding what the Levush wrote (in Siman 624) that the reason for the blessing at Motzaei Shabbos is because HaKadosh Baruch Hu (the Holy One, Blessed be He) provided light for Adam HaRishon on Motzaei Shabbos, as is also mentioned in the aforementioned Bereishis Rabbah. This reason is also true - that our Sages instituted the blessing in remembrance of Adam HaRishon's blessing over Me'orei Ha'Esh (the lights of fire) when Hashem provided him with light on Motzaei Shabbos.

However, the primary basis for this institution is in remembrance of the light that was created on the first day, as it is the root of all light as mentioned above. This is proven from the words of the Levush from the aforementioned Bereishis Rabbah. Similarly, it is stated in the Yerushalmi in Perek Eilu Devarim that we learn that we don't recite the blessing over the flame until we can benefit from its light, from the verse "And God saw that the light was good, and He separated..." This verse refers to the creation of light on the first day. This implies that the main purpose of the blessing was instituted in remembrance of the light of the first day, as stated by the Levush of blessed memory.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the deeper meaning behind the blessing over fire during Havdalah (מאורי האש). The text explains that all light in existence stems from the primordial light (אור הגנוז) that was created on the first day of Creation. While there is a connection to Adam HaRishon's discovery of fire after Shabbat, the primary reason for this blessing is to commemorate that original divine light which is the root source of all subsequent light. The passage synthesizes both the practical historical reason (Adam's first encounter with fire) and the deeper mystical meaning (the primordial light), showing how the blessing serves to connect us to both the immediate physical reality of light and its ultimate spiritual source.
keywords: אור הגנוז (Or HaGanuz) ,בריאת האור (Briat HaOr) ,השי"ת (HaShem Yitbarach) ,אדה"ר (Adam HaRishon) ,מאורי האש (Me'orei HaEsh) ,מוצאי שבת (Motzaei Shabbat) ,ברכה (Bracha) ,שורש האור (Shoresh HaOr) ,בריאת יום ראשון (Briat Yom Rishon) ,הקב"ה (HaKadosh Baruch Hu)

hebrew_text: אמנם ראוי להבין מ"ט קבעו חז"ל ברכה על בריאת האור לבד, ולא תקנו לברך על בריאת שמים וארץ וכל הנבראים בששת ימי המעשה בזמן תחלת ברייתם, וטעמא בעי. ויובן עפימ"ש החיד"א ז"ל בשם הרב החסיד יהודא חאביליי זלל"ה, בטעם שצונו יוצרנו לעשות זכר לענני הכבוד במצות סוכה, ולא צו' כן במן ובאר לעשות זכר למו, להיות ענני כבוד היו רק ישראל מיוחדים בטובה, כו הערב רב פלט אותם הענן. משא"כ מן ובאר גם הע"ר נהנו מהם עכ"ד ז"ל. ופי' בזה הבני יששכר ז"ל למען ידעו דורותיכם כי בסוכות הושבתי וגו', היינו דרין בתראי דקיימין העיר עלייהו כלי חמס ודחקין לן בגלותא (כמבואר בזוהר הקדוש) הנה יכירו וידעו בנו ישראל שלא יהיה להם התחברות עמהם, כי בסוכות הושבתי את בני ישראל, וחבה יתירה נודעת להם במה שהלביש אותם בענני הכבוד ולא זכו הערב רב ליהנות ממנה עכת"ד.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

However, it is worthy to understand why Chazal (our Sages) established a blessing specifically for the creation of light, and did not establish blessings for the creation of heaven and earth and all other creations of the six days of Creation at the time of their initial creation - this requires explanation.

This can be understood based on what the Chida wrote in the name of the pious Rabbi Yehuda Chavilio, regarding the reason why our Creator commanded us to make a remembrance for the Clouds of Glory through the mitzvah of Sukkah, but did not command similarly regarding the manna and the well to make a remembrance for them. This is because the Clouds of Glory were exclusively for the benefit of Israel, as the Erev Rav (Mixed Multitude) were expelled by the cloud. This was not the case with the manna and the well, from which the Erev Rav also benefited.

The Bnei Yissaschar explained the verse "So that your generations will know that I caused the Children of Israel to dwell in Sukkot," meaning that the later generations, who would be oppressed by violent forces in exile (as explained in the holy Zohar), should recognize and know that the Children of Israel should not associate with them. For "I caused the Children of Israel to dwell in Sukkot" - special love was shown to them through the Clouds of Glory, from which the Erev Rav did not merit to benefit.
summary: This passage discusses why the Sages instituted a blessing specifically for the creation of light but not for other aspects of creation like heaven and earth. The text explains this through an analogy to the Sukkah, citing the Chida who explains that the Sukkot commemoration was established specifically because the Clouds of Glory (Ananei HaKavod) benefited only the Jewish people, while excluding the Erev Rav (mixed multitude). The Bnei Yissaschar expands on this, explaining that this selective nature of the Clouds of Glory serves as a reminder to future generations about the unique relationship between God and the Jewish people, particularly during times of exile and persecution. The underlying theological message emphasizes the special distinction (havdalah) between Israel and other nations, and how certain divine benefits are exclusively channeled to the Jewish people.
keywords: ענני הכבוד (Ananei HaKavod) ,בני ישראל (Bnei Yisrael) ,ערב רב (Erev Rav) ,חבה יתירה (Chiba Yeteira) ,זוהר הקדוש (Zohar HaKadosh) ,בני יששכר (Bnei Yissachar) ,גלותא (Galuta) ,דרין בתראי (Darin Batrai) ,יוצרנו (Yotzreinu) ,חז"ל (Chazal)

hebrew_text: ומעתה יובן לענינינו שלא תקנו חז"ל ברכה על תחלת ברייתה של שמים וארץ ושאר הנבראים, שכולם נהנים בה גם הרשעים, אמנם חיבה יתירה נודעת בבריאת האור הראשון. שאמרז"ל ראהו שאינו כדאי להשתמש בו רשעים והבדילו לצדיקים לעתיד לבא, ואיתא בספה"ק דאור הגנוז נגנז בתוה"ק, והצדיקים העמלים בה לשמה, זוכים ליהנות מאורה גם בעולם הזה, ובזה חשיבות ומעלת האור יתירה על כל הנבראים, שהבדילו השי"ת רק לצדיקים ולא ניתן לרשעים ליהנות ממנה, וע"כ תקנו חז"ל ברכה על בריאת האור לבד על שהבדיל מרשעים אורה, ובזה א"ש מה שלמדו חז"ל בתנחומא הנ"ל דיני ברכת הנר מהאי קרא וירא אלקים את האור ויבדל וגו'. אע"ג דלא כתיבא ברכה בהאי קרא כקושיחנו הנ"ל, אמנם עיקר תקנת ברכה זו על האור, מפני שהי' בו הבדלה ונבדל מרשעים אורה, וע"כ למדוה מפסוק זה שהוא יסוד ושורש תקנה זו וכנ"ל
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Now we can understand regarding our matter why Chazal (our Sages) did not establish a blessing for the initial creation of heaven and earth and other creations, as all beings benefit from them, including the wicked. However, special love was made known in the creation of the Original Light, about which Chazal said that Hashem saw it was not fitting for the wicked to use it, and set it aside for the tzaddikim (righteous ones) in the future to come. It is written in the holy sefarim that this hidden light was concealed in the Torah, and the tzaddikim who toil in it lishmah (for its own sake) merit to benefit from its light even in this world. In this way, the importance and virtue of the light is greater than all other creations, as Hashem set it apart only for the tzaddikim and did not allow the wicked to benefit from it. Therefore, Chazal established a blessing specifically for the creation of light, because its light was separated from the wicked. This explains well why Chazal in the aforementioned Tanchuma derived the laws of the blessing over light from the verse "And G-d saw the light and separated," etc. Although no blessing is written in this verse, as per our earlier question, the main establishment of this blessing over light was because it contained separation and its light was separated from the wicked. Therefore, they derived it from this verse, which is the foundation and root of this enactment, as mentioned above.
summary: This passage discusses the unique spiritual significance of light in Jewish thought, particularly focusing on the "Or HaGanuz" (the hidden primordial light). The key insight is that while the Sages didn't establish blessings for the initial creation of heaven, earth, and other elements (which both righteous and wicked benefit from), they specifically instituted a blessing for light because God set it apart for the righteous. The text explains that this primordial light was hidden away in the Torah, and only the righteous who study Torah for its own sake can benefit from its illumination even in this world. This concept connects to the broader theological principle of divine discernment between the righteous and wicked, suggesting that certain spiritual benefits are reserved exclusively for those who pursue righteousness through Torah study.

hebrew_text: והנה לכאורה אצל הבוי"ת לא יתכן המלכה ושינוי רצון, ומתחלה ידע הבוי"ת והסתכל במעשיהם של רשעים שאינם כדאי להשתמש באור ההוא. ומעתה למה לא גנזו מיד. שיהיה התגלות האור ההוא רק לעתיד לבוא, ויש דיעה במדרש ששמשה האור הגנוז כל ששת ימי בראשית עד מו"ש ועכ"פ הכל מודים דעד יום הרביעי שימשה האור הראשון שנגנז אח"כ, ולמה עשה ד' ככה אחרי שהיתה במחשבתו הקדומה לגנזו, ואפשר דאילולי כן לא היה אפשר לברך על בריאת האור. דאין מברכין על האור עד שיאותו לאורו, אלא ע"י שבא האור הזה לידי התגלות וירא א' את האור כי טוב, וכל העולם כולו ומלואו נהנו מן האור ההוא מד מוצ"ש לחד מ"ד, או עד יום הרביעי לכ"ע, ע"כ שפיר אפשר לברך על האור הנאצל משורש האור ההוא, ושפיר נשמע מפסוק זה דאין מברכין על האור עד שיאותו לאורו. מדכתיב וירא אלקים ואח"כ ויבדל ולא גנזו מתחילה כנ"ל.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

Behold, at first glance, regarding the Borei Yitbarach [Creator, blessed be He], the concept of changing counsel or will is impossible, and from the beginning, the Borei Yitbarach knew and foresaw the actions of the wicked who would not be worthy of using that light. So why then did He not hide it immediately? [Why didn't He arrange that] the revelation of that light would only be for the future to come?

There is an opinion in the Midrash that the hidden light (Ohr HaGanuz) served during all six days of Creation until Motzaei Shabbos, and in any case, all agree that until the fourth day, the original light that was later hidden served [the world]. Why did Hashem do this, given that it was in His primordial thought to eventually hide it?

It's possible that without this, it would have been impossible to make a blessing over the creation of light, for one doesn't make a blessing over light until they benefit from its illumination. Rather, through this light coming into revelation, and "God saw that the light was good," and the entire world and all its contents benefited from that light until Motzaei Shabbos according to one opinion, or until the fourth day according to all opinions, therefore it is properly possible to make a blessing over the light that emanates from the root of that original light.

And we properly learn from this verse that one doesn't make a blessing over light until they benefit from its illumination, as it is written "And God saw" and only afterward "And He divided," and He didn't hide it from the beginning, as mentioned above.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the profound concept of the primordial light (Or HaGanuz) created on the first day of Creation. The text explores an apparent paradox: if God knew from the beginning that this light would need to be hidden away from the wicked, why wasn't it immediately concealed? The resolution offered is that the light needed to first manifest in the world so that future generations could make a blessing over light - since one cannot make a blessing over something until they have benefited from it. This connects to the deeper theological principle that even temporary revelations of divine light serve an eternal purpose, as demonstrated by how this original light served during the first days of Creation before being hidden away for the righteous in the future world.

translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic concepts and terminology:

"Behold, the reason that Yaakov and Yosef chose the land of Goshen was to be separated and isolated there from the tumah (spiritual impurity) of Egypt. And from the land of Goshen, only a portion was chosen, which is the land of Rameses, as implied by the verse in Parshat Vayigash 'in the best of the land, in the land of Rameses.' The Egyptians were separated and removed from there, as it is written 'for all shepherds are an abomination to Egypt.' Therefore, Yaakov sent Yehudah ahead of him to Goshen to establish a Beis Talmud (house of study) specifically in Goshen, because the place was cherished for being separated from the wicked. This is also the reason for the blessing over light, and this explains well the connection that our Sages linked this halacha of the blessing over light to this verse."

Note: I've kept Hebrew terms like "tumah," "Beis Talmud," and proper names in their original form to maintain the authentic Hasidic context of the text.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses why Yaakov and Yosef specifically chose the land of Goshen in Egypt, with a focus on the concept of spiritual separation (havdalah). The key insight is that they deliberately selected Goshen, and specifically the region of Rameses within it, because it provided physical and spiritual separation from Egyptian impurity (tumat Mitzrayim). The text emphasizes that this separation was so important that Yaakov sent Yehuda ahead to establish a beit midrash (house of study) specifically in Goshen, highlighting the spiritual significance of maintaining distinct boundaries between holy and profane spaces. This concept is then connected to the laws of birchat ha'or (blessing over light), suggesting a deeper parallel between physical/spiritual separation and the distinction between light and darkness in Jewish thought.

hebrew_text: ואת יהודה שלח לפניו אל יוסף להורות לפניו גושנה, פרש"י ז"ל להורות לפניו לתקן לו בית תלמוד שמשם תצא הוראה, וצ"ב דאם כוונת מלת גושנה לציין מקום השליחות, הול"ל ואת יהודה שלח גושנה להורות לפניו. ואם קאי על להורות לפניו דסמיך לי', וכדרשתם ז"ל לתקן לו בית תלמוד בגושן, הול"ל להורות לפניו בגושו.
translation:

"And he sent Yehuda before him to Yosef to guide him to Goshen." Rashi of blessed memory explains "to guide him" means to establish for him a Beis Talmud (house of study) from which hora'ah (Torah instruction/ruling) would emanate. This requires explanation: if the word "Goshnah" (to Goshen) is meant to indicate the destination of the mission, it should have said "And he sent Yehuda to Goshen to guide him." And if it refers to "to guide him" which follows it, as our Sages of blessed memory interpreted it to mean establishing a Beis Talmud in Goshen, it should have said "to guide him in Goshen."

Note: I've preserved terms like "hora'ah" and "Beis Talmud" which are specific to Jewish religious discourse. The text is analyzing the precise language and word order of the biblical verse and Rashi's commentary on it, questioning why certain prepositions and word arrangements were used instead of seemingly more straightforward alternatives.
summary: This passage discusses the verse about Jacob sending Judah ahead to Joseph "להורות לפניו גושנה" (to prepare before him in Goshen). The text analyzes Rashi's interpretation that this meant establishing a house of study (beit midrash) from which Torah instruction would emanate. The key theological insight centers on the precise placement of the word "גושנה" (Goshen) in the verse, questioning whether it refers to the destination of the mission or specifically to where the house of study would be established. This textual analysis reflects the Hasidic emphasis on finding deeper spiritual meaning in seemingly minor grammatical nuances, suggesting that the establishment of Torah learning takes precedence even before physical settlement in a new place.

"3) In the holy Zohar, our Sages of blessed memory expounded on the verse 'And Israel dwelt in the land of Goshen and they took possession of it' [as meaning] 'eternal inheritance.' The intention requires understanding - how can it be called an eternal inheritance when ultimately the Israelites left there and would never return again? And in Targum Yonatan it is explained as 'And Israel dwelt in the land of Egypt and they built for themselves houses of study (batei midrashim) and palaces, etc.' We need to understand how this interpretation is hinted at in the meaning of the verse."

summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a question about the Zohar's interpretation of the verse "And Israel dwelt in the land of Goshen and took possession of it" (Genesis 47:27). The key theological question raised is how this dwelling in Goshen could be characterized as an "eternal inheritance" (אחסנת עלמין) when the Jewish people ultimately left Egypt and would never return. The passage also notes the Targum Yonatan's interpretation that the Jews built study halls and palaces in Egypt, raising the question of how this construction activity is hinted at in the biblical text. This creates a tension between the temporary nature of the Jewish settlement in Egypt and the seemingly permanent language used to describe it, pointing to deeper questions about the spiritual significance of the Egyptian exile.

hebrew_text: ד) החת"ס זלל"ה דקדק במאמר הכתוב ויאמרו אל פרעה לגור בארץ באנו וגו' ועתה ישבו נא עבדיך בארץ גושן. דפתח הכתוב בלשון גירות לגור בארץ וגו', ומסיים ועתה ישבו נא וגו' המורה על התיישבות שהוא ההיפוך, ע"כ קושיתו. גם יל"ד איך אמרו בלשון ישיבה ישבו נא וגו'. ולא יתכן להחזיק את עצמו לתושב בעולם הזה רק לגר, וכמו שהביא ק"ז הייטב לב זלה"ה ששמע מדודו הארי' דבי עילאה לפרש מאמרם יציבא בארעא וכו' דמי שמחזיק את עצמו לתושב בארעא, הוא גיורא בשמי שמיא, שלמעלה הוא נחשב לגר, כי העיקר בעולם הזה הוא להיות כגר ואז נחשבין למעלה לתושב, ובפרט כי ירדו למצרים על מנת לקבל עול הגלות, ואיך אמרו ישבו נא עבדיך וגו' שהוא לשון התוישבות, וכמו כן יל"ד במאמר הכתוב בסוף הפרשה וישב ישראל בארץ מצרים.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

The Chasam Sofer z"l"h was precise in analyzing the verse where they said to Pharaoh "to sojourn (lagur) in the land have we come," etc., and then "Now, let your servants dwell (yeshvu) in the land of Goshen." The verse begins with language of temporary dwelling (geirut) "to sojourn in the land," but concludes with "Now let them dwell," which implies permanent settlement (hityashvut), which is the opposite. This was his question.

Also, one should analyze why they used the language of dwelling (yeshiva) "let them dwell," etc. It is not appropriate to consider oneself a permanent resident (toshav) in this world, but rather only a sojourner (ger). As the holy Yitav Lev z"l"h brought that he heard from his uncle, the Aryeh D'bei Ila'ah, explaining their saying "permanent in the land (yatziva b'ara)," etc. - that whoever considers himself a permanent resident on earth is considered a stranger (giora) in the heavens above. For in the heavens, they consider him a stranger, because the main thing in this world is to be like a sojourner (ger), and then one is considered above as a permanent resident (toshav).

This is especially pertinent since they went down to Egypt with the intention of accepting the burden of exile (ol hagalut), so how could they say "let your servants dwell," which is language of permanent settlement? Similarly, one should analyze the verse at the end of the parsha, "And Israel dwelt (vayeshev) in the land of Egypt."
summary: This passage discusses a textual analysis from the Chasam Sofer regarding the seeming contradiction in how Jacob's sons presented themselves to Pharaoh - first saying they came "to sojourn" (lagur) in Egypt but then requesting "to settle" (yeshvu) in Goshen. The key theological insight centers on the proper Jewish attitude toward this world - that one should view themselves as a temporary resident (ger) rather than a permanent settler, as explained by the Yitav Lev citing the Aryeh D'bei Ila'ah. The passage highlights the paradox that when one considers themselves a temporary dweller in this world, they merit to be considered a permanent resident in the spiritual realms above, while those who view themselves as permanent residents here are considered strangers in the heavenly spheres.

hebrew_text: ונצ"מ בהקדם אמרם ז"ל (יומא דף כ"ח ע"ב) מימיהן של אבותינו לא פרשה ישיבה מהם, היו במצרים ישיבה עמהם וכו', היו במדבר ישיבה עמהם וכו', ראוי להבין הטעם שכינו חז"ל למקום תורה בשם ישיבה סתם, הרי כמו שישנם יושבי בית המדרש ישנם גם כן יושבי קרנות, ומשמעות לשון ישיבה סובל שניהם א"כ מאן מפיס, והו"ל לפרש יושבי ביהמ"ד, אמנם ברור כי היושבי קרנות אינם ראויים להתכנות בשם ישיבה כלל, דלשון ישיבה מורה על דבר שהוא נצחי וקיים לעד, ורק התוה"ק הוא נצחי ואין דבר זולתו, וע"ד שבקש דוד המלך ע"ה (תהלים ס"א) אגורה באהלך עולמים, ודרשו רז"ל (יבמות צ"ו ע"ב) וכי אפשר לו לאדם לגור בשני עולמים. אלא אמר דוד לפני הקב"ה רבש"ע יהי רצון שיאמרו דבר שמועה מפי בעוה"ז. דאמר ר"י וכו' כל ת"ח שאומרים דבר שמועה מפיו בעולם הזה שפתותיו דובבות בקבר עכ"ד הגמרא, וכמו כן המחזיקין במוסדות התורה ומסייעין לגדל דורות ישראל לתורה, יש לפעולה זו קיום נצחי לעד, ורק ישיבה של תורה מקרי ישיבה בשם העצם וכמו שארז"ל במשנה (דאבות (פ"ב מ"ז) מרבה ישיבה מרבה חכמה, מבואר דלא מקרי ישיבה כו אם במקום שיש הרבצת התורה, והנה יעקב אבינו והשבטים הקדושים רצו להיות נפרדים מהמצרים לגמרי, ולטעם זה נתיישבו בארץ גושן. וז"ש אל פרעה לגור בארץ באנו, היינו בארץ מצרים אנחנו בבחינת גרים, ועתה אישבו" נא עבדיך בארץ גושן. להעמיד שם ישיבה ומקום להרבצת התורה שהוא דבר נצחי, וא"א רק בגושן ששם יהיו מובדלין ומופרשים מהמצרים, וז"ש הכתוב שוישב" ישראל וגו' בארץ גושן להורות שקבעו שם ישיבה ובית תלמוד כפירש"י ז"ל.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

It can be explained by first considering what our Sages said (Yoma 28b): "Our forefathers never ceased having a yeshiva with them. When they were in Egypt, they had a yeshiva with them... when they were in the desert, they had a yeshiva with them..." We should understand why Chazal specifically used the term "yeshiva" to refer to a place of Torah, for just as there are those who sit in the Beis Midrash (study hall), there are also those who sit idly at street corners. The term "sitting" could apply to both, so what distinguishes one from the other? They should have specified "those who sit in the Beis Midrash."

However, it is clear that those who sit idly at street corners are not worthy of being called a "yeshiva" at all, because the term "yeshiva" indicates something that is eternal and endures forever. Only the holy Torah is eternal, and nothing else. This is similar to what King David requested (Psalms 61): "Let me dwell in Your tent forever," and our Sages explained (Yevamos 96b): "Is it possible for a person to dwell in two worlds? Rather, David said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: 'Master of the Universe, may it be Your will that they say teachings in my name in this world.' For Rabbi Yochanan said... any Torah scholar whose teachings are quoted in this world, his lips move in the grave."

Similarly, those who support Torah institutions and help raise generations of Jewish children in Torah - this activity has eternal existence. Only a Torah yeshiva is called a "yeshiva" in the essential sense, as our Sages said in the Mishnah (Avos 2:7): "The more sitting (learning), the more wisdom." This clarifies that the term "yeshiva" only applies to a place where Torah is disseminated.

Our forefather Yaakov and the holy tribes wanted to be completely separate from the Egyptians, and for this reason they settled in the land of Goshen. This is what they said to Pharaoh: "We have come to sojourn in the land" - meaning, in Egypt we are merely temporary residents - "Now, please let your servants dwell in the land of Goshen." This was to establish there a yeshiva and place for spreading Torah, which is eternal, and this was only possible in Goshen where they would be separate and distinct from the Egyptians. This is what the verse means when it says "And Israel dwelled... in the land of Goshen," indicating that they established there a yeshiva and house of study, as Rashi explains.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the concept of "yeshiva" (sitting/dwelling) in relation to Torah study, focusing on how our forefathers maintained their Torah institutions even in Egypt. The key theological insight is that true "yeshiva" only refers to Torah study because Torah alone is eternal (nitzchi), while all other forms of "sitting" or dwelling are temporary. The text connects this to King David's request to "dwell in God's tent forever" (Psalms 61), explaining that one achieves eternal dwelling through Torah teachings that continue to resonate even after death, when one's "lips move in the grave." The passage concludes by explaining that Jacob and the tribes specifically chose to settle in Goshen to establish a permanent Torah institution (yeshiva) separate from Egyptian influence, emphasizing the importance of maintaining spiritual separation for authentic Torah study.

hebrew_text: והנה איתא במד"ר פ' ויקרא (פ"ב סימן א') בנוהג שבעולם אלף בני אדם נכנסין למקרא וכו' יוצא מהם ק', ק' למשנה יוצאין מהם יי, י' לתלמוד יוצא מהם א', הה"ד (קהלת ז') אדם אחד מאלף מצאתי עכ"ד המדרש, מבואר דמועטין הם הזוכים לכתרה של תורה להיות מחובשי בית המדרש, אולם להחזיק וידי לומדי תורה שייך בכל אחד, והחוב מוטל על כל אחד להחזיק לומדי התורה, ולזה אמר הכתוב בלשון יחיד וישב ישראל בארץ גושן. כי היושבים בישיבה להיות תורתן אומנתם הם יחידים ובמתו מספר, אבל ויאחזו בה המורה על החזקת התורה נכתב בלשון רבים, שבזה צריך כ"א ליטול חלקו הראוי לו ורבים הם.

And behold, it is brought in Midrash Rabbah Parshat Vayikra (Chapter 2, Sign 1): It is the way of the world that of one thousand people who enter to study Mikra [Scripture], one hundred emerge. Of one hundred who study Mishnah, ten emerge. Of ten who study Talmud, one emerges. This is what is meant by the verse (Kohelet 7), "One man among a thousand have I found." These are the words of the Midrash.

It is clear that few merit the crown of Torah to be among those who sit in the Beit Midrash [house of study]. However, supporting Torah scholars is something that everyone can participate in, and the obligation to support Torah scholars rests upon everyone. This is why the verse uses the singular form "And Israel dwelt in the land of Goshen." For those who sit in the yeshiva, making Torah their profession, are few in number. But "and they took possession of it," which refers to supporting Torah, is written in plural form, because in this aspect everyone must take their appropriate portion, and they are many.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a Midrash from Vayikra Rabbah about the progressive rarity of Torah scholarship: out of 1,000 who begin learning Scripture, 100 continue to Mishnah, 10 to Talmud, and only one achieves true mastery, fulfilling the verse "One man among a thousand have I found" (Kohelet 7:28). The text then makes a crucial theological point about the relationship between Torah scholars and their supporters, explaining that while only select individuals may achieve the highest levels of Torah scholarship, everyone has an obligation and opportunity to support Torah study. This is derived from a careful reading of the verse about the Jews settling in Goshen, where the singular form ("vayeshev/and he settled") refers to the individual scholars, while the plural form ("vayei'achazu/and they took possession") refers to the broader community's role in supporting Torah study.

hebrew_text: ומעולם תמהתי במ"ש יוסף לאחיו והיה כי יקרא לכם פרעה ואמר מה מעשיכם ואמרתם אנשי מקנה היו עבדיך וגו' בעבור תשבו בארץ גושן כו תועבת מצרים כל רועי צאן, ראוי להבין איך הי' התוושבות ארץ גושן טרם באו בנו יעקב לשם, אם דרו שם המצריים. א"כ מהו היחוס בארץ גושן יתירה על ארץ מצרים. הלא כל עיקר רצונם ומאוים להתיישב בה בשביל שלא יהיו מעורבים בין המצריים, ואם לא התיישבו בה המצריים מעולם, באמת טעמא בעו, הלא ארץ גושן הי' מיטב הארץ. כמו שאמר פרעה ליוסף במיטב הארץ הושב את אביך ואת אחיך ישבו בארץ גושן. ואיך יתכן שלא התוישבו בה המצריים.

I have always wondered about what Yosef said to his brothers: "When Pharaoh calls you and asks 'What is your occupation?' you should say 'Your servants have been keepers of livestock'... so that you may dwell in the land of Goshen, for all shepherds are an abomination to Egypt." It is worthy to understand how the settlement of the land of Goshen was [possible] before Yaakov's sons came there, if the Egyptians were dwelling there. If so, what was the special distinction of the land of Goshen over the rest of Egypt? After all, their main desire and aim to settle there was to avoid being mixed among the Egyptians. And if the Egyptians never settled there, this truly requires explanation, for wasn't Goshen the best of the land? As Pharaoh said to Yosef, "Settle your father and brothers in the best of the land; let them dwell in the land of Goshen." So how is it possible that the Egyptians did not settle there?

Note: I've maintained Hebrew terms like "Yosef," "Yaakov," and "Goshen" as they appear in the original text, as these are commonly used in Jewish religious discourse.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses a fundamental question about Yosef's instructions to his brothers regarding settling in Goshen. The author raises an apparent contradiction: if Goshen was considered "the best of the land" as Pharaoh stated, why would the Egyptians, who despised shepherds, leave it uninhabited? The deeper theological insight here appears to be about Divine Providence - how God prepared a separate dwelling place for B'nei Yisrael that would allow them to maintain their spiritual identity while in exile, even though logically this choice piece of land should have been already settled by Egyptians. This paradox points to the hidden ways Hashem orchestrates events to protect the Jewish people's spiritual integrity even within hostile environments.

hebrew_text: אך נראה עפי"מ שפירשתי במאמר הכתוב (פ' חיו שרה) ויקם שדה עפרון אשר במכפלה וגו' לאברהם למקנה וגו', פירש"י תקומה היתה לו שיצא מיד הדיוט לוד מלך וכו', דהנה אברהם אבינו שילם לעפרון עבור המערה ד' מאות שקל כסף. ואליבא דאמת לפי יקר ערך מערת המכפלה לא נחשב הכסף הזה לכלום. אך ידוע מה דאיתא בזוה"ק ומדרשו חז"ל שעפרון מימיו לא ראה במערה זולת החושך והבהלה. ורק אחר שעברה לרשותו של אברהם אבינו נודע גודל ערכה ומעלתה, נמצא דכ"ז שהיתה ברשותו של עפרון לא הי' לה שום ערך, ואין שום טענת אונאה לעפרון, ומאת ה' היתה זאת לטובת אברהם אבינו שלא תהי' לשדה זו תקומה ולא יוודע גודל ערכה עד שבא לידו של אברהם ונגמר הקנין, ואז לא יכול עוד עפרון לערער על המקח, לפי שברשותו של אברהם השביח, ואולי כמו כן אירע בארץ גושן, כו טרם התיישבו בה יעקב אבינו עם השבעים הקדושים, לא הכירו המצריים שהוא מיטב הארץ וראו שם חושך ובהלה כמו עפרון במערת המכפלה, ומה שאמר פרעה ליוסף במיטב הארץ הושב את אביך, אמר כן עמד גוזמא והפלגה. וניבא ואינו יודע מה ניבא, ורש"י ז"ל פי' עה"פ ואתנה לכם את טוב ארץ מצרים, ארץ גושן, ניבא ואינו יודע מה ניבא וכו', רק אחר שבאו לשם יעקב אבינו ובניו הקדושים נעשה שם אור גדול, והנה עדיין לא ידע יעקב אבינו מדריגת צדקתו של יוסף טרם התראה עמו, אם יודע להבחין ערכו של ארץ גושן, וע"כ שלח את יהודה לפניו אל יוסף להראות לו את גושן. שיבחין אם הוא מיטב הארץ וראוי לקבוע שם ישיבה, וז"ש ואת יהודה שלח לפניו אל יוסף להורות לפניו גושנה. היינו להראות לו את גושן אם ראוי להעמיד שם ישיבה, וז"ש בזוה"ק על ארץ גושן והאחזו בה אחסנת עלמין, וכדברי התרגום יוב"ע ובנו להון בתו מדרשין וכו'. ונרמז כן במאמה"כ וישב ישראל וגו' שהישיבה להרבצת התורה הוא דבר נצחי ואחסנת עלמין בעולם הזה ובעולם הבא, כמ"ש ז"ל עה"פ אגורה באהלך עולמים. אי

However, it appears based on what I explained regarding the verse (in Parshat Chayei Sarah) "And Ephron's field which was in Machpelah... was established for Abraham as a possession," Rashi explains that it was an "establishment" as it went from the possession of a commoner to that of a king, etc. For Abraham Avinu paid Ephron 400 silver shekels for the cave. In truth, considering the precious value of Me'arat HaMachpelah, this money was insignificant. But it is known what is written in the holy Zohar and our Sages' midrashim that Ephron never saw anything in the cave except darkness and confusion. Only after it passed into Abraham Avinu's possession was its great value and elevation made known.

Therefore, as long as it was in Ephron's possession, it had no value, and Ephron had no claim of ona'ah (unfair pricing). This was from Hashem for Abraham Avinu's benefit, that this field should not have "establishment" and its great value should not be known until it came into Abraham's possession and the purchase was completed. Then Ephron could no longer contest the sale, because it only appreciated in Abraham's possession.

Perhaps similarly occurred with the land of Goshen - before Yaakov Avinu settled there with the seventy holy ones, the Egyptians did not recognize it as the best of the land and saw only darkness and confusion there, just like Ephron with Me'arat HaMachpelah. When Pharaoh told Yosef "Settle your father in the best of the land," he said this as an exaggeration, and he prophesied without knowing what he prophesied. As Rashi explains on the verse "I will give you the best of Egypt" - referring to the land of Goshen - he prophesied without knowing what he prophesied.

Only after Yaakov Avinu and his holy sons came there did it become filled with great light. Yaakov Avinu still didn't know Yosef's level of righteousness before meeting him, whether he knew how to discern the value of the land of Goshen. Therefore, he sent Yehuda ahead to Yosef to show him Goshen, to discern if it was indeed the best of the land and suitable for establishing a yeshiva there. This is the meaning of "And he sent Yehuda ahead to Yosef to direct before him to Goshen" - meaning to show him Goshen to see if it was suitable for establishing a yeshiva there.

This is what the holy Zohar says about the land of Goshen "and they took possession of it as an eternal inheritance," and as Targum Yonatan ben Uziel says "and they built houses of study there." This is alluded to in the verse "And Israel dwelled..." that the yeshiva for spreading Torah is eternal and an everlasting inheritance in this world and the World to Come, as our Sages said on the verse "I will dwell in Your tent forever."
summary: This passage discusses a profound theological concept regarding sacred spaces and their spiritual recognition, using two parallel stories: the Cave of Machpelah purchased by Abraham and the land of Goshen settled by Jacob's family. The key insight is that these holy places had their true spiritual value concealed from their previous owners (Ephron and the Egyptians), who only saw darkness and confusion. Only when these locations came into the possession of the righteous (tzaddikim) - Abraham and Jacob's family respectively - did their true spiritual worth and light become revealed. The text emphasizes that this divine arrangement ensured these sacred spaces would be properly acquired by the patriarchs and transformed into centers of Torah study and spiritual elevation, representing an eternal inheritance both in this world and the next.

hebrew_text: ויאמר ישראל אל יוסף אמותה הפעם אחרי ראותי את פניך כי עודך חי וגו', פי' רש"י ז"ל אבל יעקב לא נפל על צוארי יוסף ולא נשקו, ואמרו רז"ל שהי' קורא את שמע, הקשו המפרשים מה ראה יעקב לקרות ק"ש דוקא בעת הראתו אל יוסף. אשר זה זמן כביר עמד על המצפה בכליון עינים לראותו (וכמעט אבד סברו ותוחלתו ממנו) וא"כ מדוע בחר לו יעקב דוקא לקרות קריאת שמע ברגע ההוא אשר אין ערוך אלי', ולא המתין מעע עד שושתעשע עם בנו האהוב לו, ואם היתה הרגע ההוא בסוף זמן ק"ש, א"כ גם יוסף מדוע לא קרא קריאת שמע בעת ההוא, גם צ"ב מאמר אמותה הפעם, עיין פירש"י והתרגום, ולפי פשוטו עדיין צ"ב.

"And Israel said to Joseph, 'Now I can die, after seeing your face, because you are still alive, etc.' Rashi explains that Jacob did not fall upon Joseph's neck nor kiss him, and our Sages teach that he was reciting the Shema. The commentators ask: Why did Jacob choose specifically this moment to recite Krias Shema when seeing Joseph? For such a long time he had been waiting anxiously to see him (and had almost lost hope and expectation), so why did Jacob specifically choose to recite Krias Shema at this incomparable moment, and not wait a bit until he could rejoice with his beloved son? And if it was the end of the time period for reciting Shema, then why didn't Joseph also recite Krias Shema at that time? Also requiring explanation is the statement 'Now I can die.' See Rashi and the Targum's explanations, but according to the simple meaning it still requires explanation."

Notes:
- "Krias Shema" or "K"Sh" refers to the recitation of the Shema prayer
- "Rashi" and "Targum" are kept as is, being proper names of commentators/commentaries
- The parenthetical phrases are maintained as they appear in the original
- "Our Sages" (Razal/רז"ל) is a traditional reference to the rabbinic authorities
summary: This passage discusses the emotional reunion between Jacob (Yaakov) and Joseph (Yosef), specifically focusing on the puzzling detail that Jacob was reciting the Shema prayer during their meeting instead of immediately embracing his long-lost son. The text raises the fundamental question of why Jacob chose precisely this moment of intense emotional significance to recite the Shema, especially given how long he had yearned to see Joseph. The theological complexity centers on the relationship between divine service (as represented by the Shema) and human emotional experience, suggesting that Jacob's choice to recite the Shema at this pivotal moment reflects a deep understanding that even moments of greatest personal joy must be channeled into spiritual connection with the Divine.

hebrew_text: ואפ"ל בהקדם מאחז"ל (ברכות ה' ע"א) לעולם ירגיז אדם יצר טוב על וצר הרע שנאמר רגזו ואל תחטאו, אם נצחו מוטב ואם לאו יעסוק בתורה שנאמר אמרו בלבבכם וכו', ואם לאו יקרא ק"ש וכו' ואם לאו יזכור לו יום המיתה, ובעיון יעקב (מבעל שבות יעקב) הקשה דלמה לוה כולי האי, הול"ל מיד יזכיר לו יום המיתה, שסגולתה ברורה ומועלת בודאי, ותי' כו אין העצבות עוב כדכתיב ושבח אני את השמחה זו שמחה של מצוה ואין השכינה שורה אלא מתוך שמחה, כדאמרינן (ברכות ל"א ע"ב) ובכמה דוכתי, להכי קאמר תחילה שיעסוק בתורה או יקרא ק"ש, ואם בכל זה לא יועיל אזי יזכור יום המיתה עכ"ל. ופי' המפרשים ע"ד הרמז במאמר הכתוב הנה נא זקנתי לא ידעתי יום מותי, שאמר יצחק אבינו ע"ה שלמרות הפלגת זקנותו, לא הוצרך לידע ולזכור יום מיתתו בשום פעם, כו אם ידע לנצחו ליצה"ר בסגולת התורה וק"ש ולעבוד השי"ת מתוך שמחה, אמנם יע"א ע"ה כ"ז שהיה שרוי בצער והתאבל על יוסף לא שרתה עליו שכינה כאמרז"ל, לא היה אפשר לו לנצח את היצה"ר ע"י תורה וק"ש ומתוך שמחה של מצוה, והוצרך לנצחו בזכרון יום המיתה, וזה ירמוז מאמר הכתוב כי ארד אל בני אבל שאולה היינו כו ע"ו צער האבילות על יוסף שנסתלקה ממנו שכינה, הנני מוכרח לירד ממדרגתי לנצח את היצה"ר ע"ו ק"ש או תורה ומתוך שמחה של מצוה ולא נשאר רק סגולת שאולה, לנצחו ע"י זכרון יום המיתה.

One can explain by first considering what our Sages taught (Berachos 5a): A person should always incite the yetzer tov (good inclination) against the yetzer hara (evil inclination), as it is said "Tremble and sin not." If he overcomes it, good; if not, he should engage in Torah study, as it is said "Speak in your hearts, etc." If this doesn't help, he should recite Krias Shema, etc. If this doesn't help, he should remember the day of death.

The Iyun Yaakov (by the author of Shvus Yaakov) asks why go through all this - why not immediately suggest remembering the day of death, since its effectiveness is clear and certain? He answers that sadness is not good, as it is written "And I praise joy" - referring to the joy of mitzvos, and the Shechinah (Divine Presence) only rests in a state of joy, as we learn in Berachos 31b and other places. Therefore, it first suggests engaging in Torah or reciting Krias Shema, and only if these don't help should one remember the day of death.

The commentators explain allegorically the verse "Behold now, I have grown old, I know not the day of my death" - Yitzchak Avinu said that despite his advanced age, he never needed to know or remember his day of death, because he knew how to overcome the yetzer hara through the power of Torah and Krias Shema, serving Hashem with joy. However, Yaakov Avinu, as long as he was in distress mourning for Yosef and the Shechinah departed from him (as our Sages say), couldn't overcome the yetzer hara through Torah and Krias Shema and through the joy of mitzvos, and needed to overcome it by remembering the day of death. This is hinted at in the verse "For I will go down to my son mourning to Sheol" - meaning that through the pain of mourning for Yosef, when the Shechinah departed from him, he was forced to descend from his level of overcoming the yetzer hara through Krias Shema or Torah and the joy of mitzvos, and only the remedy of Sheol remained - overcoming it through remembering the day of death.
summary: This passage from Divrei Yoel discusses the Talmudic teaching (Berachot 5a) about strategies for combating the evil inclination (yetzer hara). The text explores why there's a specific sequence to these strategies - first using Torah study, then reciting Shema, and only finally contemplating death - rather than jumping straight to contemplating death which seems most effective. The key insight is that serving God should ideally be done through joy (simcha), not sadness, which is why more positive methods are tried first. The passage connects this to the stories of Isaac (who never needed to contemplate death due to his success with Torah study) and Jacob (who, in his grief over Joseph, couldn't access the higher methods and had to resort to contemplating death), demonstrating how one's spiritual state affects their approach to overcoming the evil inclination.

hebrew_text: והנה ג' סגולות הללו הם תמידיים נוהגין בכל רגע ורגע ולא אתה בן חורין להבעל מהן, ובל"ס שיעקב אבינו השתוקק מאוד שיוכל לעבוד את השי"ת בשמחה ולנצח את היצה"ר עמי תורה וק"ש ומתוך שמחה של מצוה, לכן ברגע שראה את יוסף ושרתה עליו שכינה, קרא ק"ש שלא להחמיץ את המצוה כאמרז"ל מצוה הבאה לידך אל תחמיצנה, אולם יוסף לא היה נעצב אל אביו כ"כ כו ודע שיעקב אבינו חי ושרתה עליו שכינה כמ"ש ויהי ה' את יוסף, ע"כ לא הוצרך מעולם לסגולת יום המיתה, לכן לא קרא ק"ש בעת נראה אל אביו. כי היה דרכו מאז ומעולם לנצח היצה"ר ע"י תורה וק"ש, ובזה יתבאר לנו לנכון מאמר הכתוב ויאמר ישראל אל יוסף אמותה הפעם, כו עד עתה היה נחוץ לו זכרון יום המיתה בכל עת, אמנם כעת לא אמות רק פעם אחד בעת יבא יומי ויגיע קצי. וכל עוד שאהיה בחיים לא אצטרך לזכרון יום המיתה רק אוכל לנצח את היצה"ר מתוך שמחה של מצוה ע"ו תורה וק"ש, ופי' הטעם אחרי ראותי את פניך כי עודך חי ואוכל לעבוד הבוי"ת מתוך שמחה. אי
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving the Hasidic terminology:

These three segulos (spiritual remedies) are constant, applying at every moment, and one is not free to be exempt from them. Without doubt, Yaakov Avinu greatly desired to serve Hashem with simcha (joy) and to overcome the yetzer hara (evil inclination) through Torah and Krias Shema, and through the simcha shel mitzvah (joy of performing mitzvos). Therefore, at the moment he saw Yosef and the Shechinah (Divine Presence) rested upon him, he recited Krias Shema so as not to miss the mitzvah, as our Sages said, "When a mitzvah comes to your hand, do not delay it."

However, Yosef was not so distressed about his father because he knew that Yaakov Avinu was alive and the Shechinah rested upon him, as it is written "And Hashem was with Yosef." Therefore, he never needed the segulah of remembering the day of death, and thus did not recite Krias Shema when he appeared before his father. For his way had always been to overcome the yetzer hara through Torah and Krias Shema.

This explains well the verse "And Yisrael said to Yosef, 'I will die this time.'" Until now, he needed to remember the day of death at all times, but now "I will only die once, when my day comes and my end arrives." And as long as I shall live, I will not need the remembrance of the day of death, but I can overcome the yetzer hara through the simcha shel mitzvah via Torah and Krias Shema. And he explained the reason: "after I have seen your face, that you are still alive," and I can serve Hashem with joy.
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the spiritual encounter between Jacob and Joseph, focusing on three continuous spiritual remedies (segulot) that one should never abandon. The text explains that when Jacob saw Joseph and the Divine Presence (Shechinah) rested upon him, he recited the Shema, seizing the immediate opportunity for this mitzvah. A key insight is that Jacob no longer needed to contemplate death as a spiritual tool (zichron yom hamitah) after seeing Joseph alive, as he could now serve God with joy and overcome the evil inclination (yetzer hara) through Torah study and reciting Shema. The passage emphasizes the superiority of serving God through joy rather than through contemplation of mortality, highlighting how Jacob's reunion with Joseph transformed his spiritual service from one based in somber reflection to one rooted in simcha shel mitzvah (joy of performing mitzvot).

hebrew_text: בזוה"ק וישב ישראל בארץ מצרים בארץ גושן ויאחזו בה אחסנת עלמין, וצ"ב איך יתכן לכנות התיושבות ארץ גושן ירושת עולם. הלא יצאו ישראל מארץ מצרים ולא יחזרו עוד לעולם, ונל"פ בפשטות עפ"י מה דאיתא בגמ' (מגילה דף כ"ט ע"א) עתידים בתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשות שבבבל שיקבעו בארץ ישראל, נמצא ע"י שנתיישבו יעקב ובניו בארץ גושן וקבעו שם בתי כנסיות ובתי מדרשות ובתי חינוך לתלמוד תורה, כל אלו המקומות עתידין שיקבעו בארץ ישראל לעתיד לבא ויתקיימו לישראל לאחוזת עולם.

The holy Zohar comments on "And Israel dwelt in the land of Egypt, in the land of Goshen, and they took possession of it" that this refers to an eternal inheritance. This requires explanation: How can the settlement in the land of Goshen be called an eternal inheritance? After all, the Jewish people left Egypt and will never return there.

It can be explained simply based on what is stated in the Gemara (Megillah 29a) that in the future, the synagogues and study halls (batei knesiot and batei midrashot) of Babylon will be established in Eretz Yisrael. Therefore, through Yaakov and his sons settling in the land of Goshen and establishing there synagogues, study halls, and institutions for Torah study (batei chinuch l'talmud Torah), all these places are destined to be established in Eretz Yisrael in the future (le'atid lavo) and will remain for Israel as an eternal possession (achuzat olam).
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the puzzling description in the Zohar of the Israelites' settlement in Goshen as an "eternal inheritance" (achsanas almin). The author resolves this difficulty by connecting it to the Talmudic teaching (Megillah 29a) that the synagogues and study houses of exile will eventually be transplanted to the Land of Israel. The key insight is that when Jacob and his sons established places of prayer, study, and Torah education in Goshen, they created spiritual structures that would have eternal significance - not through their physical location in Egypt, but because these holy spaces would ultimately be transferred to and permanently established in Eretz Yisrael in the messianic future.
keywords: זוה"ק (Zohar HaKadosh) ,אחסנת עלמין (Achsanat Almin) ,בתי כנסיות (Batei Knesiot) ,בתי מדרשות (Batei Midrashot) ,ארץ ישראל (Eretz Yisrael) ,אחוזת עולם (Achuzat Olam) ,לעתיד לבא (L'atid Lavo) ,תלמוד תורה (Talmud Torah) ,בתי חינוך (Batei Chinuch) ,ירושת עולם (Yerushat Olam)

hebrew_text: עוד אפ"ל דהנה בפסוק (יהושע י"א ט"ז) חושב ארץ גושן בין ערי ארץ ישראל, ופי' שם הרד"ק וז"ל: אין זה גושן של מצרים, ובמדרש אומר כי הי' גושן של מצרים והיא נבלעת בתוך ערי ישראל וכו' עיי"ש, ובש"ך עה"ת פ' ויגש פי' עה"פ ואת יהודה שלח וגו', שנשתלחה רצועה מארץ ישראל לגושן, ואותה רצועה היתה נעלמת שלא היתה נודעת אלא ליעקב ולבניו, ויע"א ע"ה לא נכנס באויר חו"ל, אלא היתה הרצועה של ארץ ישראל מתקפלת והולכת לפניו והוא בתוכה, וכן כשהוליכוהו לאחר מיתה היתה מתקפלת והולכת עמו עכ"ד, ולפי"ז אותה ארץ גושן חזרה להיות אח"כ מערי ארץ ישראל ושפיר הוא אחוזת עולם לישראל.

One can further explain that in the verse (Joshua 11:16), the land of Goshen is counted among the cities of Eretz Yisrael. The Radak explains there: "This is not the Goshen of Egypt." However, in the Midrash it says that this was indeed the Goshen of Egypt, and it was absorbed within the cities of Israel, etc.

The Shach on the Torah, in Parshat Vayigash, explains the verse "And he sent Yehuda, etc." that a strip of land extended from Eretz Yisrael to Goshen, and this strip was hidden and was known only to Yaakov and his sons. And Yaakov Avinu alav hashalom never entered the air of chutz la'aretz (outside of the Holy Land), rather this strip of Eretz Yisrael would fold and go before him while he was within it. Similarly, when they carried him after his death, it would fold and go with him.

According to this, that land of Goshen later returned to being among the cities of Eretz Yisrael, and it is properly an eternal inheritance for Israel.
summary: This passage discusses the unique status of the land of Goshen and presents a fascinating theological concept about the connection between the Land of Israel and the Jewish diaspora. According to the text, based on interpretations from the Radak and Shach, there was a hidden strip of land that extended from Eretz Yisrael to Goshen in Egypt, known only to Jacob and his sons. This mystical pathway ensured that Jacob never technically stepped into the impurity of the diaspora (chutz la'aretz), as the strip of holy land would fold and unfold before him as he traveled, maintaining his constant connection to the sanctity of Eretz Yisrael. This interpretation reconciles how Goshen could later be counted among the cities of Israel, suggesting a deeper spiritual understanding of how certain spaces can maintain their inherent holiness and connection to Eretz Yisrael even when geographically distant.

hebrew_text: ונראה לפרש לעניננו המשך דברי הפסוק ויאחזו בה ויפרו וירבו מאוד, עפי"מ שפי' כ"ק אבא מארי זלה"ה (בקדויו"ט פ' וישלח) במאמה"כ אשרי איש ירא את ה' במצותיו חפץ מאוד וגו' וזל"ק: בהקדם אמרם ז"ל אר"ש ביותר צריך הכתוב לזרז במקום שיש חסרון כיס, י"ל בכוונתו כי יש כמה אנשים אשר מנשרים קלו ומאריות גברו לעשות רצון קונם וחפץ צורם, ועכ"ז כשיבא לידם מצוה התלוי' בממון מושכים את ידיהם מהמצוה ואינם עושים בשלימות, וע"כ בא הציווי ואהבת את ה' אלקיך בכל לבבך וגו' ובכל מאודך, ודרשו חז"ל (ברכות נ"ד) בכל מאודך בכל ממונך. והיינו שצריך להיות ירא השם וחושב שמו ית' גם במצוה התלוי' בממון, ולהיות מן הזריזין מקדימין לעשות צדקה וחסד בתכלית השלימות, ויבטח בה' ובידו הגדולה כי הוא רב להושיע, וז"ש דוד המע"ה אשרי איש ירא את ה' במצותיו חפץ מא"ד, רומז למצות התלוים בממון, ואז עי"ז ובא על שכרו שגבור בארץ יהי' זרעו דור ישרים יבורך הון ועושר בביתו וכו' עכדה"ק לעניננו, וזהו שאמר ויפרו וירבו מא"ד, היינו בממונם, שע"י שנתנו מכספם להחזקת ת"ת ולמצות עי"ז זכו להפרות ולהרבות במאודם, שהקב"ה השפיע להם כל טוב ונשתלחה הברכה בממונם.

It appears we can explain for our matter the continuation of the verse "And they took possession of it and were fruitful and multiplied greatly (me'od)," based on how my holy father of blessed memory explained (in Kedushas Yom Tov, Parshas Vayishlach) the verse "Blessed is the man who fears Hashem, who greatly desires His commandments, etc." Here are his holy words:

First, considering what our Sages said: Rabbi Shimon said that Scripture needs to especially encourage in matters where there is monetary loss. The explanation is that there are many people who are swifter than eagles and mightier than lions in doing their Creator's will and their Maker's desire, yet when they encounter a mitzvah that involves money, they withdraw their hands and don't fulfill it completely.

Therefore comes the commandment "And you shall love Hashem your God with all your heart... and with all your me'od (might)," which our Sages (Berachos 54) interpreted as "with all your money." This means one must be God-fearing and mindful of His blessed name even with money-dependent mitzvos, and be among those who are quick to perform tzedakah and chesed (charity and kindness) with complete perfection, trusting in Hashem and His mighty hand that He is abundant in salvation.

This is what King David meant by "Blessed is the man who fears Hashem, who greatly (me'od) desires His commandments" - alluding to mitzvos involving money. Through this, he receives his reward: "His offspring shall be mighty in the land, a generation of the upright will be blessed, wealth and riches will be in his house, etc."

This relates to our matter - "And they were fruitful and multiplied greatly (me'od)" refers to their wealth. Because they gave of their money to support Torah study and mitzvos, they merited to be fruitful and multiply in their resources, as the Holy One Blessed be He bestowed upon them all good things and sent blessing into their wealth.
summary: This passage from Sefer Divrey Yoel discusses the relationship between financial sacrifice for mitzvot and divine blessing. The key teaching, based on an interpretation from the author's father, focuses on the verse "Fortunate is the man who fears God and greatly desires His commandments," explaining that while many people are quick to perform mitzvot in general, they often hesitate when it comes to commandments involving monetary expense. The text emphasizes that true fear of Heaven requires equal enthusiasm for financially demanding mitzvot, teaching that when one gives generously for Torah education and other mitzvot requiring monetary sacrifice, God responds with increased material blessing and prosperity. This creates a spiritual cycle where financial sacrifice for holy purposes leads to greater divine abundance.

hebrew_text: ונל"פ במאמה"כ וישלחנו אלקים לפניכם וגו', דהנה השובע הי' רק במצרים, והרעב הו' בכל הארצות. והאיך הי' מספיק השובע של מצרים לזון בו את כל העולם, אלא שנתברכו תבואותיו של יוסף בתוספת ברכה מן השמים, כמ"ש ויצבור יוסף בר כחול הים הרבה מאוד עד כי חדל לספור כי אין מספר, ולכאורה צ"ב הכפל כי חדל לספור כי אין מספר, ואפ"ל הכוונה דהנה בדבר הסמוי מן העין שורה בו הברכה, וע"כ חדלו לספור שלא יהי' דבר המדוד, ועי"ז נכנס בהם הברכה עד כי אין מספר, שלא הי' חשבון למספרו שתמיד נתרבה בהם הברכה יותר ויותר, וז"ש יוסף הצדיק וישלחני ה' אלקים לפניכם לשום לכם שארית בארץ. דמה שהכינותי לכם תבואה מספיק רק שיהי' לכם שארית בארץ, אבל ע"ו שהקב"ה יוסיף בהם הברכה עי"ז תזכו להחיות לכם לפליטה גדולה.

It appears to explain the verse "And God sent me before you, etc." For behold, the abundance was only in Egypt, while the famine was in all other lands. How could Egypt's abundance have been sufficient to sustain the entire world? Rather, Yosef's grain was blessed with additional blessing from Heaven, as it is written "And Yosef gathered grain like the sand of the sea, very much, until he stopped counting because it was without number." At first glance, we need to understand the repetition of "he stopped counting because it was without number."

One can explain that the intention is that blessing rests upon that which is hidden from the eye. Therefore, they stopped counting so that it would not be something measured, and through this, blessing entered into them "until there was no number" - meaning there was no accounting for its number as the blessing constantly increased more and more.

This is what Yosef HaTzaddik meant when he said "Hashem Elokim sent me before you to establish for you a remnant in the land." For what I prepared for you in terms of grain would only be sufficient for you to have a remnant in the land, but through the Holy One Blessed Be He adding His blessing to it, you will merit "to save your lives as a great deliverance."
summary: This passage from Divrey Yoel discusses the miraculous nature of Joseph's grain storage in Egypt during the seven years of plenty. The key theological insight centers on the concept of divine blessing (bracha) that occurs specifically when things are not counted or measured (davar hasamui min ha'ayin). The text explains that Joseph deliberately stopped counting the grain so that it could receive unlimited divine blessing, transforming a finite supply into an infinite one that could sustain not just Egypt but the entire world. This demonstrates the profound Hasidic principle that by removing human limitations and measurements, we create a vessel for God's unlimited blessing, as evidenced by the phrase "ein mispar" (without number) which indicates the supernatural abundance that sustained the Jewish people through divine intervention.
keywords: ברכה (Bracha) ,שמים (Shamayim) ,אלקים (Elokim) ,צדיק (Tzaddik) ,שארית (She'erit) ,פליטה (Pleitah) ,הקב"ה (HaKadosh Baruch Hu) ,השגחה פרטית (implied in text) ,ברכה מן השמים (Bracha min HaShamayim) ,דבר הסמוי מן העין (Davar HaSamui min HaAyin)

hebrew_text: והנה יוסף הצדיק הי' שליחו של הקב"ה לשום שארית בארץ ולהחיות בית ישראל לפליטה גדולה, אמנם אנן מה נענה שאין לנו יוסף הצדיק והקב"ה שלח אותנו בארצות הגלות להעמיד בתי חינוך על טהרת הקודש בלי שום תערובת זר, וכולנו שלוחים לדבר מצוה זאת, והחוב על כל אחד מאתנו להתאמץ ולסייע לקיום החינוך הזה, ואני תקוה שתשרה ברכה במעשה ידינו ויגדלו פירות נאים ומשובחים. ובעזרתו יתברך גידולי ישיבתינו יתקיימו כולם נאמנים לה' ולתורתו הקדושה בדרך התורה והיראה, ולעת עתה הוא רק בבחי' שארית בארץ. אבל נקוה שיתברכו הדורות להחיות לפליטה גדולה ואמר הכתוב זרעו לכם לצדקה, והכוונה שהקב"ה זורע את הצדקה שאדם עושה ולפי חשבון הגידולים משלם לו פירותיהן ופירות פירותיהן, והקב"ה ישלם לכל אחד פירותיהן בעולם הזה והקרן קיימת לו לעולם הבא, ויזכנו ויחיינו לחזק ולקיים את דרך התורה בדרכי אבותינו ורבותינו הקדושים, ובמהרה נזכה לקבל פני משיח צדקנו ולהתגלות כבוד שמים עלינו במהרה בימינו אמן.
translation:
Here's the English translation, preserving Hasidic terminology:

Behold, Yosef HaTzaddik was the messenger of the Holy One, Blessed be He, to establish a remnant in the land and to sustain Beis Yisroel (the House of Israel) for a great deliverance. However, what can we say, as we don't have Yosef HaTzaddik, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, has sent us to lands of exile to establish houses of education (chinuch) in pure holiness without any foreign mixture. We are all messengers for this mitzvah, and it is the obligation of each one of us to strive and assist in maintaining this education.

I hope that blessing will rest upon our handiwork, and beautiful and praiseworthy fruits will grow. With Hashem's help, the products of our yeshiva will all remain faithful to Hashem and His holy Torah in the way of Torah and yirah (fear of Heaven), and for now it is only in the aspect of a remnant in the land. But we hope that the generations will be blessed to sustain a great deliverance.

The verse states "Sow for yourselves righteousness (tzedakah)," meaning that the Holy One, Blessed be He, sows the tzedakah that a person does, and according to the calculation of growth, He pays him its fruits and the fruits of its fruits. Hashem will pay everyone their fruits in this world (Olam Hazeh), while the principal remains intact for the World to Come (Olam Haba).

May He merit us and sustain us to strengthen and maintain the way of Torah in the paths of our holy fathers and rabbis, and may we soon merit to receive our righteous Mashiach and witness the revelation of Heaven's glory upon us, speedily in our days, Amen.
summary:
This passage from Divrey Yoel draws a parallel between Yosef HaTzaddik's divine mission to preserve the Jewish people in Egypt and the contemporary obligation to maintain authentic Jewish education in exile. The text emphasizes that while we don't have Yosef today, every Jew is tasked as God's messenger to establish and support pure Torah education without foreign influences. The author uses the agricultural metaphor of "planting righteousness" (זרעו לכם לצדקה) to explain how supporting Torah education yields both immediate fruits in this world and eternal rewards in the World to Come. The passage concludes with messianic hope, suggesting that proper Jewish education in exile will help bring about the ultimate redemption and revelation of God's glory.

This summary captures the key Hasidic themes of divine providence in exile, the importance of pure Torah education, spiritual reward systems, and messianic anticipation.
